Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021101155610.00a6fec0@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021101155610.00a6fec0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <200211010005.55786.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I went through this a few weeks ago for my 2 year old Athlon Thunderbird 
system. I didn't have any problems finding another SDRAM 128MB PC-100 
DIMM. They're quite cheap now if you look around. I wasn't sure if my 
MSI mobo could handle a mix of PC-100/PC-133 so I played it safe and 
got the PC-100 memory.

Tony

From todd.sarratt at attbi.com  Fri Nov  1 02:49:04 2002
From: todd.sarratt at attbi.com (todd.sarratt)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 02:49:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: SUCCESS! adding new ethernet card to Sun20
References: <003f01c28096$f5c567c0$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> <20021031044500.GT1521@phunnypharm.org> <006001c28154$ff709740$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> <20021101034245.GA490@ccpu.com>
Message-ID: <013e01c28194$4c123600$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com>

Success!  Thanks everyone who nudged me in the right direction.  My debian
guru / mentor will kill me for the blunt force, but I'm still working on
debian kernel compiles vs. the rest of the Linux world.  Here's how I got my
new Sun SBUS FastEthernet card to work :

gibraltar:/usr/src/linux# make modules

<2 hours later>

gibraltar:/usr/src/linux# insmod
/lib/modules/2.4.18/kernel/drivers/net/sunhme.o
Warning: loading /lib/msoduulnesh/2m.4e.1.8/cke:rnvel1/d.ri9ve9rs
/n1et2/s/unShm
ee.po /wi9ll9 t aiDnta tvhei kder neSl:. n o Mliicelnsle
 r (davem at redhat.com)
eth2: HAPPY MEAL (SBUS) 10/100baseT Ethernet 08:00:20:72:f3:7a
gibraltar:/usr/src/linux# ifconfig -a

<snip>

eth2      Link encap:Ethernet  HWaddr 08:00:20:72:F3:7A
          inet addr:10.0.0.1  Bcast:10.255.255.255  Mask:255.0.0.0
          UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST  MTU:1500  Metric:1
          RX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0
          TX packets:0 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0
          collisions:0 txqueuelen:100
          RX bytes:0 (0.0 b)  TX bytes:0 (0.0 b)
          Interrupt:55
          Interrupt:55

gibraltar:/usr/src/linux#

Thanks!
Todd

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov  1 10:01:24 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 10:01:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C
In-Reply-To: <200210312102.17361.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200210312100.03361.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <200210312102.17361.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <20021101180124.GA16951@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> [2002-10-31 21:03]:
> 
> > If you run
> > env LANG=en_EN abiword
> >
> > it generates an error message:
> > Gdk-WARNING **: locale not supported by C library
> >
> 
> Duh, the correct command is
> env LANG=en_US abiword
> 
> which generates no error.....
> 
> still want to know what the C stands for.

According to the man page for lang (chapter 5) C and POSIX are
interchangable.

So, C means POSIX. (Maybe "Compliant"?)

Also, if the LANG environment variable is NOT set, then it will default
to C.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Nov  1 09:46:04 2002

In-Reply-To: <h4vxke.hqs@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Message-ID: <200211010946.04243.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

> Carla Schroder wrote:
> > Okay, smarter persons, who can explain what LANG=C means? The context is
> > using it as a pre-command to running a program, for example:
> >
> > env LANG=C abiword
> >
> > The effect is to set the locale of Abiword to US English ASCII- I want to
> > know what C itself stands for.

OK, let's try a different approach- When using the command env LANG=C to run a 
program, for example

env LANG=C gnumeric

is it correct to say, this sets the locale for gnumeric as defined within 
gnumeric's own code? In order to override the system locale? That C = the 
default as coded in the app itself?

Or am I like totally confused? Here are some reference docs I found:

http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~mgk25/unicode.html
http://www.ccd.bnl.gov/bcf/cluster/pgi/pgC++_lib/stdlibug/sta_9169.htm

I can firmly and confidently state that env is a bash command. By dang, got 
that much.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Nov  1 10:29:22 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 10:29:22 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021101155610.00a6fec0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <13473-08168@sneakemail.com>

On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Stephen Liu satimis-at-writeme.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I have a PC running SDRAM PC-100 and I want to add another 128MB RAM.  
> Now it is difficult to find SDRAM PC-100 on the market.  Can I mix-use
> SDRAM PC-100 with SDRAM PC-133?

Yes, just be sure that both the exising memory and the new memory are
unregisterred.  (This is the most common type, registerred memory is
usually only used in large memory configs of >1GB.)  Registerred PC133
memory will not work in many PC100 motherboards.

You should also buy from someplace that will let you return the memory for
exchange if it doesn't work.  I've had very good luck with Crucial
(http://www.crucial.com).  They also have a large database of
configurations they or their customers have tried.  If you can tell them
the type of PC or motherboard you have, they should be able to tell you
what kind of RAM to use.

  -- Steve





From don at truedisk.com  Fri Nov  1 09:04:45 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 09:04:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021101155610.00a6fec0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <3DC2B42D.4050606@truedisk.com>

yes.  PC-133 memory must pass more stringent (e.g. higher speed)
tests than PC-100.  It will perform just fine at the slower 100MHz
front-side bus speed used by your CPU/mainboard.

Also, when looking for hard-to-find memory, I like to give Memory Time
a call:  http://www.memorytime.com  (they're local).

- Don

From don at truedisk.com  Fri Nov  1 09:09:29 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 09:09:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Adding new ethernet card to Sun20 running debian
References: <200210311513.g9VFDP203317@tinman.seitzassoc.com> <00fa01c28168$1cbe2340$1600a8c0@vncvr1.wa.home.com> <20021101054952.31356C5CE@max.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <3DC2B549.2030905@truedisk.com>

Sean Whitney wrote:
> What really concerns me with the two cards that you have so far, is that they 
> seem to be displaying the same MAC address.
> 

Sun systems do that.  The MAC address is not actually tied to the
ethernet adapter.  The last 3 bytes of the MAC address are pulled
out of the system-id ROM chip.  (Remember the big hu-hu when Intel
was adding CPU serial numbers to the Pentium?  Sun has been putting
serial numbers on their mainboards since .... 1990(?))

- Don

From richard.langis at Sun.COM  Fri Nov  1 08:38:54 2002

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0210311818110.7807-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Instead of copying the file, use the bookmark import function.  Your 
bookmarks *should* come up just fine after closing and re-opening.

Bookmarks -> Manage Bookmarks | Import

HTH,

-R

Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   I'll answer my own question by explaining how I fooled mozilla into
> behaving properly.
> 
>   chmod 400 the new bookmarks.html file copied from the backup directory.
> Exited mozilla. Restarted mozilla. Ta-da! The correct bookmark file was not
> overwritten this time. Exited mozilla. Restarted mozilla. The proper
> bookmarks are _still_ there.
> 
>   It must be stored in a prefs file and instantly overwrites the existing
> bookmarks file as the program loads. And this now explains the problem I've
> been having the past few weeks: saved bookmarks disappear the next time I
> start mozilla. Don't know what to do about this other than post the
> information somewhere the developers may see it.
> 
> Rich

NEW SUSE LINUX OS TO RUN OFFICE 2000, OTHER WINDOWS APPS
     (Source: Computerworld) Microsoft Office users will soon be
able to try Linux while still using their beloved Office
applications from Microsoft.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741232

TRICKS FOR TASKS THAT RUN EVERY OTHER WEEK
     (Source: ITworld.com) Running a task every other week or
every other day presents a challenge. The cron command doesn't
have any way to express odd or even weeks, but here are a few
tricks to try.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741236

WHY THE DMCA IS BAD FOR OPEN SOURCE
     (Source: InfoWorld.com) The DMCA cripples free speech to the
point where a company such as Red Hat is too scared to release
details of a patch it is distributing, something is dreadfully
wrong. This law crosses the line from protecting business to
enforcing ignorance.
http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741239

From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Fri Nov  1 12:28:50 2002
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Fri, 01 Nov 2002 12:28:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Tricks for tasks that run every other week | LinuxWorld
 (fwd)
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011058340.11543-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3DC2E402.3030306@anarchysoftware.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
> TRICKS FOR TASKS THAT RUN EVERY OTHER WEEK
>      (Source: ITworld.com) Running a task every other week or
> every other day presents a challenge. The cron command doesn't
> have any way to express odd or even weeks, but here are a few
> tricks to try.
> http://www.linuxworld.com/go.cgi?id=741236

Hmmm... Going to the site, it says this:

<<
A shell (/bin/sh) script to send a message on even weeks might look 
something like this:

-------------
#!/bin/sh

WK=`date +%W`
ON_WK=`expr $WK % 2`

if [ $ON_WK = 1 ]; then
   cat /opt/stats/msgs | mailx -s "stats report" someone at someplace.org
fi
-------------
 >>

Since there's 52 weeks and one extra day (two on leap years), every so 
often we have an odd number of weeks in a year (53 instead of 52). That 
is we'd have two odd weeks in a row every five or six years. It seems 
like the above code would break every few years.


-- 
Oh, she bit her dog, eh?
~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
    Richard Seymour, the Man Behind the Curtain
CHEEP GEEKS      Anarchy Software       FREE GEEK




From wallywharton at attbi.com  Fri Nov  1 12:56:05 2002
From: wallywharton at attbi.com (Wally Wharton)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 12:56:05 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C
In-Reply-To: <20021101180124.GA16951@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211011229220.24791-100000@dhcp-73-190.attbi.com>

: * Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> [2002-10-31 21:03]:
: >
: > > If you run
: > > env LANG=en_EN abiword
: > >
: > > it generates an error message:
: > > Gdk-WARNING **: locale not supported by C library
: > >
: >
: > Duh, the correct command is
: > env LANG=en_US abiword
: >
: > which generates no error.....
: >
: > still want to know what the C stands for.
:

I think LANG=en_US has to do with National Language Support in the
application.  LANG=<language>_<territory>, so en_US is the US
localization of English.  An application might use this information in
formatting dates and numbers, for instance, so that Americans will see
their decimal numbers as "2499.99" and europeans would see the same
value displayed as "2499,99".

I don't know what LANG=C would mean in an environment.

Wally

> I don't know what LANG=C would mean in an environment.

Rich

From: BNordlund at whpacific.com (Nordlund, Brian)

Subject: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........
Message-ID: <1816590960AE2B4D8541E6173BEC6B3E07B318@irvexwhp00.theitgroup.com>

All-
My Mandrake 7.2 installation has never been a clean one.  As a result, I
have always had to manually insmod 8390, then insmod ne2k-pci, then network
restart after boot.  This is because, during boot, eth0 and eth1 fail
because 8390 is not in place prior to starting the network.  Even though my
proc time averages about 6 months between reboots, I decided I needed to
"fix" things so the machine can reboot and come up working without my
intervention.  Now it's "fixed" alright: just like my dog......
I read that etc/conf.modules would be the file to edit and add my "insmod
8390" statement.  However, my system does not have this file, only a file
etc/modules.conf and another one etc/modules.  My reading lead me to believe
the modules file might contain a list of modules to load during boot.
Therefore, I edited it to contain "8390".  Previously, the file was empty,
with a size of 0.  This change did not seem to affect the machine at all.
Next, I edited etc/rc.d/rc5.d/S10network.  It seemed to be the only family
of files containing anything resembling command prompt-like statements.  So,
I added a line "insmod 8390" on a line a little before the network stuff
starts happening.
During boot, and a little after level 5 starts going, I see a couple error
statements ("something?something?command not found"), then I see a brief
blip about loading lo, then my screen starts rolling with a partial error
message (it looks like something that ends in "[?.true]", thousands of
times.
I rebooted without network support and vi'ed S10network to remove the line
"insmod 8390" (but I left the blank line).  I also edited out the
etc/modules file back to being empty, however I wonder if it really is
empty, since it probably now contains an EOF so it probably is now size 1
instead of 0 like it was (maybe it is not supposed to be a text file?).
Any thoughts?
				Thanks,
				Brian.




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Fri Nov  1 13:51:53 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 13:51:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........
In-Reply-To: <1816590960AE2B4D8541E6173BEC6B3E07B318@irvexwhp00.theitgroup.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011347150.25100-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Nordlund, Brian wrote:

>I rebooted without network support and vi'ed S10network to remove the line
>"insmod 8390" (but I left the blank line).  I also edited out the
>etc/modules file back to being empty, however I wonder if it really is
>empty, since it probably now contains an EOF so it probably is now size 1
>instead of 0 like it was (maybe it is not supposed to be a text file?).
>Any thoughts?

Hey Brian,

You should be able to add this line to /etc/modules.conf

	alias eth0 ne2k-pci

and that should be it. When you restart the network (reboot or run
/sbin/service network restart), it should automagically load the 
8390 & ne2k-pci modules.

If that doesn't do the trick, you can force it by adding a couple lines
to rc.local. I'm not sure exactly where rc.local is on Mandrake 7.2, 
probably /etc/rc.local or /etc/rc.d/rc.local

	/sbin/insmod 8390
	/sbin/insmod ne2k-pci

-Eric 




From sandy at herring.org  Fri Nov  1 14:13:04 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 14:13:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........
In-Reply-To: <1816590960AE2B4D8541E6173BEC6B3E07B318@irvexwhp00.theitgroup.com>; from BNordlund@whpacific.com on Fri, Nov 01, 2002 at 01:25:43PM -0800
References: <1816590960AE2B4D8541E6173BEC6B3E07B318@irvexwhp00.theitgroup.com>
Message-ID: <20021101141304.B15519@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 01 Nov 2002, Nordlund, Brian wrote: 
> All-
> My Mandrake 7.2 installation has never been a clean one.  
[...]
> Now it's "fixed" alright: just like my dog......
> I read that etc/conf.modules would be the file to edit and add my "insmod
> 8390" statement.  However, my system does not have this file, only a file
> etc/modules.conf and another one etc/modules.  

...from the `man' page for modules.conf...

ALTERNATIVE CONFIGURATION FILE
       For  historical  reasons,  if  /etc/modules.conf  does not exist,
       modutils will read /etc/conf.modules instead.  However the use of
       this historical name is deprecated and it should be replaced with
       /etc/modules.conf.  This version of  modutils  issues  a  warning
       message  if /etc/conf.modules exists, later versions will give an
       error message and refuse to load modules.

[...]
> I also edited out the etc/modules file back to being empty, however I
> wonder if it really is empty, since it probably now contains an EOF so it
> probably is now size 1 instead of 0 like it was (maybe it is not supposed
> to be a text file?). Any thoughts?

You can create it as a zero length file by simply...

    cp /dev/null /etc/modules

cheers,
Sandy

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Fri Nov  1 15:07:51 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 15:07:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211011507.51290.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

LANG=C does mean language = the C programming language. As several of you 
said. The missing link for me was what the heck does that have to do with 
locale? Well duh, C itself is written in ASCII. So 'env LANG=C' literally 
means 'turn off localization', though the end result is similar to setting 
the locale as American English. Technically, it's not the same as 'env 
LANG=en_US', because that is setting a locale, rather than turning it off. 
But to the beleagured end user who just wants their screen fonts to not look 
bizarre, it's the same.

This is an issue because of the move towards internationalization with 
Unicode. Many legacy apps do not support Unicode, so when they run in a 
Unicode environment like Red Hat 8, interesting glitches appear. Some of them 
go beyond cosmetic, for example if filenames are encoded in in the encoding 
of the locale this creates most interesting complications. (UTF-8 is the 
ASCII-compatible Unicode encoding, found in RH8 and other *nixes.)

Never a dull moment.

__
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Red Hat 8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~



From m at netpro.to  Fri Nov  1 15:42:08 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 15:42:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <200211011507.51290.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211011517510.28182-100000@lukem.com>

Sorry, Carla, but that's incorrect.  Technically, the "C" stands for
"Coconut", and according to m-w.com, it means, "the drupaceous fruit of
the coconut palm whose outer fibrous husk yields coir and whose nut
contains thick edible meat and coconut milk".  Personally, I find it
rather odd to think of this as "meat".  But, alas, I digress.  Anyway,
back to the topic at hand.  As I was saying, the letter "C" rhymes with
"three" and "oh gee", and if you've studied your latin, you'd realize that
this is an ancient riddle that has the potential to unlock vast stores of
gold and myrrh buried deep within the volcanic ashes of an uncharted
island off the coast of Madagascar.  Beware the neoprene!  And with that,
I bid thee ado.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Nov  1 15:45:12 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 01 Nov 2002 15:45:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <200211011507.51290.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	<200211011507.51290.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <8665vgzwfr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:

Carla> LANG=C does mean language = the C programming language. As
Carla> several of you said. The missing link for me was what the heck
Carla> does that have to do with locale? Well duh, C itself is written
Carla> in ASCII. So 'env LANG=C' literally means 'turn off
Carla> localization', though the end result is similar to setting the
Carla> locale as American English. Technically, it's not the same as
Carla> 'env LANG=en_US', because that is setting a locale, rather than
Carla> turning it off.  But to the beleagured end user who just wants
Carla> their screen fonts to not look bizarre, it's the same.

One of the *important* differences between LANG=C and LANG=en_US is
that capitalization matters in the former and not in the latter, that
is LANG=C is in ASCII order, LANG=en_US is in alphabetic order.  Old
timers like me are used to the LANG=C behavior.

                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!''

From satimis at writeme.com  Fri Nov  1 16:09:03 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 08:09:03 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question
In-Reply-To: <13473-08168@sneakemail.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021101155610.00a6fec0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021102080641.00a74a40@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi Steve,

Thanks for your advice

At 10:29 AM 2002/11/1 -0800, you wrote:
>On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Stephen Liu satimis-at-writeme.com |PDX Linux| wrote:
>
> > I have a PC running SDRAM PC-100 and I want to add another 128MB RAM.
> > Now it is difficult to find SDRAM PC-100 on the market.  Can I mix-use
> > SDRAM PC-100 with SDRAM PC-133?
>
>Yes, just be sure that both the exising memory and the new memory are
>unregisterred.  (This is the most common type, registerred memory is
>usually only used in large memory configs of >1GB.)  Registerred PC133
>memory will not work in many PC100 motherboards.

Can visual inspection identify whether they are registered or unregistered.

Thanks

Stephen Liu



>You should also buy from someplace that will let you return the memory for
>exchange if it doesn't work.  I've had very good luck with Crucial
>(http://www.crucial.com).  They also have a large database of
>configurations they or their customers have tried.  If you can tell them
>the type of PC or motherboard you have, they should be able to tell you
>what kind of RAM to use.
>
>   -- Steve
>
>
>

>PLUG mailing list
>PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Eric Harrison [mailto:eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us] 
Sent:	Friday, November 01, 2002 1:52 PM
To:	'PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org'
Subject:	Re: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........

On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Nordlund, Brian wrote:

>I rebooted without network support and vi'ed S10network to remove the line
>"insmod 8390" (but I left the blank line).  I also edited out the
>etc/modules file back to being empty, however I wonder if it really is
>empty, since it probably now contains an EOF so it probably is now size 1
>instead of 0 like it was (maybe it is not supposed to be a text file?).
>Any thoughts?

Hey Brian,

You should be able to add this line to /etc/modules.conf

	alias eth0 ne2k-pci

and that should be it. When you restart the network (reboot or run
/sbin/service network restart), it should automagically load the 
8390 & ne2k-pci modules.

If that doesn't do the trick, you can force it by adding a couple lines
to rc.local. I'm not sure exactly where rc.local is on Mandrake 7.2, 
probably /etc/rc.local or /etc/rc.d/rc.local

	/sbin/insmod 8390
	/sbin/insmod ne2k-pci

-Eric

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Nov  1 17:41:02 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 01 Nov 2002 17:41:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <200211011727.08334.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	<8665vgzwfr.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<200211011652.23109.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
	<200211011727.08334.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
Message-ID: <8665vgiw9d.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Marvin" == Marvin  <lamsokvr at xprt.net> writes:

Russell> One of the *important* differences between LANG=C and
Russell> LANG=en_US is that capitalization matters in the former and
Russell> not in the latter, that is LANG=C is in ASCII order,
Russell> LANG=en_US is in alphabetic order.  Old timers like me are
Russell> used to the LANG=C behavior.

Carla> Thanks Russell, that's the kind of information I've been
Carla> looking for.

Marvin> So that means that in LANG=C, "A" is 41h?  What is "A" in
Marvin> LANG=en_US ?

It doesn't matter what code it is, it is only the order that is
important to collating operations.  In other words, for en_US, "A" has
the same value as "a".

Try this little experiment:

  mkdir test
  cd test
  touch a A b B c C

then 

  LANG=C ls -l

then 

  LANG=en_US ls -l

Notice the difference?

From lamsokvr at xprt.net  Fri Nov  1 17:51:07 2002
From: lamsokvr at xprt.net (Marvin)

Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <8665vgiw9d.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200211011727.08334.lamsokvr@xprt.net> <8665vgiw9d.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

Hare are my results....  

Debkos:/home/mkosmal/test# LANG=C ls -l
total 0
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 A
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 B
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 C
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 a
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 b
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 c
Debkos:/home/mkosmal/test# LANG=en_US ls -l
total 0
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 A
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 B
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 C
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 a
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 b
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root            0 Nov  1 17:46 c

What am I missing????

Marvin

On Friday 01 November 2002 5:41 pm, Russell Senior wrote:
> >>>>> "Marvin" == Marvin  <lamsokvr at xprt.net> writes:
>
> Russell> One of the *important* differences between LANG=C and
> Russell> LANG=en_US is that capitalization matters in the former and
> Russell> not in the latter, that is LANG=C is in ASCII order,
> Russell> LANG=en_US is in alphabetic order.  Old timers like me are
> Russell> used to the LANG=C behavior.
>
> Carla> Thanks Russell, that's the kind of information I've been
> Carla> looking for.
>
> Marvin> So that means that in LANG=C, "A" is 41h?  What is "A" in
> Marvin> LANG=en_US ?
>
> It doesn't matter what code it is, it is only the order that is
> important to collating operations.  In other words, for en_US, "A" has
> the same value as "a".
>
> Try this little experiment:
>
>   mkdir test
>   cd test
>   touch a A b B c C
>
> then
>
>   LANG=C ls -l
>
> then
>
>   LANG=en_US ls -l
>
> Notice the difference?

It should look like this:

[keith at laptop lang]$ touch a A b B c C
[keith at laptop lang]$ LANG=C ls -l
total 0
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 A
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 B
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 C

-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 b
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 c
[keith at laptop lang]$ LANG=en_US ls -l
total 0
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 a
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 A
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 b
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 B
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 c
-rw-rw-r--    1 keith    keith           0 Nov  1 18:00 C


Keith

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov  1 19:21:23 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 19:21:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LPRng doesn't work on local printer.
Message-ID: <200211011921.23588.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Well I thought I had printing working with CUPS but one thing I'm
finding painful is the fact that CUPS doesn't support a simple (no
filter) forward to a remote printer queue. One remote printer server I
have to deal runs "apsfilter" and so it's smart enough to know how to
convert PostScript to something the PCL-based HP laser printer connected
to the server can handle.

I tried setting up CUPS to filter and produce the proper output but I
find on the remote printer I then gets an extra one inch of top margin
on every page printed and I also get two empty pages which preceed every 
print job I send from my Linux box.

I removed CUPS and the only other option that SuSE 8.1 offers is the use 
of LPRng. This solved all of my remote problems expect now I can't get 
my locally connected inkjet printer to work at all. I keep seeing the
following messages from "lpr" and my syslog is filled with "connection
refused" errors:

Nov  1 17:41:57 tigger lpd[9643]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:43:25 tigger lpd[9889]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:43:37 tigger last message repeated 2 times
Nov  1 17:46:16 tigger lpd[9889]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:48:57 tigger lpd[10296]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:49:29 tigger lpd[10391]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:51:54 tigger lpd[10519]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:52:12 tigger lpd[10619]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:52:45 tigger lpd[10915]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:53:30 tigger lpd[10915]: connection refused from unknown
Nov  1 17:54:33 tigger last message repeated 7 times

When I try to print something to th local printer I get the following
errors from "lpr":

tigger:/usr/sbin # cat /etc/hosts | lpr -Poptra
Status Information:
 sending job 'root at tigger+997' to optra at localhost
 connecting to 'localhost', attempt 1
 connected to 'localhost'
 requesting printer optra at localhost
 job 'root at tigger+997' transfer to optra at localhost failed
  error 'ERROR TRANSFERRING DATA'
  sending str '^Boptra' to optra at localhost
tigger:/usr/sbin #

Can anyone help? I don't see that "lpd" is actively listening to port
515 which is what I used to see when I was using a BSD-style LPD
process. "lpd" is running and I get a completely different error asking 
me to check that "lpd" is running. I'm at wits end as to why any LPRng 
client programs are unable to transfer any data.

Thanks,

Tony

--
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com

http://www.taclug.org/mailman/listinfo/taclug-general

From keith at ahapala.net  Fri Nov  1 19:28:45 2002
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: 01 Nov 2002 19:28:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RPM "memory alloc (12 bytes) returned NULL." error
Message-ID: <1036207727.9847.19.camel@laptop.ahapala.net>

This one is for the archives :-)

 This error can occur on machines with limited memory and swap space.
This error occurred on my firewall which has 16Mb RAM and 32Mb swap
space. The cure is to just create some more swap space with the
following procedure.

   1. cd to /
   2. issue "dd if=/dev/zero of=swapfile bs=1024 count=64000" to create
64Mb of swap, change the count value to suit
   3. format the file as swap space: "mkswap swapfile"
   4. use the swapon command to bring the swap space online: "swapon
swapfile"
   5. "swapon" -s will show you your swap file usage
   6. add a line to your /etc/fstab so that the swap file will be used
upon each booting
   7. proceed on with your rpm transaction remembering that while this
transaction will complete, it will be very slow because of all the
swapping to disk.
   


Keith




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov  1 20:03:38 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 1 Nov 2002 20:03:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LPRng doesn't work on local printer.
In-Reply-To: <200211011921.23588.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <200211011921.23588.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211012003.38058.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I got this partially working if I do the following with "lpr".

cat <some-file> | lpr -Poptra at tigger

This works when I specify the printer and host name. The problem I have 
with alot of my KDE programs is that they run "lpr -Poptra" instead 
which fails since "optra" is converted to "optra at localhost" which for 
some reason doesn't work.

Tony

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat Nov  2 02:06:33 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat, 2 Nov 2002 02:06:33 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021102080641.00a74a40@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <30830-84666@sneakemail.com>

On Sat, 2 Nov 2002, Stephen Liu satimis-at-writeme.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> >Yes, just be sure that both the exising memory and the new memory are
> >unregisterred.  (This is the most common type, registerred memory is
> >usually only used in large memory configs of >1GB.)  Registerred PC133
> >memory will not work in many PC100 motherboards.
> 
> Can visual inspection identify whether they are registered or unregistered.

Alas, no.  I also do not know of any utility to determine this.  You might
be able to tell if you have brand-name RAM from the DIMM part number.  You
probably will not be able to tell from the SDRAM chips themselves.

Odds are if it just came with the PC, it's unregisterred.

  -- Steve




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sat Nov  2 09:11:18 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 09:11:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Sat, 02 Nov 2002 02:06:33 PST."
             <30830-84666@sneakemail.com> 
Message-ID: <200211021711.gA2HBI218772@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > >Yes, just be sure that both the exising memory and the new memory are
> > >unregisterred.  (This is the most common type, registerred memory is
> > >usually only used in large memory configs of >1GB.)  Registerred PC133
> > >memory will not work in many PC100 motherboards.
> > 
> > Can visual inspection identify whether they are registered or unregistered.
> 
> Alas, no.  I also do not know of any utility to determine this.  You might
> be able to tell if you have brand-name RAM from the DIMM part number.  You
> probably will not be able to tell from the SDRAM chips themselves.
> 
> Odds are if it just came with the PC, it's unregisterred.
> 

The registers on a registered DIMM are external to the SDRAM devices, so
yes, you can visually spot them.  They will typically be oriented parallel
to the edge connector, unlike the SDRAMs, which are typically perpendicular
to the edge connector.  Here's an example from Micron's web site:
http://download.micron.com/pdf/datasheets/modules/SD18C16_32_64x72G_B.pdf

Registered memory is typically used in higher end systems such as servers.
The use of registers to buffer the signals from the SDRAM controller
allows more memory to be installed.  For example, in an unregistered
system, each address line from the controller has to go to every SDRAM.
If you have 4 DIMM slots and 8 SDRAMs per DIMM, that's 32 loads.  Driving
that many loads at 133 MHz is a difficult thing to do.  If those same
4 DIMMs were to use registered DIMMs, there would only be 4 loads on the
address line.  Driving 4 loads at 133 MHz is no problem.

galen





From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Nov  2 09:22:36 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 2 Nov 2002 09:22:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
In-Reply-To: <200211011751.07519.lamsokvr@xprt.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211020922140.5449-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Marvin wrote:

> What am I missing????

What does 'ls --version' return?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Nov  2 10:45:39 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 10:45:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C
References: <mailman.1036126803.17076.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <h4vxke.hqs@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <mailman.1036175406.17376.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4ypgb.di3@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Carla Schroder wrote:

> OK, let's try a different approach- When using the command env LANG=C to
> run a program, for example
> 
> env LANG=C gnumeric
> 
> is it correct to say, this sets the locale for gnumeric as defined within
> gnumeric's own code? In order to override the system locale? That C = the
> default as coded in the app itself?

Well, yes and no, for certain meanings of "default".  For an 
internationalized application, there are no hard-coded "defaults" 
(otherwise, it wouldn't be flexible enough to make translations for).  
However, for a newly created application, C is typically the first 
"translation" done--there is, I think, a standard or at least informal 
convention that this locale always exist.

I've never done any actual development with i18n'd applications, so past 
that I can't tell you.  Of course, locales change things other than 
language text strings--it also controls the way numbers and dates are 
formatted in some standard C functions.
 
> Or am I like totally confused? Here are some reference docs I found:
> 
> http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~mgk25/unicode.html
> http://www.ccd.bnl.gov/bcf/cluster/pgi/pgC++_lib/stdlibug/sta_9169.htm
> 
> I can firmly and confidently state that env is a bash command. By dang,
> got that much.

Yes and no :)  It is a command, but it's not a bash built-in command, like 
'test' or 'echo'.  It's also not necessary in your example above--'LANG=C 
gnumeric' would have worked just fine.  The only reason I can think of for 
prepending 'env' would be to make it portable to other shells--my example 
wouldn't work in csh but yours would.  But now I'm OT. 

Hm, maybe this from POSIX/The Single Unix Specification v2 will be 
enlightening (and then again, maybe not :):

  POSIX Locale
  All systems provide a POSIX locale, also known as the C locale. The   
  behaviour of standard utilities and functions in the POSIX locale is as if 
  the locale was defined via the localedef utility with input data from the   
  POSIX locale tables in Locale Definition .

  The tables in Locale Definition describe the characteristics and behaviour 
  of the POSIX locale for data consisting entirely of characters from the 
  portable character set and the control character set. For other 
  characters, the behaviour is unspecified. For C-language programs, the 
  POSIX locale is the default locale when the setlocale() function is not 
  called.

  The POSIX locale can be specified by assigning to the appropriate 
  environment variables the values C or POSIX.

  All implementations define a locale as the default locale, to be invoked 
  when no environment variables are set, or set to the empty string. This 
  default locale can be the POSIX locale or any other, 
  implementation-dependent locale. Some implementations may provide 
  facilities for local installation administrators to set the default 
  locale, customising it for each location. This specification set does not 
  require such a facility. 

If you don't want to go through the mess of getting a downloadable copy of 
SUSv2 from http://www.opengroup.org, you might also look at the glibc info 
pages.

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Nov  2 11:00:50 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 11:00:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] env LANG=C -resolved
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011302100.11639-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <200211011507.51290.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <mailman.1036194363.8195.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4yq5e.dyj@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Russell Senior wrote:

>>>>>> "Carla" == Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> writes:
> 
> One of the *important* differences between LANG=C and LANG=en_US is
> that capitalization matters in the former and not in the latter, that
> is LANG=C is in ASCII order, LANG=en_US is in alphabetic order.  Old
> timers like me are used to the LANG=C behavior.

And, as I'm sure you know, you can compromise between the two with:

LANG=en_US
LC_COLLATE=C 

Of course, you could set 'LANG=C' to begin with, but then you wouldn't be 
able to display high-bit Latin-1 characters, so you couldn't write things 
like "G?tterd?merung" or "beim Ma?" or even "el Ni?o".

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sat Nov  2 11:07:13 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 11:07:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SDRAM PC-100 question 
References: <mailman.1036257126.3661.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <h4yqg1.ecg@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Galen Seitz wrote:

> Registered memory is typically used in higher end systems such as servers.
> The use of registers to buffer the signals from the SDRAM controller
> allows more memory to be installed.  For example, in an unregistered
> system, each address line from the controller has to go to every SDRAM.
> If you have 4 DIMM slots and 8 SDRAMs per DIMM, that's 32 loads.  Driving
> that many loads at 133 MHz is a difficult thing to do.  If those same
> 4 DIMMs were to use registered DIMMs, there would only be 4 loads on the
> address line.  Driving 4 loads at 133 MHz is no problem.

That's great information Galen, thanks!

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

The theme of the current Linux Journal is internationalization. The article 
about India is quite interesting; it's a mess. There are no common standards, 
software vendors try to lock customers in with a particular character set 
that competing products cannot read. There aren't even universal fonts for 
email and Web pages.

advise you well.
 
> Also, admitting that we still live in a wintel dominated world, what
> linux/gnu-based web browser handles the latest web tricks (flash, etc) the
> best?

  We use both mozilla and opera. There are only a few sites that are so
Microsofted that I cannot get a page from them. So I don't. The sites that
have all the eye candy opening stuff almost always have a link to bypass it
and that's what I use. So, these two do the job for me. Why two?

  Mozilla is set up with cookies and java off. Opera is set up with them on
and reports itself as Internet Exploder 5. When a site insists on cookies, I
just switch to the opera desktop and go on from there. Works for us, YMMV.

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Nov  2 16:01:31 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 2 Nov 2002 16:01:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LPRng doesn't work on local printer - RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <200211011921.23588.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <200211011921.23588.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211021601.31494.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Well it looks like I was fighting a "tcpwrappers" problem and that is 
why I couldn't connect to "lpd" when I didn't use a 
-P<printer>@<hostname> agument. It looks like there might be a bug in 
"lpr" as it appears to use a hostname of "unknown" when no hostname is 
specified with the "-P" argument even through it spits out the name 
"localhost" all over the place in the debug messages.

I added the following to my /etc/hosts.allow file and I'm glad my 
workstation sits behind a firewall as I don't like specifing "UNKNOWN" 
here to make things work:

lpd : 192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0 LOCAL UNKNOWN : ALLOW

It's a rather glaring bug IMHO but things at least work for me now:

tigger:/etc # pr -f /etc/hosts | lpr -Poptra -V
LPRng-3.8.12, Copyright 1988-2002 Patrick Powell, <papowell at lprng.com>
sending job 'root at tigger+504' to optra at localhost
connecting to 'localhost', attempt 1
connected to 'localhost'
requesting printer optra at localhost
sending control file 'cfA504tigger.home.lan' to optra at localhost
completed sending 'cfA504tigger.home.lan' to optra at localhost
sending data file 'dfA504tigger.home.lan' to optra at localhost
completed sending 'dfA504tigger.home.lan' to optra at localhost
done job 'root at tigger+504' transfer to optra at localhost

And the syslog messages confirm this behavior:

Nov  2 15:53:42 tigger lpd[24358]: connection from unknown
Nov  2 15:54:00 tigger lpd[24358]: connection from unknown

Tony

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sat Nov  2 16:08:12 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Sat, 02 Nov 2002 16:08:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] XMMS SKINS
Message-ID: <3DC468EC.6080908@attbi.com>

I've made a /usr/share/xmms/SKINS directory. I've unzipped various skins 
to that directory. This is all per ;

   "mkdir /usr/share/xmms/Skins" <upper-case "S" on "Skins"
4) Download skin.zip to "/home" or right to "/usr/share/xmms/Skins"
5) if you DL'd to /home, then "cp *.zip /usr/share/xmms/Skins"
6) "unzip /usr/share/xmms/Skins/*.zip"
(This should give you a folder for each skin you DL'd)
7) Launch XMMS, and pick your skin!

]# unzip *.zip
Archive:  Apple_Platinum_Amp.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Aqua.zip
caution: filename not matched:  BrushedMetal_Xmms.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Covenant.zip
caution: filename not matched:  eMac_Xmms_color_schemes.zip
caution: filename not matched:  eMac-XMMS.zip
caution: filename not matched:  FreeBSD.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Freshmeat_Amp.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Marble.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Ultrafina-pw.zip
caution: filename not matched:  UltrafinaSE.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Ultrafina.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Vegetali_1-1.zip
caution: filename not matched:  XawMMS.zip

What does caution: filename not matched: mean? Why don't the unzipped 
files show up in the preferences box for xmms?
Dirk




From robbert at vafam.com  Sat Nov  2 16:46:22 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: 02 Nov 2002 16:46:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Finally ready to cut the cord but need some questions
	answered
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211021536570.16179-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211021536570.16179-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1036284384.1331.9.camel@linux>

Real Player has a unix version.  I have it installed on a Red Hat 7.3
box and it works great.  There is a program called XMMS that comes with
RedHat 7.3.  Looks exactly like WinAmp.

I recently upgraded by Mozilla browser's flash plugin. The readme that
comes with the software (fount at www.flash.com or www.macromedia.com)
is made for Netscape, but replace the word netscape with the directory
your mozilla is installed it and the installation works great.  The PLUG
list was a great resource when I did that little exercise.

I've found only one website that I can't display the home page and that
is StarTrek.com.  They insist you need flash 6 which is not available
for Linux.  Also some pictures, when viewed by themselves (like clicking
on a picutre in a gallery) don't display because mozilla says the
picture is corrupted but it displays fine on IE.

I generally use Mozilla with a lot of success.  It does take longer to
load then Opera, but it has expanded capabilities than Opera.  Opera is
nice for wanting a quick look at a website.  Never had a problem with
cookies at any website.

Hope this helps.

Robbert van Andel

On Sat, 2002-11-02 at 15:40, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 2 Nov 2002 hilsy at hilsy.com wrote:
> 
> > So, I'm willing to try RH at home. However, I need
> > equivalents in the linux/gnu world of the multimedia
> > options that windows offered. Specifically I need the
> > same/equivalent of the following:
> >   winamp (for listening to streaming radio, ie
> > radioparadise)
> >   realplayer (for video; do they make one for
> > linux/gnu?)
> 
> Jim,
> 
>    Don't know. We don't use the computer for these. Others do and will
> advise you well.
>  
> > Also, admitting that we still live in a wintel dominated world, what
> > linux/gnu-based web browser handles the latest web tricks (flash, etc) the
> > best?
> 
>   We use both mozilla and opera. There are only a few sites that are so
> Microsofted that I cannot get a page from them. So I don't. The sites that
> have all the eye candy opening stuff almost always have a link to bypass it
> and that's what I use. So, these two do the job for me. Why two?
> 
>   Mozilla is set up with cookies and java off. Opera is set up with them on
> and reports itself as Internet Exploder 5. When a site insists on cookies, I
> just switch to the opera desktop and go on from there. Works for us, YMMV.
> 
> Rich
>

From bl.nordlund at verizon.net  Sat Nov  2 16:44:22 2002
From: bl.nordlund at verizon.net (Brian & Lori Nordlund)
Date: Sat, 2 Nov 2002 16:44:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........ Back from the grave
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211011347150.25100-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <007d01c282d2$2751a3c0$021ea8c0@nisse>

Eric & Sandy-
Thanks to both of you for helping me learn enough to get through this.  I am
back up and running, and I was successful in getting my machine to load the
modules when it boots, without my intervention.  This fixes a minor problem,
but one that has been bugging me for six months.  It feels good to
understand a little more about the in's and out's of this module thing and
the booting process in general.

Thanks Again,
Brian.


----- Original Message -----
From: Eric Harrison <eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us>
To: 'PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org' <plug at lists.pdxlinux.org>
Sent: Friday, November 01, 2002 1:51 PM
Subject: Re: [PLUG] OK I'm Dead Now........


> On Fri, 1 Nov 2002, Nordlund, Brian wrote:
>
> >I rebooted without network support and vi'ed S10network to remove the
line
> >"insmod 8390" (but I left the blank line).  I also edited out the
> >etc/modules file back to being empty, however I wonder if it really is
> >empty, since it probably now contains an EOF so it probably is now size 1
> >instead of 0 like it was (maybe it is not supposed to be a text file?).
> >Any thoughts?
>
> Hey Brian,
>
> You should be able to add this line to /etc/modules.conf
>
> alias eth0 ne2k-pci
>
> and that should be it. When you restart the network (reboot or run
> /sbin/service network restart), it should automagically load the
> 8390 & ne2k-pci modules.
>
> If that doesn't do the trick, you can force it by adding a couple lines
> to rc.local. I'm not sure exactly where rc.local is on Mandrake 7.2,
> probably /etc/rc.local or /etc/rc.d/rc.local
>
> /sbin/insmod 8390
> /sbin/insmod ne2k-pci
>
> -Eric
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From russj at dimstar.net  Sat Nov  2 22:51:28 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sat, 2 Nov 2002 22:51:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] XMMS SKINS
In-Reply-To: <3DC468EC.6080908@attbi.com>
References: <3DC468EC.6080908@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021103065128.GC24989@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Dirk Ouellette <hapibeli at attbi.com> [2002-11-02 16:09]:
> ]# unzip *.zip
> Archive:  Apple_Platinum_Amp.zip
> caution: filename not matched:  Aqua.zip
> ...

What you are seeing is normal for unzip. 

What you are telling unzip is to extract all those files (Aqua.zip,
BruchedMetal_Xmms.zip, etc.) from the file Apple_Platinum_Amp.zip. Those
files don't exist inside the zip file, so it doesn't create anything. 

xmms seems to be able to handle the files in a zipped state anyway.
That's all I have in my .../Skins/ directory. When I browse skins,
they're all listed. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

On Sat, 2 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 2 Nov 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:
> 
> > The theme of the current Linux Journal is internationalization. The article 
> > about India is quite interesting; it's a mess. There are no common standards, 
> > software vendors try to lock customers in with a particular character set 
> > that competing products cannot read. There aren't even universal fonts for 
> > email and Web pages.
>  
>   Yup. And you know where they got that business model, don't you?

Absolutely!  They got it from embracing the notion thats competition is
superior to cooperation, all human interaction is best described (and,
indeed, optimized) in terms of a market, and that profits are a right
granted to those who endeavor in entreprenuerialism.

>From there, it's just a short leap to recognizing that profits are
exploitation and the most exploitation yields the most profits.

They're just doing their job as good little capitalists in making public
life a baffling ordeal so that private property is expanded and
consolidated into the hands of the very few.

Surely you can't disagree with that.  You're an American, aren't you?

United We Stand and all that...
J.

Hello Folks,

The Red Hat Road Tour 2002 will be in Portland for the weekend of
November 15-18. There are several planned events, open to all...

http://k12linux.org/roadtour/

Friday - 15th - BridgePort Brew Pub, 7:00 - 10:00
Red Hat Road Tour Round Table "State of Linux in America" from the guys
who just crossed the country in a giant red motor home to see it. Open
to all but limited to the first 200. (Or at least 200 at one time.)

Saturday - 16th - Riverdale High School, Linux Clinic 11:00 - 5:00
Hands on workshop for installing Linux and making it do what you want it
to. Our clinics are always busy and fun but this one will be WILD!

Monday - 18th - Riverdale High School (location may change) 9am - 11am
K-20 Open Source in EDU Round Table, Where are we, where are we going?
Please contact me if you're planning on coming to this event. I need a
head count as we may need a larger space.

All events are free and open to all.
;-) Paul

From paul at pflnet.ws  Sun Nov  3 20:01:39 2002
From: paul at pflnet.ws (Paul)
Date: Sun, 03 Nov 2002 20:01:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Domain host suggestion
Message-ID: <3DC5F123.9070104@pflnet.ws>

I have used active domain for over a year. They have been flawless. 
Redirections can be done to an IP or URL. You can redirect mail to an IP 
or foreword to an email address. Very flexible. Web page interface. 
Changed take effect immediately (subject to your name server, of 
course). The time I had password trouble, I had an email replay from 
tech support in less than 24 hours on a weekend. All this for $10/yr. I 
can't say enough for these guys.

http://www.active-domain.com

Regards,
Paul

I am trying to get my attbi mail account to point to either Pine or Sendmail. Can anyone explain what I need to do here. Considering that I am a fairly new Linux user, Pine would be preferred, but any help would be appreciated (And samples of configuration files and such would be great too). Thanks. Scott Alban

Outgrown your current e-mail service? Get 25MB Storage, POP3 Access,

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov  4 10:13:12 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 10:13:12 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Pine Question...
In-Reply-To: <ACAJDBNGBJLACAAA@mailcity.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041006090.11557-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, scott alban wrote:

> I am trying to get my attbi mail account to point to either Pine or
> Sendmail. Can anyone explain what I need to do here. Considering
> that I am a fairly new Linux user, Pine would be preferred, but any
> help would be appreciated (And samples of configuration files and
> such would be great too).

I use a pine/fetchmail combo to retrieve and read my attbi.com mail. 
In ~/.fetchmailrc, I've got

poll mail.attbi.com proto pop3
        user "heinlein", with password "SeCrEt", is "heinlein" here,
        ssl,
        sslfingerprint "1D:E5:D5:34:FE:9C:B0:00:9C:5E:12:0F:79:0E:34:7D"

In ~/.pinerc, I've defined a role for my attbi.com account:

patterns-roles=LIT:pattern="/NICK=home/FLDTYPE=EMAIL" 
  action="/ROLE=1/FROM=Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>/
  LSIG=--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>\\n/RTYPE=YES/
  FTYPE=YES/CTYPE=YES"

This is all on one line in .pinerc; I've broken it over multiple lines
for the sake of readability. You probably ought to create yours using
Main -> Setup -> Rules -> Roles.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From Paul at Kingsway.ws  Sun Nov  3 19:59:41 2002
From: Paul at Kingsway.ws (Paul)
Date: Sun, 03 Nov 2002 19:59:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Domain Register
References: <20021104034600.28950.qmail@web10901.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3DC5F0AD.5020409@Kingsway.ws>

I have used active domain for over a year. They have been flawless. 
Redirections can be done to an IP or URL. You can redirect mail to an IP 
or foreword to an email address. Very flexible. Web page interface. 
Changed take effect immediately (subject to your name server, of 
course). The time I had password trouble, I had an email replay from 
tech support in less than 24 hours on a weekend. All this for $10/yr. I 
can't say enough for these guys.

http://www.active-domain.com

Regards,
Paul

Since the switch from @Home to ATTBI, you can forward from attbi.com
to the address of your choice.  Go to:

  <https://memberservices.attbi.com/msws/MemberServices>

or equivalent and "email settings".  Of course, this assumes that you
have somewhere more convenient to forward too, but I'll irresponsibly
assume the reference to Sendmail is a positive indication.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov  4 10:41:09 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 10:41:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] why segfault
In-Reply-To: <5ZLIVRRSQJD83TRUSKF41KESQGNKHD.3dc6bc84@mike>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041034290.11557-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I've got a corrupted rpm database on a RH 7.3 system, so:
> #rpm -rebuilddb

I assume you mean 'rpm --rebuilddb' (with two hyphens, not just one).

> It runs for a while, but instead of finishing, I get:
> Seegmentation fault

The best thing to do is wrap rpm in strace so you can figure out which 
system call is the one causing it to hang:

# strace -o /tmp/rpmcrash.txt rpm --rebuilddb

You might also consider verifying the db files to see if you can spot 
the error:

# db3_verify /var/lib/rpm/*

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From spj318ti at yahoo.com  Mon Nov  4 10:49:43 2002

I know this is not the answer to the question but it is related. If you like XMMS skins try the K-Jofol plugin. You can get a link off of http://www.xmms.org under the visualization plugins. -----Original Message-----
From: Dirk Ouellette 
Sent: Saturday, November 02, 2002 4:11 PM
To: PLUG
Subject: [PLUG] XMMS SKINS


I've made a /usr/share/xmms/SKINS directory. I've unzipped various skins 
to that directory. This is all per ;

   "mkdir /usr/share/xmms/Skins" <upper-case "S" on "Skins"
4) Download skin.zip to "/home" or right to "/usr/share/xmms/Skins"
5) if you DL'd to /home, then "cp *.zip /usr/share/xmms/Skins"
6) "unzip /usr/share/xmms/Skins/*.zip"
(This should give you a folder for each skin you DL'd)
7) Launch XMMS, and pick your skin!

]# unzip *.zip
Archive:  Apple_Platinum_Amp.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Aqua.zip
caution: filename not matched:  BrushedMetal_Xmms.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Covenant.zip
caution: filename not matched:  eMac_Xmms_color_schemes.zip
caution: filename not matched:  eMac-XMMS.zip
caution: filename not matched:  FreeBSD.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Freshmeat_Amp.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Marble.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Ultrafina-pw.zip
caution: filename not matched:  UltrafinaSE.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Ultrafina.zip
caution: filename not matched:  Vegetali_1-1.zip
caution: filename not matched:  XawMMS.zip

What does caution: filename not matched: mean? Why don't the unzipped 
files show up in the preferences box for xmms?
Dirk

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov  4 11:34:52 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 11:34:52 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Pine Question...
In-Reply-To: <MMCJAKBLAEIJGBAA@mailcity.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041131540.2970-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, scott alban wrote:

> I edited the .pinerc file with all of my account info. I downloaded and
> installed fetchmail, but don't seem to have a .fetchmailrc file located in
> my home directory. I ran a locate before and after the installation and
> still no results. Is this a file that I need to create, or should it be
> invoked when I installed fetchmail.

  It's a diy file (Do It Yourself).

  The locate command works off the 'whereis' command and is updated daily
(if the machine's on all the time) or when you tell it to update the
database. Running it immediately after installing an application will not
help you. Try 'which fetchmail' and it will show you where the executable
has been installed.

  Follow Paul's model for .fetchmailrc and modify it to your situation.

Rich




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon Nov  4 11:47:57 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 11:47:57 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Domain Register
In-Reply-To: <bgbGPY5y0yCUy8hnCUu7TsTCBoOS@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <26745-54404@sneakemail.com>

On Sun, 3 Nov 2002, Prutzer techmage-at-aracnet.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> On 03 Nov 2002 19:25:54 -0800, you wrote:
> 
> >I need to register my domain..
> >
> >Is there one place better then the others???

Short version: yes. ;-)

> About a year ago I took Carla's s suggestion and went with Dotster.com
> Not to expensive and they're local

I've used them as well and they're good, but bare-bones.  You'll need to
find someone to actually host your DNS entries.  I like zoneedit since
they're free.  Set your support expectations accordingly.

I have had horrible luck with register.com.  It was so bad that I couldn't
even pay them to renew my domains.  You'd think this would be one thing a
company would like to get right.  But they didn't.

  -- Steve

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Nov  4 13:21:48 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 13:21:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Pine Question...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041131540.2970-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211041252440.1048-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

>   The locate command works off the 'whereis' command and is updated daily

How is 'locate' related to whereis? I thought whereis searched a generic
list of directories, and locate used a special database.

1. which - searches PATH
2. whereis - searches generic list
3. locate - searches locatedb

Tyler

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Mon Nov  4 13:24:12 2002

> > installed fetchmail, but don't seem to have a .fetchmailrc file located in
> > my home directory. I ran a locate before and after the installation and
> > still no results. Is this a file that I need to create, or should it be
> > invoked when I installed fetchmail.
>
>   It's a diy file (Do It Yourself).
>
>   The locate command works off the 'whereis' command and is updated daily
> (if the machine's on all the time) or when you tell it to update the
> database. Running it immediately after installing an application will not
> help you. Try 'which fetchmail' and it will show you where the executable
> has been installed.
>
>   Follow Paul's model for .fetchmailrc and modify it to your situation.
>
> Rich
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>



_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov  4 13:39:54 2002

Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 13:39:54 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Pine Question...
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211041252440.1048-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041338490.3416-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> How is 'locate' related to whereis? I thought whereis searched a generic
> list of directories, and locate used a special database.
> 
> 1. which - searches PATH
> 2. whereis - searches generic list
> 3. locate - searches locatedb
 
Tyler,

  You're probably absolutely correct. I thought that the locatedb was built
using the whereis command. Ergo, they were equivalent. Apparently my
thoughts were incorrect.

Mea culpa!

Rich

From griffint at aracnet.com  Mon Nov  4 16:58:50 2002
From: griffint at aracnet.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 16:58:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Any gnucash users here?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211041441400.3607-100000@appl-ecosys.com> from "Rich Shepard" at Nov 04, 2002 02:43:31 PM
Message-ID: <200211050058.gA50won05332@shell1.aracnet.com>

Learn to use the tab key to navigate when entering transactions. It 
makes pretty good guesses at what you want to enter and really speeds 
things up. Also, use the "+" when entering a check numbers. It 
automatically increments from the most recently entered number.

Those are all the gnucash speed tricks I know.

Terry

> 
>   I believe that some of you are using gnucash. I've just started with it
> (after a long hiatus) and I must be doing things incorrectly because

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov  4 18:08:16 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 18:08:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Any gnucash users here?
In-Reply-To: <200211050058.gA50won05332@shell1.aracnet.com>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, Terry Griffin wrote:

> Learn to use the tab key to navigate when entering transactions. It 
> makes pretty good guesses at what you want to enter and really speeds 
> things up. Also, use the "+" when entering a check numbers. It 
> automatically increments from the most recently entered number.
> 
> Those are all the gnucash speed tricks I know.
 
Terry,

  Thanks a lot. I was using the tab key, but in the transfer dialog box. I
learned from someone else that it's faster to just enter transactions on the
bottom line of the register. Despite reading the manual I didn't pick up on
all this. The plus key is particularly handy.

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Mon Nov  4 19:47:53 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Mon, 04 Nov 2002 20:47:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Domain host suggestion
References: <3DC5F123.9070104@pflnet.ws> <p05100327b9ece81386ea@[192.168.3.1]>
Message-ID: <3DC73F69.1010201@coyotesong.com>

>     Mother always told me that "if something sounds too good to be true, 
> it probably is."
> 
>     I don't see any way that a company can give people the sky for 
> $10/yr.

By this logic, I must be ecstatic with my service from Verisign.

LO *thump* L

*ouch*  I hate it when I fall out of my chair laughing.

Verisign has really shitty service because they've figured out that most 
people are suckers who will pay $70 (or whatever it is they charge) for 
"expedited" service.  Actually, most people don't have a choice because 
of the damage that will be caused if the can't update their records, etc.

In contrast, the $10/year folks have figured out that there's really not 
much cost associated with maintaining these records if the forms are 
good enough for most people to take care of things themselves.  Whois 
servers aren't hit *that* hard, so if you could put, oh, 20,000 records 
on a single box that's still $200,000 year for hardware, power, 
bandwidth and a person or two...

But even that analysis is bogus.  There's only a handful of true 
registrars, most of them are resellers who buy in bulk.  They may only 
pay a few bucks per domain per year, and essentially no one-time charges 
to set up the domain beyond the cost of running a server.  As long as 
they can minimize customer service calls, they make a nice profit.

Bear




From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Mon Nov  4 20:06:30 2002
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)

Here's an odd question for you.  Are you running Gentoo 1.4?  Or any
other system compiled on gcc3.2?  All the java's I've seen compiled were
compiled using gcc2.95, and since java uses C++ and bianary
incompatabilitys abound...Well, you see what I'm talking about I hope.

Anyways, this might explain it.
Also, you might want to start up using galeon, on the command line, as
it gives slightly more verbose info about plugin loading, Mozilla trys
to hide problems...

Chris

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov  4 20:09:16 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 4 Nov 2002 20:09:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Any gnucash users here?
In-Reply-To: <1036466763.1632.5.camel@linux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211042006490.4078-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 4 Nov 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:

> I use gnucash (only for checking).  Speed seems to be no problem for me,
> except registering the transaction.  When I press enter, it takes a
> second to go to the next line.  Other than that no problems.  What are
> you using the trackball for?
 
Robbert,

  Doing date entry incorrectly. I was selecting the "transfer" button for
each transaction and filling in the dialog box. SLOW! Boring! Turns out the
slick way is to enter the transaction on the bottom line of the register.
Then the software remembers what you entered before and it's _much_ faster.

  Of course, they have the debits and credits in reverse order of every
other accounting package, but ... one adjusts after a bit.

Thanks,

Rich -- the happy camper now.

In-Reply-To: <200211042026.13324.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211050624460.5621-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 4 Nov 2002, Terry Griffin wrote:

> Which reminds me, the +/- keys also work in the date field.

  Yes. Both data and transaction number. As long as they are the grey keys
on the numeric pad and not on top of the main keys.

Rich

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Nov  5 15:27:33 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 05 Nov 2002 15:27:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] STARTTLS in Mac OS X mail client?
References: <mailman.1036530605.3358.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86smyf1tsq.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

Paul> I'm stymied: it appears that the mail client that ships with Mac OS
Paul> 10.2 does NOT have the ability to use TLS to connect to a SMTP server.

Paul> A search around the AppleCare Support web site was fruitless, as was
Paul> Googling.

Paul> Can anyone confirm or deny my observation?

There are some settings for "use encryption" down in the depths of a
particular connection.  But as is normal in an Apple product, I can't
seem to make out what they do from a technical perspective... just
a marketspeak perspective.

I typed "encrypted mail" into the AppleCare Sherlock, and the
first hit talks about CRAM-MD5.

Ahh, but another link further down talks about

   Mac OS X Mail: About Secure Email Communications (SSL)

That seems to imply that it attempts a IMAPS or POPS connection
in preference to an IMAP or POP connection, *unless* you disable
the magic box.

Does that help?

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Tue Nov  5 16:38:07 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Tue, 5 Nov 2002 16:38:07 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <3dc857f9.6f8.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <20021106003807.17909.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>

Hello all. I'm new to the list, so I'll start by saying "Hi everybody!"

My problems is this: I have Samba shares set up on Linux servers
(RedHat 8.0, 7.1, etc), and some NT4 servers. Windows computers can
access them correctly, and can read, write and delete. I want my Linux
workstations to be able to access them, but I can only mount them if
I'm root. The problem is that since root mounted them, I have limited
access as a normal user.  I can read files, and even edit them, but I
cannot create files or copy files to these shares. I have full access
when I "su" to root, but that's inconvenient.

How do I mount them such that any user on the workstation can have full
access to them? I'm thinking of maybe using the "sudo" command, but it
seems pretty complicated. Is there an easier way?

-Scott

=====
-Scott

these two CPU's??  Either/Or??

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov  5 16:57:55 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 05 Nov 2002 16:57:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <20021106003807.17909.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021106003807.17909.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1036544282.27377.528.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Scott,

Welcome to PLUG.

On Tue, 2002-11-05 at 16:38, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> Hello all. I'm new to the list, so I'll start by saying "Hi everybody!"
> 
> My problems is this: I have Samba shares set up on Linux servers
> (RedHat 8.0, 7.1, etc), and some NT4 servers. Windows computers can
> access them correctly, and can read, write and delete. I want my Linux
> workstations to be able to access them, but I can only mount them if
> I'm root. The problem is that since root mounted them, I have limited
> access as a normal user.  I can read files, and even edit them, but I
> cannot create files or copy files to these shares. I have full access
> when I "su" to root, but that's inconvenient.

You should be able to mount SAMBA shares as a normal user using the
smbmount command (smbumount to un-mount the share).
> 
> How do I mount them such that any user on the workstation can have full
> access to them? I'm thinking of maybe using the "sudo" command, but it
> seems pretty complicated. Is there an easier way?

This depends on how your shares are set up, user level or share level. 
Also, what do you mean by "full access".  Having a single user be able
to read and write to his/her home directory is very different from any
user being able to read and write to any other users home directory.

In any case "sudo" is not needed (or recommended, you would still have
users with root privileges to the file system).

HTH

Derek Loree





From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Nov  5 17:20:23 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 5 Nov 2002 17:20:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <20021106003807.17909.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021106003807.17909.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200211051720.23221.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've been in the situation of sharing files with both Windows and Linux 
clients and use Samba for the Windows systems and NFS for the 
Unix/Linux clients. You can mount Samba shares to Linux systems using 
"smbmount" if want to to SMB rather than NFS.

Tony 

On Tuesday 05 November 2002 16:38 pm, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Tue Nov  5 18:10:48 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Tue, 5 Nov 2002 18:10:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <200211051720.23221.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021106021048.83078.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com>

I tried using smbmount, but got the following error message:

$ smbmount //patsy/web /home/scott/web-patsy -o
username=scott,password=mypassword

smbmnt must be installed suid root for direct user mounts (500,500)
smbmnt failed: 1

I have Samba running on both machines (server and client) and can mount
them as root with:

$ mount -t smbfs -o username=scott,password=mypassword

But the above method can only be run as root, and causes me the
problems I mentioned.

System: both running RedHat 8.0, samba-2.2.5-10.

-Scott

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Tue Nov  5 18:14:47 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Tue, 5 Nov 2002 18:14:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <1036544282.27377.528.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <20021106021447.58063.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>

Derek,

My shares were created by modifying the defaults in smb.conf. I have
home directories only accessible by the user that owns it, and I have a
public "transfer" directory that is full read/write access by anyone
with a valid sambapasswd account.

-Scott

From m at netpro.to  Tue Nov  5 18:18:16 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue, 5 Nov 2002 18:18:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba question
In-Reply-To: <20021106021048.83078.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211051817300.18559-100000@lukem.com>

chmod 4755 /usr/bin/smbmnt
chmod 4755 /usr/bin/smbumount

> > > access them correctly, and can read, write and delete. I want my
> > > Linux workstations to be able to access them, but I can only mount
> > > them if I'm root. The problem is that since root mounted them, I
> > have
> > > limited access as a normal user.  I can read files, and even edit
> > > them, but I cannot create files or copy files to these shares. I
> > have
> > > full access when I "su" to root, but that's inconvenient.
> > >
> > > How do I mount them such that any user on the workstation can have
> > > full access to them? I'm thinking of maybe using the "sudo"
> > command,
> > > but it seems pretty complicated. Is there an easier way?
> > >
> > > -Scott
> > >
> > > =====
> > > -Scott

Matt,

smbmount //patsy/web /home/scott/web-patsy -o username=scott%mypassword

libsmb based programs must *NOT* be setuid root.
