From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Nov 13 15:35:25 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 15:35:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Fw: Re: [Taclug-General] Portland RH stop 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 13 Nov 2002 14:14:02 PST."
             <20021113224101.FQQN24365.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux> 
Message-ID: <200211132335.gADNZP206724@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

revans at e-z.net said:
> For any coming down to Portland for Friday's event, there is a Blazer
> game on Friday that may cause a little traffic. The train station down
> town is about a thirty minute walk from the pub, but some there are
> some bad areas between the two. If there is going to be a few coming
> down, and you are willing to walk, I will be happy to walk with you to
> the pub. I need to know when you are coming in to meet you there. If I
> get only three responses or less I will drive the people from the
> train station to the pub.  

The pub is only 15 blocks from the station, so I'd say 20 minutes or
less.  Portland blocks are small.  

There are two bus options. 
The #77 goes right by the pub.  $1.25  Pick it up at the corner of Hoyt & 
Broadway.
http://www.tri-met.org/schedule/r077.htm

The #17 runs on Glisan, leaving you with a 6 block walk north to Marshall.
The advantage of this is that it is free because you are traveling within
the fareless zone.
Pick it up at the corner of Glisan & Broadway.
http://www.tri-met.org/schedule/r017.htm


I would have to respectfully disagree with the implication that this
is an unsafe area to walk.  If walking, I would walk south from the
station to Hoyt, then west to 11th, then north to Lovejoy, then west
to 13th, then north to the pub.

galen

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 13 15:43:50 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 15:43:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Wanting software to "just work" (was: Streaming media in
 Linux?)
In-Reply-To: <200211131134.53631.mark@linuxhardware.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211131514010.27381-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 13 Nov 2002, Mark Griskey wrote:
> For the new Linux "convert", installing an application from source,
> and encountering errors could be very daunting.  Especially if this
> user came from a Windows environment and just wanted to click on a
> file and have it play in something like Windows Media Player.  Having
> installation problems and then looking for answers only to be met with
> brusque responses would be disappointing, maybe enough to make this
> user abandon Linux althogether.
> 
> On the other hand, this software is free and is being developed by
> people on their watch.  They are giving it to the community, free for
> anyone to use.  They can behave as they want, it is their project.  
> Developing free software and having to offer support for it can be
> very time consuming.

OK, up to here, I agree with you.  We have an anarchic system and people
can and should be left to do whatever they please (though they also can
and should be encouraged to be courteous and helpful and hard-working and
self-actuating).  The new user has a responsibility to put as much time
and effort into learning as he possibly can and the developer has a
responsibility to provide the best software she possibly can.

> So where does that leave Linux from an advocacy point of view?  
> Encouraging folks to use Linux, only to have them become frustrated
> isn't going to help wide spread adoption.

Don't let them become frustrated.  Don't leave them in the hands of
developers who have no time for frustrated and frustrating newbies.

> But also criticizing the author of a free piece of software because of
> the developer's attitude or comments isn't going to help either.

Criticizing an author is one thing, whining is another.  If you provide
useful critical commentary, perhaps you can bring about positive change
(or encourage a meaningful code fork).  But if you just complain and want
someone to come be the magic code at the back of an "Install" button, then
you're not criticizing, you're bitching.

> Is the middle ground the responsibility of the major distros?

Absolutely not.  The middle ground is YOU.  If you encourage a convert,
follow up with them.  Help them.  Put them in contact with people who will
give sympathetic support (if you can't do it yourself, which should be
your first choice).

Conversion isn't just getting someone to try Free Software, it's
indoctrination into the community.  You are part of that community and the
closest and most personal part to your new convert.  You can help them
join a larger community when they're ready.  But take some of the
responsibility on yourself right now.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Nov 13 16:23:53 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 16:23:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG-org - Call for attendance.
In-Reply-To: <3DD2D335.1020402@sun.com>
References: <1036825030.30338.96.camel@bittersweet> <20021113072443.ZDPU24365.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux> <1037214531.26304.29.camel@bittersweet> <20021113221812.GC22066@sthelens.dimstar.net> <3DD2D335.1020402@sun.com>
Message-ID: <20021114002353.GD22066@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Richard Langis <richard.langis at sun.com> [2002-11-13 14:34]:
> Unfortunately, your questions will probably go unanswered, because...
> 
> Russ Johnson wrote:
> >* Karl M. Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org> [2002-11-13 11:09]:
> 
> **
> >>Please follow up on plug-org.
> **

I realized that when I posted it. However, I also realize that these are
the types of questions that *SHOULD* be answered BEFORE discussions
start about what the origanization should look like. 

You don't start a company with a statement like, "OK, I'm CEO of *blah*
company, now, what do we do?"

I have this distinct impression of folks running off behind a curtain,
making plans, instituting changes, and then coming back to tell us what
changes have been made. All before we've decided if those changes needed
to be made in the first place. 

Who knows, it might be a good idea to make the changes. It just seems to
me that we're on step 5 already, and steps 1-4 haven't been taken yet.
Sort of like running make before you run ./configure or tar.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

List  Description    
apt-listchanges  Mailed output of apt-listchanges -
pdxlinux.org software upgrade changelogs.    
PLUG  General Linux discussion and assistance    
PLUG-announce  Meeting and other announcements (not job postings)    
PLUG-business  Using Linux and OSS in business    
PLUG-crypto  Cryptography and Internet Security
PLUG-devel  Technical discussion re: Software & Product Development
PLUG-edu  Linux in Schools    
PLUG-government  Using Linux and OSS in Government Information Systems    
PLUG-jobs  Help Wanted and Work Needed
PLUG-talk  Random clatter and time wasting chat    
PLUG-web  www.pdxlinux.org related discussion

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Nov 13 17:46:16 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 17:46:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] GRUB won't boot
References: <3DD2DDD3.5050006@pacifier.com> <1037230558.7698.5.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <3DD30068.7090800@pacifier.com>

Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Assuming your /boot and / partition is /dev/hda1 and your kernel name is
> /boot/vmlinuz_2.4.19:
> 
> grub> root (hd0,0)
> grub> setup (hd0)
> grub> kernel /vmlinuz_2.4.19
> grub> boot
> 
> That should get you booting again. Note that I have no idea what the
> name of your kernel is (mine is vmlinuz_2.4.19). You may have to mount
> your /boot partition using a rescue disk to find out.

Yeah, I did something like that from the info pages, but it brought up the 
grub shell on boot--it wasn't finding my grub.conf file.

Then I got it to bring up the menu on boot, but it created /boot/boot/grub/
which I didn't want.  Per the info pages, this worked

grub> root (hd0,4)
grub> install /grub/stage1 d (hd0) /grub/stage2 p /grub/grub.conf

it's all good now.

This all started because my /boot partition is too small.  (Tip: Don't try 
to move /boot when it's mounted)

Now off to see if gpartd will resize partitions.


Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Nov 13 18:00:05 2002

Oops, that's `parted` and that's what it's designed for, but looks quite

From mark at linuxhardware.net  Wed Nov 13 17:59:28 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 2002 17:59:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wanting software to "just work" (was: Streaming media in Linux?)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211131514010.27381-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211131514010.27381-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <200211131759.28923.mark@linuxhardware.net>

On Wednesday 13 November 2002 03:43 pm, Jeme A Brelin wrote: 
> If you encourage a convert, 
> follow up with them. Help them. Put them in contact with people who will 
> give sympathetic support (if you can't do it yourself, which should be 
> your first choice).

I think these are very sage words and illustrate another advantage Linux has 
over the alternatives - a large, very knowledgeable community with a wealth 
of experience that is willing to lend a helping hand to those who need it. Of 
the few people who I have encouraged to switch to Linux, all are still happy 
users (3 years on now). I found that by not only being there when they hit 
the rough spots, but showing them how to find help, whether through Usenet, 
the Web, discussion forums or encouraging them to join the local LUG, gave 
them the tools they needed to solve whatever was thrown their way. Sometimes 
showing someone how to problem solve was a bigger challenge than explaining 
the concept of a boot loader. But to this day:

"Mark, how do I configure my new NIC?" 
"man ifconfig" 
"but it's easier to ask you!" 
"what are you going to do when I'm on vacation?" 
"Call you at your hotel, you will leave the number, right?"

LOL

Mark

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Nov 14 07:59:38 2002
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 07:59:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Streaming media in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211130143170.19064-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211130143170.19064-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20021114155717.5957336B16@ados.com>

Reply regarding Re: [PLUG] Streaming media in Linux? from Jeme A Brelin:
: On Tue, 12 Nov 2002, guy1656 wrote:
: > Reply regarding Re: [PLUG] Streaming media in Linux? from Dan Young:
: > : mplayer seems like a jack-of-all-trades media player, notwithstanding
: > : compilation/installlation issues depending on your distro of choice.
: >
: > That ("compilation/installlation issues depending on your distro of
: > choice") has been a show-stopper for me many times.
:
: MPlayer has compiled for me straight out of the tarball every single time
: with no trouble whatsoever (...) so I'm not bitching.

There is a difference between bitching and -cautioning.- MPlayer might have 
rave reviews in some circles, but since it doesn't come in what I'll call a 
single-intent/single-action format, I was CAUTIONING that the install may 
require a bit more research and perhaps even a higher level of risk to one's 
computer system.

A good rule of thumb for user interface design is that if you can descibe 
what you want to do in a human language, then the number of actuation steps 
it should take should equal the number of verbs in that phrase.

So, since this thing is available only as a tar.gz, then it is simply THE 
TRUTH to say that 'the install in NOT straightforward,' and 'that can be a 
show-stopper for many users.'

: Your response reminds me of a time in my high school chemistry class ...

Neat. I didn't know that installing something to be used for FUN was supposed 
to feel like a chemistry test. Actually, that was EXACTLY the problem I was 
trying to bring out. Remember, we're talking about a program written for 
playing ENTERTAINMENT files. (Hint: Most people don't find learning what to 
do with a 'tarball' ENTERTAINING.)

If -you- do, that's great, but it's still a FACT that MOST people DON'T. To 
say so is NOT indicative of an attitude problem on my part. (Nothing of the 
foregoing is a reflection on willingness or ability to learn, mind you, it's 
a statement of how accessible something is, as assessed by and for 'regular 
folks.')

: > The MPlayer site introduced me to the term 'lamer' which they define
: > as a user who installs a program as-is and expects it to run. Geez,
: > that's probably 90% of the PC users I know of. Thanks.
:
: Well, if you're not making any effort, you may as well be lame.

False. First of all, you don't know what efforts I -have- made. Second, do 
you seriously believe that learning curves are the spice of life, and that 
every intent, even in leisure, ought to be tested in an arduous cruicible of 
success versus failure, of blood, sweat, toil, study, and tears?

I don't, so my opinion is: "Yeah, but it doesn't install with a double-click 
and the website mentions security problems which you have to be a computer 
networking expert to understand. So, MPlayer in its currently available form 
is probably -NOT- ready for most users. And, incidentally, the authors of the 
website have even contrived a derogatory term for a majority of good people 
who might otherwise be interested in trying out their program" (they just 
happen to be good at other things, like my vet down the street. This guy is 
-NOT- 'lame' by any means.)

I know a man with a lathe in his garage. He bitched and cussed (in a friendly 
way - I love working with machinists) about how they wanted $8 at Freddy's 
for a hose coupler to convert pipe thread to garden-hose thread, when 'any 
dork' can turn one up in brass.

I guess everybody else who doesn't do this is somehow deficient on the 
evolutionary scale, right? Don't know the taper angle for standard pipe 
thread? Then I guess you're an idiot, right? After all, it's on page 1659 in 
my 24th ed. of "Machinery's Handbook." (c.1992) I mean, geez, it's a
standard so I thought that EVERYBODY already knew that. It's been the same 
value for at least 70 years, mind you. (p. 871 in "Mechanical Engineer's 
Handbook, 3rd Ed." Lionel S. Marks, 1930. I would have checked my 2nd Ed 
dated 1919, but that's currently on diplay in an engineering museum in 
Salem.) What, are you too lazy to look it up? I just did so twice. What's 
wrong with you?

: change your behavior to be less lame.
I already did that.

- GLL

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 09:13:55 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 09:13:55 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211140838140.27344-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a
> Linux-clone. Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?

Linux is not UNIX.

"UNIX" refers to the operating system originally developed by the AT&T 
Bell Labs and its partners. The UNIX code is copyrighted and is in no 
way Free. The UNIX trademark is currently managed by The Open Group:

  http://www.unix-systems.org/

Linux is a UNIX workalike. It emulates the UNIX system calls, libc
base, the "everything's a file" philosophy, POSIX specs, and many
other traits -- but there is no UNIX code in Linux, nor has The Open
Group certified Linux under any of its UNIX standards.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu Nov 14 09:23:11 2002

> On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> 
> > I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a
> > Linux-clone. Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?

> base, the "everything's a file" philosophy, POSIX specs, and many
> other traits -- but there is no UNIX code in Linux, nor has The Open
> Group certified Linux under any of its UNIX standards.
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Nov 14 09:33:57 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 14 Nov 2002 09:33:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1037295237.23815.58.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Scott,

Linux is indeed a clone of Unix. Unix was ``invented'' by Ken Thompson
after Bell Labs left the Multics project, originally so he could play
games on his scavenged PDP-7. Dennis Ritche, inventor of the ``C''
programming language is considered the coauthor of the system.

 The term 'Unix' was a play on words the creators used to describe it as
a clone of Multics, a multi-user platform. It is ironic that the systems
we now hold has the bellweather for multi-user platforms was originally
a single user platform!

Over time, two distinct versions, or `flavors' of Unix developed: System
V and BSD, note however that there were still considerable
cross-influence between them. 

Until the early 80's, that was it: basically two flavors of Unix. Then,
seemingly out of nowhere, a proliferation of new computer companies
brought several versions of new UNIX systems to the market. Worse, many
of their enhancements were kept proprietary. Soon administrators found
that a script working on one system did not work on another. Unix
forked.

Everyone now knows the story of how Torvolds wrote a rudimentory kernel
for the Intel platform and released it under a liscence develeped by
Stallman, the GPL.

Linux is a clone of Unix, but it has several key differences that make
it so exciting.

First, Linux combines the most popular features of the prior Unices and
melds them into a really usable system. I personally, for example, have
never really liked System V's printing commands, opting instead for the
BSD style.

Second, Linux is totally open source. This makes it nary impossible for
any single vendor to take the code and run away with it.

Third, Linux supports a wide variety of hardware platforms from Intel,
to Sparc, to PowerPC and others. This makes it possible to take a
program's source code from an Intel box and 

Finally, Linux is just cool; it supports most of the hardware available
for the x86 architecture, no small feat indeed.


-Cooper

> 
On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 07:48, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a Linux-clone.
> Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?
> 
> -Scott

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Nov 14 09:46:58 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 09:46:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211140833080.12678-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?

"UNIX" is a registered trademark of X/Open, and no OS can technically be
called UNIX without their permission. Also Linux is not based directly on
the source code from the original version of UNIX, unlike FreeBSD,
Solaris, HPUX, Chord, or Xenix.

Like minix, linux (a kernel) is described as unix-like because it
implements UNIX interfaces and takes a Unix-like approach in its design.
To be accurate, Linux is not a version of Unix because it is not patterned
from the Unix codebase.

1. UNIX(tm): the original Bell labs Unix.

2. Unix version: HPUX, Solaris, Xenix, Chord, BSD. ("True Unixes")

3. Unix-like: Linux, minix.


HTH,

Tyler


On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a Linux-clone.
> Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 09:58:12 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 09:58:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114172548.10081.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021114172548.10081.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200211140958.12026.aschlemm@attbi.com>

At one time BSD Unix had AT&T Unix code in it but as I recall all of the 
AT&T code was eventually removed from the BSD sources because of the 
licensing issues this caused.

As a guy that has used a number of different Unix systems over the last 
19 years all I can see is Linux feels like Unix. I didn't have any 
problems configuring and using Linux when I first installed it and may 
of the same files were used to configure the system just like many of 
the Unix systems I had worked on. 

The biggest thing for me was that Linux changed my perception of the 
Intel platform. I found that it could be run for months or even years 
with out a crash. Up until my first taste of Linux I had only used DOS, 
Windows, OS/2, and WinNT on Intel platforms and none of those systems 
were that resistant to crashes. OS/2 and WinNT were better than DOS and 
Window 3.x but I saw my share of BSOD on NT and OS/2 had alot of 
problems with GUI lockups because of the way Presentation Manager  
handled its input queue.

The freely available BSDs are also quite good although they don't 
necessarily have the level of hardware support Linux has. Many of the 
BSDs also support multiple hardware platforms just like Linux. I have 
found that many programs are easily compiled under BSD with the same 
"./configure", "make", "make install" steps I've used under Linux.

Tony

On Thursday 14 November 2002 09:25 am, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> Does that mean that only AT&T's *nix is Unix? Are the various flavors
> of BSD, HP-UX and Solaris not Unix then?
>
> -Scott
>
> --- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> wrote:
> > On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> > > I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a
> > > Linux-clone. Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?
> >
> > Linux is not UNIX.
> >
> > "UNIX" refers to the operating system originally developed by the
> > AT&T
> > Bell Labs and its partners. The UNIX code is copyrighted and is in
> > no
> >
> > way Free. The UNIX trademark is currently managed by The Open
> > Group:
> >
> >   http://www.unix-systems.org/
> >
> > Linux is a UNIX workalike. It emulates the UNIX system calls, libc
> > base, the "everything's a file" philosophy, POSIX specs, and many
> > other traits -- but there is no UNIX code in Linux, nor has The
> > Open Group certified Linux under any of its UNIX standards.
> >
> > --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
> >
> >
> > _______________________________________________
> > PLUG mailing list
> > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                                     
                             November 16, 2002
                                     
                                1PM - 4PM
                                     
                            Riverdale Highschool                                                          
                          9727 SW Terwilliger Blvd,                                                     
                             Portland, Oregon
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials
       
   For directions to the school see:
   http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/info/direct.html
   
   For questions regarding the Clinics email Dan Haskell at:
   dhaskell at acm.org
   
   For information about PLUG or the Clinics see:
   http://www.pdxlinux.org

From pem at nellump.net  Thu Nov 14 10:41:49 2002

In-Reply-To: <1037295237.23815.58.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

On Thu, Nov 14, 2002 at 09:33:57AM -0800, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> 
> Linux is indeed a clone of Unix. Unix was ``invented'' by Ken Thompson
> after Bell Labs left the Multics project, originally so he could play
> games on his scavenged PDP-7. Dennis Ritche, inventor of the ``C''

Wow. Creating a brand new OS just so you can game on some second-hand
hardware. That's truly hardcore.  :-)


Paul




From flee at aracnet.com  Thu Nov 14 08:58:32 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 08:58:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com> on Thu, 14 Nov 2002 07:48:52 PST.
Message-ID: <200211141658.gAEGwXj18560@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Scott VanHoosen <octopus024 at yahoo.com>:
> I've heard Linux called Unix, and I've heard it called a Linux-clone.
> Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?

1. Unix is a family of operating systems:
     http://www.levenez.com/unix/

2. Unix is an operating system standard:
     http://www.unix-systems.org/what_is_unix.html
--



From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 10:47:31 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)

Message-ID: <200211141047.31762.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Computer systems were incredibly expensive back in those days and so it 
was probably cheaper to write your own OS to get the functionality you 
needed. :) 

Years ago I once worked with a guy that was proud of the fact that he 
had a PDP-8 in his home. I don't think he used it much anymore but he 
said it still booted and ran.

Tony

> Why not make it legal to attack the offender's systems?  Or we could use the
> technique of England against Spain and commision privateers who would have
> the right to retaliate against the systems of spammers.

Here's a description and some real examples of "Letters of
Marque" for an enterprising cyber-privateer:

http://www.geocities.com/Tokyo/Garden/5213/marque.htm

Maybe if we all chip in we can offer a bag of gold to whoever can
engage Korea, Inc. and blow it to boxwood. ;-)  Seems to me that
direct action is about all that will make spammers sit up and
take notice. I doubt the govt can make a law against spamming
that will hurt the spammers more than it will hurt the rest of
us.

-- 
- Bill Thoen



From don at truedisk.com  Thu Nov 14 11:22:13 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 11:22:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG-org - Call for attendance.
References: <1036825030.30338.96.camel@bittersweet> <20021113072443.ZDPU24365.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux> <1037214531.26304.29.camel@bittersweet> <20021113194328.GA676@nellump.net> <1037217563.26304.39.camel@bittersweet> <20021114183635.GA771@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <3DD3F7E5.2000405@truedisk.com>

Well, we've been picking on Karl for a day now, but I suspect
the "plug-org" idea does have merit.  There is definately a
core of volunteers in PLUG doing a lot of work: web site, mail
list maintenance, scheduling meetings, holding clinics ...
This year, we've had discussion on bringing high profile
speakers to Portland, and recently the RedHat Road Trip.
IIRC, a couple of years ago, there was talk about holding
a Linux convention in Portland.

These things take time and organization.  If those who are
actually doing the work need/want a mechanism to communicate,
and not bore the rest of us with tedious details, (hey, I've
more than enough tedious details in my own life that y'all
don't want to know about) I say "go for it!".

The reality is PLUG does have an steering committee (or, if
you prefer "cabal", "inner circle", "secret council" :-) ).
They are the guys/gals getting things done.  And, I must say,
they've been doing a pretty damned good job.  I certainly get
a lot of benefit from PLUG ... and I don't do squat!  (Well,
I try and answer at least one question for every one that I
post ... but that's pretty minimal in exchange for all the
other goodness this group makes available.)

My comments/suggestions for "plug-org" are:

   * Make any proceedings/notes open [for reading] to all.

   * Public write access is not necessary.  If one of us lurkers
     really has a serious itch, we will have e-mail addresses
     of the partcipants, and we'll just have to lobby the
     individuals to accept our idea.  Or ... we put our own
     butts on the line, and join the group!  Our organizors
     put their reputation on the line by taking responsibility
     for keeping the meetings/clinics going, making sure the
     pdxlinux.org servers work, etc.  And they do it as
     volunteers.

   * It might be a good idea to write up an informal charter
     that plug-org and plug-er's can review to remind ourselves
     why plug-org exists.

I too missed Karl's original post.  Going back an re-reading it,
he is right.  If we are ever to become ambitious enough to try
and host a convention (at least to host as "PLUG") we will need
some quasi-legal proof of existance -- you know, the ability to
sign agreements for leasing expo space, etc.

I am dismayed though, that his e-mail to PLUG occurred *before*
the infrastructure (web page and mailman config) were ready.

... ok, I yield the soapbox to the our next distinguished speaker ...

- Don




From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Nov 14 11:50:50 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 11:50:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] nice process
In-Reply-To: <1ZPM943X3WSMQONJQKC7A5WRSOIF9NK.3dd1e376@miked>
Message-ID: <9485-24433@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 12 Nov 2002, Mike De La Mater mikedela-at-ipns.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> That helps, but it still allows my idle to drop to under 5%, still not
> what I was looking for. Before renice, it would totally monopolize the
> cycles. I'm going to drop the compression rate a bit.

Dropping the compression rate won't improve your idle time.  The "--fast"
compression will still use 100% of the CPU available to it, but will do so
for a shorter period of time.

  -- Steve

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 12:34:40 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 12:34:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <3DD40153.30602@sun.com>
References: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com> <20021114184149.GB771@nellump.net> <3DD40153.30602@sun.com>
Message-ID: <200211141234.40542.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think the best networked tank game I ever played was one written in GL 
called "bz" that we ran under IRIX. It was like Battle Zone but it was 
in 3D color and we had to capture the other teams flag. All of the 
developers in the group I worked in had SGI boxes on their desks and we 
would sometime stay late of Fridays playing in two teams. 

We even went so far as to hack the code to make the gun projectiles 
fired by our tanks twice as fast as normal so we could beat the team 
that was unbeatable! There was now way our opponents could ever move 
fast enough to get our of the way in time.

Yea it was bad that we cheated but the other team was impressed at our 
craftiness. :) Later on with enough practice we were good enough that 
we could win a few games now and then due to our skill at the game. :)

Tony

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Nov 14 13:52:04 2002
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 13:52:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
References: <mailman.1037294779.15854.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3DD41B04.7050205@nakedape.cc>

Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> Does that mean that only AT&T's *nix is Unix? Are the various flavors
> of BSD, HP-UX and Solaris not Unix then?

HP-UX, Solaris, AIX, SCO OpenServer and UnixWare are all derived various 
System V codebases, so they are in fact "UNIX" by this definition.  They 
  also pay a nice license fee to use the term "UNIX" to whomever owns 
the trademark now (SCO, I think).

BSD is another story, you can read up on it at the BSD Complete FAQ, at 
http://nakedape.cc/info/bsd-complete.faq.html#0.1

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc
* * * * Linux, UNIX, Networking and Security Solutions * * * *
QCSNet                                     http://www.qcsn.com
* * * * T1, Frame Relay, DSL, Dial-up, and Web Hosting * * * *

On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 09:58, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> 
> The freely available BSDs are also quite good although they don't 
> necessarily have the level of hardware support Linux has. Many of the 

When I ran BSD only, I though that Linux had better support for newer
hardward, soundcards and the like.  When I started running Linux I found
that was not universally true, that there was no way to predict which
had better support and it seemed that things were pretty equal.

as for the AT&T code being removed, I view that rather like a "seed"
crystal around which BSD grew, the fact that the original "seed" has
been replaced does not change the shape of the crystal :), but then
again, what is UNIX is a matter of opinion, in my opinion.

On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 10:37, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> 
> Source: O'Reilly's ``Essential System Administration,'' 2nd Edtion by
> AEleen Frisch.
> 
> -Cooper
> 
> On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 09:40, Brian Beattie wrote:
> > On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 09:33, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > 
> > > 
> > > Linux is a clone of Unix, but it has several key differences that make
> > > it so exciting.
> > > 
> > > First, Linux combines the most popular features of the prior Unices and
> > > melds them into a really usable system. I personally, for example, have
> > > never really liked System V's printing commands, opting instead for the
> > > BSD style.
> > 
> > System V rel 4 included most BSD features
> > 
> > > 
> > > Second, Linux is totally open source. This makes it nary impossible for
> > > any single vendor to take the code and run away with it.
> > 
> > Originly UNIX was delivered wit the source code and BSD is directly
> > derived from AT&T UNIX and is open source.
> > 
> > > 
> > > Third, Linux supports a wide variety of hardware platforms from Intel,
> > > to Sparc, to PowerPC and others. This makes it possible to take a
> > > program's source code from an Intel box and 
> > > 
> > 
> > UNIX has run on a number of platforms, DEC PDP, Intel, MIPS, Alpha,
> > Sparc, PowerPC.
> > 
> > > Finally, Linux is just cool; it supports most of the hardware available
> > > for the x86 architecture, no small feat indeed.
> > 
> > so do flavors of UNIX.
> > 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > -Cooper
> > > 
> > > >

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Thu Nov 14 14:11:54 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 14 Nov 2002 14:11:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211140833080.12678-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211140833080.12678-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1037311914.2868.147.camel@coyote>

On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 09:46, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> > Is Linux truly Unix? If not, how do you define Unix?
> 
> "UNIX" is a registered trademark of X/Open, and no OS can technically be
> called UNIX without their permission. Also Linux is not based directly on
> the source code from the original version of UNIX, unlike FreeBSD,
> Solaris, HPUX, Chord, or Xenix.

And Kleenex is (or was) a trademark, and Asprin was trademark.  As a
private citizen I am entitled to my opinion and if there is no essential
difference between two items, I see no need to make a distinction just
because some fool has paid millions of dollars for the rights to some
word.  UNIX is as UNIX does.  Having worked with UNIX* for some 20 years
kernel and user-space I feel entitled to my opinions, I don't feel
lawyers or courts are entitled to an opinion on this matter.

Unix systems I have worked on.

UNIX Edition 6
UNIX Edition 7
BSD 2.9, 2.10
BSD 4.1c
PWB
System III
System V rel 2
System V rel 2.2
System V rel 4
SUN OS
Solaris
HP/UX
BSD/OS
FreeBSD
OpenBSD
Linux

--

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 14 13:50:07 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 13:50:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Streaming media in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20021114155717.5957336B16@ados.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211130143170.19064-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
    <20021114155717.5957336B16@ados.com>
Message-ID: <20021114221620.XUNG2683.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>

SuSE 8.1 has mplayer packaged. If its not on the personal cd set it is on the
ftp server for you to grab. I'm not sure if you can use the package on RH but
it might be worth a try. This are the other package requirements as best that I
can tell.

SDL-1.2.4-200
aalib-1.2-697
alsa-0.9.0.cvs20020903-32
audiofile-0.2.3-171
cdparanoia-IIIalpha9.8-286
MPlayer-0.90pre6-52
DirectFB-0.9.11-53
libdv-0.98-63
libdvdread-0.9.3-43
esound-0.2.28-64
gtk-1.2.10-460
glib-1.2.10-324
gpm-1.20.1-46
gtk-1.2.10-460
libjpeg-6.2.0-480
lirc-0.6.5-196
mad-0.14.2b-151
libogg-1.0-42
libpng-1.2.4-40
popt-1.6-281
slang-1.4.5-52
libstdc++-3.2-44
libvorbis-1.0-43

I used this to find the requirements. I might have missed something.
for i in `rpm -qR MPlayer-0.90pre6-52` ; do rpm -q --whatprovides `find
/usr/lib/ -name $i 2>%1 | grep -v "find"` 2>%1 | grep -v rpm ; done

These are the requirements the above searched on. 
rpm -qR MPlayer-0.90pre6-52

/bin/bash

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 14 16:01:31 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 16:01:31 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114172548.10081.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141558440.21003-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> Does that mean that only AT&T's *nix is Unix? Are the various flavors
> of BSD, HP-UX and Solaris not Unix then?

Scott,

  They are UNIX-like, or 'unices'. When you buy (or drive) a car, you find
all the expected pieces in the same places: clutch on the left, brake in the
middle, accelerator on the right; drive on the left, wheels on each corner,
etc. Brand doesn't matter -- to the functioning of the vehicle, that is.

  Same with the unices. They all work pretty much the same. Some have power
windows (oops! a pun!), others have hand cranks. Some have the fuel tank
opening on the left, others on the right. Paint schemes differ, too. But,
they're all working the same where the bits meet the wire.

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 14 16:07:39 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 16:07:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <200211140958.12026.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141605230.21003-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> The biggest thing for me was that Linux changed my perception of the 
> Intel platform. I found that it could be run for months or even years 
> with out a crash. Up until my first taste of Linux I had only used DOS, 
> Windows, OS/2, and WinNT on Intel platforms and none of those systems 
> were that resistant to crashes. OS/2 and WinNT were better than DOS and 
> Window 3.x but I saw my share of BSOD on NT and OS/2 had alot of 
> problems with GUI lockups because of the way Presentation Manager  
> handled its input queue.

  From the perspective of one who worked on mainframes (primarily CDC,
Burroughs, and IBM S/360) and minis (HP-3000, Prime, DEC/System 10, and the
odd PDP-ll/750 and VAX), I gotta' say what you all neglected to write: that
linux has put the FUN back into working on a PC. DOS was OK, but not as good
as CP/M, windows I always thought was a dog, but linux ...? It's happy time
again!

Rich

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 16:31:30 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 16:31:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141605230.21003-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141605230.21003-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211141631.30622.aschlemm@attbi.com>

VAXes were fun so long as they had BSD or DEC Ultrix on them. :-) I did 
do my share of work under VMS though too. I did think DOS was a bit of 
a step up from plain old CP/M-80. My CP/M machine was a 6MHZ Z80B 
system with 64K of memory. My DOS system which I got later on had 640K 
and later versions of DOS included support for subdirectories and stuff 
which was something my old CP/M-80 system didn't have. 

I do believe there were some much more functional versions of CP/M that 
came out later on that supported concurrent users and stuff but I had 
already moved on to Unix by that time and was out of the loop. I had 
endless hours of fun with CP/M and taught myself 8080 and Z80 assembly 
language when I had the system. 

Later on Borland's Turbo Pascal was available for CP/M and it was 
offered quite inexpensively that I was able to afford a copy even 
though I was a poor college student at the time. :)

Tony

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 16:42:52 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 16:42:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <20021114144329.66050879.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
References: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com> <200211141234.40542.aschlemm@attbi.com> <20021114144329.66050879.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211141642.52489.aschlemm@attbi.com>

>From the description on the website and the mention of SGI I would have 
to assume that it is the same game. It looks alot more sophisticated 
now. When I was playing it the battleground looked like a moon with 
hills and large boulders. I was playing this game back in a 1994-95 
timeframe.

In looking at the logfile information in the screen shots it brings back 
alot of fond memories. I can still here people scream in the office 
when their tank got killed. :)

We also had another game called "Battalion". It had some cool graphics 
and had monsters like Godzilla and Mothra. You fought against tanks, 
helicopters and other stuff. It was cool to shot the tanks as they sort 
of melted into slag. There was even a red and silver man-like enemy 
that looked like a crude rendering of Ultra Man. 

Looks like Battalion is still around and is available for Linux. It 
looks alot different than I remember:

http://www.evl.uic.edu/aej/AndyBattalionMesa.html

Tony

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 14 16:57:54 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 16:57:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <3DD4295B.8020104@nakedape.cc>
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211140833080.12678-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU> <mailman.1037311995.26295.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <3DD4295B.8020104@nakedape.cc>
Message-ID: <200211141657.54569.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I remember working on a 68000 based S100 based system that ran System V 
Rel 1.5. It was from a company called Dual that was in Berkeley, CA. 
The systems had these amazing 80MB Fujitsu hard drives that had a 
repretation of lasting nearly forever. 

The systems where purchased in 1983/4 timeframe and were still running 
24/7 in 1991 with the same hardware when I left the company. The only 
changes over those 7 years was some additional memory to support more 
users and ethernet cards so we didn't have to use UUCP to transfer 
files between systems anymore. 

The system held a patient billing system on a Unify database and the 
drives were thrashed pretty hard twice a month with the billing cycles 
and report generation that was done.

Tony

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> The systems where purchased in 1983/4 timeframe and were still running 
> 24/7 in 1991 with the same hardware when I left the company. The only 
> changes over those 7 years was some additional memory to support more 
> users and ethernet cards so we didn't have to use UUCP to transfer

  Take a look at how many Okidata dot-matrix printers are still working in
retail stores and other places after 20 years. Hardware used to be well
made. Many systems are still running but the companies that designed and
built them failed. What lesson do we gain from this?

Rich

 - APM is configured in the kernel

   motherboard.

computer.  It just goes through the shutdown process and where
the last thing to print to the screen is:

    Halting.
    Power down.

Then it just sits there powered up and doing nothing.  How can I
get this to power off?

I'm running Mandrake 9.0 on this Pentium I MMX 233MHz system.

Thanks....

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Thu Nov 14 18:01:14 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
>
> > The biggest thing for me was that Linux changed my perception of the
> > Intel platform. I found that it could be run for months or even years
> > with out a crash. Up until my first taste of Linux I had only used DOS,
> > Windows, OS/2, and WinNT on Intel platforms and none of those systems
> > were that resistant to crashes. OS/2 and WinNT were better than DOS and
> > Window 3.x but I saw my share of BSOD on NT and OS/2 had alot of
> > problems with GUI lockups because of the way Presentation Manager
> > handled its input queue.
>
>   From the perspective of one who worked on mainframes (primarily CDC,
> Burroughs, and IBM S/360) and minis (HP-3000, Prime, DEC/System 10, and the
> odd PDP-ll/750 and VAX), I gotta' say what you all neglected to write: that
> linux has put the FUN back into working on a PC. DOS was OK, but not as good
> as CP/M, windows I always thought was a dog, but linux ...? It's happy time
> again!

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Thu Nov 14 18:06:23 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 18:06:23 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <20021115014814.3C4812FEF8@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <20021115020623.39297.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com>

Pentium 1? For that era, it is most likely an AT power supply rather
than an ATX. AT power supplies have a "hard" switch and cannot turn
themselves off.

-Scott

> shutdown process and where the last thing to print to the screen is:

>     Halting.
>     Power down.

this is a stretch: my box requires one to hold the power button in until it
finally recognizes that I really mean it. OTOH, when I issue, 'shutdown -h
now' it does so.

On Thursday 14 November 2002 13:52 pm, you wrote:
> Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> > Does that mean that only AT&T's *nix is Unix? Are the various flavors
> > of BSD, HP-UX and Solaris not Unix then?
>
> HP-UX, Solaris, AIX, SCO OpenServer and UnixWare are all derived various
> System V codebases, so they are in fact "UNIX" by this definition.  They
>   also pay a nice license fee to use the term "UNIX" to whomever owns
> the trademark now (SCO, I think).
>
> BSD is another story, you can read up on it at the BSD Complete FAQ, at
> http://nakedape.cc/info/bsd-complete.faq.html#0.1
>
> Wil

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 14 22:26:57 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 14 Nov 2002 22:26:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Subject: Inet Connection Sharing (Mandrake 8.0
    gateway, MDK 9.0 host)
In-Reply-To: <20021115014444.BDA6E2FEF8@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20021115014444.BDA6E2FEF8@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <E18CaOP-0005KY-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Switch, hub, or cross over cable?

Switch or hub, it could be a 10/100 auto negotiation issue. Manually setting
the client's Ethernet speed, 10 or 100 and mode, half or full, might solve the
issue.

If cross over cable, when the client powers off, the Ethernet link would go
dead. Your firewall, if you have one, might not allow connections until it was
was restarted after the link comes back up. Also routing might be automatically
disabled in the event of link loss and only restarted when you restart your
network.

If you are using a cross over cable and the client is a newer box with WOL,
wake on LAN, then turning it on should leave the Ethernet link intact when the
client is powered down but not unplugged.  

Thank you


On Thu, 14 Nov 2002 17:44:42 -0800, Kevin Cosgrove said:

> 
>  The short answer is that I had to reboot the gateway computer, in
>  spite of restarting necessary services, which I would hope MCC
>  would have done for me anyway.
>

>  subsequently turn it back on, then I have to restart my "network"
>  service, or network traffic just won't go there.  Anyone know why
>  this would be?  Rebooting the client PC without powering it down,
>  does not cause this trouble.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Nov 14 23:39:20 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 14 Nov 2002 23:39:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] perl question
In-Reply-To: <1037320113.18207.4.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
References: <1037320113.18207.4.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
Message-ID: <86bs4r7047.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt Whiteley <matt-whiteley at attbi.com> writes:

Matt> I am trying to rename a bunch of files in a directory into a
Matt> consecutive pattern.  That was pretty easy, however I am trying
Matt> to name them in order of the mtime of the file.  I have been
Matt> messing around with File::stat, but this is above my knowledge
Matt> of perl.  I am reading the llama book now but this problem just
Matt> cropped up.  I also was reading the man perlfunc pages.  If one
Matt> of you more talented types could help me out or point me in a
Matt> different direction it would be greatly appreciated.  Looking
Matt> forward to meeting a bunch of you tomorrow.

How about this in bash:

  j=1 ; for i in `ls -1tr` ; do echo $i $j ; j=$(($j+1)) ; done

The "echo" is there as a placeholder to show what is in each
variable.  When you've got them how you want them, replace it with
"mv".


--

seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 15 00:06:46 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 00:06:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141711470.21404-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211141711470.21404-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211150006.46642.aschlemm@attbi.com>

By far finest dot matrix printers I ever used were the DEC Writer IIIs. 
With a 1200 bps connection they were reasonably fast and were 
absolutely fantastic for multi-part forms. One place I worked at picked 
up a number of them for almost nothing from the local community college 
that had them collecting dust in the basement. I saw a number of 
businesses continue to use the DW IIIs even after laser printers were 
pretty much the norm then.

I guess the lesson would be that if a company makes something very well 
that never breaks they'll have a hard time staying in business since 
there isn't alot of revenue to be made on replacement parts and/or 
repeat business from customers.

Tony

On Thursday 14 November 2002 17:13 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > The systems where purchased in 1983/4 timeframe and were still
> > running 24/7 in 1991 with the same hardware when I left the
> > company. The only changes over those 7 years was some additional
> > memory to support more users and ethernet cards so we didn't have
> > to use UUCP to transfer files between systems anymore.
>
>   Take a look at how many Okidata dot-matrix printers are still
> working in retail stores and other places after 20 years. Hardware
> used to be well made. Many systems are still running but the
> companies that designed and built them failed. What lesson do we gain
> from this?
>
> Rich
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com





From mark at linuxhardware.net  Fri Nov 15 00:02:11 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 00:02:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] perl question
In-Reply-To: <1037320113.18207.4.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
References: <1037320113.18207.4.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
Message-ID: <200211150002.11648.mark@linuxhardware.net>

Hi, 

Stat is the way to go:

$mtime=(stat($filename))[9];

then put it in a hash:

$all{$filename}=$mtime;

then sort it:

foreach $g(sort { $all{$a} <=> $all{$b} } keys %all){
print "$all{$g} $g\n";
#and do some noodling around here as well.
}

hope this helps.  

Mark



On Thursday 14 November 2002 04:28 pm, Matt Whiteley wrote:
> I am trying to rename a bunch of files in a directory into a consecutive

> order of the mtime of the file.  I have been messing around with
> File::stat, but this is above my knowledge of perl.  I am reading the
> llama book now but this problem just cropped up.  I also was reading the
> man perlfunc pages.  If one of you more talented types could help me out

Mark Griskey

On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 19:10, BMDimaculangan wrote:
> Recently we change our ISP.  do some reconfigurations to the following:
> 
> /etc/sysconfig/network
> /etc/resolv.conf
> /etc/dhcpd.conf
> /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0
> 
> after the reconfigurations, the mail system is up and running again.  the
> problem now is the our IMP WebMail, we cannot display the page.  Am i
> missing some configurations...or our ISP is missing something for us..

Is this a service on your server?  What is the error that you are
getting, server not found, or page not found?

The most likely suspects are /etc/apache/httpd.conf (or the config file
for your web server) or your DNS is not pointing to the web server.

HTH a little anyway.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov 15 09:47:43 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 09:47:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?
In-Reply-To: <1037344334.2869.178.camel@coyote>
References: <20021114154852.95361.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com> <1037295235.2868.117.camel@coyote> <20021115061234.GA30055@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1037344334.2869.178.camel@coyote>
Message-ID: <20021115174743.GA18332@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Brian Beattie <beattie at beattie-home.net> [2002-11-14 23:13]:
> On Thu, 2002-11-14 at 22:12, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > * Brian Beattie <beattie at beattie-home.net> [2002-11-14 09:34]:
> > > having worked with UNIX since version 6 days, I consider Linux, a
> > > version of UNIX.
> > 
> > Careful who you say that to. I think Linus disagrees with you. :)
> 
> He's entitled to his opinion, but I suspect I've seen more AT&T code
> than he has :)
> 

As if that matters...

My point is, that if people start calling is "UNIX", and that becomes
common, then someone will be sued by the folks that own the copyright on
the term UNIX. 

Regardless of your, my or anyone elses opinion, that's the law of the
land. 

That's also why the folks at GNU and Linus all say that it's not "Unix",
but it is a "Unix-workalike". That's as close as you can legally get
without stepping into potentially scalding water. 

This is especially important for those of us that actively support and
advocate the use of Linux. If we "sell" the use of Linux as "a form of
Unix", then we are opening ourselves up to being sued by the copyright
holders. 

In addition, the copyright holder (as I'm sure you are aware) is
REQUIRED to defend his copyright. If he doesn't, he loses it. So, you
are really asking to be sued by purporting Linux to be a UNIX, when in
fact, the creator and distributors of said product states that it is not in fact, a UNIX.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Sex is a three-letter word which needs some old-fashioned four-letter words to convey its full meaning -- Murphy's Laws on Sex n?33

> I have a couple of ATX P1 boards.  The last iterations of the P1's would

I've seen boards that have both AT and ATX connectors (the FIC 503+
comes to mind)  usually designed for the AMD processors that still used
the socket 7 pinout.  Most of these could run up to 100Mhz front side
bus.  Some of these could take either SIMMS or DIMMS for memory too.

> 
> -R

Well, the question still stands - is it an ATX or AT
powersupply/motherboard?

If it is AT, then nothing you do will let it automatically shut down. 
If it is an ATX, then we may be able to figure something out.

Rob

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Nov 15 10:09:19 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 15 Nov 2002 10:09:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021115-104603-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
References: <EX-20021115-104603-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <1037383765.27377.789.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-11-15 at 08:42, Percival, Ray wrote:
> OK so ignore the P1 part of the question I have almost identical kernel/BIOS settings with a brand new AMD based box. Mostly I don't mind but my wife would like the auto shutdown. So does anyone have any thoughts on how to implement from this point?
> 
> 
This is probably not the answer you are looking for, but I "fixed" by
powerdown by selecting the "use real mode to power down" option while
configuring my kernel (I always compile a kernel for each system that I
install).  Make sure that you select the "enable APM on boot" as well.

This option is probably enabled in most pre-compiled kernels, but the
"enable APM on boot" is not.  To enable APM on these kernels, you need
to have your bootloader tell the kernel to turn it on.

Good Luck

Derek Loree





From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Fri Nov 15 10:14:24 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 12:14:24 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
Message-ID: <EX-20021115-121752-0004@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

That is most likely what I was looking for. Since I'll be building a new kernel tonight, kernel-package just makes it to fun and easy and I *love* to see it compile on my new box, I'll try that thanks.

=======================================================================

Note: The Redhat Road Tour will be at this Clinic. See here for more
information:  http://www.redhat.com/roadtour/planned_stops/

          *** Portland Linux User's Group (PLUG) Announcement ***
                                     
             The Linux Clinic - third Saturday of every month
                                     
    Interested in Linux? Need help installing or configuring Linux? Be
           sure to attend the next session of the Linux Clinic.
                                     
                               Linux Clinic
                                     
                             November 16, 2002
                                     
                                1PM - 4PM

                          9727 SW Terwilliger Blvd,                                                     
                             Portland, Oregon
                                     
   What to bring:
     * Your computer, monitor, keyboard and mouse.
     * Any relevant peripherals (printer, modem, etc).
     * Your Linux distribution (if you have already installed).
     * The manuals for your hardware - especially your monitor manual.
       
   Resources available:
     * Volunteers skilled in Linux installation and maintenance.
     * The PLUG CD library (including several recent Linux
       distributions).
     * T-1 Internet connection
     * phone jacks for testing modem and Internet setups.
     * Ethernet drops.
     * Infocus projector for demonstrations.
     * An extra Linux box for experimenting.
     * A number of reference materials

   http://www.riverdale.k12.or.us/info/direct.html

   dhaskell at acm.org

From revans at e-z.net  Fri Nov 15 10:11:37 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 10:11:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021115-104603-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
References: <EX-20021115-104603-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Try 'noapic'  at the boot prompt and then try a poweroff once the box boots. If
it works then add noapic to the append line.

Russell


On Fri, 15 Nov 2002 10:42:25 -0600, Percival, Ray said:

> OK so ignore the P1 part of the question I have almost identical kernel/BIOS settings with a brand new AMD based box. Mostly I don't mind but my wife would like the auto shutdown. So does anyone have any thoughts on how to implement from this point?
>



From kevinc at dOink.COM  Fri Nov 15 10:32:56 2002

to power down" and "enable APM on boot".

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 15 11:00:47 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 11:00:47 -0800
Subject: ATX vs AT (was: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down)
In-Reply-To: <3DD536CD.4060904@sun.com>
References: <20021115020623.39297.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com> <1037382882.25572.782.camel@dereklinux> <3DD536CD.4060904@sun.com>
Message-ID: <200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've got a system with an Asus SP97V mobo and it has both AT and ATX 
power supply connectors on the board. It does have a AT style keyboard 
connector but it did come with a PS/2 style connector for converting 
one of the onboard serial ports to a PS/2 connector. 

A little strange to say the least and I've always used an AT power 
supply on the thing even when replacing the old power supply with a new 
one. I was surprised to find I could still find new AT power supplies. 
I don't know how I could use an ATX power supply on the thing unless 
those power supplies fit in an PC/AT case. More importantly...without a 
PS/2 style keyboard connector and, DB25 and DB9 connectors mounted on 
the back of the board I don't see how I can put this mobo into an ATX 
case.

Tony

On Friday 15 November 2002 10:02 am, Richard Langis wrote:
> My neighbor had a Socket 370 board with an AT-Style Keyboard
> connector. I think the PS was ATX, but the combination was odd, to
> say the least.
>
> -R
>
> Derek Loree wrote:
> > On Fri, 2002-11-15 at 08:04, Richard Langis wrote:
> >>I have a couple of ATX P1 boards.  The last iterations of the P1's
> >> would allow higher bus speeds (75/83+), ATX form factor, PC100
> >> DIMMS, etc etc.
> >
> > I've seen boards that have both AT and ATX connectors (the FIC 503+
> > comes to mind)  usually designed for the AMD processors that still
> > used the socket 7 pinout.  Most of these could run up to 100Mhz
> > front side bus.  Some of these could take either SIMMS or DIMMS for
> > memory too.
> >
> >>-R
> >>
> >>Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> >>>Pentium 1? For that era, it is most likely an AT power supply
> >>> rather than an ATX. AT power supplies have a "hard" switch and
> >>> cannot turn themselves off.
> >>>
> >>>-Scott

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov 15 11:01:44 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 11:01:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <20021115183259.4C01B2FEF8@joseph.doink.com>
References: <EX-20021115-121752-0004@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net> <20021115183259.4C01B2FEF8@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <20021115190144.GB18332@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Kevin Cosgrove <kevinc at dOink.COM> [2002-11-15 10:47]:
> 
> This is my motherboard:
> 
> http://tyan.com/products/html/a%5Ftitanturboat2.html
> 
> It's described as AT like, or AT2.  I don't see ATX
> anywhere.
> 
> It looks like I need to recompile my kernel with "use real mode
> to power down" and "enable APM on boot".

According to the picture at that URL, it has only an AT power connector.
If that's actually the case, then you won't be able to have it auto
power off. The motherboard has nothing to do with it. 

Manually turning off the power supply is the only way to accomplish a
complete shutdown.

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Sex is a three-letter word which needs some old-fashioned four-letter words to convey its full meaning -- Murphy's Laws on Sex n?33



From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov 15 11:07:57 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 11:07:57 -0800
Subject: ATX vs AT (was: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down)
In-Reply-To: <200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <20021115020623.39297.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com> <1037382882.25572.782.camel@dereklinux> <3DD536CD.4060904@sun.com> <200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021115190757.GC18332@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com> [2002-11-15 11:02]:
> I've got a system with an Asus SP97V mobo and it has both AT and ATX 
> power supply connectors on the board. It does have a AT style keyboard 
> connector but it did come with a PS/2 style connector for converting 
> one of the onboard serial ports to a PS/2 connector. 
> 
> A little strange to say the least and I've always used an AT power 
> supply on the thing even when replacing the old power supply with a new 
> one. I was surprised to find I could still find new AT power supplies. 
> I don't know how I could use an ATX power supply on the thing unless 
> those power supplies fit in an PC/AT case. More importantly...without a 
> PS/2 style keyboard connector and, DB25 and DB9 connectors mounted on 
> the back of the board I don't see how I can put this mobo into an ATX 
> case.

Not unusual, just not common. :)

I've built several computers over the last 4 years or so that had ATX cases
that came with a special insert for that type of motherboard. The insert
only had the keyboard hole in it, and that had a knockout so you could
make the hole bigger if the MB had the AT style keyboard socket. 

I think I've still got some of those inserts lying around, as I've never
actually used them. I was building computers with ATX motherboards, so I
used the other insert that came with the case. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From alan at clueserver.org  Fri Nov 15 02:41:27 2002

On Fri, 15 Nov 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:

> > to power down" and "enable APM on boot".
> 
> According to the picture at that URL, it has only an AT power connector.
> If that's actually the case, then you won't be able to have it auto
> power off. The motherboard has nothing to do with it. 
> 
> Manually turning off the power supply is the only way to accomplish a
> complete shutdown.


Actually this is a different problem.

Turn off APM.

Turn on ACPI.

I have the same problem with my Dual Athalon 2100+ MP.  The default 
install of Redhat sees enough of ACPI to think that APM is there and stops 
looking.  (Probably because ACPI is brain-damaged on some motherboards.)





From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Nov 15 11:11:26 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 11:11:26 -0800
Subject: ATX vs AT (was: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down)
References: <20021115020623.39297.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com> <1037382882.25572.782.camel@dereklinux> <3DD536CD.4060904@sun.com> <200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DD546DE.7080301@sun.com>

One of my older ATX cases has an insert for the rectangular IO 'hole' 
that has a AT-Style keyboard hole, and that's it.  I don't think any of 
the newer ones I've bought have that insert, although they may be 
available from the manufacturer after the fact.

-R

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Nov 15 11:12:25 2002

Looking at the picture, there is only an AT power connector, you will
always have to hit the power button to power this board down.  It is the
way the power supply is designed.

From derek at infotects.com  Fri Nov 15 11:24:40 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 15 Nov 2002 11:24:40 -0800
Subject: ATX vs AT (was: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down)
In-Reply-To: <200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <20021115020623.39297.qmail@web10409.mail.yahoo.com>
	<1037382882.25572.782.camel@dereklinux> <3DD536CD.4060904@sun.com> 
	<200211151100.47164.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1037388280.27377.804.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2002-11-15 at 11:00, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> I've got a system with an Asus SP97V mobo and it has both AT and ATX 
> power supply connectors on the board. It does have a AT style keyboard 
> connector but it did come with a PS/2 style connector for converting 
> one of the onboard serial ports to a PS/2 connector. 
> 
> A little strange to say the least and I've always used an AT power 
> supply on the thing even when replacing the old power supply with a new 
> one. I was surprised to find I could still find new AT power supplies. 
> I don't know how I could use an ATX power supply on the thing unless 
> those power supplies fit in an PC/AT case. More importantly...without a 
> PS/2 style keyboard connector and, DB25 and DB9 connectors mounted on 
> the back of the board I don't see how I can put this mobo into an ATX 
> case.

The ATX power supply and the AT power supply usually (I say this because
some OEM's have proprietary power supplies) have the same case size and
mounting holes.  To convert your case from AT power to ATX power, all
you need is a push button switch (normally open, momentary push to
close) that you can connect to the appropriate pins on the motherboard. 
The tricky part is usually finding a switch that looks like it belongs
to the case, but that is only a matter of aesthetics.

Derek
> 
> Tony
> 
> On Friday 15 November 2002 10:02 am, Richard Langis wrote:
> > My neighbor had a Socket 370 board with an AT-Style Keyboard
> > connector. I think the PS was ATX, but the combination was odd, to
> > say the least.
> >
> > -R
> >
> > Derek Loree wrote:
> > > On Fri, 2002-11-15 at 08:04, Richard Langis wrote:
> > >>I have a couple of ATX P1 boards.  The last iterations of the P1's
> > >> would allow higher bus speeds (75/83+), ATX form factor, PC100
> > >> DIMMS, etc etc.
> > >
> > > I've seen boards that have both AT and ATX connectors (the FIC 503+
> > > comes to mind)  usually designed for the AMD processors that still
> > > used the socket 7 pinout.  Most of these could run up to 100Mhz
> > > front side bus.  Some of these could take either SIMMS or DIMMS for
> > > memory too.
