From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 15 11:30:40 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 11:30:40 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Gates offers to buy India
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211151128080.25214-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I suppose it's a reasonable assumption that he could buy India after
buying the curent Administration here.

---------- Forwarded message ----------

                    Tux Fights Bux for the Soul of India

   Thursday, November 14, 2002--I worked in radio back during that
   industry's Jurassic, when disc jockeys still picked the music and it
   was okay for everybody to have fun. Even commercial stations were
   about as corporate as the corner bar.

   My best years were spent at WDBS, a commercial "progressive" rocker
   incongruously owned but not operated by Duke University. Its operators
   were a bunch of deeply committed and barely organized folks who, in
   retrospect, resembled the free software and open-source cadres of
   today.

   With no profit motive and the lousiest signal on the dial, we had a
   hard time selling advertising. So we'd make up ads for things that
   didn't exist and run those instead. Many were by a weird announcer
   named Doctor Dave. That was me. My nickname today is a fossil remnant
   of that old radio persona.

   We ran ads for Bangweasel Stone & Rubber Company, Mumbling Pines
   Apartment Village and Wellington Raffelators. In many cases the actual
   nature of the business was left unrevealed. "If you need a pipe
   cleaned or a zipper laid, we'll do the job for you... remember you
   can't take a customer without taking his money."

   One fake ad with a recognizable purpose pushed a record collection
   that consisted of "All the world's most beautiful music, all at once."
   The listener was then treated to an overdubbed blast of countless
   simultaneous music selections.

   That's kind of the way I feel about the current news about the
   conflict between Microsoft and Linux in India, where Bill Gates is
   touring right now, causing free PR for Linux wherever he goes.

   Still, I've managed to put together a chronology of Our Story So Far.
   If it reads like a series of dispatches from The Front, well... maybe
   it is.

     * October 10 - The Inquirer:
       http://inquirerinside.com/?article=5767 writes "India Moving to
       Linux", explaining things this way:

     India's government Department of Information Technology has
     announced a sweeping initiative (the Linux India Initiative) to
     move the entire country to Linux as its "platform of choice"...

     The plan is to establish Linux in Indian academic institutions as
     well as throughout central and state government offices. India's
     business sector also is likely to move to Linux for its lower costs
     and to employ the Linux skills developed in the large Indian IT
     workforce.

     As a developing country, India feels the bite of expensive
     proprietary software licenses much more acutely than other
     countries with mature economies. Enforcing intellectual property
     rights--as India has pledged to do--will spur its takeup of Linux
     open-source software.

     * November 11 - The William and Melinda Gates Foundation:
       http://www.gatesfoundation.org/globalhealth/hivaidstb/hivaids/anno
       uncements/announcement-021111.htm grants $100 million for an
       HIV/AIDs initiative in India.
     * November 11 - The Washington Post:
       http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A38446-2002Nov11.htm
       l reports that the Gates' generosity follows suspiciously close on
       the heels of news about the Linux India Initiative.
     * November 11 - Business World India runs "The War for India's
       Software Soul":
       http://www.businessworldindia.com/cover1.htm. An excerpt:

     The battle has spilled over into India. Look around. There are
     noises being made about how proactively the government is
     considering Linux. The Supreme Court has a few pilot projects
     underway. So have High Courts in Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. The
     Central Excise Department has moved 1,000 desktops to Linux. The
     Delhi Road Transport Office (RTO) has implemented a pilot [program]
     to examine its viability. C-DAC, the government's supercomputing
     arm, has moved lock, stock and barrel to Linux.

     Then there is the National Stock Exchange - among the early
     adopters who used Linux to implement a solution unique to stock
     exchanges anywhere in the world. Corporates like Asian Paints and
     IDBI are cheerleading the free source OS. Others like Reliance,
     Texas Instruments, the Times of India group (publishers of The
     Times of India), Raymond, Bombay Dyeing, Godrej Infotech, HDFC
     Bank, Hindustan Dorr Oliver, Central Railways and Air-India have
     deployed Linux to power at least a part of their backends.
     At premier educational institutions like the Indian Institute of
     Technology, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research and Bhabha
     Atomic Research Centre, Linux exists - de facto. Those not on the
     bandwagon, are slowly getting onto it. To get a sense of that, step
     into the Sardar Patel Engineering College in Andheri, Mumbai.
     You'll find people like Dinesh Shah, Trevor Warren and Harsh Busa
     of the Mumbai Linux Users Group (MLUG) bubbling with enthusiasm. On
     weekends, they spend time at educational institutions across the
     country spreading the gospel of Linux in neatly slotted two-day
     workshops. In Maharashtra, the clamour for their workshops has gone
     up because the government made Linux mandatory to their curriculum,
     beginning this year. "Catch them young and watch them grow," says
     Trevor gleefully.

     * November 12 - Business Times Asia runs "Bill Gates lands in India
       amid a Linux debate":
       http://business-times.asia1.com.sg/news/story/0,2276,63470,00.html
       , adding this about the initiative:

     Just weeks before Mr Gates' impending arrival, officials in India's
     Department of Information Technology in New Delhi leaked details of
     an effort called the Linux India Initiative. It is meant to promote
     Linux for use in government departments and corporations.
     Information Technology Minister Pramod Mahajan has declined to
     discuss the initiative. "I don't want to comment on Linux so close
     to Gates' visit," he said last week.

     * November 12 - Microsoft establishes a $400 million fund:
       http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/press/2002/Nov02/11-12IndiaPR.a
       sp for various development projects in India
     * November 12 - Bill Gates announces an additional $20 million:
       http://www.financialexpress.com/fe_full_story.php?content_id=21608
       to spread computer education in Indian schools. And somewhere in
       there, Microsoft also became the commercial investor in the Media
       Lab Asia project, investing $1 million, bringing the total to $421
       million.
     * November 12 - ZDNet runs "MS invests in India--to stave off
       Linux?":
       http://zdnet.com.com/2100-1106-965378.html
     * November 13 - The Register's Thomas C. Green writes:
       http://www.theregister.co.uk/content/4/28063.html, "That means
       that Linux is more than four times worse than AIDS to Billg and
       his happy Redmond family."
     * November 13 - The Hindustan Times:
       http://www.hindustantimes.com/news/181_101371,0003.htm carries a
       Reuters story that opens this way:

     Microsoft Corp chairman Bill Gates coaxed Indian engineers on
     Wednesday to use his firm's proprietary software, as he dismissed
     threats to his Windows system from rival Linux in the battle over
     network computing.

     The world's richest man, on the third day of his trip to India,
     didn't bring any gifts, but instead delivered a sales pitch in the
     nation's technology capital. More than 1,000 software companies are
     based in Bangalore.

     Gates, who said on Tuesday that his firm would invest $400 million
     in India over three years on education, partnerships and boosting
     its own software centre, used his Bangalore visit to promote
     Microsoft's .NET (dot-net) network platforms and tools.

     * November 13 - The Seattle Post-Intelligencer:
       http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/business/95307_india13.shtml opens
       their story along pretty much the same lines:

     NEW DELHI, India--Hoping to stave off a rise in the popularity of
     free, open-source software, Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates
     announced yesterday a $400 million investment in India to expand
     the company's operations and boost computer literacy.

     * November 13 - The Financial Express:
       http://www.financialexpress.com/fe_full_story.php?content_id=21608
       writes that Gates "ducked a couple of Linux-related questions"
       before "replying to a pointed questions on Linux" with a dig at
       Sun. "There is a visible shift in UNIX space from Sun platforms to
       Linux. In fact, it is Sun which is losing market share to Linux,"
       Gates said.

   Meanwhile, the grass roots grow deeper and wider on the subcontinent.
   Linux Bangalore, for example, is pushing its Linux Localization
   Initiative:
   http://lli.linux-bangalore.org--the kind of quiet and steady purpose
   that will cause countless Linux victories on fronts no publication
   covers.

   Actually, I doubt it's a battle either side will lose. It's a big
   country. There is an awful lot of work--a majority of it,
   probably--that can only be done on highly capable, flexible, reliable
   and cost-free platforms. That's a "threat" that Microsoft can't do a
   thing about, no matter how much money they throw at it.

   Doc Searls:
   mailto:doc at ssc.com is senior editor of Linux Journal.




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 15 12:31:13 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)

Subject: ATX vs AT (was: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down)
In-Reply-To: <1037388280.27377.804.camel@dereklinux>

Message-ID: <200211151231.13984.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I guess I'll have to see if I can find such an insert as it would be 
nice to go with an ATX case and power supply since all of my other 
systems are ATX based. My little old Socket 7 system is not that fast 
and so it makes a perfect gateway/firewall system that I hope to keep 
alive for many years to come. 

Because it's a critical system I'm forced to keep a spare PC/AT power 
supply and CPU cooler on hand for it.

Tony

> > > > that still used the socket 7 pinout.  Most of these could run
> > > > up to 100Mhz front side bus.  Some of these could take either
> > > > SIMMS or DIMMS for memory too.
> > > >
> > > >>-R
> > > >>
> > > >>Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> > > >>>Pentium 1? For that era, it is most likely an AT power supply
> > > >>> rather than an ATX. AT power supplies have a "hard" switch
> > > >>> and cannot turn themselves off.
> > > >>>
> > > >>>-Scott
> > >

From sandy at herring.org  Fri Nov 15 13:22:42 2002
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 13:22:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FTC targets deceptive spam
Message-ID: <20021115132242.B17029@kippered.herring.org>

http://www.computerworld.com/securitytopics/security/privacy/story/0,10801,75880,00.html

ObTeaser:   Yesterday, the FTC said in a statement that it had filed three
            more complaints against three spammers and settled with four
            others who used spam to promote chain e-mail schemes and were
            caught in an FTC sting. 

            [...]

            Chris Hoofnagle, legislative counsel for the Washington-based
            Electronic Privacy Information Center, said that while it's good
            for the FTC to go after spammers who send fraudulent e-mails,
            the agency should do more to protect consumers against
            mainstream spammers. 

            He called on Congress to pass "opt-in" legislation for spammers,
            requiring them to get a user's permission before sending out
            spam e-mails. In addition, the legislation should require
            spammers to label their e-mails as advertisements.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Nov 15 16:39:17 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 16:39:17 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Streaming media in Linux?
In-Reply-To: <20021114155717.5957336B16@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211151542080.25477-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 14 Nov 2002, guy1656 wrote:
> : Your response reminds me of a time in my high school chemistry class ...
> 
> Neat. I didn't know that installing something to be used for FUN was
> supposed to feel like a chemistry test. Actually, that was EXACTLY the
> problem I was trying to bring out. Remember, we're talking about a
> program written for playing ENTERTAINMENT files.


Oh, so the program WASN'T written for playing datastreams that are not
entertaining or have entertainment intent?

> (Hint: Most people don't find learning what to do with a 'tarball'
> ENTERTAINING.) To say so is NOT indicative of an attitude problem on
> my part. (Nothing of the foregoing is a reflection on willingness or
> ability to learn, mind you, it's a statement of how accessible
> something is, as assessed by and for 'regular folks.')

Your emphasis on entertainment is either way off-base or purposely
misdirecting the argument here.  It's not a matter of what a person does
for fun, rather it is a matter of what a person should be willing to do to
improve their own situation (however they judge that improvement on their
own).

If a person cannot install or use a piece of software, then they must
determine the value of that software to the improvement they hoped to
bring to their life and maybe even re-evaluate the improvement itself
taking into account the amount of time and energy they'd like to spend to
reach their desired result.  That's just an overly-verbose way of
describing a natural process that all people have always followed
throughout history.  But we in the post-industrialist world have become a
pack of spoiled whiners that expect to get what we like with little or no
effort on our own and (worse yet, in my mind) believe that money is ALWAYS
a substitute for effort.

On a side note, I do, in fact, believe that learning how to do things for
yourself is fun and that the primary goal of nearly all human action and
interaction should be to improve your world and your self.  We should work
very hard to reprogram ourselves and our culture to use that end as our
basis for the determination of "fun".  Pleasure without productivity is
empty and base.  [As a straightforward example to which we all can relate
(chosen for its universality and appropriateness, not to shock those of
repressive and regressive morality), consider the value of sex with your
partner as a relationship-building exercise versus masturbation or casual
sex with a virtual stranger.  Which gives you the greater sense of
satisfaction?  Which is more fun?  Consider the reasoning behind your
answer and try to see how that measures against your ideas about
constructive and destructive behavior.]

> : > The MPlayer site introduced me to the term 'lamer' which they define
> : > as a user who installs a program as-is and expects it to run. Geez,
> : > that's probably 90% of the PC users I know of. Thanks.
> :
> : Well, if you're not making any effort, you may as well be lame.
> 
> False.

If what I wrote were "false", it would be logically flawed or
contradictory to some verifiable fact.  This is not an argument of logic,
but of semantics.  And the contradiction is in our respective ideas of
what the word "lame" means in this context.

> First of all, you don't know what efforts I -have- made.

My statement was a conditional:  IF you're not making any effort, you may
as well be lame.

I didn't say anything about the effort you made, specifically.

> Second, do you seriously believe that learning curves are the spice of
> life, and that every intent, even in leisure, ought to be tested in an
> arduous cruicible of success versus failure, of blood, sweat, toil,
> study, and tears?

Yes.  Leisure time (time when work isn't required for mere survival) can
either be constructive or destructive.  Construction is usually hard, but
it can be fun and relaxing, too.  The point is that you are putting in
effort to build something, not to consume or destroy or lay inert.

> I don't, so my opinion is: "Yeah, but it doesn't install with a
> double-click and the website mentions security problems which you have
> to be a computer networking expert to understand. So, MPlayer in its
> currently available form is probably -NOT- ready for most users. And,
> incidentally, the authors of the website have even contrived a
> derogatory term for a majority of good people who might otherwise be
> interested in trying out their program" (they just happen to be good
> at other things, like my vet down the street. This guy is -NOT- 'lame'
> by any means.)

You perceive it as derogatory.  I certainly don't.  It's just a statement
of fact, in my view of the word.  If you're not being constructive, you
are acting like a lame person (one who CANNOT be constructive).

I think you're missing the fact that "lame" is a sort of double-subjective
term.  First, it is in reference to a particular capacity.  Second, it is
in reference to level of competence and apability within that capacity.  
It is, if you pardon me, a measure of capacity within a capacity.

To say that a particular person is "-NOT- 'lame' by any means" is to say
that that person is exactly as capable and able in every endeavor as any
other person.  This would truly be a superman; as good as the best in
every field of human endeavor.

The word "lame" means "lacking in needful or desirable substance".  Both
"need" and "desire" are subject to the person defining the nature of the
substance.  As far as the MPlayer developers go, they are making a
judgment of certain user's lack of needful and desirable skills and/or
equipment required to use or improve their software.

So the term might be considered "derogatory" because the people using it
are describing people by what they have not, but it is no more derogatory
than calling a group "the poor" or "the infirm".  Really, it is only the
arrogant who are insulted by such statements.  Most people, I think,
realize their deficiencies and own up to them.  If they don't, they
should.

> I know a man with a lathe in his garage. He bitched and cussed (in a
> friendly way - I love working with machinists) about how they wanted
> $8 at Freddy's for a hose coupler to convert pipe thread to
> garden-hose thread, when 'any dork' can turn one up in brass.
>
> I guess everybody else who doesn't do this is somehow deficient on the
> evolutionary scale, right?

Nobody said that.  But I wouldn't at all be offended if he called me
"lame" for not knowing how to construct the thing and not trying to learn.

Hell, the reason that fifteen cents worth of brass (with six cents worth
of labor and maybe a dollar in shipping and stocking, plus, for gross
overestimation, another dollar in overhead costs for lighting and storing
the piece) costs EIGHT DOLLARS is because we live in a society that works
very hard to exploit the failings of others for private gain and profit.
Embracing your flawed nature and recognizing your deficiencies is the
first step in improving yourself and breaking out of a system of
exploitation and greed.

> Don't know the taper angle for standard pipe thread? Then I guess
> you're an idiot, right?

Nope.  Just a lame fuckin' machinist.  And that doesn't offend me because
it's completely true.

> What, are you too lazy to look it up? I just did so twice.

Well, if you'd given me the opportunity to look it up, I'm sure I could
have.  I'm not a lame researcher... not by my standards or most who've
bothered to judge me on those merits, anyway.

> What's wrong with you?

With respect to the question of knowing the thread taper of standard
pipe?  What's wrong with me is that I lack knowledge.  Sucks, huh?

Thankfully, I have resources that can show me that a 1" pipe has
11.5 threads per inch (assuming you meant NPT).

And, of course, garden hose thread has an outside diameter of 1-1/8, with
the same 11.5 threads per inch.

So now I'm slightly less lame, but still a VERY lame machinist.

> : change your behavior to be less lame.
> I already did that.

Cool.  Keep going.  Laurels are not a license to stop working.

I hope you understood the sentence you chopped for the above quote,
though.  The point is that IF you are offended by being called lame, then
you should change your behavior so that it complies with the competency
standard.  If you are NOT willing and able to comply with the standard to
which you were being held when you were called lame, then you shouldn't be
offended, you should merely accept the designation.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Nov 15 17:42:40 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 17:42:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backup mistake
Message-ID: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com>

I started a backup of my /var/www/html by copying it to another drive.
Unfortunately, I failed to account for a link that points back to the
root of the destination drive, so I've filled up a 40Gb drive with what
should have been less than a gig! Now, I'm looking for what to do to
undo this mistake. 

How I got where I am:

I have the 40 Gb drive mounted at /home/mp3. I've created a directory in
there called NECbackup, and I created a directory in there called
021115-var-www-html-backup. While at /home/mp3/NECbackup, I started the
copy by running:

# cp -R /var/www/html 021115-var-www-html-backup/

Inside one of the directories under /var/www/html is a directory,
MusicDB, with a link to /home/mp3. So, I've recursively created a large
number of copies that I shouldn't have. I suspect that there's an option
to ignore links, but I didn't read up enough to understand that before I
began.

So, now that I have all this, should I go to the first place down the
tree that the recursive copies begin and delete that by running:

cd /home/mp3/NECbackup/021115-var-www-html-backup/MusicDB
rm -R mp3

I note that ls -l shows mp3 in
/home/mp3/NECbackup/021115-var-www-html-backup/MusicDB as a directory,
whereas it shows mp3 as a link in /var/www/html/MusicDB.

For future reference, what should I have done? I just looked at the man
page for cp and didn't see a way to ignore links.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Fri Nov 15 17:50:47 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: 15 Nov 2002 17:50:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backup mistake
In-Reply-To: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com>
References: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1037411447.17613.56.camel@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us>

On Fri, 2002-11-15 at 17:42, Richard Steffens wrote:
> For future reference, what should I have done? I just looked at the man
> page for cp and didn't see a way to ignore links.

"man cp" gave me --no-dereference as an option, which indicates to
"never follow symbolic links"

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District




From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Nov 15 18:02:54 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Nov 15 20:34:18 2002

Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
> I started a backup of my /var/www/html by copying it to another drive.
> Unfortunately, I failed to account for a link that points back to the
> root of the destination drive, so I've filled up a 40Gb drive with what
> should have been less than a gig! 
<snip>
> So, now that I have all this, should I go to the first place down the
> tree that the recursive copies begin and delete that by running:
> 
> cd /home/mp3/NECbackup/021115-var-www-html-backup/MusicDB
> rm -R mp3

No. That doesn't work. However, rm -rf mp3 does the job. I found the
answer on page 338 of the Sybex book, Mastering Red Hat Linux 7.1, by
Arman Danesh, under the heading, "Deleting Whole Directories."

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Nov 15 22:53:25 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 2002 22:53:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] StartX only for root, but not for user
In-Reply-To: <1037417028.10687.142.camel@lana>
References: <1037417028.10687.142.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <20021116065324.GA30999@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net> [2002-11-15 19:34]:
> Why the hell would startx not work for a user but only for root?  I had
> run this under the user just today.  I accidently started X as root and
> then logged out.  Since then, I cannot start it as that same non-root
> user.

Sounds to me as if the owner/group or permissions on some file (in the users
directory?) got changed to root or somehow made so the user can't read
it.

This could possibly happen if you startx after 'su'ing to root without the dash.

Stargate Online

From rkurth at starband.net  Sat Nov 16 00:29:54 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 00:29:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] replacing lines in a httpd.conf file
Message-ID: <36303646270.20021116002954@starband.net>

I need to replace a series of lines in a httpd.conf file on the fly.
So it needs to be done in a bash file. I have been trying a bunch of
different ways mostly with sed. It seams there would be a cleaner way
to do it. Below is what I have so far. There are five different
sections that have to be changed or have lines added to them.
Is there a better way of doing this?


cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.autocontrol

sed -e '/my (@ssl_conf,$ip,$group,$rewrite_rules,$proto,$ret);/a\
my ($portnumber);
'  < /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf > /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new
cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf
rm /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new


sed -e '/$proto = 'https';/a\
    $portnumber = '5001';
'  < /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf > /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new
cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf
rm /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new

        
sed -e '/$proto = 'http';/a\
   $portnumber = '5000';
'  < /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf > /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new
cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf
rm /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new 


sed -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
### Begin - Autocontrol ###\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/acp/?$                     proto://servername:portnumber/autocontrol/index.php\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}               ^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$                     proto://servername:portnumber/user/index.php\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$                     proto://servername:portnumber/resellerpanel/index.php\
### End - Autocontrol ###\
'  < /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf > /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new
cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf
rm /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new


sed -e '/$rewrite_rules =~ s/proto/$proto/g;/a\
$rewrite_rules =~ s/portnumber/$portnumber/g;
'  < /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf > /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new
cp /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf
rm /tmp/TESTSCRIPT/.httpd.new



  

-- 
Best regards,
 Richard                          mailto:rkurth at starband.net

Actually, you want /tmp at permission 1777
This sets sticky mode.

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Nov 16 10:43:18 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 10:43:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] replacing lines in a httpd.conf file
In-Reply-To: <36303646270.20021116002954@starband.net>
References: <36303646270.20021116002954@starband.net>
Message-ID: <E18D8Lh-00036v-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

You can use the option -e multiple times in one call of sed. I didn't see in
your pattern matches where the following pattern relied on the proceeding
pattern being in the file, so I believe you can combine them into one call. I
might have missed something though. 

#!/bin/sh

ORGINAL=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf 
KOPY=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.autocontrol
OUTPUT=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.new

cp $ORGINAL $KOPY

sed -e '/my (@ssl_conf,$ip,$group,$rewrite_rules,$proto,$ret);/a\
my ($portnumber);
' -e '/$proto = 'https';/a\
    $portnumber = '5001';
' -e '/$proto = 'http';/a\
   $portnumber = '5000';
' -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
### Begin - Autocontrol ###\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}		^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/acp/?$			
proto://servername:portnumber/autocontrol/index.php\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}	       ^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$			
proto://servername:portnumber/user/index.php\
RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}		^([^:]+)\
RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$			
proto://servername:portnumber/resellerpanel/index.php\
### End - Autocontrol ###\
' -e '/$rewrite_rules =~ s/proto/$proto/g;/a\
$rewrite_rules =~ s/portnumber/$portnumber/g;
' < $ORGINAL > $OUTPUT

mv $OUTPUT $ORGINAL

exit 0

Thank you
Russell

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sat Nov 16 11:28:21 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 11:28:21 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Vim mode for procmail logs
In-Reply-To: <E18D8Lh-00036v-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211161121250.1853-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

FYI, someone wrote me this cool vim syntax file for viewing procmail logs.
I placed it in ~/.vim/syntax/proclog.vim and use it with: "vim '+set
syntax=proclog' "

Enjoy!

Tyler


  set background=dark
  syn clear

  syn match  MiscChar      "[^a-zA-Z0-9]"
  syn match  LowPriority   "^procmail:\s\+\(Assigning\|Unlocking\|Locking\|Opening\|Acquiring\|Executing\).*$"
  syn match  Score         "Score:\s\+-\?\d\+\s\+-\?\d\+"
  syn match  RecipeMatch   "\(Matched\|Match on\)"
  syn match  RecipeNoMatch  "No match on"
  syn match  Delivery      "^\(From\| Subject:\|  Folder:\)\s\+.*$"

  "  ----  ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----
  "  0: black, 1: red,     2: green, 3: brown/yellow,
  "  4: blue,  5: magenta, 6: cyan,  7: grey/white
  "  ----  ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----

  hi MiscChar      term=none     cterm=none  ctermfg=6
  hi LowPriority   term=none     cterm=none  ctermfg=4

  hi Score         term=none     cterm=none  ctermfg=3  ctermbg=0
  hi RecipeMatch   term=none     cterm=none  ctermfg=2  ctermbg=0
  hi RecipeNoMatch term=none     cterm=none  ctermfg=1  ctermbg=0

  hi Delivery      term=reverse  cterm=bold  ctermfg=3  ctermbg=0




From rkurth at starband.net  Sat Nov 16 11:45:33 2002
From: rkurth at starband.net (Richard Kurth)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 11:45:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] replacing lines in a httpd.conf file

 <E18D8Lh-00036v-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <104344185382.20021116114533@starband.net>

Hello Russell,
I just ran this and I get this error message
sed: -e expression #5, char 23: Extra characters after command

I removed the last -e expression and the script works. It looks like it
does not like the ~ in this line ' -e '/$rewrite_rules =~ s/proto/$proto/g;/a\
because that is char 23 what can I do to fix that. will a \ work to
make sed not read that as a Command

Also it added everything except these two lines
' -e '/$proto = 'https';/a\
    $portnumber = '5001';
' -e '/$proto = 'http';/a\
   $portnumber = '5000';

   Is that because of the '' around https and http if so do I put a \
   in front of them so sed does not read that as a Command


Saturday, November 16, 2002, 10:43:18 AM, you wrote:


RE> You can use the option -e multiple times in one call of sed. I didn't see in
RE> your pattern matches where the following pattern relied on the proceeding
RE> pattern being in the file, so I believe you can combine them into one call. I
RE> might have missed something though. 

RE> #!/bin/sh

RE> ORGINAL=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf 
RE> KOPY=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.autocontrol
RE> OUTPUT=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.new

RE> cp $ORGINAL $KOPY

RE> sed -e '/my (@ssl_conf,$ip,$group,$rewrite_rules,$proto,$ret);/a\
RE> my ($portnumber);
RE> ' -e '/$proto = 'https';/a\
RE>     $portnumber = '5001';
RE> ' -e '/$proto = 'http';/a\
RE>    $portnumber = '5000';
RE> ' -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
RE> ### Begin - Autocontrol ###\
RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
RE> RewriteRule ^/acp/?$                    
RE> proto://servername:portnumber/autocontrol/index.php\
RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}               ^([^:]+)\
RE> RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$                    
RE> proto://servername:portnumber/user/index.php\
RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
RE> RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$                    
RE> proto://servername:portnumber/resellerpanel/index.php\
RE> ### End - Autocontrol ###\
RE> ' -e '/$rewrite_rules =~ s/proto/$proto/g;/a\
RE> $rewrite_rules =~ s/portnumber/$portnumber/g;
RE> ' < $ORGINAL > $OUTPUT

RE> mv $OUTPUT $ORGINAL

RE> exit 0

RE> Thank you
RE> Russell



RE> On Sat, 16 Nov 2002 00:29:54 -0800, Richard Kurth said:

>>

RE> pattern being in the file, so I believe you can combine them into one call. I
RE> might have missed something though. 

RE> #!/bin/sh

RE> my ($portnumber);

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Sat Nov 16 14:19:34 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 15:19:34 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Backup mistake
References: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DD6C476.1030101@coyotesong.com>

Nobody else has mentioned this, so I will....

Don't use 'cp,' use a real archiver.  E.g., 'tar,' 'cpio' or even 'zip.' 
  That will preserve all information, can be easily compressed (to get 
you more backups into the same space), and can be safely copied onto any 
backup media.

In contrast, something like 'cp' can bite you if you try copy it to some 
media.  E.g., a recent article in SysAdmin magazine mentioned making 
backup copies to CD-R, but (IIRC) didn't mention that you can't have 
long filenames or more than 1024 entries in any directory under ISO9660.

Bear




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Nov 16 14:29:05 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 16 Nov 2002 14:29:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LinkSys WPC11 Wireless Card and Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <1037484208.10683.202.camel@lana>
References: <1037482132.10683.198.camel@lana> <863cq1419b.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<1037484208.10683.202.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <86y97t2lou.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jon" == Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net> writes:

Jon> Someone else suggested (was that you) on the PTP list.  What is
Jon> hostAP and how do I use it?  Also, is this really a driver
Jon> problem?

I haven't been keeping up on the PTP list recently, so if it was
recently, it wasn't me.  All I remember is screwing around back in
June, then finally getting it to work and I am using the hostAP
drivers now, so infer what you want.  The URL seems to be:

  <http://hostap.epitest.fi/>

You don't have to use the drivers in "host" mode, but you can if you
want.  So, for example, you could plug your laptop into a network jack
and become an WiFi Access Point for everyone else in the room... if
you wanted to do that, which you might.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sat Nov 16 14:33:44 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 16 Nov 2002 14:33:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backup mistake
In-Reply-To: <3DD6C476.1030101@coyotesong.com>
References: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com> <3DD6C476.1030101@coyotesong.com>
Message-ID: <86u1ih2lh3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Bear" == Bear Giles <bgiles at coyotesong.com> writes:

Bear> Nobody else has mentioned this, so I will....  Don't use 'cp,'
Bear> use a real archiver.  E.g., 'tar,' 'cpio' or even 'zip.' That
Bear> will preserve all information, can be easily compressed (to get
Bear> you more backups into the same space), and can be safely copied
Bear> onto any backup media.

"rsync" is popular for copying trees these days, too.  I am still
mostly doing tar-to-tar for fresh copies (or tar-to-ssh-tar for
non-local copies), but I use rsync too, particularly when I just want
to sychronize two mostly-the-same trees.

This brings up a question... does anyone know the difference between the
different archival programs ar, shar, and tar ?  My impression from the
manual is they're the same, and all I ever see used is tar, but is it
sometimes better to use ar or shar?

Tyler

From judah at opusnet.com  Sat Nov 16 15:25:15 2002
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: 16 Nov 2002 15:25:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] LinkSys WPC11 Wireless Card and Redhat 7.3
In-Reply-To: <1037482132.10683.198.camel@lana>
References: <1037482132.10683.198.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <1037489116.17772.12.camel@laptop>

On Sat, 2002-11-16 at 13:28, Jon Jacob wrote:
> selection when adding.  To rememdy that, I coped ifcfg-eth0 to
> ifcfg-eth1 and tried to force it, but no soap.  It seemed to understand
> that it was a wireless device, but it would not let me activate it.

When you did this did you edit the line inside the file the identifies
the device?
ie.. change

DEVICE=eth0
to 
DEVICE=eth1


also, do you have a profile set up in /etc/pcmcia/wireless.opts for the
card that sets the ESSID and Channel, Rate and other information, since
you are still running RH 7.3

(notice in RedHat 8.0 they've utilized the device scripts in
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts to set these preferences, like essid and
channel)

When you get the good beeps when inserting the card, you don't see any
device in ifconfig. However, do you see any information with the
iwconfig tool? (part of the wireless-tools package, also see iwlist and
other tools in this package.)

You may see your device there but no use information.. use iwconfig to
mess with these.. 

iwconfig <device> essid "any"
iwconfig <device> rate 11M
iwconfig <device> txpower 30mW

iwlist <device> txpower 

and other commands.. 

A-
 
-- 
----
Aaron Baer
judah at opusnet.com
http://www.cat.pdx.edu/~baera/




From raanders at acm.org  Sat Nov 16 16:10:24 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 16:10:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Any Scsi Experts?
In-Reply-To: <1MfWPbwPq7pX7lzSXH7NEQX=LNbM@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211161603050.5012-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sat, 16 Nov 2002, Prutzer wrote:

> Hi All,
> I've got a problem with some scsi drives.
> They don't seemingly want to format and now I can't get them to be
> recognized by DOS  enough to run a fdisk or format on them from DOS
> I was attempting to format from the SCSI utility in the SCSI
> controller and they just hung. I have three drives that are this way.
> Any help?

Suddenly not working or from the beginning?  I'm not an expert but I've 
made my share of mistakes and then figured them out - or had someone slap 
me up-along the back of the head ...

Do you have them all at separate device numbers?  Is there termination on
the SCSI chain?  Are the cables well seated?  Can you start with one
connected and get it to work?
   And then so we can pick the right nits.  What SCSI controller card are
you using and what types/models/makes of drives?


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

Tyler> This brings up a question... does anyone know the difference
Tyler> between the different archival programs ar, shar, and tar ?  My
Tyler> impression from the manual is they're the same, and all I ever
Tyler> see used is tar, but is it sometimes better to use ar or shar?

It is better to use shar when you don't have tar on the target system.
One of the few packages that GNU distributes in shar format is for
tar.  Used to be, before MIME attachments, that shar could be more
useful, because it produced text that could be email'd.

Today "shar" is mostly a relic.

"ar" is mostly used for creating object file libraries, and is mostly
invisible to the normal user (i.e. the user executes it indirectly
through make files, etc.).  Debian packages are actually "ar" archives
of two files, IIRC.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy

From beattie at beattie-home.net  Sat Nov 16 17:29:54 2002
From: beattie at beattie-home.net (Brian Beattie)
Date: 16 Nov 2002 17:29:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Any Scsi Experts?
In-Reply-To: <1MfWPbwPq7pX7lzSXH7NEQX=LNbM@4ax.com>
References: <1MfWPbwPq7pX7lzSXH7NEQX=LNbM@4ax.com>
Message-ID: <1037496594.2868.222.camel@coyote>

On Sat, 2002-11-16 at 14:37, Prutzer wrote:
> Hi All,
> I've got a problem with some scsi drives.
> They don't seemingly want to format and now I can't get them to be
> recognized by DOS  enough to run a fdisk or format on them from DOS
> I was attempting to format from the SCSI utility in the SCSI
> controller and they just hung. I have three drives that are this way.
> Any help?

Why oh why did MS insist on using the format utility to create a
filesystem on a harddrive?

format in dos, does not format a harddrive, it just initizes the file
system.

The format on the controller does format the hardrive, but if it starts
and fails, the drive will likely then be unusable.

One word, formating a large drive takes a long time ... hours.

Without having your system in front of me I really could not say what
the state of your drives is, but I would suggest, that you put one drive
in, bring up the controller utility and format the drive, let it run
overnight if necessary.

From robbert at vafam.com  Sat Nov 16 17:57:09 2002

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Nov 16 17:46:54 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 17:46:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless D-link PCI card
In-Reply-To: <200211161110.06627.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
References: <200211161110.06627.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
Message-ID: <E18DExe-0000IR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Does yast2 see the card and only the wireless setting are not available? If so,
setup the card in yast2, `yast2 lan`. This should leave a ifcfg-ethX file in
the /etc/sysconfig/network directory.

Open the ifcfg-ethX in an editor and add  WIRELESS='yes'  or 
echo WIRELESS='yes' >> /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-ethX.

Start yast2 lan again and choose edit. Choose ethX and the options for wireless
should now be avialable for you to setup.

You will need to have the wireless tools, pcmcia, and wlan-ng rpms installed. 

If `yast2 lan` does not see the card at the command prompt 

modprobe prism2_pci 
#see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above
rmmod prism2_pci
modprobe prism2_plx
#see if yast2sees the card, do the above
rmmod prism2_plx

modprobe orinoco_pci
#see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above
rmmod orinoco_pci
modprobe orinoco_plx
#see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above

Thank you
Russell

I thought you had your patterns matching what you wanted, sorry. I believe the
' in 'https' is the issue. Replace the ' with .   .htps.

/$proto = .https.;/a\

Russell

>  RE> might have missed something though.

>  RE> #!/bin/sh
>  
>  RE> ORGINAL=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf 
>  RE> KOPY=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.autocontrol
>  RE> OUTPUT=/tmp/TESTSCRIPT/httpd.conf.new
>  
>  RE> cp $ORGINAL $KOPY
>  
>  RE> sed -e '/my (@ssl_conf,$ip,$group,$rewrite_rules,$proto,$ret);/a\
>  RE> my ($portnumber);
>  RE> ' -e '/$proto = 'https';/a\
>  RE>     $portnumber = '5001';
>  RE> ' -e '/$proto = 'http';/a\
>  RE>    $portnumber = '5000';
>  RE> ' -e '/RewriteRule .*cgi-bin\/.cobalt.* proto:\/\/servername:81.*/a\
>  RE> ### Begin - Autocontrol ###\
>  RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
>  RE> RewriteRule ^/acp/?$                    
>  RE> proto://servername:portnumber/autocontrol/index.php\
>  RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}               ^([^:]+)\
>  RE> RewriteRule ^/ucp/?$                    
>  RE> proto://servername:portnumber/user/index.php\
>  RE> RewriteCond %{HTTP_HOST}                ^([^:]+)\
>  RE> RewriteRule ^/rcp/?$                    
>  RE> proto://servername:portnumber/resellerpanel/index.php\
>  RE> ### End - Autocontrol ###\
>  RE> ' -e '/$rewrite_rules =~ s/proto/$proto/g;/a\
>  RE> $rewrite_rules =~ s/portnumber/$portnumber/g;
>  RE> ' < $ORGINAL > $OUTPUT
>  
>  RE> mv $OUTPUT $ORGINAL
>  
>  RE> exit 0
>  
>  RE> Thank you
>  RE> Russell
>  
>

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Sat Nov 16 19:56:40 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 2002 20:56:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] shar, tar, ar ?
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211161454530.26627-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <3DD71378.2050407@coyotesong.com>

Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> This brings up a question... does anyone know the difference between the
> different archival programs ar, shar, and tar ?  My impression from the
> manual is they're the same, and all I ever see used is tar, but is it
> sometimes better to use ar or shar?

ar(1) is a very limited format - only 14 bytes for filename, no symlinks 
or other special devices, etc.  I can't remember if it's byte or word 
aligned - whichever it saves some modest space over tar format which is 
512-byte (or larger) block aligned.  It does not have a TOC - you can 
easily stick additional files to the end.  ar archives are typically 
neither compressed or encrypted.

As somebody else pointed out, the Debian .deb format is actually an ar 
format with three files.  A version marker, "data.tar.gz" (what the 
upstream package produces), and "control.tar.gz" (the Debian control 
information), and derived packages can add additional files with ease as 
long as they observe a few basic rules.  (E.g., for a while I was 
playing with embedding security info in an additional entry.)

tar(1) is a general format - it stores permissions, dates, special 
files, etc.  It can support 100 (150?) byte filenames trivially, a bit 
longer with the "prefix" field, and arbitrarily long files with a widely 
recognized extension.  It can also cleanly support "sparse" files, and 
has limited support for multiple volume archives.  It does not have 
either header or TOC.

tar files are typically externally compressed, with either gzip (.gz) or 
bzip2 (.bz2).  They are not encrypted except on an ad hoc basis.

shar(1) is a transportation archive format designed for portability. 
It's not widely used anymore.

cpio(1) is a legacy format that some organizations still use.  Most 
notably, a Red Hat RPM file is a non-standard header followed by a cpio 
archive.

zip(1) is a general format that hasn't been widely used in the Unix 
world, but it is gaining popularity with the increased use of Java. 
(.jar, .war, etc files are basically .zip files with some content rules 
and specialized additional files.)  Zip directly supports compression 
and modest encryption, and extensions provide for Unix file permissions 
to be archived and some PKIX info.  I don't think a standard extension 
supports PKI encryption yet.  Zip has a TOC in a "central directory" 
block at the end of the file and per-file headers.

Like most of life, the best choice for you depends on your specific 
needs.  As a rule of thumb, if you only have regular files owned by a 
single user, zip may be better - at least if you know Java. :-)  If you 
have special files, multiple users, or the like you'll probably want to 
stick with tar.

Bear




From daveclark15 at attbi.com  Sat Nov 16 21:38:33 2002

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Nov 16 22:29:22 2002

A while back, I believe there was a post on one of these lists, for a way to
easily setup time based internet access. There was, IIRC, one reply to that
post that stated it was possible via iptables but didn't provide an easy to use
tool to do this. The following is a floppy based router that seems to provide
the functionality asked for. 

This is the time based access documentation for the tool.
http://www.bbiagent.net/en/docs/explorer/300.htm

This is the project home.
http://www.bbiagent.net/en/index.html

I have no experience with this and only came across it searching freshmeat for
another tool.

From mikedela at ipns.com  Sat Nov 16 23:16:14 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: 16 Nov 2002 23:16:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Backup mistake
In-Reply-To: <3DD6C476.1030101@coyotesong.com>
References: <3DD5A290.566477EC@attbi.com>  <3DD6C476.1030101@coyotesong.com>
Message-ID: <1037517375.1924.8.camel@rhl>

I'm using flexbackup. It's designed for tape drives, but it works well
for drive to drive backups. I like that it automagically names the files
with the date and source, and I can tweak the compression rate and lots
of other stuff.

Mike

On Sat, 2002-11-16 at 14:19, Bear Giles wrote:
> Nobody else has mentioned this, so I will....
> 
> Don't use 'cp,' use a real archiver.  E.g., 'tar,' 'cpio' or even 'zip.' 
>   That will preserve all information, can be easily compressed (to get 
> you more backups into the same space), and can be safely copied onto any 
> backup media.
> 
> In contrast, something like 'cp' can bite you if you try copy it to some 
> media.  E.g., a recent article in SysAdmin magazine mentioned making 
> backup copies to CD-R, but (IIRC) didn't mention that you can't have 
> long filenames or more than 1024 entries in any directory under ISO9660.
> 
> Bear
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
-- 
Mike De La Mater
Mike De La Mater Consulting
Networks, PC hardware, Business Solution Consulting
25 Years PC experience
503-702-6749




From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Sun Nov 17 00:53:15 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 17 Nov 2002 00:53:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Evolution 1.2
Message-ID: <1037523194.16548.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

I just wanted to share my experience with using Evolution 1.2.....

I downloaded it and spent a bit of time compiling the sucker (and
everything it depends on)...

Now, I compiled it with far less optimizations (-march=athlon
-mcpu=athlon -O3 -s -ffast-math -funroll-loops) than I had 1.0.8
compiled with.  It is, however, a *lot* faster.  It loads up my mailbox
probably twice as fast and whenever I receive new email, there isn't
that churning of the disk I had with 1.0.8 - they really fixed their
mail storage problem.  The interface also seems a bit more refined -
nothing I can really put my finger on, though.

Now we run in to problems.  I open up the PLUG VFolder, click on a
message up at the top, and hit 'n' for 'next unread message'.  Ooops, no
dice.  I hunted around for several minutes - I think that keybinding and
event have just vanished.  Bummer.

So I go prancing through the config settings (which are all in one place
now... nice).  Can't find it.  I changed a few things and hit OK or
Apply (don't remember which)... the evolution-mail portion of ev
seg-faulted.  No biggy, I say, I do a oaf-slay && killev && oaf-slay to
be sure it is gone and launch it again.  Now whenever I go in to that
Settings box, evolution-mail dies.  Errm... bummer.

The shortcuts on the side seem to also have problems updating - new mail
came in (3 plug messages) but Inbox's count didn't go up - PLUG's did. 
I have yet to see if the 'Unmatched' count works properly or not (it
didn't update with 1.0.8 unless I was viewing the unmatched folder when
the mail came in).

That about sums it up.  I'd wait for another release - hopefully with a
fixed 'n' key.  :-)

But if you store a lot of email in ev, you'll find a much much snappier
system.  I have about 5300 emails in my inbox and definitely noticed a
big improvement.  I'm sure those of you with years' worth of email will
find an even bigger jump in speed.  :-)

Rob

-- 
"That's between you and your god.  Oh wait a 
minute, you *are* your god.  That's a problem."
  - Col. Jack O'Neill in "The Serpent's song"

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Nov 17 01:30:32 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 01:30:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Evolution 1.2
In-Reply-To: <1037523194.16548.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211170129090.7404-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 17 Nov 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> Now we run in to problems.  I open up the PLUG VFolder, click on a
> message up at the top, and hit 'n' for 'next unread message'.  Ooops,
> no dice.  I hunted around for several minutes - I think that
> keybinding and event have just vanished.  Bummer.

If I'm not mistaken, evolution is a GTK+ app, which means you can add a
keybinding by highlighting the appriopriate action on a pull-down menu and
hitting the key you would like bound to the action.

Don't know if this is possible in your case, but I thought I'd throw that
out there.

J.

From bob at bmtsolutions.com  Sun Nov 17 02:03:02 2002
From: bob at bmtsolutions.com (Bob)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 02:03:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless D-link PCI card
In-Reply-To: <E18DExe-0000IR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <200211161110.06627.bob@bmtsolutions.com> <E18DExe-0000IR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200211170203.02795.bob@bmtsolutions.com>

On Saturday 16 November 2002 17:46, Russell Evans wrote:
> Does yast2 see the card and only the wireless setting are not available? If
> so, setup the card in yast2, `yast2 lan`. This should leave a ifcfg-ethX
> file in the /etc/sysconfig/network directory.
>
> Open the ifcfg-ethX in an editor and add  WIRELESS='yes'  or
> echo WIRELESS='yes' >> /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcfg-ethX.
>
> Start yast2 lan again and choose edit. Choose ethX and the options for
> wireless should now be avialable for you to setup.
>
> You will need to have the wireless tools, pcmcia, and wlan-ng rpms
> installed.
>
> If `yast2 lan` does not see the card at the command prompt
>
> modprobe prism2_pci
> #see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above
> rmmod prism2_pci
> modprobe prism2_plx
> #see if yast2sees the card, do the above
> rmmod prism2_plx
>
> modprobe orinoco_pci
> #see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above
> rmmod orinoco_pci
> modprobe orinoco_plx
> #see if yast2 lan sees the card, do the above
>
> Thank you
> Russell
>
> On Sat, 16 Nov 2002 11:10:06 -0800, Bob said:
> > Good Morning Everyone;
> >
> >  I am running SuSe 8.1.  I have a DWL-520+, D-Link AirPlus Wireless PCI
> >  adapter, I would like to use it on the modest server I put up. I tried
> > using the iwconfig tool.  When I tried to use iwconfig it spits out "no
> > wireless extensions find"  AT this point I assume the D-Link card I am
> > using is not going to be usable. . Can anyone suggest a card the does
> > work in linux or any more ideas.  I would like to get the server out of
> > the small office to different place.  I was hoping to avoid doing any
> > cable running.
> >
> >  Thanks for your help
> >  bob


Thanks for all your help Russell,

I went to /etc/sysconfig/network and edited the file ifcfg-eth0 and changed 
wireless='no' to wireless='yes'.  As you said,  when I started 'yast2 lan', I 
now had the wireless configuration.  When I went here the very first thing I 
saw was Operating mode, which was set to Ad-hoc ( i believe this is used for 
peer-to-peer networking?)  In the installation guide for the DWL-520+ D-Link 
AirPLus PCI adapter, (guide geared towards windows installation), I noticed 
they have the wireless mode set to infrastructure.  This of course is not one 
of the options.  So I set it to automatic ( I tried the other setting and the 
results were all the same) .  Next the essid, I set to 'default', which is 
the same setting on the router ( I figured I would change this later and 
assigned name , of my choosing, for the wireless network). Everything else I 
left as is.  I set the card to static IP of 192.168.0.101, GW: 192.168.0.1, 
etc  I going to use port forwarding to be able to have my email server and 
webserver on the internet.  

Note: I did check to see wireless tools, pcmcia and wlan-ng packages were 
installed.  All but wlan-ng were installed. I went to yast2 / install and 
remove software and did a search for wlan-ng and came up empty handed. Would 
this package be bunched together with another package? You mentioned this has 
be to installed so where would I find this package on the installation disks.  
Is package usually used w/ redhat?

I tried to ping the gateway and was not able to.   Out of curiousity I did a 
rcnetwork restart and recieved the following errors:
    eth0 ifup-wireless command  'iwconfig eth0 mode automatic ' returned
            ifup-wireless: Error wirless request "set mode" (8B06): set failed  
            eth0 operation not supported


I am still very new to all the linux.  Thanks to your great help I was able to 
get this far.  Do you have any more suggestions on how to proceed.  I will 
continue to look over FAQs an linux documentation to see if I can make head 
way.  

Oh, I forgot to mention I did try modprob prism2_pci, prism_plx, orinoco_pci 
and orinoco_plx.  I get "init_module: no such device"  

Thanks again for all you help!

bob


 



From bsr at spek.org  Sun Nov 17 03:15:36 2002
From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: 17 Nov 2002 03:15:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Evolution 1.2
In-Reply-To: <1037523194.16548.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <1037523194.16548.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1037531735.17318.154.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

On Sun, 2002-11-17 at 00:53, AthlonRob wrote:
> Now we run in to problems.  I open up the PLUG VFolder, click on a
> message up at the top, and hit 'n' for 'next unread message'.  Ooops, no
> dice.  I hunted around for several minutes - I think that keybinding and
> event have just vanished.  Bummer.

It's still there, just bound to odd keys  ("[", "]", "," and ".") -
which I'm sure seemed like good a idea at the time but nobody now seems
to like them.  You can change them by editing the
evolution-mail-message.xml file that's (probably) located in
/usr/share/gnome/ui.  Changing the 'accel=' will change the key binding

    <cmd name="MailNextUnread"
     _tip="Display the next unread message"
     accel="n"/>

    <cmd name="MailPreviousUnread"
     _tip="Display the previous unread message"
     accel="p"/>

Poke around and you'll probably see some other things you might like to
bind keys to or change the binding of and how to name the keystroke. 
You may want to make a backup before you tweak the file, and you'll have
to stop and restart evolution before the changes get picked up; I don't
know what will happen if you bind two commands to the same key.  Also
make a backup of your changes, an Evolution upgrade will probably
overwrite it.  I wish this was configurable in the application..

> The shortcuts on the side seem to also have problems updating - new mail
> came in (3 plug messages) but Inbox's count didn't go up - PLUG's did. 
> I have yet to see if the 'Unmatched' count works properly or not (it
> didn't update with 1.0.8 unless I was viewing the unmatched folder when
> the mail came in).

I've not noticed this - do you mean on the "Shortcut" bar or in the
"Folders" bar?  Shortcuts in the shortcut bar have never shown
new/unread/read message counters for me, but the folder list does.  You 
did mentioned that you stuff your PLUG messages into a VFolder, which
I've noticed "broken" behavior from (not updating sometimes as new mail
flows in).  I filter my incoming mail into mailboxes organized into
folders and subfolders and haven't noticed new message counts being off.

I've never really used VFolders except as a way to search across
mailboxes and to have persistent searches in place - do the messages get
hidden from your Inbox?

> But if you store a lot of email in ev, you'll find a much much snappier
> system.  I have about 5300 emails in my inbox and definitely noticed a
> big improvement.  I'm sure those of you with years' worth of email will
> find an even bigger jump in speed.  :-)

Evo 1.2 has a HUGE speed improvement over 1.0.8 for large mailboxes!
Overall startup times went from about 2 minutes to a couple seconds for
me.  Opening a large mailbox went from a few seconds to about 1 second. 
Performing multiple operations at once like deleting hundreds of
messages while opening another mailbox and reading a message is now
feasible whereas before it would seem to wait for all the messages to be
deleted before loading the other mailbox's message to read.  Filtering
is much faster too, which is probably related to the faster mailbox
handling. 

> That about sums it up.  I'd wait for another release - hopefully with a
> fixed 'n' key.  :-)

I wouldn't wait if one is looking for a new mail program and Evolution
has the features you need - it's a very nice program I think.

The things I like:

 - If you're a packrat like I am and subscribe to dozens of mailing
   lists it's very nice (though not perfect) for managing thousands of
   messages. I've got about 29,000 messages in it now and it's far
   better to use than anything else I've used (pine, mutt, outlook,
   eudora (older versions only, recent ones might be better)).

 - Filtering is very easy and quite powerful - 97% of procmail's
   capability at about %3 of procmail's effort.

 - The built-in mail editor is pretty nice - features like inline spell
   checking and some handy text formatting features (but not enough)

 - It's reliable (at least for me, some people have had other
   experiences), I often leave it running for weeks at a time with no
   problems.  On the rare occasions when it as crashed it's not lost any
   mail, even messages in the process of being composed.  YMMV of
   course.

The things I don't like:

 - About once a day I wish it had was a way to easily search across
   folders.

 - I wish it had a better text editor with a richer set of text
   formatting features.

The things that would be nice to have:

 - A text-only mode

--Brent

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Sun Nov 17 10:29:26 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 17 Nov 2002 10:29:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Evolution 1.2
In-Reply-To: <1037524400.11408.3.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
References: <1037523194.16548.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <1037524400.11408.3.camel@atlas.subnet.gotdns.org>
Message-ID: <1037557766.17886.6.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sun, 2002-11-17 at 01:13, Matt Whiteley wrote:

> I missed the 'n' key function also.  It seems to move to the next or
> previous unread messages you use the ']' and '[' keys.  My experience is
> a lot better speed also.

Thanks everybody who came up with solutions for the keybinding issues -
cool.  :-)

And Jeme - I was aware of the GTK+ keybinding stuff, but in my
experience it cannot bind to regular keys (just n) but must have a
modifier.  And "Go to next unread message" isn't in any of the menus. 
:-\

> The only problem I have is the calendar crashes the program if I select
> it.

I don't use the calendar yet.  In Windoze, I was able to use my Yahoo
Calendar and it would sync with my palm - giving me access to my
calendar anywhere I was.  I haven't used a calendar on the PC side since
I dropped Windows - and will not until I find something that can sync up
with the Internet and my palm.
  
> You said you used the vfolders, is there an advantage to that over
> making a lot of regular folders?

I don't think so.  I started using VFolders with my old CS2K IMAP
account and just stuck with them.  Regular folders would do the sorting
as mail came in - just once - rather than sorting them every time the
program is launched *or* when new mail comes in.  It does, however, give
me better mail count control.

As far as speed and usability are concerned, regular folders should be
better.  I just don't feel like switching.  :-)

Rob  <~~Just found another glitch (probably due to gtkhtml
optimizations) . the end key doesn't work.

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>

> 
> I've never really used VFolders except as a way to search across
> mailboxes and to have persistent searches in place - do the messages get
> hidden from your Inbox?

VFolders work by taking a filter rule and applying it to whatever
folders you want, then take the matching emails and put them in the
VFolder, more or less.  The messages stay in your Inbox, too... and can
be in multiple VFolders if they match the criteria for them.

Yeah, I am speaking of the 'Shortcuts' bar and not the 'Folders' bar.  I
put all my VFolders in that and it looks pretty.  It has always (1.0.8
did) had the number of unread messages in parenthesis.

With 1.0.8, the 'Unmatched' VFolder - which catches everything not
matched by other VFolders... did not ever update as new mail came in
unless the folder was open.  This still seems to be the case with 1.2.0,
unfortunately.

Now, with 1.2.0, the 'Inbox' real folder in the Shortcuts bar is not
listing a number at all, ever.  It just says Inbox with no number beside
it.  Not a big deal, I guess.

Rob  <~~Off to recompile gtkhtml in hopes of getting his end key back

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From revans at e-z.net  Sun Nov 17 11:01:26 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 11:01:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless D-link PCI card
In-Reply-To: <200211170203.02795.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
References: <200211161110.06627.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
    <E18DExe-0000IR-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
    <200211170203.02795.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
Message-ID: <20021117192858.JGMC21905.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

My bad on the wlan-ng. I thought it was a rpm. I think it was a seperate
package in the past, but it is now part of the kernel package. So you're good
to go.

The error is because the card doesn't understand "automatic" use "managed". It
is the same as "infrastructure" i.e. in managed mode your box talk to an AP.
You won't be able to ping the gateway until you have the link setup. At the
command prompt you want to run iwconfig after setting the card to managed. The
things to look for are; the Mode, confirm it is in Managed, the Cell, make sure
your seeing your AP ( some places in town it is easy to pick up someone elses
AP ), and Signal level, if its 0 you know you can't "see" the AP and need to
start closer to the AP or look at the AP to make sure it's working.   


Mode:Managed  Frequency:2.462GHz  Cell: 00:00:00:00:00:00
	  Bit Rate=11Mb/s   Tx-Power=15 dBm   Sensitivity:1/3  
	  Retry min limit:8   RTS thr:off   Fragment thr:off
	  Power Management:off
	  Link Quality:0  Signal level:0  Noise level:0
	  Rx invalid nwid:0  Rx invalid crypt:0  Rx invalid frag:0
	  Tx excessive retries:0  Invalid misc:0   Missed beacon:0


I'm not sure why you weren't able it install modules. It is good that it falled
because that was only needed if yast didn't see your card which it did. 

Thank you
Russell

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sun Nov 17 13:36:28 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: 17 Nov 2002 13:36:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SU ?
Message-ID: <1037568988.18696.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've noticed that su - chamges you to root's home dir, whereas plain su
leaves you in the user's dir. Shouldn't make any difference to $PATH,
though, I shouldn't think, so there's more to it than that..

I saw this statement. Is this true? Why or why not?
Thanks, Dirk






From nknight at pocketinet.com  Sun Nov 17 14:41:52 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 14:41:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SU ?
In-Reply-To: <1037568988.18696.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1037568988.18696.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200211171441.52676.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Sunday 17 November 2002 01:36 pm, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> I've noticed that su - chamges you to root's home dir, whereas plain su
> leaves you in the user's dir. Shouldn't make any difference to $PATH,
> though, I shouldn't think, so there's more to it than that..
>
> I saw this statement. Is this true? Why or why not?

from the 'su' man page:

	-, -l, --login
 	             make the shell a login shell

so 'su -' sets up the environment as if root had logged in normally, rather 
than with 'su'. It's the same difference as starting bash as 'bash' rather 
than 'bash -l' or 'bash --login'.





From nknight at pocketinet.com  Sun Nov 17 14:48:46 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 14:48:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SU ?
In-Reply-To: <200211171441.52676.nknight@pocketinet.com>
References: <1037568988.18696.6.camel@localhost.localdomain> <200211171441.52676.nknight@pocketinet.com>
Message-ID: <200211171448.46519.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Sunday 17 November 2002 02:41 pm, Nicholas Knight wrote:

> so 'su -' sets up the environment as if root had logged in normally, rather
> than with 'su'. It's the same difference as starting bash as 'bash' rather
> than 'bash -l' or 'bash --login'.

Err, sorry, that's not quite correct, bash doesn't behave quite like that. I'm 
awake, really! :)

This, out of the 'su' info page is better:

`-'
`-l'
`--login'
     Make the shell a login shell.  This means the following.  Unset all
     environment variables except `TERM', `HOME', and `SHELL' (which
     are set as described above), and `USER' and `LOGNAME' (which are
     set, even for the super-user, as described above), and set `PATH'
     to a compiled-in default value.  Change to USER's home directory.
     Prepend `-' to the shell's name, intended to make it read its
     login startup file(s).





From mwlist at planetwills.com  Sun Nov 17 16:10:40 2002
From: mwlist at planetwills.com (Mark Wills)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 16:10:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless D-link PCI card
Message-ID: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEMBCNAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>

>From what I've been able to gather none of the 22Mb/s cards have Linux
driver support. These use a TI chipset, not the Prism2 chipset so common in
most of the other cards. I've heard the 22Mb/s access points can talk to 11
Mb/s cards. If you haven't read through
http://www.hpl.hp.com/personal/Jean_Tourrilhes/Linux/ yet you may want to
give it a try.

Mark

Thanks for all the great feedback.  I worked on this all day and still got no 
where.  I was on the verge of committing electronnic suicide when I shot off 
an email to the suse group.  I got the following reply back from a Rick 
Green...

"The 'plus' series of wireless adapters from D-link is using a new chipset
from Texas Instruments(ACX-100), not the intersil prism chipset that has
been common up to this point.To date, there is no open-source driver for the 
TI chipset, and TI has declined to release the information necessary to write 
one. I did see a few weeks ago, a note from a representative of the
Australian division of D-Link to a LUG there, that a closed-source
binary-only driver was under development and scheduled for release around
the end of the year.I, too, am awaiting more information, as this chipset is 
purported to have significant performance advantages over the intersil part, 
and has been adopted as the new standard by D-Link, USR, and others."

I thought I would shared the info just in case someone else has purchased or 
thinking about purchasing this particular card..... DWL-520+ D-link Airplus 
Wireless PCI adapter..   So I guess I am off to purchase a different card.  I 
would love to hear about any suggestions on cards that you or anyone else 
knows that works.  

Times like this reminds me on how little I know. I have come along way, over 
the last couple of years but maybe someday I can graduate to at least an 
intermediate user.  I am forever stuck on newbie..   Thanks for you valuable 
time and feedback.

bob

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Sun Nov 17 15:00:53 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)

Subject: [PLUG] SU ?

Dirk Ouellette said:
> I've noticed that su - chamges you to root's home dir, whereas plain su
> leaves you in the user's dir. Shouldn't make any difference to $PATH,
> though, I shouldn't think, so there's more to it than that..
>
> I saw this statement. Is this true? Why or why not?

>From the "su" man page:

"The optional argument - may be used to provide an environment similiar to
what the user would expect had the user logged in directly."

My experience has been that $PATH is part of the user's environment and is
set appropriately upon invoking "su -", i.e. /sbin and /usr/sbin are in
$PATH, whereas they might not be for Joe User.

Hrm, I'm trying this out right now, and $PATH is being set for root even
when just using su (sans -). I know I've seen this not happen, where 'su'
does not set $PATH for root, but 'su -' does. I'm using Gentoo 1.4rc1
here. Am I crazy?

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sun Nov 17 22:05:25 2002
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sun, 17 Nov 2002 22:05:25 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux = Unix?

> >> UNIX Edition 7

> >> System V rel 2.2
> >> System V rel 4
> >> SUN OS
> >> Solaris
> >> HP/UX
> >> BSD/OS
> >> FreeBSD
> >> OpenBSD
> >> Linux
> >
> >
> > What, no NeXTSTEP, OSF/1/Digital UNIX/Tru64, SCO OpenServer, Novell/SCO
> > UnixWare, Microsoft/SCO Xenix, IRIX, DG-UX, AIX, A-UX, Dynix or NetBSD?
> >  And you call yourself a man!
>
> You forgot Coherent and Interactive as well. I think Coherent just
> disolved at one point and Interactive was sold to Kodak and then to Sun
> to become Sun OS or Solaris. (I don't remember now.)
>
Coherent went bankrupt around 1997, IIRC. According to the guy who told me
about this, they just couldn't compete against Linux. (And had Linux
never been created, I'd bet that it would have been one of the *BSD that
would have killed Coherent.)

Then again, a few years ago my source started claiming that Windows would
replace Linux, so take that bit of 2nd-hand information with a grain of
salt. (He said some stuff after that, but I stopped listening to him;
every time he claimed to have the scoop about What's New in computers,
I would end up getting into a flamewar with him because his view of
reality was perpendicular to mine. I didn't need one more excuse to get
mad about stuff.) Lots of potentially useful developments in computing
have shrivelled up & died entirely because of a few bad business decisions.
Not that any of us could think of an example or two we have witnessed in
the last few years.

Geoff




From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov 18 10:05:08 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 10:05:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SU ?
In-Reply-To: <64944.12.231.181.15.1037574053.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211181000590.1196-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Sun, 17 Nov 2002, Dan Young wrote:

> Hrm, I'm trying this out right now, and $PATH is being set for root
> even when just using su (sans -). I know I've seen this not happen,
> where 'su' does not set $PATH for root, but 'su -' does. I'm using
> Gentoo 1.4rc1 here. Am I crazy?

caveat: I'm shooting from the hip

I've never investigated how the various su invocations do shell 
initialization, but my hunch is that root's interactive 
(~/.bash_profile, ~/.bash_login, or ~/.profile) and non-interactive 
(~/.bashrc) login scripts are identical, or nearly so.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From kevinc at dOink.COM  Mon Nov 18 10:27:34 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 10:27:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] 11/16 Clinic & Linux Software
Message-ID: <20021118182736.CEBF42FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

At last Saturday's clinic I overheard a father say to a son
something like, "Well, Linux is only really good for email
anyway."  It seems the father was wanting Mathcad to run on
Linux.  I suggested that Mathematica would run on Linux and is a
better program than Mathcad.  Yes, it's expensive.  But, maybe
the son can buy the student version, which is identical to the
professional version except that you don't get tech. supt. and
it's about 90% cheaper.  I also suggested some open source math
software, specificly:  Maxima, Scilab and octave.

If anyone else thinks that Linux is only good for
email, or if you know someone who thinks that, then you
really need to know about this Linux applications list:
http://home.xnet.com/~blatura/linapps.shtml

Oddly enough, Maxima isn't listed there.  Its URL is
http://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/wfs/maxima.html


Cheers....

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov 18 11:29:08 2002

In-Reply-To: <20021118182736.CEBF42FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

On Mon, 18 Nov 2002, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:

> I also suggested some open source math software, specificly:  
> Maxima, Scilab and octave.

And R: http://www.r-project.org/

>From the README:

  R is a system for statistical computation and graphics. It consists 
  of a language plus a run-time environment with graphics, a debugger, 
  access to certain system functions, and the ability to run programs 
  stored in script files.

  The design of R has been heavily influenced by two existing 
  languages: Becker, Chambers & Wilks' S and Sussman's Scheme.  
  Whereas the resulting language is very similar in appearance to S, 
  the underlying implementation and semantics are derived from Scheme.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Nov 18 03:16:32 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 03:16:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 8.0 / Nvidia Drivers
In-Reply-To: <20021118054628.31374.qmail@web10410.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211180310140.14971-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Sun, 17 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> Dave,
> 
> I haven't had any luck with this either. I also tried installing Nvidia
> drivers from tarball and from source RPM, but no luck either way.
> Hopefully nVidia will put out a RH8 driver soon, and hopefully in time
> for the Linux version of Neverwinter Nights comes out.

Weird. I have it working fine.

Get the source RPM. (I don't remember version numbers and I am not in 
front of the computer.)

rpmbuild --rebuild NVIDIA_kernel-<whatever>.src.rpm

Find the rpm it built

rpm -ivh /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/i386/NVIDIA_kernel<version>.rpm

rpm -ivh NVIDIA_GLX<version>.i386.rpm  (Might have to rebuild this too.)

The tricky part is that you may need to force the module load the fist 
time.  You also need to make sure that the XF86Config* files are pointing 
to the correct driver.  (That works as documented.)

The only real issue is that there are some issues with it complaining 
about gcc 3.2 and lack of GPL issues.  insmod --force will take care of 
the complaints.

It works pretty well on my system.  (I can run Unreal Tournement 2003 with 
little or no problem.)


> 
> -Scott
> 
> --- Dave Clark <daveclark15 at attbi.com> wrote:
> > hey folks,
> >      Has anyone has any success getting the latest Nvidia drivers to
> > work with Redhat 8.0.  Bit frustrating for me as I have followed the
> > directions to the "T" and still have yet to get acceleration
> > operating correctly (3d acceleration).  Thanks for any feedback you
> > folks can give me.
> > 
> > Dave
> > 
> > btw - Running a GeForce 3 Ti 200 card and Redhat 8.0 (2.4.17).
