From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Mon Nov 18 11:49:26 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 11:49:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] FrontPage clone
In-Reply-To: <1037647287.19961.2.camel@enlightenment>
References: <1037498230.1405.1.camel@localhost.localdomain> <1037647287.19961.2.camel@enlightenment>
Message-ID: <20021118194926.GA6963@dalsemi.com>

On Mon, Nov 18, 2002 at 11:21:26AM -0800, Josh Zeckser wrote:
> On Sat, 2002-11-16 at 17:57, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> > I'm looking for a good FrontPage clone that will allow me to do
> > scripting and some automatic html creation like FrontPage or
> > DreamWeaver.  Is there such a beast for Linux?  If so, what is it (are
> > they) and where can it/they be obtained.
> > 
> > Robbert van Andel
> 
> 
> Have you tried Amaya? It's the only linux web design app with WYSIWYG
> editing. Here is the address: http://www.w3.org/Amaya/

Mozilla has WYSIWIG.

So does OpenOffice, and it's not that bad for simple pages.

I wouldn't doubt that WYSIWIG modules could be built for Bluefish or
Quanta.  Quanta Gold (from The Kompany) may have a WYSIWIG mode, but it
costs money, although you do get the source.

Here's the thing.  Until people start using WYSIWIG on Linux, no one
will develop it.  If a bunch of people started submitting bug
fixes/feature requests to the Bugzilla sites for each project, then
work would be done.  Every Linux person that continues to use FrontPage
and Dreamweaver on a different partition or under Wine/Win4Lin/etc
actively hinders the development of those tools under Linux.

Colin

may be? Sounds more like there was no parallel development and they have
just started writing the Linux client pretty much from scratch.

http://community.linuxfromscratch.org/explanation.txt

"... LFS needs a new home. We've tried contacting some ISPs but
nothing worked out. Either we don't get a response at all, or a rejection...

"While LFS will be limping around a bit (pardon the pun) I'm requestion
assistance from you LFS'ers. Is there anybody on this list who is able to
co-locate the LFS server? I must point out that I don't make any money off
LFS and personal funds aren't available to pay for it..."

Passing this along in case anyone can lend a hand.

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Nov 18 06:00:37 2002

Subject: [PLUG] linuxfromscratch needs a home

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211180558210.16096-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

I hosted one of their mirros for a while.

They EAT bandwidth.  Instead of putting pointers to  usable tarballs for 
the stuff you need, they host it all there. Double-plus ungood.

A very cool project though.  Not certain if I like the copyright 
requirements for contributors.  (Basically the autor of the site claims 
all copyrights.  Or did the last time I looked.)

On Monday 18 November 2002 02:43 pm, Jim Webb wrote:
> What did this website provide?  I'm not familiar with it.

There's still a mirror up at http://lfs.sourceforge.net
Short version: Instructions for compiling a Linux system from scratch (LFS - 
"Linux From Scratch"). They eat bandwidth because they provide a tarball of 
all the required source for the base install.



From bob at bmtsolutions.com  Mon Nov 18 15:10:45 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Wireless D-link PCI card
In-Reply-To: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEMBCNAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
References: <CAENLEIHEHPLANCLMFKMMEMBCNAA.mwlist@planetwills.com>
Message-ID: <200211181510.45396.bob@bmtsolutions.com>

On Sunday 17 November 2002 16:10, Mark Wills wrote:
> From what I've been able to gather none of the 22Mb/s cards have Linux
> driver support. These use a TI chipset, not the Prism2 chipset so common in
> most of the other cards. I've heard the 22Mb/s access points can talk to 11
> Mb/s cards. If you haven't read through
> http://www.hpl.hp.com/personal/Jean_Tourrilhes/Linux/ yet you may want to
> give it a try.
>
> Mark


Thanks Mark,
I missed your posting.  You are correct though  I did not come to this 
conclusion, on the driver support, until early this morning. I wish I did not 
miss your post I could have same myself some time. I ordered another card 
that uses the Prism2 chipset.    I hope the card I just order will have a 
smooth install. 

Thanks for helping out.   



From kevinc at dOink.COM  Mon Nov 18 15:19:33 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 15:19:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] linuxfromscratch needs a home 
In-Reply-To: <200211181451.55720.nknight@pocketinet.com> 
Message-ID: <20021118231935.81D672FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

I asked a friend of mine if he might be able to handle the colo of 
LFS.  His answer is below.  Bottom line is that it looks like there 
could be help for LFS if they could restructure the data for smaller 
downloads or if they could share the load across mirrors somehow.

Sigh...




===============================================================


I certainly have the physical room, but can you give me an idea
of the amount of bandwidth they typically use? I had a "friend"
sink all 7 of the t1's here after they put out a set of U2 MP3's
on their website - I can handle a lot but this ain't a 100 mbit
pittock building colo... If they have ten thousand people a day
downloading ISO's I probably can't handle it :-)

> http://community.linuxfromscratch.org/explanation.txt

oh, gulp - 23GB/day ... I just read that. Last paragraph stats
2500-3000kbit/second, in otherwords, maxing out of two $900/month
T1 circuits... at that level I don't think I can do it... I know
a company down at the pittock that has the bandwidth but they
also have to pay for it - about $300/meg, so a 3000kbit/second
connection would cost them $900/month (much cheaper than t1's but
still $$$)...

so... ahem, I hate to say no but I can't handle the load they
are talking about...  I think they need to find a well located,
and well heeled ISP that is not paying $/bits (like my friends
at the pittock) or limited to smaller pipes, even if there are a
lot of them (like me). No doubt this is why they are having such
problems finding a new home... If there is a reduced version of
the site or they could stand to be bandwidth limited, I would be
more than happy to help out.


===============================================================

> Kevin Cosgrove <kevinc at dOink.COM>
I've tried the Mandrake 9.0 download and I like it on my system.
It's a little lean compared to the 7.0 and 8.0 PowerPacks that
I've used in the past, and I want to upgrade this via either
MandrakeClub or by buying a Mandrake 9.0 PowerPack.

What do you recommend?

in the past and are now, or have been, MandrakeClub members.

I am NOT an expert user. However, I have purchased Mandrake and am a Club
member so here's my two cents . . . Joining the Mandrake Club is way better
than purchasing stale code on coasters, unless you're still using a dialup
connection. Purchasing the retail product helps keep Mandrake functioning,
but so does joining the Club.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Mon Nov 18 16:41:09 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 16:41:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] linuxfromscratch needs a home 
In-Reply-To: <20021118231935.81D672FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0211181604050.12329-100000@cod.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> Bottom line is that it looks like there could be help for LFS if they
> could restructure the data for smaller downloads or if they could share
> the load across mirrors somehow.

Goneril:
As you are old, you shou'd be staid and wise,
Here do you keep an hundred Sources and Tarballs,
Files so debaucht and bold that this our Palace
Shews like a riotous Inn, a Tavern, Brothel;
Be then advised by she that else will take
The she that beggs, to lessen your Bandwidth,
Take half a way, and see that the remainder
Be such as may befit your Age, and know
Themselves and you.

Lear/LFS:
Darkness and Devils!
Saddle my Horses, call my Train together,
Degenerate Viper, I'll not colloc my files with Thee;
I yet have left a Server. Serpent, Monster,
Lessen my Tarballs, and call 'em riotous?
All Kernel Sources approv'd of choice and rarest Parts,
That each particular of duty know?
How small, Sourceforge, was thy Fault? O LFS,
Beat at this Gate that let thy Folly in,
And thy dear Judgment out.

ActI, ll 380.

Anyone else reminded of King Lear?  :-)

-TYler

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Nov 18 16:57:34 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 16:57:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hate 8.0 Network Config
Message-ID: <3DD98C7E.4A9F3EB9@attbi.com>

I remembered to back up a lot of stuff before installing RH 8 on my
machine named nec, but I neglected to make copies of config files that
worked on RH 7, so I don't have those to refer to.

When I start httpd, other machines in the house can see the web site on
nec, and I can bring up the maintenance web page of my Netgear router by
typing in the address 192.168.0.1 in Mozilla on nec, so I know that the
eth0 is working. But I can't see anything other than local pages. 

The Netgear documentation said to use 192.168.0.1 as the default gateway
address.

Suggestions on where to start looking will be greatly appreciated.

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Mon Nov 18 17:14:00 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 17:14:00 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] RedHat Road Show 2002 Clinic
In-Reply-To: <3DD94FA8.9090800@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211181659270.19885-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Mon, 18 Nov 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

>Kenneth G. Stephens wrote:
>> Here's some pictures of the clinic, yesterday.
>> 
>> http://www.cadtocam.com/pictures/Plug%20Clinic/thumbnails/
>
>Anyone who was in attendance care to give a summary.  Any interesting 
>material or was it just marketing?

Three events in all:

   * Friday night @ Bridgport: Pretty much like a typical post-PLUG meeting
          at the Lucky Lab, but with a dog-n-pony show in the middle. 
          Imagine a PLUG meeting where we had beer before and after the
          presentation.

   * Saturday clinic at Riverdale: Pretty much like a regular clinic but
          with three times the normal crowd. The RH techs jumped in and
          helped with installations/debugging/general-geek-stuff and there
          was a seperate room setup for presentations (marketing stuff I
          would assume, but I spent the whole time doing geek-stuff).

   * Monday education round-table: Roughly 45-50 educators discussing how
          they are using Linux, why they are using Linux, what would it take
          for them to use more Linux, etc. Red Hat folks talked about what
          they are doing to help schools.


Also see:

    http://www.redhat.com/roadtour/journal/archives/111502.html
    http://www.redhat.com/roadtour/journal/archives/111602.html

-Eric

I attended the opening lecture, he was funny and did a geat 
overview of the new desktop and new features. He was funny 
and pointed (at M$) I spent the rest of the time in the lab, 
where there was a mondo install fest. LOTS of copies of the 
first two disks were distributed.

I understand that the stump-the-geek festival in the separate 
classroom was fun for those more saavy than I.

I made two public school people happy by sending them out 
with fully functional RH 8.0 installs on hardware they could 
play with at their work sites.

Mike

Message-ID: <20021119014848.GD6963@dalsemi.com>

On Mon, Nov 18, 2002 at 05:14:01PM -0800, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> 11/18/02 11:49:26 AM, Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com> wrote:
> 
> > Every Linux person that continues to use FrontPage
> >and Dreamweaver on a different partition or under Wine/Win4Lin/etc
> >actively hinders the development of those tools under Linux.
> >
> >Colin
> 
> I believe tht's true if the Linux person is a programmer. Without the ability to 
> program a better tool.
> 
> I don't see how I could help, for instance.

I didn't say you have to be a programmer, I said you have to be a
user.  In my opinion, large software projects are usually desperate for
people to fulfill two jobs:

1) Insightful user.  This person is committed to using the software and
can write informative bug reports in a clear concise manner.  They are
usually able to type "make clean all install" to check out bug-fixed
versions of software.  Coding skill can help here, since patches are
always welcome.

2) Documentation guru.  This person can write copious amounts of
documentation with little or no guidance from developers.  Most
documentation is created from bad bug reports and email list traffic.
Coding skill is definitely a plus here, but not necessary.

A large user base usually guarantees the success of a given project,
since there are enough people to fill those two tasks.

Colin

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov 18 18:17:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 18:17:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] FrontPage clone
In-Reply-To: <20021119014848.GD6963@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211181813390.16808-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Mon, 18 Nov 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> 2) Documentation guru.  This person can write copious amounts of
> documentation with little or no guidance from developers.  Most
> documentation is created from bad bug reports and email list traffic.
> Coding skill is definitely a plus here, but not necessary.

  Coders make terrible documentation writers. Despite my writing skills, I
learned that writing documention for applications _I_ wrote is a very, very
difficult job. Not because I don't know the software, but because I know it
so well. I assume that the reader knows things that are obvious to me. They
don't. Responding, "Well, _everyone_ knows that" doesn't cut it. :-)

  The best end-user docs come from end users who are not intimately familiar
with the program design decisions and the code. Sad but true.

Rich

From jimwebb at charter.net  Mon Nov 18 18:56:28 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (Jim Webb)
Date: 18 Nov 2002 21:56:28 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] RedHat Road Show 2002 Clinic
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211181742540.16808-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211181742540.16808-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1037674588.1193.21.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Gentlemen,

Bluecurve is their graphical interface that appears no matter what you
do.  I believe that it is Red Hat's desktop that tries to make either
KDE or Gnome have a similar appearance and function somewhat similarly
with by improving the menus from KDE and Gnome so that they appear
somewhat similar.  I installed both desktop environment packages during
my install.

After playing around I realized that the desktop and panel for both
environments looked similar, yet different.  If you ahve installed both
environemnts and then used the desktop switching tool you can see the
differences.  The main menu button for both KDE & Gnome environment has
a red hat and not the K gear or footprint that you may be used to.  In
both environments, you'll, initially, see the evolution groupware
package and then office.org application buttons and so on.  

The desktops look different and open up different file managers.  The
first desktop that my sytem started with, I believe, was bluevurve based
on gnome since I recognized nautilus file manager.  I used the desktop
switching tool and changed to bluecurve based on KDE and my file manager
was Konqueror.

I hope that this makes some sense.

TIA,

Jim

> 
> Weird. I have it working fine.
> 
> Get the source RPM. (I don't remember version numbers and I am not in
> 
> front of the computer.)
> 
> rpmbuild --rebuild NVIDIA_kernel-<whatever>.src.rpm
> 
> Find the rpm it built
> 
> rpm -ivh /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/i386/NVIDIA_kernel<version>.rpm
> 
> rpm -ivh NVIDIA_GLX<version>.i386.rpm  (Might have to rebuild this
> too.)
> 
> The tricky part is that you may need to force the module load the
> fist 
> time.  You also need to make sure that the XF86Config* files are
> pointing 
> to the correct driver.  (That works as documented.)
> 
> The only real issue is that there are some issues with it complaining
> 
> about gcc 3.2 and lack of GPL issues.  insmod --force will take care
> of 
> the complaints.
> 
> It works pretty well on my system.  (I can run Unreal Tournement 2003
> with 
> little or no problem.)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov 18 20:18:11 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 20:18:11 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 8.0 / Nvidia Drivers
In-Reply-To: <20021119035527.97736.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>

On Mon, 18 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> I tried your instructions, but it didn't work, as before. Here is what
> I did:
> 
> rpm -ivh NVIDIA_kernel-1.0-3123.src.rpm

Instead, try

  rpmbuild --rebuild NVIDIA_kernel-1.0-3123.src.rpm

You should end up with some sort of rpm in /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/i386. 
Install that one.

From robbert at vafam.com  Mon Nov 18 20:26:05 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: 18 Nov 2002 20:26:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hate 8.0 Network Config
In-Reply-To: <3DD98C7E.4A9F3EB9@attbi.com>
References: <3DD98C7E.4A9F3EB9@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1037679967.2123.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Are you saying you can't browse the internet?  If not, can you ping urls
and/or ips (yahoo's ip is 66.218.71.84)?  If you can ping by IP and not
url, make sure your dns configuration is correct.  If you can't ping by
IP or URL you may need to make sure that your router is routing traffic
from your machine.  My guess, form personal experience is that it's a
dns problem.

Robbert van Andel

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Nov 18 20:26:54 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 20:26:54 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat 8.0 / Nvidia Drivers
In-Reply-To: <20021119035527.97736.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211180310140.14971-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
        <20021119035527.97736.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <65451.12.231.181.15.1037680014.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Scott VanHoosen said:
> I tried your instructions, but it didn't work, as before. Here is what I
> did:
>
> rpm -ivh NVIDIA_kernel-1.0-3123.src.rpm
>>
>> Weird. I have it working fine.
>>
>> Get the source RPM. (I don't remember version numbers and I am not in
>>
>> front of the computer.)
>>
>> rpmbuild --rebuild NVIDIA_kernel-<whatever>.src.rpm

Read those instructions again.

You need to do an "rpmbuild --rebuild NVIDIA_kernel-<version>.src.rpm,
rather than installing the src.rpm. Building from the src.rpm will drop
the rpm in /usr/src/redhat/RPMS/<arch>/NVIDIA_kernel-<version>.<arch>.rpm.
You want to "rpm -ivh" that to get the kernel module installed. Then edit
your /etc/X11/XF86Config and change 'Driver "nv"' to 'Driver "nvidia"'.
You'll need to install the GLX rpm also.

I didn't have any problems when building from "source" <cough, cough>
rpms, and otherwise following NVIDIA's instructions.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From robbert at vafam.com  Mon Nov 18 20:36:55 2002

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Nov 18 21:15:43 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 21:15:43 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting USB drive
In-Reply-To: <1037680617.2121.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1037680617.2121.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <64522.12.231.181.15.1037682943.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Robbert van Andel said:
> I have a firewire drive on my windows machine.  It also has a usb
> connection that I can put on my linux machine.  I'm wondering if this is
> compatible with linux (the usb connection) and how I would mount it.

I'd check out the Linux-USB website. There is support for mass storage USB
devices in 2.4 kernels. It looks like they emulate SCSI devices, and would
therefore be mounted by doing a "mount /dev/sdxX /mnt/<mountpoint>" or
whatever.

http://www.linux-usb.org/USB-guide/book1.html

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District





From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Nov 18 21:18:49 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 21:18:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
Message-ID: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>

Here's the situation.

I have a machine at home configured like so:

Athlon XP 1800+
Soyo kt333 motherboard
512 mb RAM
40 gb hard drive
32 mb ATI video card
DVD drive
Creative CD-RW 12/10/32
Mandrake 9.0

At work, I have the following configuration:

P4 2.4 ghz
Dell mb (Sorry, it's a dell workstation. work bought it for me...)
1 gb RAM
40 gb hard drive
32 mb ATI video card
cd/dvd/cdrw combo drive
Mandrake 9.0

Here's the catch... The Athlon can handle more load than the P4. I'm
writing this message while downloading files, burning a CD, listening to 
mp3s, and untaring BIG tarballs. No problem at all. 

If I try this same thing at work, the system is EXTREMELY sluggish. The
mouse pointer jumps instead of smoothly crossing the screen, I can't
drag windows around. It's hard to get the mouse pointer to stop on the
window bar, let alone on a corner...

Why would the P4 be such a dog (besides the fact that "it's a dell,
man."

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Love is a hole in the heart -- Murphy's Laws on Sex n?29



From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Mon Nov 18 21:24:18 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 18 Nov 2002 21:24:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1037683457.28955.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2002-11-18 at 21:18, Russ Johnson wrote:

> Why would the P4 be such a dog (besides the fact that "it's a dell,
> man."

Could it be the P4 system doesn't have dma enabled?

As root, try hdparm /dev/hda (assuming hda is your hard drive)...

Mine outputs this... it uses DMA, but I haven't played with any of the
other settings.  :-)

/dev/hda:
 multcount    =  0 (off)
 IO_support   =  1 (32-bit)
 unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
 using_dma    =  1 (on)
 keepsettings =  0 (off)
 readonly     =  0 (off)
 readahead    =  8 (on)
 geometry     = 2501/255/63, sectors = 40188960, start = 0

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Nov 18 21:39:47 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 18 Nov 2002 21:39:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
Message-ID: <1037684387.20343.21.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

All,

I just finished writing a script for a friend (actually a pretty fun
``script on demand'' session really) that converts a directory listing
into an html page who's links point to your files.

It's single argument is the name of the directory who's contents you
want written out an html file.

You may need to change the first line (#!/usr/local/bin/ksh) as your ksh
shell may very well be in a different directory.

Also, if you do not have the Korn shell, I 1) highly recommend the Korn
shell and 2) you can modify the `print' statements to `echo' statements.


#------------------Begin Script----------------------


#!/usr/local/bin/ksh

#html_list.ksh
#Usage: html_list.ksh [name of directory to list]

#define the output file as a variable change only this variable to
change it.

output_file=/home/arat/dirindex.html

#Write header information to file
print '<html><head></head><body>' > $output_file

#Okay, grab the directory listing and append it to the file.

find $1 | while read file
name
do
 print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$filename"'</A><BR>' >> $output_file
done

#Append the final statement
print '</body></html>' >> $output_file

#---------------------------End Script---------------------------


-Cooper




From nknight at pocketinet.com  Mon Nov 18 21:39:53 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 21:39:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <1037683457.28955.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net> <1037683457.28955.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <200211182139.53976.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Monday 18 November 2002 09:24 pm, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Mon, 2002-11-18 at 21:18, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > Why would the P4 be such a dog (besides the fact that "it's a dell,
> > man."
>
> Could it be the P4 system doesn't have dma enabled?
>
> As root, try hdparm /dev/hda (assuming hda is your hard drive)...

Be sure to check the cd/rw/dvd combo drive, too. I've never dealt with a combo 
drive, but MDK9 defaults to DMA off on my desktop's DVD drive (actually, my 
DVD drive doesn't handle DMA all that well anyway, but who knows).



From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Mon Nov 18 21:53:31 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 18 Nov 2002 21:53:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <200211182139.53976.nknight@pocketinet.com>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	 <1037683457.28955.1.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <200211182139.53976.nknight@pocketinet.com>
Message-ID: <1037685211.28955.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2002-11-18 at 21:39, Nicholas Knight wrote:

> Be sure to check the cd/rw/dvd combo drive, too. I've never dealt with a combo 
> drive, but MDK9 defaults to DMA off on my desktop's DVD drive (actually, my 
> DVD drive doesn't handle DMA all that well anyway, but who knows).

That's wierd - the kernel defaulted to dma being on for both my DVD and
CD-RW drives - and I don't have a well-supported chipset.  I have to
manually set DMA for my hard drive.  Go figure.  :-)

Either way, unless you're playing a DVD or reading from the drive or
writing to it, DMA on the combo drive shouldn't come in to play in
general system performance.

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Mon Nov 18 22:14:59 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2002 22:14:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <1037685746.20343.23.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
        <1037685746.20343.23.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <64716.12.231.181.15.1037686499.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Cooper Stevenson said:
> Is the BIOS on the P4 set to ``Optimized Defaults?''

Good tip, Cooper.

I've got a bunch Micronics M6Me (P-Pro) boards at work that will fall back
to "unoptimized" defaults if they are interrupted during POST.
Essentially, they turn the L2 cache off, resulting in incredibly pitiful
performance. I've rebooted servers with these a few times, neglecting to
make sure the cache was enabled, then pounding my head on the nearest hard
surface trying to figure out why they were booting sooooooo sloooooowly.
Doh!

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

    probeall usb-interface usb-uhci
    alias eth0 eepro100
    alias autofs autofs4
    alias sound-slot-0 snd-ymfpci
    probeall scsi_hostadapter BusLogic
    above snd-ymfpci snd-pcm-oss

On Monday 18 November 2002 10:40 pm, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:

> I fired up the alsamixer and played with all the sliders.  It
> does look like the sliders match the functions of the card, some
> of which are unique, like S/PDIF i/o.  This leads me to believe
> that something is right.  But, aplay doesn't cause any sound to
> come out of the speakers.  A CD playing app. doesn't make any
> sound either.

Just a thought: Boot to the command line (don't start X) and play an mp3/ogg 
with mpg123/ogg123. If it works, you may have an issue with aRts (or a 
similiar sound server for a non-KDE environment (I think GNOME uses esound)).

From m at netpro.to  Tue Nov 19 07:48:51 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 07:48:51 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Simple Script
In-Reply-To: <1037684142.20344.14.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211190747150.12322-100000@lukem.com>

Or, in PHP:

<?
$dir_name = getcwd();
$dir = opendir($dir_name);
$file_list = "<ul>";

while ($file_name = readdir($dir)) {
	if (($file_name != ".")	&& ($file_name != "..") && ($file_name != "index.php")) {
		$file_list .= "<li><a href=\"$file_name\">$file_name</a>";
	}
}

$file_list .= "</ul>";
closedir($dir);
?>

<html>
<head>
<title>My Files</title>
</head>
<body>
<b><h2>My Files:</h2></b>
<? echo "$file_list"; ?>
</body>
</html>



On 18 Nov 2002, Cooper Stevenson wrote:

> All,
>
> I just finished writing a script for a friend (pretty fun ``script on
> demand,'' really) that converts a directory listing into an html page
> who's links point to your files.

> It's single argument is the name of the directory who's contents you
> want written out to html.
>

> shell may very well be in a different directory.
>
> Also, if you do not have the Korn shell, I 1) highly recommend the Korn
> shell and 2) you can modify the `print' statements to `echo' statements.
>
> Let the emails from the csh guys roll!
>

> #------------------Begin Script----------------------
>
>
> #!/usr/local/bin/ksh
>
> #html_list.ksh
> #Usage: html_list.ksh [name of directory to list]
>
> #define the output file as a variable change only this variable to
> change it.
>
> output_file=/home/arat/dirindex.html
>
> #Write header information to file
> print '<html><head></head><body>' > $output_file
>
> #Okay, grab the directory listing and append it to the file.
>
> find $1 | while read file
> name
> do
>  print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$filename"'</A><BR>' >> $output_file
> done
>
> #Append the final statement
> print '</body></html>' >> $output_file
>
> #---------------------------End Script---------------------------

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Nov 19 08:17:59 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 08:17:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Simple Script
In-Reply-To: <7094.66.93.41.98.1037720958.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

	<Pine.GSO.4.33.0211190747150.12322-100000@lukem.com>

Message-ID: <86el9hv8i0.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Matt" == Matt King <plug at magnetinternet.com> writes:

Matt> ...or use Apache's autoindex feature...why re-invent the wheel?

One reason might be that you don't usually run Apache on your
CD-ROM's.

I created an online photo album that is generated with a single fairly
simple Makefile.  It takes a directory full of full-sized images named
*.JPG and builds thumbnails, medium-sized images and the necessary
HTML glue to hold them all together.  Works pretty well by itself with
a web server.  

Trouble is, when multiple such directories full of images are burned
on a CD-ROM, browsers don't provide very nice ways of navigating the
folders.  I found it useful to provide some top-level HTML glue.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Nov 19 08:22:06 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 08:22:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Resolv-ed: Red Hate 8.0 Network Config
References: <3DD98C7E.4A9F3EB9@attbi.com> <1037679967.2123.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3DDA652E.E4BD38A2@attbi.com>

Robbert van Andel wrote:

> Are you saying you can't browse the internet?  If not, can you ping urls
> and/or ips (yahoo's ip is 66.218.71.84)?  If you can ping by IP and not
> url, make sure your dns configuration is correct.  If you can't ping by
> IP or URL you may need to make sure that your router is routing traffic
> from your machine.  My guess, form personal experience is that it's a
> dns problem.

That's what I needed to point me towards the answer - always start with
the question! It was indeed a DNS problem. I successfully pinged yahoo
by ip address. My problem was not realizing that /etc/resolv.conf was
empty. I got out the notebook from Ed Sawiki's Linux Networking course,
looked up the section on DNS, found the place where he describes
configuring the resolver, looked on my Debian system to see what it had
for resolv.conf, and entered that into the empty resolv.conf on the RH8
system.

The world is a brighter place this morning. Thanks for the help!

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 08:19:34 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:19:34 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
Message-ID: <EX-20021119-102419-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

What hard drive is in the machine at work? I'm guessing you bought something nice while Dell tends to put cheap stuff in theirs. Also the Soyo is a pretty good chipset once again Dell not so much. The other reason is in almost everything except multimedia the Athlons tend to do better than the P4s. Also have you built a nice custom kernel for one and not for the other. Turning on processor support when building a kernel can make a *huge* difference.



-----Original Message-----
From: Russ Johnson 
Sent: Monday, November 18, 2002 9:22 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?


Here's the situation.

I have a machine at home configured like so:

Athlon XP 1800+
Soyo kt333 motherboard
512 mb RAM
40 gb hard drive
32 mb ATI video card
DVD drive
Creative CD-RW 12/10/32
Mandrake 9.0

At work, I have the following configuration:

P4 2.4 ghz
Dell mb (Sorry, it's a dell workstation. work bought it for me...)
1 gb RAM
40 gb hard drive
32 mb ATI video card
cd/dvd/cdrw combo drive
Mandrake 9.0

Here's the catch... The Athlon can handle more load than the P4. I'm
writing this message while downloading files, burning a CD, listening to 
mp3s, and untaring BIG tarballs. No problem at all. 

If I try this same thing at work, the system is EXTREMELY sluggish. The
mouse pointer jumps instead of smoothly crossing the screen, I can't
drag windows around. It's hard to get the mouse pointer to stop on the
window bar, let alone on a corner...

Why would the P4 be such a dog (besides the fact that "it's a dell,
man."

-- 
Russ Johnson

http://www.dimstar.net

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 19 08:51:31 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 08:51:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Inspirion 8200
References: <1037709410.10686.311.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <3DDA6C13.80100@sun.com>

I've got an 8100.  It was installed by default with Windows XP.  Just 
recently I wiped it and installed W2k and Gentoo.  It runs quite well, 
hardware is detected easily and is pretty snappy for a sub-Ghz machine.

Knoppix runs nearly flawlessly on it as well (wireless nic was the only 
thing it didn't auto-detect).

Take a look here:  http://www.linux-laptop.net/

They've got TONS of howtos on installing your distro of choice on your 
laptop of choice.  If there's a laptop out there that can run Linux, 
chances are someone has it, has done it, and has a howto up on that site.

Good luck.

-R

   richard.langis at sun.com


Your mouse has moved.
Windows NT must be restarted for the change to take effect.
Reboot now?  [OK]




From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Nov 19 09:43:06 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 09:43:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20021119174305.GB15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>

Thanks to everyone who sent help. I found that my Athlon system has all
the DMA stuff turned on by default, and the Dell (Smell?) P4 has it all
turned off by default. 

However, there's no joy in Muddville this morning, as here's the results
of my attempts to turn it on.

First, I rebooted, and verified that DMA (UDMA in this case) is enabled
in BIOS.

There is no POST screen on a DELL Optiplex. It just shows the stupid
Dell logo. Like I didn't know it was a Dell?

When I run hdparm /dev/hda, I get this:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
multcount    = 16 (on)
IO_support   =  0 (default 16-bit)
unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
keepsettings =  0 (off)
readonly     =  0 (off)
readahead    =  8 (on)
geometry     = 4865/255/63, sectors = 78165360, start = 0
	
I can turn on IO_support:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -c1 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting 32-bit IO_support flag to 1
IO_support   =  1 (32-bit)
 
But I'm unable to turn on dma mode:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -d1 -X34 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting using_dma to 1 (on)
HDIO_SET_DMA failed: Operation not permitted
setting xfermode to 34 (multiword DMA mode2)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
    
I've been googling for awhile now, and I don't find much in the way of
help. At this point, I'm assuming the chipset is not supported.

* Russ Johnson <russj at dimstar.net> [2002-11-18 21:20]:
> Here's the situation.
> 
> I have a machine at home configured like so:
> 
> Athlon XP 1800+
> Soyo kt333 motherboard
> 512 mb RAM
> 40 gb hard drive
> 32 mb ATI video card
> DVD drive
> Creative CD-RW 12/10/32
> Mandrake 9.0
> 
> At work, I have the following configuration:
> 
> P4 2.4 ghz
> Dell mb (Sorry, it's a dell workstation. work bought it for me...)
> 1 gb RAM
> 40 gb hard drive
> 32 mb ATI video card
> cd/dvd/cdrw combo drive
> Mandrake 9.0
> 
> Here's the catch... The Athlon can handle more load than the P4. I'm
> writing this message while downloading files, burning a CD, listening to 
> mp3s, and untaring BIG tarballs. No problem at all. 
> 
> If I try this same thing at work, the system is EXTREMELY sluggish. The
> mouse pointer jumps instead of smoothly crossing the screen, I can't
> drag windows around. It's hard to get the mouse pointer to stop on the
> window bar, let alone on a corner...
> 
> Why would the P4 be such a dog (besides the fact that "it's a dell,
> man."
>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 19 09:45:23 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 09:45:23 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211190941150.19205-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  There's a domain, mail.com, that's infested with spammers. But, if I put
in a postfix filter, /mail\.com/	REJECT, in the header_checks file,
then domains such as hotmail.com are also rejected. Not a bad idea, but not
practical, unfortunately.

  Would specifying the regex as /@mail\.com/	REJECT solve this problem
and limit the rejection to only the mail.com domain? If not, is there a way
of writing the expression to catch the one and not all of the others?

TIA,

Rich




From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 19 09:47:56 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 09:47:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net> <20021119174305.GB15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <3DDA794C.7060508@sun.com>

Hit ESC when the Dell screen comes up, or just hit DEL (or F1, F12, or 
whatever it is that Dell uses nowadays).

Chances are that there's a BIOS setting (or two or seven) keeping things 
slow.

-R

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 09:54:47 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 09:54:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <20021119174305.GB15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	 <20021119174305.GB15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1037728487.30279.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 09:43, Russ Johnson wrote:

> But I'm unable to turn on dma mode:
> 
> [root at ciclid root]# hdparm -d1 -X34 /dev/hda
> 
> /dev/hda:
> setting using_dma to 1 (on)
> HDIO_SET_DMA failed: Operation not permitted
> setting xfermode to 34 (multiword DMA mode2)
> using_dma    =  0 (off)
>     
> I've been googling for awhile now, and I don't find much in the way of
> help. At this point, I'm assuming the chipset is not supported.

Find out what the chipset is.

/sbin/lspci should give you a route to start with.  Or googling for your
specific dell model.

Once we know what kind of chipset it is, we can find out what we need to
do in the kernel to get 'er working well.  There is likely support
*somewhere* for it - be it in the form of a few obscure kernel settings
or a patch to the kernel... or maybe using a -pre kernel.

Is it a brand new Dell?

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>

Thanks to everyone who sent help. I found that my Athlon system has all
the DMA stuff turned on by default, and the Dell (Smell?) P4 has it all
turned off by default. 

However, there's no joy in Muddville this morning, as here's the results
of my attempts to turn it on.

in BIOS.

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
multcount    = 16 (on)
IO_support   =  0 (default 16-bit)
unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
keepsettings =  0 (off)

IO_support   =  1 (32-bit)

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -d1 -X34 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting using_dma to 1 (on)
HDIO_SET_DMA failed: Operation not permitted
setting xfermode to 34 (multiword DMA mode2)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
    
I've been googling for awhile now, and I don't find much in the way of
help. At this point, I'm assuming the chipset is not supported.

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Nov 19 10:03:18 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:03:18 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211190941150.19205-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211191000300.12505-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   There's a domain, mail.com, that's infested with spammers. But, if I put
> in a postfix filter, /mail\.com/	REJECT, in the header_checks file,
> then domains such as hotmail.com are also rejected. Not a bad idea, but not
> practical, unfortunately.

How about /^mail\.com/.  I'm guessing postfix peels the doamin out of the 
address - everything after the @ so this would only match mail.com


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 09:53:14 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 11:53:14 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
Message-ID: <EX-20021119-120040-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

I just had to take this chance to brag.

I block all domains named *mail.com. 
I block all of Asia and Africa. 
I block all of AOL.
I block all of netzero and juno and yahoo and any other webmail type services that come to my attention.
I block MSN.
I block Earthlink.

Having said that my advice may be a bit extreme. Why not block hotmail. In this day and age who really uses hotmail or Yahoo or anything else like it for real mail anymore. And if you have friends or whoever that do just put them in a "whitelist" and block the rest. But as you can see from the above there is a large portion of the species I just don't want to talk to. But that's just me.  

-----Original Message-----
From: Rich Shepard 
Sent: Tuesday, November 19, 2002 9:51 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested


  There's a domain, mail.com, that's infested with spammers. But, if I put
in a postfix filter, /mail\.com/	REJECT, in the header_checks file,
then domains such as hotmail.com are also rejected. Not a bad idea, but not
practical, unfortunately.

  Would specifying the regex as /@mail\.com/	REJECT solve this problem
and limit the rejection to only the mail.com domain? If not, is there a way
of writing the expression to catch the one and not all of the others?

TIA,

Rich

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 09:59:52 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 09:59:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.0 + ALSA 0.9 + Yamaha YMF 754 = NO SOUND
In-Reply-To: <20021119064046.BBF912FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20021119064046.BBF912FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <1037728791.30279.12.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2002-11-18 at 22:40, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> A CD playing app. doesn't make any
> sound either.

The CD player apps just talk to the CD-ROM drive - not the sound card. 
If everything is working properly on the hardware end of things, the
CD-ROM plays, no software involved.

Wow that was a lot of modules loaded!  I have 21 loaded and thought that
was a bit insane.

You might think about looking at alsa-project.org for any notes specific
to your soundcard... maybe there's something somewhere you need to tweak
that Mandrake didn't catch.

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 10:04:18 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 10:04:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Inspirion 8200
In-Reply-To: <1037709410.10686.311.camel@lana>
References: <1037709410.10686.311.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <1037729058.30279.17.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 04:36, Jon Jacob wrote:
> I am considering buying a Dell Inspirion 8200.  Does anyone have any
> experience with this machine, even with windows, that they might want to
> share.  I am a RedHat user, so if you use RedHat it would be good to
> hear what you know.

I don't know about OSS-free drivers, but the ALSA drivers for the sound
chip in the 8200 are lacking.  It uses the i8x0 driver, as does a
bajillion other chips (including my nForce), so they have a hard time
implamenting anything for it.  If you do any sound recording either line
in or mic doesn't work.  There's also no hardware mixing support in the
alsa drivers - although the hardware itself seems to support it.  I
believe there are OSS drivers (free or commercial - I don't recall) that
say they support hardware mixing (multiple audio streams) but in
reality, the guy whose email I read said it didn't work.

That's about all I know about the 8200... it looks like a good laptop. 
I plan on buying one (or something similar) after I have a little bit of
cash.  :-)

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Tue Nov 19 10:07:58 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:07:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211190941150.19205-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211190941150.19205-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021119180758.GA8753@dalsemi.com>

On Tue, Nov 19, 2002 at 09:45:23AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   There's a domain, mail.com, that's infested with spammers. But, if I put
> in a postfix filter, /mail\.com/	REJECT, in the header_checks file,
> then domains such as hotmail.com are also rejected. Not a bad idea, but not
> practical, unfortunately.
> 
>   Would specifying the regex as /@mail\.com/	REJECT solve this problem
> and limit the rejection to only the mail.com domain? If not, is there a way
> of writing the expression to catch the one and not all of the others?

You should do that, and anchor the end.

/@mail\.com/  matches:
   mail.com
   mail.computers.net

If you think in filesystem wildcards, then it would look like this:

@mail.com*

If you anchor the end, /@mail\.com$/ then it should do the right
thing.

Colin



From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Tue Nov 19 10:16:52 2002
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:16:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
Message-ID: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2ADD@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

Is the controller set to Auto mode?
If so it may be that the drive doesnt support "standard" DMA modes. Try
setting it to a manual mode 3 or 4. (if the bios lets you)

-----Original Message-----
From: Russ Johnson [mailto:russj at dimstar.net]
Sent: Tuesday, November 19, 2002 9:43 AM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Cc: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?


Thanks to everyone who sent help. I found that my Athlon system has all
the DMA stuff turned on by default, and the Dell (Smell?) P4 has it all
turned off by default. 

However, there's no joy in Muddville this morning, as here's the results
of my attempts to turn it on.

First, I rebooted, and verified that DMA (UDMA in this case) is enabled
in BIOS.

There is no POST screen on a DELL Optiplex. It just shows the stupid
Dell logo. Like I didn't know it was a Dell?

When I run hdparm /dev/hda, I get this:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
multcount    = 16 (on)
IO_support   =  0 (default 16-bit)
unmaskirq    =  0 (off)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
keepsettings =  0 (off)
readonly     =  0 (off)
readahead    =  8 (on)
geometry     = 4865/255/63, sectors = 78165360, start = 0
	
I can turn on IO_support:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -c1 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting 32-bit IO_support flag to 1
IO_support   =  1 (32-bit)
 
But I'm unable to turn on dma mode:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -d1 -X34 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting using_dma to 1 (on)
HDIO_SET_DMA failed: Operation not permitted
setting xfermode to 34 (multiword DMA mode2)
using_dma    =  0 (off)
    
I've been googling for awhile now, and I don't find much in the way of
help. At this point, I'm assuming the chipset is not supported.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 19 10:26:23 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:26:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
References: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2ADD@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <3DDA824F.7080009@sun.com>

That reminds me:  try seeing if DMA is available on the drive:

hdparm -i /dev/hda

Here's what my 60Gig WD drive shows:

[belgarath:~]# hdparm -i /dev/hdc

/dev/hdc:

  Model=WDC WD600BB-00CFC0, FwRev=02.08B02, SerialNo=WD-WMA9F1024079
  Config={ HardSect NotMFM HdSw>15uSec SpinMotCtl Fixed DTR>5Mbs FmtGapReq }
  RawCHS=16383/16/63, TrkSize=57600, SectSize=600, ECCbytes=40
  BuffType=DualPortCache, BuffSize=2048kB, MaxMultSect=16, MultSect=16
  CurCHS=16383/16/63, CurSects=16514064, LBA=yes, LBAsects=117231408
  IORDY=on/off, tPIO={min:120,w/IORDY:120}, tDMA={min:120,rec:120}
  PIO modes:  pio0 pio1 pio2 pio3 pio4
  DMA modes:  mdma0 mdma1 mdma2
  UDMA modes: udma0 udma1 udma2 udma3 udma4 *udma5
  AdvancedPM=no WriteCache=enabled
  Drive conforms to: device does not report version:  1 2 3 4 5

[belgarath:~]#  hdparm -d /dev/hdc

/dev/hdc:
  using_dma    =  1 (on)

-R



Pluimer, Randal T wrote:
> Is the controller set to Auto mode?
> If so it may be that the drive doesnt support "standard" DMA modes. Try
> setting it to a manual mode 3 or 4. (if the bios lets you)
>

configuration which allows to pass mail traffic through the
firewall and redirect it to the mail server behind the firewall.

a separate host as well.

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov 19 10:43:50 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 10:43:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <20021119051849.GB27602@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1037731430.1978.21.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2002-11-18 at 21:18, Russ Johnson wrote:
> Here's the situation.
> 
> I have a machine at home configured like so:
> 
> Athlon XP 1800+
> Soyo kt333 motherboard
> 512 mb RAM
> 40 gb hard drive
> 32 mb ATI video card
> DVD drive
> Creative CD-RW 12/10/32
> Mandrake 9.0
> 
> At work, I have the following configuration:
> 
> P4 2.4 ghz
> Dell mb (Sorry, it's a dell workstation. work bought it for me...)
> 1 gb RAM

What type of RAM?  I've seen a LOT of Dell's running very fast P4's with
only PC133 (SDRAM) memory (doesn't matter how much there is it is still
slow).  Talk about a huge waste of silicon.  Most of these will have the
stupid integrated video (sounds like yours doesn't though), that uses
system memory as video memory, another huge waste of silicon.  This
combination will make a 200MMX look fast.  This combination sells
because of the P4's impressive clock speed, not because of the actual
performance.

The Athlon is running DDR memory (the only memory the kt333 can use).

There may be more to it, but this is probably a factor.

> 40 gb hard drive
> 32 mb ATI video card
> cd/dvd/cdrw combo drive
> Mandrake 9.0
> 
> Here's the catch... The Athlon can handle more load than the P4. I'm
> writing this message while downloading files, burning a CD, listening to 
> mp3s, and untaring BIG tarballs. No problem at all. 
> 
> If I try this same thing at work, the system is EXTREMELY sluggish. The
> mouse pointer jumps instead of smoothly crossing the screen, I can't
> drag windows around. It's hard to get the mouse pointer to stop on the
> window bar, let alone on a corner...

This could also be a mouse configuration problem.

HTH

Derek Loree




From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 19 10:55:33 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 10:55:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Port redirection on a firewall ?
References: <200211191840.gAJIekn22714@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3DDA8925.6060907@sun.com>

For mail:

  $iptables -A FORWARD -i $if_ext -p tcp -d $host --dport 25 -j ACCEPT

http:

  $iptables -A FORWARD -i $if_ext -p tcp -d $host --dport 80 -j ACCEPT

Where $iptables is where `which iptables` shows up, $if_ext is your 
external (firewalled) interface, and $host is the machine you are 
routing to.

-R

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,

* Percival, Ray <Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com> [2002-11-19 08:24]:
> What hard drive is in the machine at work? I'm guessing you bought something nice while Dell tends to put cheap stuff in theirs. Also the Soyo is a pretty good chipset once again Dell not so much. The other reason is in almost everything except multimedia the Athlons tend to do better than the P4s. Also have you built a nice custom kernel for one and not for the other. Turning on processor support when building a kernel can make a *huge* difference.

The hard drive in the Athlon is an IBM, the one in the Dell is a Seagate
Cheetah. I have these same drives in other machines (not Dells) and they
are very speedy. Most of those machines are PIIIs with ASUS or Abit
motherboards. Throw in a few dual proc Tyans for good measure.

Hello Linux folkz,
I'm going to setup a secure file server.
If somebody tries to mount secure filesystem without
permission all attempts should fail.
In the situation then hard drive is taken from the server
all attempts to mirror the hard drive with secure filesystem
should fail as well or at least nobody can reach and read
that replicated data.
Could somebody advise me please what secure filesystem is available
for this task or in what direction I should look.
Any advises or sources of information are greatly appreciated.
 
Alex

make the mouse sluggish.  I really can't imagine any swapping going on. 
Harddrive speed will affect application startup time, file copies and
other read-write activities, but not the mouse movement or general
application usage.

Derek

My original post was more about general slowness and treating the mouse as a side effect of that.

But it is interesting that you should bring up the mouse. On my brand new Athlon system at home I have a USB trackball. When I was first setting it up I had some issues with getting the USB working right, a 2.4.19 configuration thing that I had a hard time finding, but in any case for a short time I had my trackball set up as a PS2 device and now that you mention it as a PS2 device the mouse sucked to the point of pain. Not sure if this helps but I have seen something similar.

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 11:43:01 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 11:43:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <1037733394.1979.30.camel@dereklinux>
References: <EX-20021119-102419-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
	 <20021119185941.GC15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	 <1037733394.1979.30.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <1037734981.30836.2.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 11:16, Derek Loree wrote:

> I don't see how, with 1Gig of RAM, the DMA state of the harddrive will
> make the mouse sluggish.  I really can't imagine any swapping going on. 
> Harddrive speed will affect application startup time, file copies and
> other read-write activities, but not the mouse movement or general
> application usage.

DMA doesn't directly speed up hard disk access so much as it may be
implied...

DMA reduces the amount of CPU power needed to access the hard drive.

If you're doing any kind of disk activity, your CPU utilization will
spike, and that can cause the mouse to jump around like was described.

In reducing the amount of CPU power used when doing anything with the
drive, DMA *does* speed up disk access, though.  I would guestimate as
CPU speeds increase, DMA vs non-DMA in terms of drive speed will become
less of an issue - but in overall system performance I think it will
remain relevant.

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 11:46:32 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 11:46:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Secure filesystem?
In-Reply-To: <200211191905.gAJJ5dP22802@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211191905.gAJJ5dP22802@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1037735192.30836.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 11:05, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linux folkz,
> I'm going to setup a secure file server.
> If somebody tries to mount secure filesystem without
> permission all attempts should fail.
> In the situation then hard drive is taken from the server
> all attempts to mirror the hard drive with secure filesystem
> should fail as well or at least nobody can reach and read
> that replicated data.
> Could somebody advise me please what secure filesystem is available
> for this task or in what direction I should look.
> Any advises or sources of information are greatly appreciated.

When making a new thread, it is nice to create a new post rather than
replying to an old one - your post comes up as a response to the "Regex
help requested" thread on my threaded mail client.  :-)

If you google about a bit, you should find information regarding both
encrypted file systems and loopback encrypted file systems - it is my
understanding the latter is more secure than the former.

Remember, though, that nothing is fool-proof.  There's always a way to
get at the data.

Oh, I think Mandrake (which is icky, imho) has native support for
encrypted filesystems (loopback and not).

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>

 69 processes: 68 sleeping, 1 running, 0 zombie, 0 stopped
 CPU states:  7.7% user,  7.1% system,  0.0% nice, 85.0% idle
 Mem:  1032932K av,  283892K used,  749040K free,       0K shrd, 11012K buff
 Swap:  248968K av,       0K used,  248968K free 203416K cached
  
I'm also running vmware with Win2k running in it, but that ran REALLY
nice on my PIII 800... 

It appears that adding "idebus=100" to lilo.conf in the append line has
helped somewhat, but I'm still unable to set UDMA or DMA mode to on with
hdparm. It returns, "not implimented" when I try.

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Nov 19 12:08:42 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 12:08:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <3DDA824F.7080009@sun.com>

What I get is:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -i /dev/hda

/dev/hda:

 Model=ST340016A, FwRev=3.75, SerialNo=3HSA3JWJ
 Config={ HardSect NotMFM HdSw>15uSec Fixed DTR>10Mbs RotSpdTol>.5% }
 RawCHS=16383/16/63, TrkSize=0, SectSize=0, ECCbytes=4
 BuffType=unknown, BuffSize=2048kB, MaxMultSect=16, MultSect=16
 CurCHS=16383/16/63, CurSects=16514064, LBA=yes, LBAsects=78165360
 IORDY=on/off, tPIO={min:240,w/IORDY:120}, tDMA={min:120,rec:120}
 PIO modes:  pio0 pio1 pio2 pio3 pio4 
 DMA modes:  mdma0 mdma1 mdma2 
 UDMA modes: udma0 udma1 udma2 udma3 udma4 *udma5 
 AdvancedPM=no WriteCache=enabled
 Drive conforms to: device does not report version:  1 2 3 4 5
	   
So, if I'm reading that correctly, the drive does support DMA. 

However, I get this when attempting to set DMA:

[root at ciclid root]# hdparm -d1 /dev/hda

/dev/hda:
setting using_dma to 1 (on)
HDIO_SET_DMA failed: Operation not permitted
using_dma    =  0 (off)
   
If I set any -X mode without the -d mode on, performance goes down.

In any mode, the best I've gotten is about 5 MB/sec.

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov 19 12:19:33 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 12:19:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <1037734981.30836.2.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <EX-20021119-102419-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
	 <20021119185941.GC15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	 <1037733394.1979.30.camel@dereklinux>
	 <1037734981.30836.2.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1037737172.1978.46.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 11:43, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 11:16, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > I don't see how, with 1Gig of RAM, the DMA state of the harddrive will
> > make the mouse sluggish.  I really can't imagine any swapping going on. 
> > Harddrive speed will affect application startup time, file copies and
> > other read-write activities, but not the mouse movement or general
> > application usage.
> 
> DMA doesn't directly speed up hard disk access so much as it may be
> implied...

DMA66 or DMA100 will be a lot faster than any non-DMA mode.
> 
> DMA reduces the amount of CPU power needed to access the hard drive.
> 
> If you're doing any kind of disk activity, your CPU utilization will
> spike, and that can cause the mouse to jump around like was described.

On any machine running a 500Mhz processor or better, the spike will be
small enough that the mouse should have lots of cycles left for itself.
> 
> In reducing the amount of CPU power used when doing anything with the
> drive, DMA *does* speed up disk access, though.  I would guestimate as
> CPU speeds increase, DMA vs non-DMA in terms of drive speed will become
> less of an issue - but in overall system performance I think it will
> remain relevant.

>From personal experience, DMA mode makes a huge difference (in how fast
apps load and other drive access stuff), whether the processor is a 500,
or a 1300. Mouse behavior did not depend on the drive access mode.

Derek




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 19 12:22:50 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 12:22:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211191000300.12505-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191221330.19611-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> How about /^mail\.com/.  I'm guessing postfix peels the doamin out of the 
> address - everything after the @ so this would only match mail.com

Rod,

  Postfix reads (and processes) one line at a time. The caret (^) means
'beginning of line', so that won't work here. It's a regex string match
process going on.

Thanks much,

Rich




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Nov 19 12:34:54 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 12:34:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why is it slower on a P4?
In-Reply-To: <20021119195744.GD15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
References: <EX-20021119-102419-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
	<20021119185941.GC15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
	<1037733394.1979.30.camel@dereklinux>
	<1037734122.23378.3.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name> 
	<20021119195744.GD15077@sthelens.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1037738094.23407.43.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Russ,

Thanks for the hard numers!

It looks to me the same as it does to you... everything checks out,
except, of course, the responsiveness of the machine. and found this:

I looked at the UDMA mini-howto and found this
(http://leuksman.com/linux/Ultra-DMA-8.html):

  ``Normally, a UDMA-aware kernel will automatically enable UDMA support
for drives and interfaces that support it. In most cases that it
doesn't, the kernel either doesn't know how to drive your IDE chipset
(get yourself a patch, see above) or doesn't believe it is safe to
enable it (meaning you shouldn't!).''

When one follows the link to the patch, I get this for hdparam:

``UDMA support is provided for at least the following chipsets, and
probably many more I don't know about:''

  All Intel chipsets: FX, HX, VX, TX, LX
  All SiS chipsets (only SiS5598 tested, but this entire family of 

At this point a caviet: This documentation may be a bit dated. 

I then went out to look at what your motherboard chipset might be.
ExtremeTech tells me that if it's a Dell Dimention then it probably has
an Intel 845E chipset.

Off to http://groups.google.com to search for `Linux UDMA 845E.'

Bingo!

There's a patch for this. Also, there's tons of information about
hdparam in regard to the Intel chipsets!

Best,


Cooper

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 19 12:28:47 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 12:28:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021119-120040-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191223340.19611-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:

> Having said that my advice may be a bit extreme. Why not block hotmail. In
> this day and age who really uses hotmail or Yahoo or anything else like it
> for real mail anymore. And if you have friends or whoever that do just put
> them in a "whitelist" and block the rest. But as you can see from the
> above there is a large portion of the species I just don't want to talk
> to. But that's just me.

  There are two problems with this approach -- for me, at least. First, I
deal with lots of digitally challenged folks who use these services because
they're free or because they don't know any better. Not all these people are
bad or not worth communications. I also have clients with accounts at these
domains.

  Second, I have postfix check the entire set of headers because spammers
frequently direct their dreck to my secondary mail server (at my ISP) rather
than directly to me. This also means that a message sent to me as well as to
other folks may have hotmail, yahoo or aol in the header because that's
where other recipients get their mail. No reason to block mail to me because
others are also on the "To: " list.

Rich

  I pondered this, but realized that there may well be a closing parenthesis
after the address, or some other symbol. That's why I didn't use the end of
line metacharacter.

  If this had a simple solution I'm sure I would have stumbled over it by
now. :-)

Thanks,

Rich





From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Tue Nov 19 12:33:36 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 13:33:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Secure filesystem?
References: <200211191931.gAJJVLp22865@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3DDAA020.40602@coyotesong.com>

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> The problem is that people whos data is stored on this file server
> have no clue how to encrypt/decrypt their data files.
> They are typical M$ drones.
> If you can somehow retrieve encrypted data files and brake encryption
> even on one file, all other files of that particular user are
> accessable.
> Is there any better solution?

You need to define your problem better.  This is a proverbial bag-o-goop 
  - if you push hard on one thing (e.g., having files individually 
protected), you're going to be pushed back elsewhere (e.g., requiring 
the users to be clueful).

The first question is why are you seeking to do this?  Are you, per 
chance, trying to comply with HIPAA? :-)  If you're motivated by 
external requirements, it may be better to ask how others are solving 
this specific problem instead of asking about a generic solution.

The second question is if you're comingling requirements.  Do you really 
need to have combined encryption and access control?  Or can you 
separate them - handle encryption entirely on a closed file server 
(protecting the disk from mirroring), and use standard access control 
tools to limit access?  Or do you need to protect the data in transit, 
which means you need something like NFS-over-SSH or SMB+SSL?  Or perhaps 
you can use a standard file server since the files are stored and sent 
in ciphertext, and all decryption is done by the individual client.

Finally (for now), it also sounds like you may be looking for an 
analogue to the per-file encryption in W2K.  At least, what they 
advertise it to be - I think there's some question about how well they 
implement it.  (If you're not familiar with it, I believe the filesystem 
is extended to include support for public key crypto - each user has 
their private key bound to them, and protected files have their 
symmetric encryption key encrypted with authorized user's public keys, 
so you get transparent access to encrypted files.  Sorta like GnuPG 
pushed into the FS layer.

Bear




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 12:37:50 2002

Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Nov 19 12:56:54 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 12:56:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 19 Nov 2002 12:31:36 PST."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191229260.19611-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <200211192056.gAJKus217672@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> 
> > If you anchor the end, /@mail\.com$/ then it should do the right
> > thing.
>  
> Colin,
> 
>   I pondered this, but realized that there may well be a closing parenthesis
> after the address, or some other symbol. That's why I didn't use the end of
> line metacharacter.
> 

It sounds like you need something like /@mail\.com\([^a-zA-Z0-9.-]\|$\)/

I'm not familiar with the regex's used in postfix, so I don't know
whether this will actually work.  The intent is to match mail.com either
when it is followed by either a character which is not valid in a domain name
or end of line.

galen






From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue Nov 19 12:56:26 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 12:56:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Cooper" == Cooper Stevenson <cooper at linux-enterprise.net> writes:

Cooper> find $1 | while read file
Cooper> name
Cooper> do
Cooper>  print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$filename"'</A><BR>' >> $output_file
Cooper> done

Evil.  No HTML escaping.

touch '<blink>'; # ARGGGH!

Better thing in Perl:

    use CGI qw(:all :no_debug);
    use File::Find;
    chdir "/web/pic/" or die;
    open STDOUT, ">my_index.html";
    print start_html;
    find sub {
      print a({href => $File::Find::name}, escapeHTML($File::Find::name)), br;
    }, ".";
    print end_html;

--

<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!


From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Nov 19 13:03:22 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 13:03:22 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191229260.19611-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191258180.3266-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> 
> > If you anchor the end, /@mail\.com$/ then it should do the right
> > thing.
>
> I pondered this, but realized that there may well be a closing
> parenthesis after the address, or some other symbol. That's why I
> didn't use the end of line metacharacter.

How about

  /[@\.]mail\.com/

Or, if these regexes are perl-compatible

  /[@\.]mail\.com\b/

That'd catch anything from @mail.com or .mail.com, and rule out 
hotmail.com, etc.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> chance, trying to comply with HIPAA? :-)  If you're motivated by 
> external requirements, it may be better to ask how others are
solving 
> this specific problem instead of asking about a generic solution.

I'm not trying to comply with anything. This solution should solve
data security problems in some business operations.


> The second question is if you're comingling requirements.  Do you
really 
> need to have combined encryption and access control?  Or can you 
> separate them - handle encryption entirely on a closed file server 
> (protecting the disk from mirroring), and use standard access
control 
> tools to limit access?  Or do you need to protect the data in
transit, 
> which means you need something like NFS-over-SSH or SMB+SSL?  Or
perhaps 
> you can use a standard file server since the files are stored and
sent 
> in ciphertext, and all decryption is done by the individual client.

Imagine situation, when burglars,FBI,CIA or other crooks are breaking
into your office and taking your server or hard drive away to look
into your secret data files.
What method of data protection should be chosen in this situation
besides glueing a brick of dynamite to the each hard drive? :)
Securing data in transit is also very important, but there are many
different concepts were developed already to cover this area.

Alex

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 13:37:03 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:37:03 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Secure filesystem?
Message-ID: <EX-20021119-154134-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Alex,

Crypto is the answer to the questions you have asked. Learn how to use it and implement it. If the data is that important you will have to educate your lusers anyway. 

-----Original Message-----
From: Alex Daniloff 
Sent: Tuesday, November 19, 2002 1:38 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] Secure filesystem?


Hello,

> 
> The first question is why are you seeking to do this?  Are you, per 
> chance, trying to comply with HIPAA? :-)  If you're motivated by 
> external requirements, it may be better to ask how others are
solving 
> this specific problem instead of asking about a generic solution.
> 

I'm not trying to comply with anything. This solution should solve
data security problems in some business operations.


> The second question is if you're comingling requirements.  Do you
really 
> need to have combined encryption and access control?  Or can you 
> separate them - handle encryption entirely on a closed file server 
> (protecting the disk from mirroring), and use standard access
control 
> tools to limit access?  Or do you need to protect the data in
transit, 
> which means you need something like NFS-over-SSH or SMB+SSL?  Or
perhaps 
> you can use a standard file server since the files are stored and
sent 
> in ciphertext, and all decryption is done by the individual client.

Imagine situation, when burglars,FBI,CIA or other crooks are breaking
into your office and taking your server or hard drive away to look
into your secret data files.
What method of data protection should be chosen in this situation
besides glueing a brick of dynamite to the each hard drive? :)
Securing data in transit is also very important, but there are many
different concepts were developed already to cover this area.

Alex

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

> or end of line.

		/@mail\.com.*$/

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Nov 19 14:47:44 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 14:47:44 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191402370.19913-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211191443260.12343-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:
> 
> > It sounds like you need something like /@mail\.com\([^a-zA-Z0-9.-]\|$\)/
> > 
> > I'm not familiar with the regex's used in postfix, so I don't know
> > whether this will actually work.  The intent is to match mail.com either
> > when it is followed by either a character which is not valid in a domain name
> > or end of line.
>  
> galen,
> 
>   Aha! Extrapolating from your example above, I get
> 		/@mail\.com.*$/
> 
>   Let me think about this; perhaps I'll give it a try.

Woah!  Where do you get THAT?  THat's not extrapolated from his answer
above.  That still matches the previous example of "mail.computers.com" or
"mail.communicator.net".  You want to match mail.com ONLY when it's
followed by a illegal domain character or an end of line.

Note the carat at the beginning of the bracketted phrase.  This means NOT
one of those characters.  So if mail.com is followed by a character that
is not one of the characters you can put in a domain name, then the end of
the domain name has been reached and you've started on something else
(like a delmiter of some kind) OR the end of the line, which the |$
catches.

Dig?

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Nov 19 14:48:17 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 14:48:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] mpg123 for RH 8
Message-ID: <3DDABFB1.80C057E5@attbi.com>

Red Hat 8.0 does not include mpg123 due to mp3 the restrictions on the
mp3 technology. So, my new install of RH 8.0 won't play my mp3
collection. No problem. I'll just download the source, compile and
install it, and I'm back to where I was.

Did that, but the sound quality is choppy.

The source of the problem is not clear to me. I've noticed that RH 8.0
does more paging than RH 7.0 did on the same hardware (Pentium 200 MMX,
64 Mb RAM). With only two terminal windows open, one running top, and
the other from which I launched mpg123, top shows from 54.1% to 78.6%
idle.

Any idea what the problem is?

The version of mpg123 I downloaded and installed is mpg123-0.59r.

There is an rpm file on my RH 7.0 CD, mpg123-0.59r-8.i386.rpm. Would I
have been able to install that on RH 8.0? Should I have. It's not clear
to me whether it would have made a difference. If it might, will
installing it override the version I just installed?

Thanks for any ideas. (Suggestions that I should be using oog instead of
mp3 are fine, but I have all these mp3 files. I'd consider switching,
assuming that would make a difference in the quality of the sound, if
there is a way to convert mp3 files to oog.)

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 15:01:01 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 17:01:01 -0600
