Ah yes converting MP3 to ogg. Don't do it both a lossy formats and they are lossy in different ways. This means that a file converted from MP3 to ogg will sound like crap. OTOH rip all your new stuff in ogg. It produces smaller files that , to me, sound just as good or better. I'm far from a golden ear though. 

I can't speak to rpms but if this was a deb the answer would be that you most likely would be able to. But I don't think that will solve your problem. What might given the info you have thrown out is applying the low latency patch and building yourself a shiny new kernel.

From nknight at pocketinet.com  Tue Nov 19 15:14:00 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:14:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] mpg123 for RH 8
In-Reply-To: <3DDABFB1.80C057E5@attbi.com>
References: <3DDABFB1.80C057E5@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211191514.00874.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Tuesday 19 November 2002 02:48 pm, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Did that, but the sound quality is choppy.

As I'm not using RH, I haven't really looked into it, but apparently something 
about RH8's kernel is causing CPU usage issues with certain applications 
(mostly games, it seems). Might be related, dunno.

> Thanks for any ideas. (Suggestions that I should be using oog instead of
> mp3 are fine, but I have all these mp3 files. I'd consider switching,
> assuming that would make a difference in the quality of the sound, if
> there is a way to convert mp3 files to oog.)

If you do start moving to ogg, don't convert from mp3. There are utilities to 
do it, but both are lossy formats, and the quality will end up, at best, the 
same as the original mp3, but likely worse than if you'd left them as mp3's.

That said, ogg does produce higher quality sound at the same bitrates, if 
you're encoding straight from the source (the CD). It also uses good VBR 
techniques to further reduce filesize without sacrificing quality.

The main drawback to ogg, aside from lack of widespread adoption, is that 
current decoders are slower than those for mp3. This might be an issue 
considering you're only on a P200. Encoding is slower, too, but that's a 
one-time penalty.



From jon at manymoons.net  Tue Nov 19 15:07:06 2002
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 15:07:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Inspirion 8200

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 10:04, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 04:36, Jon Jacob wrote:
> > I am considering buying a Dell Inspirion 8200.  Does anyone have any
> > experience with this machine, even with windows, that they might want to
> > share.  I am a RedHat user, so if you use RedHat it would be good to
> > hear what you know.
> 
> I don't know about OSS-free drivers, but the ALSA drivers for the sound
> chip in the 8200 are lacking.  It uses the i8x0 driver, as does a
> bajillion other chips (including my nForce), so they have a hard time
> implamenting anything for it.  If you do any sound recording either line
> in or mic doesn't work.  There's also no hardware mixing support in the
> alsa drivers - although the hardware itself seems to support it.  I
> believe there are OSS drivers (free or commercial - I don't recall) that
> say they support hardware mixing (multiple audio streams) but in
> reality, the guy whose email I read said it didn't work.
> 
> That's about all I know about the 8200... it looks like a good laptop. 
> I plan on buying one (or something similar) after I have a little bit of
> cash.  :-)
> 
> Rob
-- 
Jon Jacob <jon at manymoons.net>

From revans at e-z.net  Tue Nov 19 15:20:04 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:20:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
In-Reply-To: <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
    <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <20021119234708.TDIW21905.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

I googled HTML escaping because I didn't understand what the issue was. I found
an example CGI and following by example I thought this would work. Does this
cover the issue or are there other characters that break the output? It seems
to deal with <BLINK> correctly.

find $1 | while read filename ; do
		htmlfilename=`print $filename | sed -e 's/&/\&amp;/g'  -e
's/\"/\&quot;/g' -e 's/>/\&gt;/g' -e 's/</\&lt;/g'`
		print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$htmlfilename"'</A><BR>' |
grep blink >> $output_file
done



On 19 Nov 2002 12:56:26 -0800, Randal L. Schwartz said:

> >>>>> "Cooper" == Cooper Stevenson <cooper at linux-enterprise.net> writes:
>  
>  Cooper> find $1 | while read file
>  Cooper> name
>  Cooper> do
>  Cooper>  print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$filename"'</A><BR>' >> $output_file
>  Cooper> done
>  
>  Evil.  No HTML escaping.
>  
>  touch '<blink>'; # ARGGGH!
>  
>  Better thing in Perl:
>  
>      use CGI qw(:all :no_debug);
>      use File::Find;
>      chdir "/web/pic/" or die;
>      open STDOUT, ">my_index.html";
>      print start_html;
>      find sub {
>        print a({href => $File::Find::name}, escapeHTML($File::Find::name)), br;
>      }, ".";
>      print end_html;
>  




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Tue Nov 19 15:49:45 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:49:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] limiting simultaneous logins in Samba
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191507060.25594-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191547180.28577-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Eric Harrison wrote:
>
>I'm trying to figure out a way to keep people from logging to a samba
>server from several different workstations (i.e. only one concurrent login
>per user).
>
>Setting maxlogins in /etc/security/limits.conf does not do the trick and
>I'm not having much luck googling it.
>
>Any ideas on how to do this?
>
>-Eric

I found what I was looking for... by default Samba ignores the PAM account
and session management. Adding the following line to the globals section
of the smb.conf changes this behavior:

	obey pam restrictions = yes

-Eric




From revans at e-z.net  Tue Nov 19 15:22:31 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:22:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021119-164607-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

Russell

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002 16:43:42 -0600, Percival, Ray said:

> OK I am a full on misanthrope but how do you get class warfare out of that list? I block all of them because they are the source of a great deal of all spam. AOL, MSN, and Earthlink are by no means cheap. Really the only reason I block Earthlink is because so many people use it. I also block a *bunch* of other neblocks.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Nov 19 15:59:44 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:59:44 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
In-Reply-To: <EX-20021119-164607-0002@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211191544020.13236-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 19 Nov 2002, Percival, Ray wrote:
> OK I am a full on misanthrope but how do you get class warfare out of
> that list? I block all of them because they are the source of a great
> deal of all spam. AOL, MSN, and Earthlink are by no means cheap.

Do you really think poor people always buy the cheapest thing?  Check out
the clothes the kids working at your local Taco Bell are wearing.

Consider that these are the largest ISPs and most people have them because
of some false economy from promotions (free 1025 hours, free with PC
purchase, etc.) or inundation through media combined with poor education
and a lack of access to the technical elite.

The perceived necessity of high cost goods and services is one of the
methods by which the poor are kept poor.

The vast majority of the people who use the services you block are poor.  
The reasons WHY that is are actually irrelevant.  The point is that you
are primarily blocking poor people.

> I also block a *bunch* of other neblocks.

Right, like asia and africa where poor brown people live.

> So no I have nothing against poor people having been poor for more
> than a few years I know it sucks.

You know that it sucks to be poor, but that doesn't prove you have nothing
against them.  Hell, you openly state your contempt for all humanity (and
I'm not even going into the self-loathing aspect of misanthropy).

> Now if you want to get into a conversation about welfare I'd think we
> would have radically differing onions.

I can guess your view, certainly.  A misanthrope would have no interest at
all in improving the welfare of people.

J.

as a preexec script, but that sounds much better! :-) I'll try it out.

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 19 16:09:10 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 16:09:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211191544020.13236-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3DDAD2A6.6000504@sun.com>

Dude, take it OFF of the main list.

Regardless of what you may think his reasoning is, the fact remains that 
those ISP's, AND those countries are where a great majority of the spam 
comes from.

People build their regexps based on the amount and type of spam they get 
from each location, not due to regional demographics.  I wouldn't block 
aracnet.com because they cater to 'middle income white people in the 
portland/metro area', I'd block them because AND ONLY because they were 
(hypothetically, of course) spamming my email account.  That's IT.  End 
of story.

Stop trying to read things into why people do the things they do. 
People are chaotic.  We don't have to HAVE a reason.  If we don't like 
it, it goes into the bit bucket.

Sheesh.

-R


Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> ### alot of nonsense, as usual ###




From Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com  Tue Nov 19 16:16:50 2002
From: Ray.Percival at summit.fiserv.com (Percival, Ray)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 18:16:50 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] regex help requested
Message-ID: <EX-20021119-181900-0001@exchange.fiserv-missive1.fiserv.net>

You may have a point about the AOL and MSN thing. I've never thought about that.
As for Asia I've lived there for at least 4 years since 1990 and my wife is Asian therefore making my children half-Asian. The reason I block Asia and Africa is simply because they have so many open relays and thus a large percentage of spam comes from those two places.

I have offered to help people I know there close these relays they simply are not interested. Leaving me with no choice but to block. Now there are clear reasons also why all of these things tend to generate spam. Let me just say this again. I block these things because that tends to be where spam comes from until your post I had never thought about the poor aspect. It is interesting but not really important to me.

As for welfare I'm all for improving the welfare of people because in the long run it helps me and means they will tend to leave me alone. I'm just not for giving them welfare mostly because from what I've seen that does nothing to improve their welfare. 

So accusing me of hating poor people is wrong I hate spammers. I also happen to have no desire to communicate with people I don't already know. This makes it easy for me to implement aggressive filtering.

From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Tue Nov 19 16:45:06 2002
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 16:45:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] limiting simultaneous logins in Samba
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191547180.28577-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0211191547180.28577-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <1037753106.31069.6.camel@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 15:49, Eric Harrison wrote:
> I found what I was looking for... by default Samba ignores the PAM account
> and session management. Adding the following line to the globals section
> of the smb.conf changes this behavior:
> 
> 	obey pam restrictions = yes

As per the samba docs:

http://us6.samba.org/samba/ftp/docs/htmldocs/smb.conf.5.html#OBEYPAMRESTRICTIONS

"Note that Samba always ignores PAM for authentication in the case of
encrypt passwords = yes  . The reason is that PAM modules cannot support
the challenge/response authentication mechanism needed in the presence
of SMB password encryption."

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Tue Nov 19 17:09:59 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 17:09:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEIDMAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Hello, pluggers!

First off, I was impressed with the turnout at the clinic. That was ver'
kewl to see that kind of response.

That said, I need help, dagnabbit!

I'm trying to set up VPN on our network. I've got Mandrake 9.0 for the
server and Win2k clients. I've also got FreeS/Wan on the server, and IPSEC
looks like it's up and running - ipsec verify returns everything hunky.

I have a Hawking firewall and it (supposedly) passes VPN traffic just fine.
I had VPN installed on our last server (NT4) and VPN worked just fine.

When I try to VPN locally from my machine, I get no answer (error 678).

Any tips/tricks/pointers/help on getting Win2k clients to VPN into a Linux
server?

Thanks in advance,

From revans at e-z.net  Tue Nov 19 16:57:17 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 16:57:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
In-Reply-To: <20021119234708.TDIW21905.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org><86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
    <20021119234708.TDIW21905.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>
Message-ID: <20021120012418.YOZI1052.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@linux>

I forgot to take out the grep for BLINK I was using for testing this. 

find $1 | while read filename ; do
	htmlfilename=`print $filename | sed -e 's/&/\&amp;/g'  \
		-e 's/\"/\&quot;/g' -e 's/>/\&gt;/g' -e 's/</\&lt;/g'`
	print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$htmlfilename"'</A><BR>' >>
$output_file
done

Thank you 
Russell


On Tue, 19 Nov 2002 15:20:04 -0800, Russell Evans said:

> I googled HTML escaping because I didn't understand what the issue was. I found
>  an example CGI and following by example I thought this would work. Does this
>  cover the issue or are there other characters that break the output? It seems
>  to deal with <BLINK> correctly.
>  
>  find $1 | while read filename ; do
>  		htmlfilename=`print $filename | sed -e 's/&/\&amp;/g'  -e
>  's/\"/\&quot;/g' -e 's/>/\&gt;/g' -e 's/</\&lt;/g'`
>  		print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$htmlfilename"'</A><BR>' |
>  grep blink >> $output_file
>  done
>  
>  
>  
>  On 19 Nov 2002 12:56:26 -0800, Randal L. Schwartz said:
>  
>  > >>>>> "Cooper" == Cooper Stevenson <cooper at linux-enterprise.net> writes:
>  >  
>  >  Cooper> find $1 | while read file
>  >  Cooper> name
>  >  Cooper> do
>  >  Cooper>  print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$filename"'</A><BR>' >> $output_file
>  >  Cooper> done
>  >  
>  >  Evil.  No HTML escaping.
>  >  
>  >  touch '<blink>'; # ARGGGH!
>  >  
>  >  Better thing in Perl:
>  >  
>  >      use CGI qw(:all :no_debug);
>  >      use File::Find;
>  >      chdir "/web/pic/" or die;
>  >      open STDOUT, ">my_index.html";
>  >      print start_html;
>  >      find sub {
>  >        print a({href => $File::Find::name}, escapeHTML($File::Find::name)), br;
>  >      }, ".";
>  >      print end_html;
>  >  
>  
>  
>  _______________________________________________
>  PLUG mailing list
>  PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
>  http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov 19 17:26:59 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 17:26:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEIDMAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEIDMAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1037755618.1978.63.camel@dereklinux>

Hi Michael,

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 17:09, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Hello, pluggers!
> 
> First off, I was impressed with the turnout at the clinic. That was ver'
> kewl to see that kind of response.
> 
> That said, I need help, dagnabbit!
> 
> I'm trying to set up VPN on our network. I've got Mandrake 9.0 for the
> server and Win2k clients. I've also got FreeS/Wan on the server, and IPSEC
> looks like it's up and running - ipsec verify returns everything hunky.

I tried this, and couldn't get it work, everything claimed to be
installed and functioning, but it still wouldn't work.  After a week of
not getting it to work, I gave up.  There are other VPN implementations
out there.
> 
> I have a Hawking firewall and it (supposedly) passes VPN traffic just fine.
> I had VPN installed on our last server (NT4) and VPN worked just fine.

The Windows implementation of VPN (uses Microsoft protocol, PPTP) is
very different from the FreeSwan implementation (uses ipsec, which must
be installed on the clients).  For the Windows version, I use PopTop
(check Source Forge) on the linux server and the native Windows
"Dial-up" VPN.  The drawback to this is the use of the GRE internet
protocol, which some firewalls have a tough time forwarding, and only
one GRE tunnel can be forwarded through a firewall at a time.


HTH

Derek Loree




From mikel at quantecllc.com  Tue Nov 19 17:40:42 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 17:40:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <1037755618.1978.63.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOMEIEMAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

I think that may be what we have, as the firewall docs say I can only have
one VPN user at a time. I'm possibly looking at getting a Cisco router
instead of the Firewall that we have, so I dunno...

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Tue Nov 19 18:48:07 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 19:48:07 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Secure filesystem?
References: <200211192137.gAJLb2B23106@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3DDAF7E7.80803@coyotesong.com>

Alex Daniloff wrote:
> I'm not trying to comply with anything. This solution should solve
> data security problems in some business operations.

I understand that, but if you get 3 people together you'll have at least 
4 different opinions on what the "data security problems" are.  We need 
to know what YOU consider to be the problem before we can give specific 
advice.

> Imagine situation, when burglars,FBI,CIA or other crooks are breaking
> into your office and taking your server or hard drive away to look
> into your secret data files.

If you're worried about the FBI or CIA, I'm not sure how much I want to 
help.... It's not that I trust them, but if they have a search warrant 
they can demand the decryption key and search the disk anyway.  If you 
want to prevent this, you want to be ready to commit obstruction of 
justice and that makes me wonder why.

At the same time, I fully understand the need to protect legally 
confidential material (financial, medical, etc.  People have found 
highly sensitive material, e.g., names and HIV test results, on 
discarded disks) or trade secrets from competitors and have no problem 
helping you protect this information.

(BTW, if you're serious you'll also store the disk's serial number 
inyour safe.  Why should the bad guys bother stealing your disk, copying 
it, and then risking getting it back into your machine when they could 
just swap in a bad disk?)

Anyway, this means your solution must involve one of the on-disk 
encryption approaches.  I tend to favor the loopback filesystem with 
encryption, but once mounted anyone with access to your filesystem can 
see all of the files on the encrypted disk, modulo the regular 
permissions.  Others prefer the CFS approach, which uses a specialized 
NFS server, since it doesn't make the contents available to everyone on 
the system and it doesn't require you to set aside dedicated space for 
it.  (That also means that somebody can immediately identify all of the 
space consumed by encrypted files - with the loopback device you don't 
know if an encrypted GB partition is empty or full.)

The other concern is that you need to be able to export whatever 
solution you use.  I think a "loopback" approach is much lower than a 
CFS approach - you can probably export a loopback FS via NFS or Samba, 
but may not be able to do so with CFS.  But I could easily be wrong 
about this.  (As a rule "like can't export like," so I doubt NFS can 
export a partition mounted by NFS/CFS.)

> Securing data in transit is also very important, but there are many
> different concepts were developed already to cover this area.

That's not the only concern.  What about somebody who copies the 
exported files to ZIP disk or CD-R file on the client system?  Or email 
a copy of the file to somebody outside of the company?  It makes no 
sense to install a heavy steel door while you leave the windows wide open.

Bear

but keep coming up with this error /dev/<whatever> is not a valid block
device. Two questions arise

1).  What am I doing wrong.
2).  Is NTFS supported?  I'm asking because I'm not sure if I have an
ntfs partition on this drive or fat32.

Robbert van Andel

> > connection that I can put on my linux machine.  I'm wondering if this is

> whatever.

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue Nov 19 21:24:42 2002
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 21:24:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting USB drive
In-Reply-To: <1037766340.1537.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1037680617.2121.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
        <64522.12.231.181.15.1037682943.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
        <1037766340.1537.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <36427.209.210.31.3.1037769882.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> I checked into the website.  According to the documentation there, my
> machine is seeing the attached drive in /proc/bus/usb/devices.  Now I am
> having trouble mounting it.  I have tried several different iterations
> but keep coming up with this error /dev/<whatever> is not a valid block
> device. Two questions arise
>
> 1).  What am I doing wrong.
> 2).  Is NTFS supported?  I'm asking because I'm not sure if I have an
> ntfs partition on this drive or fat32.

This is what I had to do to get my USB drive working:

Had to fdisk it first.  Note this will destroy any data you have on the
drive.  While it seems that you should be able to mount an NTFS or FAT32
partition, you'll need support for those file systems in your kernel. 
When I compiled this kernel I thought I was smart and didn't include it. 
Heh can't even read a dos-formatted floppy doh!

So in my machine the usb drive shows up under /dev/sda, therefore:
fdisk /dev/sda
Make a small partition to start out with, perhaps 1GB.  For some reason on
my drive when I try to use make the partition fill to the drive maximum
size, it tends to hang during fdisk and didn't even complete overnight. 
If I make it even say just 1GB smaller than the 40GB capacity, it fdisks
in about 5 minutes or less.

Next you have to make a filesystem.  Of course you must have the chosen
filesystem support in your kernel.  I recommend ext3fs using the following
command:
mke2fs -j /dev/sda1
Note that sda1 is the partition you just got done making in fdisk.

Finally you have to mount it.  So pick a place to mount the drive, I used
/mnt/usbhd,
mkdir /mnt/usbhd
mount -t auto /dev/sda1 /mnt/usbhd/

That worked for me.  It is actually a usb2.0 hard drive that is
bass-ackwards compatible with 1.1.  It seems to function okay, is pretty
slow, and is subject to what appear to be strange timeouts.  However have
found that if I am patient, the timeouts will eventually complete.

Hope this helps.

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue Nov 19 22:14:38 2002
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue, 19 Nov 2002 22:14:38 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting USB drive
In-Reply-To: <1037770295.1744.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1037680617.2121.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
        <64522.12.231.181.15.1037682943.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
        <1037766340.1537.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
        <36427.209.210.31.3.1037769882.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
        <1037770295.1744.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <36586.209.210.31.3.1037772878.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> Thanks for the help. I do want to preserve the data on the disk.  Is
> there anyway to do this without losing the data on the drive.  I can
> mount a dos floppy disk, so that shouldn't be an issue.
>

Then try just this part:
mkdir /mnt/usbhd
mount -t auto /dev/sda1 /mnt/usbhd/

See what that does for you.  The auto should (assuming your kernel can
read it) mount the drive automagically.  If it doesn't, then my guess is
that the kernel needs that filesystem support loaded in.  The file system
has nothing to do with usb drivers; usb doesn't much care about
filesystems.  It all depends on whether your kernel has the right smarts
to read whatever the drive formatted as.  Save yourself the trouble of
guessing and check the drive on your windows machine; I can't recall how
but it should be very easy to determine under file explorer (right-click
and properties I think).

Someone here with more knowledge than I can tell you how to determine what
filesystem support your kernel already has.

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Tue Nov 19 23:07:49 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 19 Nov 2002 23:07:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting USB drive
In-Reply-To: <1037773758.1670.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1037680617.2121.6.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <64522.12.231.181.15.1037682943.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>
	 <1037766340.1537.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <36427.209.210.31.3.1037769882.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
	 <1037770295.1744.10.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <36586.209.210.31.3.1037772878.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
	 <1037773758.1670.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1037776068.32372.19.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-11-19 at 22:29, Robbert van Andel wrote:

> I'm doing it the hard way now by taking another hard drive making it
> master, reinstalling windows on it and then taking the data of my
> original master drive (which I've made slave) because it'll take less
> time than figuring out th USB or IEEE 1394 mounting issue.  It's
> interesting that there is very little documentation on the 'net about
> mounting a usb drive.  When I have some more time, I will try to figure
> it out.  Perhaps I will have better luck with the IEEE 1394 card I have
> on my other computer.

I think USB drive support is new or has just changed in the kernel or
something similar - I thought I read something about it somewhere, but
can't remember specifics.

I haven't been following the thread closely, but I got the jist that you
couldn't mount it - because you didn't have information about it... the
filesystem or the actual location on the /dev tree.

Since you didn't know if there was NTFS support or not in Linux, I'm
assuming you didn't compile your own kernel.  Try modprobe ntfs and see
if you get any errors... if not, bam, you have NTFS support.  FAT
support, I would think, would be compiled in ... if not, I'll bet it
autoloads.

Now run fdisk /dev/sda as root.  Your disto may have your CD-ROM (or RW
or DVD) drive loaded as ide-scsi emulation, so if that fails, try
/dev/sdb, then c, or d, etc.  If it launches with no errors, hit p to
print the partition table - that should give you your format type and
your location on the dev tree.

Then just go from there... mount it as you would any other hard disk. 
:-)

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Nov 19 23:11:02 2002

> Does anyone know what this might mean from dmesg?
> 
> (scsi1:A:5:1): parity error detected in Data-in phase. SEQADDR(0x6f)
> SCSIRATE(0x93)
> (scsi1:A:5:1): parity error detected in Data-in phase. SEQADDR(0x71)
> SCSIRATE(0x93)
> 
> My console is flooded with these messages when I startup my backup
> software and I'm not able to access the tape library from the ARCserve web
> interface.  When I turn off the tape library or stop the software, the
> messages stop.
>

> Quantum Superloader (SDLT) attached to the card, BrightStor ARCserve 7
> Backup for Linux.
> 

Is this a new setup?  Perhaps the tape drive has parity disabled.  I 
would also try reseating all the connectors.  Make certain both ends
of the bus are properly terminated.

galen






From alexlinux at qwest.net  Tue Nov 19 21:27:50 2002
From: alexlinux at qwest.net (alex)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 00:27:50 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: OpenOffice default paper size
Message-ID: <1037770070.4258.4.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>

Here's an update to the paper size from way back when on the 26th of
September this year.

There are 3 places that you need to change the paper size at in order
for this to work but work it will.

Anthony Schlemmer wrote....

according to: http://www.jca.umbc.edu/FAQ_Computing.html

"There is no way (AFAIK) that a user can change their default page
 size. But the SysAdmin may do so by editting the file:

/path/to/OpenOffice/share/psprint/psprint.conf

In this file, look for the parameter: PPD_PageSize . Set it to an
appropriate value, like Letter."


The file is nicely commented; changing it worked great on my
 installation

From matchboy at tearitalldown.com  Wed Nov 20 06:17:08 2002
From: matchboy at tearitalldown.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 06:17:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Nov 20 09:51:47 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 09:51:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] 200Gig /home
In-Reply-To: <B6YB43ICUPVRYX93MHRLC0ZUPNLLI.3ddbc7be@mike>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211200947590.4648-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> What can I do to get this much space in a single partition?

* stripe a few drives together in a raid array

* use lvm or evms to lump multiple physical partitions into one 
  virtual partition

* buy a netapp :-)

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Nov 20 11:37:54 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 11:37:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> <mailman.1037749698.16508.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <861y5gnib1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Evans <revans at e-z.net> writes:

Russell> I googled HTML escaping because I didn't understand what the issue was. I found
Russell> an example CGI and following by example I thought this would work. Does this
Russell> cover the issue or are there other characters that break the output? It seems
Russell> to deal with <BLINK> correctly.

Russell> find $1 | while read filename ; do
Russell> 		htmlfilename=`print $filename | sed -e 's/&/\&amp;/g'  -e
Russell> 's/\"/\&quot;/g' -e 's/>/\&gt;/g' -e 's/</\&lt;/g'`
Russell> 		print '<A href="'"$filename"'">'"$htmlfilename"'</A><BR>' |
Russell> grep blink >> $output_file
Russell> done

It doesn't percentify the HREF yet.  Mine did.
A file named "please <blink me>" needs to look like:

  <a href="please%20&lt;blink%20me&gt;">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

So there's URI (%-ing) and HTML escaping on the HREF=, and
there's HTML escaping on the visible text.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

Seems OK for PHP, since that's more lightweight than a scalable language
like Perl.

Having said that, I see quite a few low-ball offers coming over the
job lists.  And they'll probably fill them, because of the glut of
people.

handles credit cards or private information, do you really want
someone who will work for $25/hr to build it?  Sounds like a recipe
for disaster, of class-action lawsuit proportions.

From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Wed Nov 20 12:40:13 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 13:40:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
References: <20021119210631.B28208@mail.hitmedia.com> <001f01c290bc$3fe50420$6501a8c0@gandalf> <20021120115135.A11810@mail.hitmedia.com>
Message-ID: <3DDBF32D.7020908@coyotesong.com>

PHP freak wrote:
>>does $25/hour seem low to anyone else for PHP experience
>
> But then, we're just a little record store, not a Big Corporate Business.
> Everyone else here works for $8/hr.

So how much do you pay your lawyer?  Your doctor?

The point being that rates are determined by the amount of experience 
and effort that goes into being qualified for the job, not just how much 
everyone else is paid.  I might not like paying a plumber or electrician 
$100/hour for work, but I know that it's usually going to be cheaper 
than me doing it myself.  (And redoing it when I screw it up the first 
time, repairnig the extra damage caused by the first attempt, etc.)

Assuming that you can figure out which guy deserves $50/hour instead of 
$25, the "more expensive" guy may be cheaper because he'll get the job 
done right the first time, and has enough similar experience to get it 
out quickly since he's already implemented something similar.  Meanwhile 
the "cheaper" guy may be more expensive since he'll implement stuff that 
could never work in practice, miss deadlines (because he doesn't yet 
have the ability to make good schedule estimates), etc.

Ultimately, it's your call.  But don't pull the "poor little me" line. 
Not unless you can show that your $8/hr workers have spent as much of 
their own time keeping current with their fields as we have.

Bear




From bgiles at coyotesong.com  Wed Nov 20 12:53:27 2002
From: bgiles at coyotesong.com (Bear Giles)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 13:53:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> <mailman.1037749698.16508.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <861y5gnib1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <3DDBF647.6070304@coyotesong.com>

Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> It doesn't percentify the HREF yet.  Mine did.
> A file named "please <blink me>" needs to look like:
> 
>   <a href="please%20&lt;blink%20me&gt;">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

Huh???

Try

     <a href="please %3cblink me%3e">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

or

     <a href="please%20%3cblink%20me%3e">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

That is, use HTML encoding outside of the tags (<,> become &lt;,&gt;) 
and hex encoding within the tags (<,> become %3c,%3e)

But I don't see why you need to escape this anyway.  Well, maybe you do 
with some scripting languages that may be over-eager to interpret the 
space, < and > characters.  (I normally use C or java and this isn't an 
issue.)  Normally this encoding is only required for the characters used 
in GET commands (&, ?, =) and possibly characters with the high bit set.

Bear




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Wed Nov 20 13:16:15 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 13:16:15 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <3DDBF32D.7020908@coyotesong.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211201308080.29547-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Bear Giles wrote:

> PHP freak wrote:
> >>does $25/hour seem low to anyone else for PHP experience
> >
> > But then, we're just a little record store, not a Big Corporate Business.
> > Everyone else here works for $8/hr.
>
> So how much do you pay your lawyer?  Your doctor?

Do you see a lot of unemployed layers or doctors on the streets?  When you
do they'll go for $25/hour too.  Right now there are lots of unemployed
programmers out there and I'm sure a lot of them would be glad to get
$25/hour.

>
> The point being that rates are determined by the amount of experience
> and effort that goes into being qualified for the job, not just how much
> everyone else is paid.  I might not like paying a plumber or electrician
> $100/hour for work, but I know that it's usually going to be cheaper
> than me doing it myself.  (And redoing it when I screw it up the first
> time, repairnig the extra damage caused by the first attempt, etc.)
>
> Assuming that you can figure out which guy deserves $50/hour instead of
> $25, the "more expensive" guy may be cheaper because he'll get the job
> done right the first time, and has enough similar experience to get it
> out quickly since he's already implemented something similar.  Meanwhile
> the "cheaper" guy may be more expensive since he'll implement stuff that
> could never work in practice, miss deadlines (because he doesn't yet
> have the ability to make good schedule estimates), etc.
>

Maybe... but as I said, right now there's plenty of good (there were a
lot of very good people who were working for companies that had bad
business plans - being unemployed right now doesn't say anything about
your level of skills), available talent out there that would be happy to
make $25/hour so they can pay their rent.  It sure beats $8/hour at
Starbucks.  It's the market at work.

It's something we have to get used to...  It's not 1999 anymore.  Hourly
rates are adjusting to market forces by going down and they're likely to
stay there for a while.  I don't like it anymore than anyone else, but
that's the reality.

Phil

[Cc'd to plug-goverment]

I saw an article on how the Indian province of Madhya Pradesh adopted free
software for its e-governance and school education programs, even though
Microsoft Corp. expressed interest in sponsoring one of them.

In the article chief minister Digvijay Singh is quoted as saying:

"For us it is not a question of Microsoft versus Linux. It is just a
matter of choosing between a free software and a monopoly. We feel that
when we are putting public information out in the open, then it should not
be through a proprietary software."

India Times
"MP opens windows to Linux"
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/cms.dll/html/uncomp/articleshow?artid=28707422

====== BEGIN RANT ======

For christ's sake, give the guy a break!

I for one am an unemployed programmer (I do mostly, perl) and would be
happy to have a job for $25/hr full time, especially at a small shop
like this.

If you don't want this job then don't apply for it.  If you can find a
better job, then take it.  If all you care about is money and don't have
enough integrity to do a good job for a good job's sake, then maybe they
are better off without you.

BTW, I am not applying for this job so I have nothing to gain by this
rant.  I am just happy to see somebody hiring web programmers and it
bothers me that anyone would complain about someone hiring in this
market.  More power to them for building web applications in a tough
market.

======= END RANT =======

On Wed, 2002-11-20 at 12:40, Bear Giles wrote:
> PHP freak wrote:
> >>does $25/hour seem low to anyone else for PHP experience
> >
> > But then, we're just a little record store, not a Big Corporate Business.
> > Everyone else here works for $8/hr.
> 
> So how much do you pay your lawyer?  Your doctor?
> 
> The point being that rates are determined by the amount of experience 
> and effort that goes into being qualified for the job, not just how much 
> everyone else is paid.  I might not like paying a plumber or electrician 
> $100/hour for work, but I know that it's usually going to be cheaper 
> than me doing it myself.  (And redoing it when I screw it up the first 
> time, repairnig the extra damage caused by the first attempt, etc.)
> 
> Assuming that you can figure out which guy deserves $50/hour instead of 
> $25, the "more expensive" guy may be cheaper because he'll get the job 
> done right the first time, and has enough similar experience to get it 
> out quickly since he's already implemented something similar.  Meanwhile 
> the "cheaper" guy may be more expensive since he'll implement stuff that 
> could never work in practice, miss deadlines (because he doesn't yet 
> have the ability to make good schedule estimates), etc.
> 
> Ultimately, it's your call.  But don't pull the "poor little me" line. 
> Not unless you can show that your $8/hr workers have spent as much of 
> their own time keeping current with their fields as we have.
> 
> Bear
>

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Nov 20 13:48:24 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 13:48:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.
References: <004a01c2907a$8ac3e8e0$74ff013d@invent>
Message-ID: <3DDC0328.7060602@truedisk.com>

1) Install software
    Find media, and chdir to RPM directory

        rpm -Uvh openssh*

    ... uh, oh, you use Debian

        apt-get openssh  (?)


2) Edit the config file

        vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config


3) Read these for a deeper understanding of SSH server, clients, and config files:

     a) "SSH, The Secure Shell: The Definitive Guide"
        published by O'Reilly ... you can buy it from Amazon.com

     b) OpenSSH website.  Specifically:
          http://www.openssh.com/manual.html
          http://www.openssh.com/faq.html
          http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=openssh-unix-dev&r=1&w=2


4) Post specific questions to users groups which indicate:
     a) you've at least made an attempt to perform an installation
     b) you've managed some rudimentary research
     c) you have a specific problem, or question, which you'd like
        to have answered.







K.Prasad wrote:
> hi friends,
> I would like to know how to configure a SSH serrver.
> thanx in advance..
> With rgds,
> 
> ----
> 
> *K . Prasad* ||  http://symonds.net/~kprasad || Kerala, INDIA.

> Debian GNU/Linux 3.0r0.  Proud and Free.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 14:37:59 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 14:37:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201432190.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

Hi.

Some of y'all helped me a week or so ago when I needed to wire a serial
cable for an old(ish) ethernet switch to get to the management console.

Well, for some reason or other, it didn't work.

I'm pretty sure I wired the cable up properly (everything straight through
except TxD->RxD & RxD->TxD... should something else be crossed over,
too?  Maybe RTS->CTS?  I have no idea), but neither minicom nor
hypterterminal gave me any output at all when I powered up the device and
repeatedly struck the enter key (as the manual suggests).

Does anyone have some reasonable steps I can go through to troubleshoot
this?

Would anyone here have and let me borrow a VT100 terminal that definitely
works so I can at least reduce it to cable/switch (rather than software
configuration) problems?

Any help appreciated.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From kevinc at dOink.COM  Wed Nov 20 14:32:28 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 14:32:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.0 + ALSA 0.9 + Yamaha YMF 754 = NO SOUND 
In-Reply-To: <200211182343.14372.nknight@pocketinet.com> 
Message-ID: <20021120223230.A92952FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

I found the problem.  Not only do I have to crank up the volume,
but I have to unmute all the channels (and there are lots) that I
care about.  All is well now, and Mandrake Control Center *DID*
it's job to configure my card.  Now if there was just some way to
turn on the speakers by default and set all the volumes low,
maybe 10%.  It seems that I see tons of postings about ALSA
driven sound cards being muted.  Even so, with this new card, I
missed it in the maze of config data.  So, it wasn't my IRQ.

Cheers....






From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Wed Nov 20 14:58:07 2002
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 14:58:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
Message-ID: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2AF0@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

Most comm/management ports require specific baud/n81/flow control settings
before they will respond. Are these set correctly?

I don't know if this qualifies as "help" or not, but here goes a
couple ideas:

a) I once had trouble talking to a device, I think it was a Cisco 675,
   until I turned _off_ all flow control (hard and soft);

b) maybe you aren't supposed to cross transmit and receive (i.e.,
   whatever document you are looking at didn't intend you to).

From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Wed Nov 20 15:16:01 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 15:16:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.0 + ALSA 0.9 + Yamaha YMF 754 = NO SOUND
In-Reply-To: <20021120223230.A92952FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20021120223230.A92952FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <1037834161.2533.6.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2002-11-20 at 14:32, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> I found the problem.  Not only do I have to crank up the volume,
> but I have to unmute all the channels (and there are lots) that I
> care about.  All is well now, and Mandrake Control Center *DID*
> it's job to configure my card.  Now if there was just some way to
> turn on the speakers by default and set all the volumes low,
> maybe 10%.  It seems that I see tons of postings about ALSA
> driven sound cards being muted.  Even so, with this new card, I
> missed it in the maze of config data.  So, it wasn't my IRQ.

Set the volume and everything else how you like it then, as root, run
'alsactl store' and add 'alsactl restore' to your init scripts.

At least, that is how to do it by hand.. I could see some Mandrake tool
automagically doing things for you and messing up the volumes you
save/restore.

I think this is in the ALSA FAQ - www.alsa-project.org.  Check it out. 
:-)

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 15:24:58 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:24:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2AF0@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Pluimer, Randal T wrote:
> Most comm/management ports require specific baud/n81/flow control
> settings before they will respond. Are these set correctly?

Yeah, no parity, eight data, one stop... it auto-senses the bitrate, but
that's why you have to hit enter a few times.

Flow control is another story.  There's nothing about it in the manual.

I'll try turning it off completely as Russel suggests.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 15:26:57 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:26:57 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <86isyrlu8a.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201525010.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 20 Nov 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> a) I once had trouble talking to a device, I think it was a Cisco 675,
>    until I turned _off_ all flow control (hard and soft);

That's the one flow control setting I have NOT tried...

> b) maybe you aren't supposed to cross transmit and receive (i.e.,
>    whatever document you are looking at didn't intend you to).

Well, according to the manual, pin 1 of the RJ45 is transmit and labelled
as "Output".  This tells me that it's not the pin to be wired TO a
transmit on the far end, but to a receive.  Hopefully that's the correct
interpretation.

I suppose there's a chance I wired the whole thing completely
backward...  oh hell.

Any more suggestions?

J.

From php at hitmedia.com  Wed Nov 20 15:29:23 2002

> > Everyone else here works for $8/hr.

$0 to both.  Don't have either.

I think the point is also the difference between being a FREELANCE person hired PER PROJECT, where you're entirely responsible for your own taxes, health care, and you don't know if the project will be there for you next week - and being a STEADY EMPLOYEE, where it's a guaranteed steady thing, taxes and health care taken care of, etc.

If I was hiring a QUICK PROJECT person, I'd pay more.   But for a steady employee $25/hr is WAY high for me, it's the equivalent of hiring three new people at once, whereas this PHP work is something I COULD do myself (I already am, right now, and have been for 4 years), but need some extra help doing it now.

Blah blah blah... it's an incredibly cool job for someone who wants it.

--
Derek Sivers, CD Baby, Hostbaby
http://www.cdbaby.com
http://www.hostbaby.com




From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Wed Nov 20 15:31:26 2002
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:31:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
Message-ID: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2AF1@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

The switches and hubs i use here require No Flow Control and a set baud rate
or they wont respond. 
IF your device is fairly old try setting to no flow control and 9600 baud.
>From there go to 19,200 and finally 115,200. One of those should work. Only
other thing i can think of is possible emulation protocol. That usually just
means you will get a garbled screen though if its not right.

-----Original Message-----
From: Jeme A Brelin [mailto:jeme at brelin.net]
Sent: Wednesday, November 20, 2002 3:25 PM
To: 'plug at lists.pdxlinux.org'
Subject: RE: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition

Flow control is another story.  There's nothing about it in the manual.

I'll try turning it off completely as Russel suggests.

From revans at e-z.net  Wed Nov 20 15:13:01 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:13:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] 200Gig /home
In-Reply-To: <C7MIOI72GA83871YC03XQM61XVC98775.3ddbea84@miked>
References: <C7MIOI72GA83871YC03XQM61XVC98775.3ddbea84@miked>
Message-ID: <20021120233918.RKQS3664.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>

I built a pII box, 128Mb RAM, with a total of 3 disk in a LV, 2 at 120GB, ATA 133
5400 RPM and 1 at 100GB, ATA 100, 7200 RPM IDE drives. The two 120GB drives used
the ATA133 PCI cards that came separate with the drives and the 100GB used the
primary on-board IDE channel. The OS lived on a separate 18GB SCSI drive. the
box is running SuSE 8.0. 

I used LVM on the three large disks creating a 300 something GB ( it wasn't 340
but in the ball park ) striped LE. From the FAQ: "In certain situations this
strategy can improve the performance of the logical volume. Be aware however,
that LVs created using striping cannot be extended past the PVs they were
originally created on." 

We are able to do 90+ Mb FTP transfers on a dedicated 100 base network. We
pulled ~90Gb off the box per run; about 3000 files, file sizes where between
64kb and ~4G, each file transfered in its own ftp session (slow approach, my
fault for scripting it this way, but I needed to know if a file transfer
failed), in about four hours. This was the only thing this box and network was
used for.

Thank you
Russell



On Wed, 20 Nov 2002 12:03:16 -0800, Mike De La Mater said:

> This looks like the ticket.
>  
>  I don't see anything about performance, any ideas if there's much of a 
>  performance loss?
>  
>  Mike
>  
>  11/20/02 9:53:42 AM, Carla Schroder <pluglist at bratgrrl.com> wrote:
>  
>  >On Wednesday 20 November 2002 09:34, Mike De La Mater wrote:
>  >> I'm doing some work on a project that will require an
>  >> extremely large /home partition.
>  >>
>  >> What can I do to get this much space in a single partition?

>  >This might be a golden opportunity to dive into the world of Logical Volume 
>  >Management. http://tldp.org/HOWTO/LVM-HOWTO/

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Nov 20 15:47:08 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:47:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201525010.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201525010.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <200211201547.08544.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do you have access to one of those little "Christmas Trees" as we used 
to call them. They're RS-232 testers with 7 LEDs on them and they have 
a male DB25 connector on one side and female DB25 connector on the 
other. It shows the following signals: TD, RTS, DSR, CD, RD, CTS, DTR. 
I got mine years ago at Radio Shack quite cheaply when I did some part 
time system admin work on a System V Rel 1.5 system that was connected 
to dumb terminals.

I even have what they call a "Breakout Box" called "Easy Bob" that has 
18 LEDs, 25 little switches on it, and bunch of jumper wires for 
connecting different pins together across the unit. I used to use the 
box to help me figure out what pins to use when I had no documentation 
to work with. 

Sure there are certain basic pin connections for RS-232 but back in the 
old days (1980's) there were some strange devices out there that 
required some interesting pin configurations. This sort of equipment 
may be rare now since everything has moved over to ethernet for the 
most part although for debugging the kernel and stuff a serial port and 
terminal is still required I think.

Tony

On Wednesday 20 November 2002 15:26 pm, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On 20 Nov 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> > a) I once had trouble talking to a device, I think it was a Cisco
> > 675, until I turned _off_ all flow control (hard and soft);
>
> That's the one flow control setting I have NOT tried...
>
> > b) maybe you aren't supposed to cross transmit and receive (i.e.,
> >    whatever document you are looking at didn't intend you to).
>
> Well, according to the manual, pin 1 of the RJ45 is transmit and
> labelled as "Output".  This tells me that it's not the pin to be
> wired TO a transmit on the far end, but to a receive.  Hopefully
> that's the correct interpretation.
>
> I suppose there's a chance I wired the whole thing completely
> backward...  oh hell.
>
> Any more suggestions?
>
> J.

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com





From randal.t.pluimer at intel.com  Wed Nov 20 15:58:06 2002
From: randal.t.pluimer at intel.com (Pluimer, Randal T)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 15:58:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
Message-ID: <D9223EB959A5D511A98F00508B68C20C135E2AF2@orsmsx108.jf.intel.com>

-----Original Message-----
From: Anthony Schlemmer [mailto:aschlemm at attbi.com]
Sent: Wednesday, November 20, 2002 3:47 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition


Do you have access to one of those little "Christmas Trees" as we used 
to call them. They're RS-232 testers with 7 LEDs on them and they have 
a male DB25 connector on one side and female DB25 connector on the 
other. It shows the following signals: TD, RTS, DSR, CD, RD, CTS, DTR. 
I got mine years ago at Radio Shack quite cheaply when I did some part 
time system admin work on a System V Rel 1.5 system that was connected 
to dumb terminals.

I even have what they call a "Breakout Box" called "Easy Bob" that has 
18 LEDs, 25 little switches on it, and bunch of jumper wires for 
connecting different pins together across the unit. I used to use the 
box to help me figure out what pins to use when I had no documentation 
to work with. 

Sure there are certain basic pin connections for RS-232 but back in the 
old days (1980's) there were some strange devices out there that 
required some interesting pin configurations. This sort of equipment 
may be rare now since everything has moved over to ethernet for the 
most part although for debugging the kernel and stuff a serial port and 
terminal is still required I think.

Tony

All,

It is with great pleasure that I announce our new home! Oregon State's Engineering Department has graciously donated the use use of one their computer labs Tuesday evenings from 7-8 p.m.!

Our new home is in Room 8 of the Huvland Building on campus. A little recon reveals this room to be a fully functioning computer lab complete with overhead projector!

Special thanks to Russell Born of the Computer Facilities department for his hard work and follow-through on this...although it took some time, he really stuck with it! Also I extend my thanks to the Oregon State University Engineering department for their generous contribution of their facilities. 

Our next meeting is scheduled beginning at 7:00 p.m. on Tuesday, November 3rd in room 8 of the Huvland Building. I will send out an official announcement in the coming days. 

So come one, come all! Whether you're a new user, IT professional, student or educator, come on out and enjoy rubbing shoulders with some of the finest computer professionals going. I guarantee you a fun and informative time!

See you there!


Best,


Cooper

From bprew at logiccloud.com  Wed Nov 20 08:17:17 2002
From: bprew at logiccloud.com (Benjamin Prew)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 08:17:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Problems Installing Linux on WinNT disk
In-Reply-To: <3D94F0A1.7DCAA3B3@gisnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0209271518500.9177-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
	<3D94F0A1.7DCAA3B3@gisnet.com>
Message-ID: <1033253151.1223.26.camel@laptop>

I went through this process recently using XP and Linux.  Here's what I
did...

1. Downloaded the trial version of PartitionMagic from
www.powerquest.com

2. Changed the size of the NTFS partition

3. Installed Linux (Debian)

This not only kept my install of XP intact, but installing Debian went
off without a hitch.  I poked around a bit on sf.net and freshmeat.net
and didn't really see anything that would split NTFS file systems... but
that doesn't mean there isn't anything, just that I didn't find it :)

On Fri, 2002-09-27 at 16:58, Bill Thoen wrote:
> Well, I got a working copy of Tom's Root Boot (I used another
> Linux machine to make it), and it worked up to "mkfs", which
> wasn't there. Didn't matter though, the disk came up as a Linux
> disk. The partition I wanted to use was /dev/hdb5, and this is
> now about 18MB in Linux native format. So I started the install
> process again...
> 
> Now the NEW problem. I can't put a boot partition on it (error is
> '> 1024 cylinders'). Linux keeps wanting to put a boot partition
> on /dev/hda, which is 1023 cylinders. However, that disk has only
> one partition and it's currently in use by Win2K. Do I have to
> use /dev/hda, or can I put Linux entirely on /dev/hdb5? What do I
> do if I have to split /dev/hda into two partitions and don't want
> to hose up Windows?
> 
> - Bill Thoen
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Ben

Does the demo version of Partitionmagic actually partition now? It has not in
any of the versions I have looked at over the years. The reason for this is
pretty obvious it is for many people a "one use" app and a fully functioning
demo would be selfdefeating in many ways. 

Having said that repartitioning with Partitionmagic and then installling Debian
is a *good* plan and  is the way I built my first dual boot box. I just doubt if
you can do it with the demo version.

From don at truedisk.com  Wed Nov 20 16:43:15 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 16:43:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201432190.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3DDC2C23.2000103@truedisk.com>

Jeme,

1)  Have you tried the "minimalist's" cable?
     Just 3 wires:  TxD -> RxD;  RxD -> TxD;
     and  GND -> GND.

     Basically, this is the hardware equivalent of
     Russell's (excellent) suggestion to turn flow
     control off.

2)  Your computer (or terminal) will be DTE.
     Do you know if the hub/switch is DCE or DTE?
     DCE ==> straight-thru cabling.
     DTE ==> null-modem config

IIRC, all that "clear to send", "terminal set ready",
"data set ready" ... is *not* a straight thru connection
for a DTE/DTE (i.e. null-modem) setup, and, in fact,
it can mean stuff like a pin on one side is connected
to *two* pins on the other!

- Don

P.S. Any chance there is a URL to the manufacturers web
site with info about the serial port?


Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Hi.
> 
> Some of y'all helped me a week or so ago when I needed to wire a serial
> cable for an old(ish) ethernet switch to get to the management console.
> 
> Well, for some reason or other, it didn't work.
> 
> I'm pretty sure I wired the cable up properly (everything straight through
> except TxD->RxD & RxD->TxD... should something else be crossed over,
> too?  Maybe RTS->CTS?  I have no idea), but neither minicom nor
> hypterterminal gave me any output at all when I powered up the device and
> repeatedly struck the enter key (as the manual suggests).
> 
> Does anyone have some reasonable steps I can go through to troubleshoot
> this?
> 
> Would anyone here have and let me borrow a VT100 terminal that definitely
> works so I can at least reduce it to cable/switch (rather than software
> configuration) problems?
> 
> Any help appreciated.
> 
> J.




From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 16:54:53 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 16:54:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <3DDC2C23.2000103@truedisk.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201650440.28907-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Don Buchholz wrote:
> 1)  Have you tried the "minimalist's" cable?
>      Just 3 wires:  TxD -> RxD;  RxD -> TxD;
>      and  GND -> GND.
> 
>      Basically, this is the hardware equivalent of
>      Russell's (excellent) suggestion to turn flow
>      control off.

This I haven't tried.  I can do this in the morning.

> 2)  Your computer (or terminal) will be DTE.
>      Do you know if the hub/switch is DCE or DTE?
>      DCE ==> straight-thru cabling.
>      DTE ==> null-modem config
> 
> IIRC, all that "clear to send", "terminal set ready",
> "data set ready" ... is *not* a straight thru connection
> for a DTE/DTE (i.e. null-modem) setup, and, in fact,
> it can mean stuff like a pin on one side is connected
> to *two* pins on the other!

I'm almost positive it's a DCE.  I called their support desk and the guy
talked to me (even though there's no kind of support contract for this
thing) and told me that he's pretty sure it's a DCE because it was
designed to be connected to a (real) VT100 terminal.  I know that doesn't
necessarily mean anything, but it's the best I've got so far.

> P.S. Any chance there is a URL to the manufacturers web site with info
> about the serial port?

I have the manual in PDF.  There are pin-outs for the RJ45 and they say
"use the connector in the kit" for connecting to a PC serial port or a
VT100 terminal.  Needless to say, "the kit" vanished probably a decade
ago.

J.

From greg at green-mind.org  Wed Nov 20 17:10:34 2002
From: greg at green-mind.org (Greg Robillard)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 17:10:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
References: <20021119210631.B28208@mail.hitmedia.com> <001f01c290bc$3fe50420$6501a8c0@gandalf> <20021120115135.A11810@mail.hitmedia.com> <3DDBF32D.7020908@coyotesong.com> <20021120152923.A31528@mail.hitmedia.com> <006a01c290f3$81ad8300$6501a8c0@gandalf> <3DDC2CFE.1010200@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <000601c290fa$cbdd58e0$6501a8c0@gandalf>

> $25/hr is more than I'm getting via Intel.  (Who just cut most
> contractors rates by 10%)  At least I'm getting benefits via my agency.

>
> I know I'm worth more than that, but I've also been looking and not
> getting any meaningful nibbles.
>
> For what it's worth, I think $25 would be a low rate for some
> programmers.  Closer to the intermediate or below than the intermediate
> to expert Derek wants.  But it is better than $0.  We do have a bit of a
> glut on our hands.  If I knew PHP, I'd be tempted.  On top of the $25
> you do have flexible hours which isn't too bad.

Which is partly what I was asking in my initial post. I've been living in
Portland for less than a year, and have been working only as a freelancer,
and spending a lot of time yoyo-ing my rates to figure out what's
reasonable. And I've seen Craig's List postings for PHP consultants for as
low as $12-$15. Which makes the job at starbucks with bennies start to look
good. Mm, all the coffee I want and I don't have to think.

Yes, even 12 bucks an hour is better than nothing, especially when rent is
due. And  I know we aren't in the heady days of 1999, when an HTML coder
could bring in $60/hr. But it is also not 1933 either, back when Perl was
the only scripting language around :)

Perl was good enough for my granny, by gosh.

I know a couple o persons who have been unemployed for two years. They are not 
on the streets, thanks to having working spouses, who IMO are far too 
patient. They're not going to find a job that meets their specs, because by 
gosh they are worth way more than anyone's offering. A person can be picky 
when they have a bidding war going for their services. Otherwise, be hush, 
get to work, and be glad to be receiving a living wage. Clerical and temp 
jobs range from $8- $12/hr, no bennies. That's not living wages. Unless you 
live in your parent's basement.

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Wed Nov 20 17:20:51 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 17:20:51 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <3DDBF32D.7020908@coyotesong.com>
Message-ID: <20021121012051.66185.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>

> The point being that rates are determined by the amount of experience
> and effort that goes into being qualified for the job

That sounds good, unfortunately it isn't true.

You can have every certification in the book, a PhD, and 25 years
experience, but if you're standing in line for a job with 200 others
with your same skills, you won't be able to demand a higher wage.

If you have 6 months experience, no certs or degree, but you're the
only one around who knows about a particular job, you might be able to
demand a nice wage.

The market decides what a good or service is worth. If you can convince
people to buy your pet rocks for $5000, then they are worth $5000. If
you can only get $50 for your used 2001 Mercedes, then it's only worth
$50.

If he can hire a skilled programmer for $25/hour (or $20 or $10 or
whatever) then good for him. If your time is worth $75/hour to you, but
he can't afford that, then he'll have to find someone who will do it
cheaper, do it himself, or do without.

I love America!

-Scott

--- Bear Giles <bgiles at coyotesong.com> wrote:
> PHP freak wrote:
> >>does $25/hour seem low to anyone else for PHP experience
> >
> > But then, we're just a little record store, not a Big Corporate
> Business.
> > Everyone else here works for $8/hr.
> 
> So how much do you pay your lawyer?  Your doctor?
> 
> The point being that rates are determined by the amount of experience
> 
> and effort that goes into being qualified for the job, not just how
> much 
> everyone else is paid.  I might not like paying a plumber or
> electrician 
> $100/hour for work, but I know that it's usually going to be cheaper 
> than me doing it myself.  (And redoing it when I screw it up the
> first 
> time, repairnig the extra damage caused by the first attempt, etc.)
> 
> Assuming that you can figure out which guy deserves $50/hour instead
> of 
> $25, the "more expensive" guy may be cheaper because he'll get the
> job 
> done right the first time, and has enough similar experience to get
> it 
> out quickly since he's already implemented something similar. 
> Meanwhile 
> the "cheaper" guy may be more expensive since he'll implement stuff
> that 
> could never work in practice, miss deadlines (because he doesn't yet 
> have the ability to make good schedule estimates), etc.
> 
> Ultimately, it's your call.  But don't pull the "poor little me"
> line. 
> Not unless you can show that your $8/hr workers have spent as much of
> 
> their own time keeping current with their fields as we have.
> 
> Bear

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 17:45:41 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 17:45:41 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <20021121012051.66185.qmail@web10403.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201731390.29159-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> The market decides what a good or service is worth. If you can
> convince people to buy your pet rocks for $5000, then they are worth
> $5000. If you can only get $50 for your used 2001 Mercedes, then it's
> only worth $50.

...which is why "worth" means absolutely nothing and should be discarded
along with "deserve" and "earn".

But anyway, the point is that the purpose of the market in labor is to
drive down wages and benefits while driving up per-worker production.  
That's why high unemployment and low growth (i.e. third-world economics)
is ideal for a booming bond market.

We have a situation in this country where all of the essential needs of
the people can be met with far less than 100% employment hence the
enormous demand generation industry (to create industries that don't need
to exist at all), the low quality of consumer goods (to encourage
re-buying), the highest incarceration rate in the industrialized world (to
decrease the number of have-nots on the street that might revolt against
the haves), and a grossly disporportionate military (both to enlist
have-nots and give them false hope and to threaten and repress the
unenlisted).  Of course, that hyper-inflated military is also what allows
us to import goods or off-load labor at a fraction of the real cost by
repressing foreign uprisings as well as domestic.

If you read the business press, they're very straightforward on the goals
of the "new economy" which include labor market flexibility (which means
job insecurity and a perpetually high unemployment rate so that folks will
take whatever wage they're given and won't bitch about cutbacks) and the
transfer of public funds into private power via government contracts
(military and otherwise).  Privatization is exactly that: a privatization
of what was formerly public property.  Many lose for the benefit of the
few.  Privatizing public works means lower wages for most and huge profits
for a small few... and those profits are all tax dollars.  Where a public
agency's goal is to USE all of the money it is given, a private
corporation's goal is to HOARD the money it takes, dispensing as little as
possible.  I ask you which is better for the people and the economy.

Hurray for the new economy.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Wed Nov 20 17:44:43 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 17:44:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Simple Directory Listing to HTML Script
References: <mailman.1037684176.9775.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <86isyts2h1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> <mailman.1037749698.16508.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org> <861y5gnib1.fsf@red.stonehenge.com> <mailman.1037825719.4388.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <868yznn1bo.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Bear" == Bear Giles <bgiles at coyotesong.com> writes:

Bear> Try

Bear>      <a href="please %3cblink me%3e">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

That's not legal.  Spaces are not legal in a URI.

Bear> or

Bear>      <a href="please%20%3cblink%20me%3e">please &lt;blink me&gt;</a>

No, you've %-encoded < in a URI, which isn't needed.  It *is*
however needed to be HTML encoded.

Let's take this example.

To create a link that passes "fred=flint stone" and "barney=rub ble"
to a CGI form response, the URI must be:

        /cgi/response?fred=flint%20stone&barney=rub%20ble

However, you can't have that "&" in HTML... it must be encoded as "&amp;",
so we show that as:

   <a href="/cgi/response?fred=flint%20stone&amp;barney=rub%20ble"> ... </a>

Thus, to go from a filename to HTML, you have to first URI encode the
dangerous stuff, then HTML-encode any remaining HTML-specific chars.

YOU CANNOT SHORTCUT ONE OR THE OTHER.

If you "get away" with something other than what I just listed, you
are simply relying on error-correction non-standard behavior that is
trying to DWIM, rather than Doing The Right Thing.

Please trust me on this.... I've been doing the web for a decade now,
and spoken to many experts.

-- 
Randal L. Schwartz - Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc. - +1 503 777 0095
<merlyn at stonehenge.com> <URL:http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/>
Perl/Unix/security consulting, Technical writing, Comedy, etc. etc.
See PerlTraining.Stonehenge.com for onsite and open-enrollment Perl training!

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Nov 20 18:36:54 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 18:36:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Headless servers 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "20 Nov 2002 08:23:55 PST."
             <1037808940.484.253.camel@laptop> 
Message-ID: <200211210236.gAL2as227629@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> Hey,
> 
> I remeber someone mentioning a while back about not having a server
> complete until it had a serial connection (I believe it was Mr.
> Heinlein) and I was wondering how this worked out exactly?  What is the
> serial connection for?  And, is it supposed to take the place of a
> mouse, keyboard and monitor, or something else?
> 

All of the above.  Or is that none of the above?  By running a serial 
console, there is no need for a keyboard, monitor, mouse, or video card.
Most management of the system is done via ssh.  For things that can't be
handled over the network, there is a serial connection which allows
access via getty/login.  The other end of the serial connection could
be a simple as a plain old ascii terminal connected to a mechanical
switch that allows selecting among multiple systems.  A fancier setup
might use some sort of serial port concentrator.

It should be noted that the BIOS of typical PC motherboards is lacking
in this department.  Usually server/high end motherboards are the only
ones that support BIOS interaction via a serial port.  If anyone knows
of inexpensive exceptions to this rule, I'd like to hear about them.

galen

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Nov 20 18:51:31 2002

In-Reply-To: <20021121022749.75541.qmail@web10405.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201849000.29675-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> That's funny, I thought this was a Linux listserve. My mistake! :)

Definitely your mistake.  This is the primary mailing list for the
Portland Linux/Unix Group.  We try to keep close to discussions of
technology and technical culture, but there is a slow gradient from tech
culture to economics (just as there's a slow grade from technology to
politics that becomes very grey indeed around Free Software).

We do have a plug-talk list for discussion the participants deem too far
away from technology and tech culture, though sometimes the slide is too
fast to move the whole discussion before it's over.

> the haves), and a grossly disporportionate military (both to enlist
> have-nots and give them false hope and to threaten and repress the
> unenlisted).  Of course, that hyper-inflated military is also what allows
> us to import goods or off-load labor at a fraction of the real cost by
> repressing foreign uprisings as well as domestic.
>
> If you read the business press, they're very straightforward on the goals
> of the "new economy" which include labor market flexibility (which means
> job insecurity and a perpetually high unemployment rate so that folks will
> take whatever wage they're given and won't bitch about cutbacks) and the
> transfer of public funds into private power via government contracts
> (military and otherwise).  Privatization is exactly that: a privatization
> of what was formerly public property.  Many lose for the benefit of the
> few.  Privatizing public works means lower wages for most and huge profits
> for a small few... and those profits are all tax dollars.  Where a public
> agency's goal is to USE all of the money it is given, a private
> corporation's goal is to HOARD the money it takes, dispensing as little as
> possible.  I ask you which is better for the people and the economy.
>
> Hurray for the new economy.
>
> J.

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Wed Nov 20 19:24:13 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 19:24:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] 200Gig /home
In-Reply-To: <20021120233918.RKQS3664.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>
References: <C7MIOI72GA83871YC03XQM61XVC98775.3ddbea84@miked> <20021120233918.RKQS3664.sccrmhc01.attbi.com@linux>
Message-ID: <200211201924.13487.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

If all you want to do is concatenate or stripe your drives, the MD system 
in Linux is just fine.  LVM is designed to do more than that.

I've used it to do things like near-instantaneous snapshots of live MySQL 
databases.  That's where LVM really starts to shine.  You can also extend 
live filesystems (some filesystems at any rate).  I haven't tried that 
yet.  Lack of trust.  Seems like an accident waiting to happen.

LVM2 is in the 2.5 kernel (well device mapper is) and should provide a lot 
of fixes for things that LVM1 didn't do so well.    That plus the EVMS 
tools in userspace will make a lot of sysadmins happy.

The 200GB drives are supposed to be out this month I think.  Ten of those 
and you're at about the limit of disk space that Linux can address (2TB 
limit).

Best,
Kyle

Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> wrote:

> > Hey,

> > I remeber someone mentioning a while back about not having a server
> > complete until it had a serial connection (I believe it was Mr.
> > Heinlein) and I was wondering how this worked out exactly?  What is the
> > serial connection for?  And, is it supposed to take the place of a
> > mouse, keyboard and monitor, or something else?
> > 
> 
> All of the above.  Or is that none of the above?  By running a serial 
> console, there is no need for a keyboard, monitor, mouse, or video card.
> Most management of the system is done via ssh.  For things that can't be
> handled over the network, there is a serial connection which allows
> access via getty/login.  The other end of the serial connection could
> be a simple as a plain old ascii terminal connected to a mechanical
> switch that allows selecting among multiple systems.  A fancier setup
> might use some sort of serial port concentrator.
> 
> It should be noted that the BIOS of typical PC motherboards is lacking
> in this department.  Usually server/high end motherboards are the only
> ones that support BIOS interaction via a serial port.  If anyone knows
> of inexpensive exceptions to this rule, I'd like to hear about them.
> 
> galen
> 

This review mentions the tyan mpx board has a bios setting to redirect video output to the serial port.

http://www.tech-report.com/reviews/2002q4/mpx-boards/index.x?pg=2

I hear it's about $200, more expensive than your basic board, but it sounds great for a 'nix box. Anybody have one? Opinions?
