From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Nov 20 20:45:10 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 2002 20:45:10 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Headless servers
In-Reply-To: <1037808940.484.253.camel@laptop>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211202026400.22886-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 20 Nov 2002, Benjamin Prew wrote:

> I remeber someone mentioning a while back about not having a server
> complete until it had a serial connection (I believe it was Mr.
> Heinlein) and I was wondering how this worked out exactly?  What is
> the serial connection for?  And, is it supposed to take the place of
> a mouse, keyboard and monitor, or something else?

Hey, I'm moving up in the world: "Mr. Heinlein" :-)

The short answer is, yes, the serial connection becomes the console, 
the moral equivalent of keyboard and monitor. The LDP's Serial 
HOWTO[1] is a good place to start for information.

The advantages of a serial console over a KVM are many:

* it works over a slow connection like a modem
* the cabling can be longer and is available at any electronics supply 
  house
* the equipment is cheaper, esp. comparing a dedicated console server 
  to one of those tricky KVM-over-IP thingees
* you can keep full logs of all your console sessions
* anything that can emulate a vt100 terminal can act as the console 
  host, including Palm Pilots[2]
* your admins have to master at least the basics of vi

There are some disadvantages:

* getting an x86 BIOS to redirect itself to a serial port can be 
  tricky and/or require an add-on card (though getting Linux to send
  /dev/console to /dev/ttySx is pretty simple)
* no access to GUI apps, though console curses work ok
* your admins have to master at least the basics of vi

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/Serial-HOWTO.html
[2] http://www.itworld.com/Comp/2384/LWD010511penguin2/




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Nov 20 20:48:23 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 20 Nov 2002 20:48:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201846570.29675-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201846570.29675-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <868yznsf3c.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> By the way, how do I get minicom to not "initialize" my device?
Jeme> Do I just null out the "modem init string" configuration (and
Jeme> the hangup, I assume)?

Here's what I use for a serial console.  I have an entry in
/etc/inittab:

  6:2345:respawn:/usr/bin/openvt -c 6 -w -- /usr/bin/minicom -o -c on serial-console

and then in /etc/minicom, I have a file called minirc.serial-console
that contains:

   # Machine-generated file - use "minicom -s" to change parameters.
   pr port             /dev/ttyS0
   pu baudrate         9600
   pu bits             8
   pu parity           N
   pu stopbits         1
   pu rtscts           No 
   pu minit            
   pu mreset           
   pu mdialpre         
   pu mdialsuf         
   pu mdialpre2        
   pu mdialsuf2        
   pu mdialpre3        
   pu mdialsuf3        
   pu mconnect         
   pu mnocon1          
   pu mnocon2          
   pu mnocon3          
   pu mnocon4          
   pu mhangup          
   pu mdialcan         

I created the serial-console "profile" (or whatever).  Probably by
starting minicom, changing parameters and then saving the config.  

The inittab entry gives me a "virtual console" on Alt-F6 for the
machine I am monitoring by way of the serial console.  This was
screwing me up for a while, because when I wanted to reboot the other
machine, I was pressing Ctl-Alt-Del on the serial console and
rebooting my desktop box instead!  Oops!

I missed you, Jeme.  After I left the geeklist, it's been boring boring
boring.

God forbid I should keep my mouth shut for too long.

Unfortunately with the current glut of technical talent in the area, wages
ARE being pushed low.  Too low.  It took me 9 months to find work after
being laid off, and that was with a 47% pay cut.  There was a lot more work
in Seattle or San Diego or DC or Richardson, but I like this area.  I just
talked to a local DSL reseller (that shall remain nameless) who offered me a
contract position for $10 - $12 / hr.  The guy said upper management decided
someone would take the job.  And they're probably right.  They probably can
get someone with expertise at layers 1, 2, and 3 to come off unemployment
(or no benefits at all) and take the job.  Someone who may have been making
3x that amount a year ago.

But that doesn't make it right.  Not by a long shot.  People deserve a fair
wage whether the market bears it or not.

I'd kill someone for $25 / hour.  With benefits?  I'd throw their wife in,
too.

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 21 00:30:06 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 00:30:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] 200Gig /home
In-Reply-To: <200211201924.13487.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
References: <C7MIOI72GA83871YC03XQM61XVC98775.3ddbea84@miked>

    <200211201924.13487.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <20021121085605.KWO21905.sccrmhc02.attbi.com@linux>

I used MD to bunch a few 8.4GB drives into one 24GB volume once. Building the
system took a lot longer. Comparing the two, even for simple striping, LVM wins
hands down. I've resized LVM volumes with reiserfs file systems, two commands
and it's done. very, very slick. 

Thank you
Russell


On Wed, 20 Nov 2002 19:24:13 -0800, Kyle Hayes said:

> 
>  If all you want to do is concatenate or stripe your drives, the MD system 
>  in Linux is just fine.  LVM is designed to do more than that.

>>>>> "Preston" == Preston Crawford <prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com> writes:

>> But remember, you get what you pay for.  If you have a site that
>> handles credit cards or private information, do you really want
>> someone who will work for $25/hr to build it?  Sounds like a recipe
>> for disaster, of class-action lawsuit proportions.

Preston> Isn't that around $50k a year? I don't know what you get
Preston> paid, but I don't consier that chump change. I make more, but
Preston> when did we become so greedy that someone willing to take
Preston> that kind of pay would be considered a risk just because they
Preston> were willing to take that kind of pay?

$25/hr+benefits as a salary for an employee (which would be $50k/yr
plus benes) is different from $25/hr as a consultant (which is $25k/yr
minus benes).  I understood this to be a consulting gig, in which case
it's a mighty poor paying consulting gig.

From brucek at kingkon.com  Thu Nov 21 06:17:13 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 06:17:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] scp in batch mode -- help
In-Reply-To: <9412.66.93.41.98.1037139035.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>; from plug@magnetinternet.com on Tue, Nov 12, 2002 at 02:10:35PM -0800
References: <20021112140233.T30936@defiant.ncplus.net> <9412.66.93.41.98.1037139035.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <20021121061713.G32455@defiant.ncplus.net>

Matt King's Log: StarDate 1112.1410:
> Put the public_key into the .ssh/authorized_keys2 file on the server you
> want to send the files to...here's how I do it (YMMV).
> 
> Machine1 = Local Machine
> Machine2 = Remote Machine
> 
> [Machine1]: ssh-keygen -t rsa
> On this step don't enter a passphrase for the key.
> 
> [Machine1]: scp .ssh/id_rsa.pub [youruser]@[Machine2]:~/.ssh/authorized_keys2
> 
> Or if you have an authorized_keys2 file on Machine2, copy it to your home
> directory, ssh to Machine2, and do 'cat id_rsa.pub >>
> .ssh/authorized_keys2'
> 
> Now you should be able to login without a password.  At least that's what
> worked for me.

Did all that. It still asks for a password.

After being frustrated with pacifier using OpenBSD, and the multitude
of things that are different there, I looked at the ISP I'm dialing
in to.

That ISP uses linux 2.4.18, with all the expected files in place.

So, some one else suggested that I use rsync (not available on the BSD
system).

And I created a new user (ipsync) on my local system that will do
nothing except this update function, so that I don't have to muck with
my keys that I use for other systems.

ran ssh-keygen as the new user. created a cron entry to run the ip
update script. The script works, except for the last bit:


RSYNC_PASSWORD=itsAsecret
export RSYNC_PASSWORD
rsync -e ssh -logptrvz renegaid.html asavage at ncplus.net:www/


This _always_ asks for a password if run by hand, and always reports:

Permission denied, please try again.
Permission denied, (publickey,password).
unexpected EOF in read_timeout

when running in the cron. Once I get this working, I'll post the full
script.

TIA!
-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

D/2B8DA3D7 g/2884A18E  49C3 BBDE 6BC5 3F39 0C03  3BE4 FBC5 2C8D 2B8D A3D7

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 21 06:24:35 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 06:24:35 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Something to think about
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211210623330.26596-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
   Some More Writing Advice

   In C, putting extra parentheses in an expression can make it clearer.
   This tactic does not work in English. Human readers are not compilers.
   Either use commas instead of parentheses or put longer explanations in
   a different sentence.

   Microsoft Windows NT 4.x, Windows 98 and Windows 98 SE enter the
   "Non-Supported Phase":
   http://www.microsoft.com/windows/lifecycleconsumer.mspx on June 30,
   2003. No future security fixes will be available for those products
   after that date. Vendors, is it time to offer a promotion to get users
   of these common products to switch to a system for which you do offer
   security updates?

From ali at axian.com  Thu Nov 21 08:09:02 2002
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 08:09:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] scp in batch mode -- help
In-Reply-To: <20021121061713.G32455@defiant.ncplus.net>; from brucek@kingkon.com on Thu, Nov 21, 2002 at 06:17:13AM -0800
References: <20021112140233.T30936@defiant.ncplus.net> <9412.66.93.41.98.1037139035.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com> <20021121061713.G32455@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <20021121080902.A9295@zaphod.axian.com>

Check the permissions of your keys file.
If it's accessible by group or world, then ssh will refuse to use it.
Ali

I'm in calc 1 (251) at PSU this term and have been using Gnuplot for some of the
homework assignments. I also have the TI-89, which has the same software as the
TI-92, but can be had for $40-$60 than the TI-92. Some of the students have
Maple, but I think the student edition is still $120. Gnuplot and the TI-89 do
it for me, but that may change in some of the higher level stuff.

From derek at infotects.com  Thu Nov 21 09:43:07 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 09:43:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] (serial) terminal condition
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201525010.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211201525010.27028-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1037900586.1978.73.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-11-20 at 15:26, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On 20 Nov 2002, Russell Senior wrote:
> > a) I once had trouble talking to a device, I think it was a Cisco 675,
> >    until I turned _off_ all flow control (hard and soft);
> 
> That's the one flow control setting I have NOT tried...
> 
> > b) maybe you aren't supposed to cross transmit and receive (i.e.,
> >    whatever document you are looking at didn't intend you to).
> 
> Well, according to the manual, pin 1 of the RJ45 is transmit and labelled
> as "Output".  This tells me that it's not the pin to be wired TO a
> transmit on the far end, but to a receive.  Hopefully that's the correct
> interpretation.
> 
> I suppose there's a chance I wired the whole thing completely
> backward...  oh hell.
> 
> Any more suggestions?

Don't depend on the auto sense to determine baud rate, try setting it
manually, some of those things NEED to have only one baud rate set, all
other baud rates can confuse both ends of the connection.

Derek





From mark at linuxhardware.net  Thu Nov 21 09:44:11 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 09:44:11 -0800
Subject: TCO, was Re: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211210722190.28370-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211210722190.28370-100000@serpentor.cobrala>
Message-ID: <200211210944.11525.mark@linuxhardware.net>

Greetings, 

I had been following the PHP programmer thread.  Yesterday, the discussion 
turned to economics and then to whether it was Linux related or not.  It most 
certainly is, one of the hot topics lately in all the IT rags has been the 
debate over the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) of the Linux operating system. 
This group seems very diverse, and I'm sure a TCO discussion could benefit.

Lets face it, buying a $6.99 set of RedHat CDs at cheapbytes.com is far less 
expensive than the proprietary alternatives.  But, this not only includes the 
Operating System, but a full set of software, everything from databases to 
Web servers, to email clients, graphics programs, etc.  Alternatively, if you 
already have access broadband, you can just download the distro of your 
choice, or get a copy from a friend.

Then there are the issues of system maintenance, uptime, etc.  I'm sure there 
are varying experiences here, but we've all heard stories of long uptime on 
Linux servers, (personally, I had a Web/database server up over two years 
without a reboot, only to come down in a power outage).  Pepper this with 
security, quality, and the benefits of open source code, I firmly believe 
Linux comes out far ahead than the alternatives at a TCO of far less. And, as 
far as tech support goes, you can beat the wealth of information on the Web, 
Usenet or the local LUG.

Lets not forget that Linux runs on a variety of hardware old and new.  I have 
a 3 year old laptop running Linux that is still rock solid, no complaints.  I 
have seen some folks around give machine specs along with their question and 
have noticed the 200MHz processors still in use.  "Dude, you're getting a 
Dell", why?  My desktop is a bit old, but works fine.

This past summer, I decided to try Windows XP and explore .NET.  I had not 
used Windows since Win95, and felt that in order to glean a fair opinion I 
needed to try Microsoft's latest offering.  In short, as I said above, I 
firmly believe Linux comes out ahead.  And its much cheaper.  Last week I was 
thrilled after I installed XDarwin on my Mac OSX machine, and then through 
the Fink project, install the Gimp, and the newsreader Pan.  Photoshop is 
expensive, and I like the Gimp, am used to it, and it does exactly what I 
want it to do. (For those of you who have seen Mac Gimp out there for $30, 
you can get the Gimp through fink.sourceforge.net for exactly $30 LESS.) 

Have a good day

Mark






From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Nov 21 10:00:35 2002

> something similar, and they had a variety of cable when I was there.
> You might want to give them a call first? (503) 788-8738 (and their
> website is Pcclub.com if you want to check them out ahead of time.

Thanks to Kelly and Dan for the PC CLub suggestion. Sadly, it only 
stocks a standard 6' null modem -- not that I expected anything 
different.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Thu Nov 21 10:32:29 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 10:32:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Maple 8 on Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <1037868894.21436.20.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <20021121035505.936EC2FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
	 <1037851285.21413.0.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1037853590.3432.25.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <1037868894.21436.20.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <1037903549.13285.35.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 00:54, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> > I suppose Maple might be useful if you got in to some of the
> > higher-level stuff, though.  But I don't know where you're at.
> 
> Perhaps I should just get by with TeXmacs, Maxima, Gnuplot, and the
> emacs calculator for the time being.  I saw a study guide on the shelf
> at the bookstore that says "... with Waterloo Maple" on the cover
> though, so I assumed that perhaps I'd like to have a copy eventually.

So you're just taking the basic Calc series?

Just looking at Maxima, it looks like it does very many things similar
to Maple.

I haevn't gotten in to TeX yet, nor gnuplot... does gnuplot let you
graph more complex things?  More than just F(x)=... type stuff, that is.

I hope between Maxima and emacs calculator you're able to pretty well
emulate a Ti-86-92 calculator, many of the professors will expect you to
have one and will teach you how to use it.

I'm guessing you'll have a laptop with you in class... not a bad idea. 
Unless you're very fast with TeX, I would be sure and have a pad and
paper ready for taking notes.

Also, be very wary of using the calculator (or software) to figure out
the problems for you, at least in Calc 1... it will mess you up down the
line if you can't do quick integrations in your head and really
understand the principles behind it.  If you do differential equations,
you will be very glad you learned all the stuff in Calc 1-3.  DiffEq is
*hard*.

Are you a full time student at PSU?  You may decide to take classes at
PCC as most math professors suck at PSU.  I had five professors from
calc 1 to diffeq (dropped diffeq the first time I attempted it because I
couldn't understand a word the professor was saying) and had only one
really good professor - Dan Streeter.  Joyce O'Halloran is probably one
you really really want to avoid.  I don't remember any of their other
names.

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 21 10:34:31 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

  Seems to me that preview images used to remain available from one time of

(with more than 100 images so far on this project) each time. The guash
plugin, I believe, needs to have the previews generated before it will
display them all.

  Have I missed something here or is there a way to get thumbnail/preview
images that are 'sticky'?

TIA,

Rich




From AthlonRob at data.lm.ro  Thu Nov 21 10:38:09 2002
From: AthlonRob at data.lm.ro (AthlonRob)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 10:38:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] NNTP Server.
In-Reply-To: <007c01c2917b$e2a9f7f0$77ff013d@invent>
References: <007c01c2917b$e2a9f7f0$77ff013d@invent>
Message-ID: <1037903888.13285.38.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 08:34, K.Prasad wrote:
> Would like to ge the procedures of configuring a NNTP server and to
> get the peak performance what all precausions I should take while
> configuring.
> I am new to NNTP , hence I would like to get info from scratch..

So I guess the SSH experiment went well?

What kind of NNTP server do you want?  Google for leafnode (that's what
I use) or INN.  They're two different classes of NNTP servers... so pick
which one you want and read its documentation.  Leafnode is very very
easy.

-- 
AthlonRob <AthlonRob at data.lm.ro>




From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Nov 21 10:46:58 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 10:46:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] NNTP Server.
References: <007c01c2917b$e2a9f7f0$77ff013d@invent> <1037903888.13285.38.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <3DDD2A22.9020906@sun.com>

It sounds to me like you could use a general primer on Linux in general.

The Linux Documentation Project (http://www.tldp.org) has a slew of 
information.  Just type what you want to know about in the search box, 
and it will come up with a HOWTO or two on that subject.

I hate giving generalized RTFM advice, but when you ask such generalized 
questions, that's all we can do besides sending back a barrage of 'which 
what why how when' querys.  Unless we get something more along the lines 
of 'I installed X to do Y on hardware Z as per the instructions in the 
README|HOWTO but it failed with AA error, and now I'm stuck', it's hard, 
VERY hard to help.

Help US help YOU.

-R

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 21 10:36:05 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 10:36:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] null modem in SE
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211028170.17089-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211028170.17089-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <E18Ewcc-0000pm-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Depending on where you are coming from Graybar might be in your path.

I think two RJ45 to DB 9 or 25 connectors and however many feet of cat5 you
need, is going to be your best bet for getting a long null modem in town. 
Don't forget to get a pin extractor if you don't have one. They are about $4-6
which is way over priced for the cheaply made tool, but it will pay for itself
if you confuse the pins. 

Graybar Electric Co., Inc.
901 Northeast 60th Avenue
Portland, OR 97213

Thank you
Russell

When buying null modem cables, be certain of what you are getting.  I've
seen some pretty odd wiring, and even, IMHO, the wrong gender of connector.

RANT: If it's supposed to look like a modem on both ends, it ought to have
female connectors on both ends.

galen

On Wed, 2002-11-20 at 18:27, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> That's funny, I thought this was a Linux listserve. My mistake! :)
> 
> -Scott

We all tend to get annoyed about someone going off topic,
especially when it's a wildly off-topic rant about something
we don't care about. However, in this case, Jeme's assessment
of the new economy is exactly correct, thought I'm not sure
giving public money away for the benefit of a few is a new
phenomenon.

We should all care about what Jeme writes about because we're
all being raped by a corrupt system that does not serve the
public good as it should. Many of us on this list are affected
by this in profound ways. Jeme is trying to point out why
we're in this sad state. Yes, this isn't the correct forum
for this kind of talk, but what is? Certainly not the media,
which is part of the problem. Where does one go to be
heard?

I sometimes wonder what drives a lone gunman to a clock tower.
Maybe it's because he had an important message and nobody would
listen.

Ed


> --- Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:
> > 
> > On Wed, 20 Nov 2002, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> > > The market decides what a good or service is worth. If you can
> > > convince people to buy your pet rocks for $5000, then they are
> > worth
> > > $5000. If you can only get $50 for your used 2001 Mercedes, then
> > it's
> > > only worth $50.
> > 
> > ...which is why "worth" means absolutely nothing and should be
> > discarded
> > along with "deserve" and "earn".
> > 
> > But anyway, the point is that the purpose of the market in labor is
> > to
> > drive down wages and benefits while driving up per-worker production.
> >  
> > That's why high unemployment and low growth (i.e. third-world
> > economics)
> > is ideal for a booming bond market.
> > 
> > We have a situation in this country where all of the essential needs
> > of
> > the people can be met with far less than 100% employment hence the
> > enormous demand generation industry (to create industries that don't
> > need
> > to exist at all), the low quality of consumer goods (to encourage
> > re-buying), the highest incarceration rate in the industrialized
> > world (to
> > decrease the number of have-nots on the street that might revolt
> > against
> > the haves), and a grossly disporportionate military (both to enlist
> > have-nots and give them false hope and to threaten and repress the
> > unenlisted).  Of course, that hyper-inflated military is also what
> > allows
> > us to import goods or off-load labor at a fraction of the real cost
> > by
> > repressing foreign uprisings as well as domestic.
> > 
> > If you read the business press, they're very straightforward on the
> > goals
> > of the "new economy" which include labor market flexibility (which
> > means
> > job insecurity and a perpetually high unemployment rate so that folks
> > will
> > take whatever wage they're given and won't bitch about cutbacks) and
> > the
> > transfer of public funds into private power via government contracts
> > (military and otherwise).  Privatization is exactly that: a
> > privatization
> > of what was formerly public property.  Many lose for the benefit of
> > the
> > few.  Privatizing public works means lower wages for most and huge
> > profits
> > for a small few... and those profits are all tax dollars.  Where a
> > public
> > agency's goal is to USE all of the money it is given, a private
> > corporation's goal is to HOARD the money it takes, dispensing as
> > little as
> > possible.  I ask you which is better for the people and the economy.
> > 
> > Hurray for the new economy.
> > 
> > J.

I don't know if it's possible for you or not, but the best experience I had 
for this situation is to back up a class or two, say calc3, diffy-q and take 
that again.  Then by the time you start the new stuff a lot of older material 
is refreshed.

Sean

By their own words, the existing Unix infrastructure was the better choice.
http://bsd.slashdot.org/bsd/02/11/21/1413247.shtml?tid=109
"Converting a UNIX .COM Site to Windows"

The non-slashdotted doc is here:
http://web.archive.org/web/20011123043914/http://www.securityoffice.net/mssecrets/hotmail.html

I-told-you-sos aside, it's a good paper that give a useful analysis and 
comparison of Unix v Windows.

  For scientific plotting there's Gri. Dan wrote it because he wasn't aware
of gnuplot and his plotting language is (IMO, of course) _much_ better than
gnuplot. See: <http://gri.sourceforge.net/gridoc/html/>.

> I had five professors from calc 1 to diffeq (dropped diffeq the first time
> I attempted it because I couldn't understand a word the professor was
> saying)

  My son started Ball State U. (Fruit Jar Tech) as a statistics major. All
the math faculty were from China and India and weren't required to be fluent
in English. He dropped that major after one year. He ended up with a degree
in CS/Math and got jobs in the insurance industry writing code in COBOL.

Rich




From sean at fork.com  Thu Nov 21 11:32:33 2002
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 11:32:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Xplanet - Gnome
Message-ID: <20021121193234.0C9A793AEE@einstein.seansdomain.org>

I'm running debian-unstable with gnome2.

For a while I was running kde2 and really enjoyed the xplanet as a 
background.  Now that I have gnome2 working again, I borrowed some code, did 
a little reading and hacked this little shell script together.  I run it out 
of cron every five minutes and it works great.

But, I am trying to figure out if there is someway to detect that 

a) I am logged in 
b) I am running gnome2

or alternatively run this with some kewl gnome2 app, so that it will
only run when I am logged in and running gnome2.  I want the cron job to
start and if I'm not logged in stop right there.  If I am logged in and 
running gnome2 it should continue.

BTW, if anyone's interested I also rewrote this script to run under gnome 
using

xsetbg, instead of gnome2

Sean


#!/bin/sh
rm /tmp/xplanet-*.jpg;
FNAME=xplanet-`date +%s`.jpg &&

find /home/sean/.xplanet -name clouds_2000.jpg -cmin +180 -exec rm {} \;
cd ~/.xplanet

if  ! [ -f clouds_2000.jpg ]; then
	wget -np -nd http://xplanet.dyndns.org/clouds/clouds_2000.jpg 
	xplanet -image earth.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg  -shade 100 -output 
day-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200 
	xplanet -image night.jpg -cloud_image clouds_2000.jpg    -cloud_shade 30 
-output night-clouds.jpg -geometry 1600x1200
fi
nice -n19 xplanet -mapdir ~/.xplanet/ -image day-clouds.jpg -night_image 
night-clouds.jpg -blend -output /tmp/$FNAME -geometry 1600x1200 -proj 
rectangular  &&
gconftool-2 -t string -s /desktop/gnome/background/picture_filename 
/tmp/$FNAME

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 21 11:48:07 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 11:48:07 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] fun slashdot story: Microsoft's Hotmail conversion
In-Reply-To: <200211211127.26133.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211144050.27390-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 21 Nov 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> By their own words, the existing Unix infrastructure was the better choice.
> http://bsd.slashdot.org/bsd/02/11/21/1413247.shtml?tid=109
> "Converting a UNIX .COM Site to Windows"
> 
> The non-slashdotted doc is here:
> http://web.archive.org/web/20011123043914/http://www.securityoffice.net/mssecrets/hotmail.html

  The only accessible URL (other than /.) was to the Register.

  Fascinating article! What really caught my attention was the costs of
setting up 3,500 servers: $6,000,000 using MS Server, $15,000,000 using MS
Advanced Server and $0 using FreeBSD or linux. And, Redmond can say -- with
a straight face, no less -- that the Windows TCO is less than that of the
unices? Wow! What's worse is that too many people apparently believe them.

  The above are only the OS licensing costs -- no hardware, time to
install/configure/whatever. To poor folks like me, that's real money.

  Thanks, Carla. I don't know if this gives me hope or depresses me, but
it's certainly good to know.

Rich

From richard.langis at sun.com  Thu Nov 21 13:00:31 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 13:00:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ?
References: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C44604041FEB@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <3DDD496F.2000909@sun.com>

It doesn't really matter to me.  I've never bought a version of Windows 
I've used.  It's not so much the cost though, it's the frustration.  I'd 
MUCH rather have an OS that I can change the network settings on WITHOUT 
having to reboot, or install an application, or restart the windowing 
system without bringing down the box, or run cron jobs, or make my 
desktop a professional-level web/mail/ftp server with a single command, 
or, or, or, or, or...

I don't think Windows being 'FREE' (as in beer) will matter much to 
those who know that Linux is the superior product, free or no.

-R

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Thu Nov 21 13:06:09 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 13:06:09 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ?
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C44604041FEB@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211301480.29535-100000@serpentor.cobrala>


On Thu, 21 Nov 2002, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:

> We have all thought about what the perfect software world would be like, but
> have we ever considered the source of those ideas, may be it is FREE
> windows. (I doubt if Billy Boy will ever allow such a thing to happen :) but
> it's a definite possibility) .If it ever happens, I think Linux and other
> Open Source OS communities should be prepared to take the challenge head-on.

Depends what you mean by "survive". Some of us use Linux (pay for it even)
not because it's cheap or free, but rather because we like contributing to
software that anyone can take advantage of. I think that's where a lot of
the popularity comes from. Even more, many of us also use Linux in large
part because it's unix-like. Windows isn't. Therefore I can't imagine a
free Windows really doing damage to Linux. It might get companies and
govt. agencies to think twice, but Linux will survive.

Preston

From kevinc at dOink.COM  Thu Nov 21 13:07:05 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 13:07:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ? 
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C44604041FEB@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com> 
Message-ID: <20021121210707.7FCD72FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

Which kind of free?  If Windows just becomes a no-charge
download, then I believe that Linux, being open source, will
survive just fine.  If Windows source becomes free (as in open
source) then there would be quite a bit of upheaval as people
scrambled to fix the bugs in that code base, to rewrite ugly
sections (look what happened when Netscape became open source),
and to point fingers of blame at back doors and stupid bugs.
After the bits settled, I think Linux would just have another
open source competitor, but one with a bit more of a foothold
than FreeBSD, for instance.  In the end that wouldn't be bad,
since the competition would be good for consumers of that
software.  Oh yeah, and I mean "competition" as defined by Adam
Smith, not Bill Gates.

Cheers....


On 21 November 2002 at 12:53, "Mathew, Tisson K" <tisson.k.mathew at intel.com> wrote:

windows. (I doubt if Billy Boy will ever allow such a thing to happen :) but
it's a definite possibility) .If it ever happens, I think Linux and other

I like minorfish (formerly minordomo).  I tried mailman but it seemed to 
require a webserver running in the system it was installed on.  Minorfish 
goes in pretty easily and the config files have pretty good comments.
   About scalability I don't know.  I running pretty low volume, low user 
count lists.

From mark at linuxhardware.net  Thu Nov 21 13:27:17 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 13:27:17 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ?
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C44604041FEB@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

Message-ID: <200211211327.17680.mark@linuxhardware.net>

Would this mean that companies like Dell could start selling Desktops without 
an OS?

Most Linux users I know use Linux because it is Linux, not because it is less 
expensive than Windows.  And, there is a whole set of open source tools 
available for Windows.  When I experimented with XP.  The CD burner software 
that came with XP will only record "track at once".  This is not an option 
for live shows, you need to record "disc at once". So I ended up using the 
win32 version of cdrecord.

later

Mark

On Thursday 21 November 2002 12:53 pm, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:

> but have we ever considered the source of those ideas, may be it is FREE
> windows. (I doubt if Billy Boy will ever allow such a thing to happen :)
> but it's a definite possibility) .If it ever happens, I think Linux and
> other Open Source OS communities should be prepared to take the challenge
> head-on.
>
>
> Cheers
> _tisson

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Nov 21 14:03:50 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211211342300.27268-100000@lukem.com>

Yea hows Microsoft supposed to support all of its other losing ventures 
and other free software givaways without Office and Windows covering 
those loses? As a paying customer of Linux distos I wouldn't be 
switching over to Windows even if it was free. I don't want to go back 
to the frustration of Windows if I can help it.

With that said though I still am forced to keep a Windows 98 box around 
for myself to handle Word documents I get from other people. Sure I use 
OpenOffice under Linux but I've found that I would have looked pretty 
foolish sending out a Word doc from OO without checking how it looks 
under MS Word.

Most of the time my OO documents look fine but every once in a while 
something is amiss and I have had to fix the document formatting in 
Word before sending the document off. I don't know it's something I'm 
doing with OO or if there are some minor incompatibilities with OO's 
handling of Word documents.

Tony

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Nov 21 14:09:28 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 14:09:28 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Will Linux survive if Windoze is FREE ? 
In-Reply-To: <20021121210707.7FCD72FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211211359290.11396-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 21 Nov 2002, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> Which kind of free?

While that's a VERY important question, it's not really relevant in that
any sort of free Windows is still Windows and hence full of design flaws
and poor user expectations that bring computer use in general down.

> If Windows just becomes a no-charge download, then I believe that
> Linux, being open source, will survive just fine.

The GNU/Linux system is not just open source, but Free.

> If Windows source becomes free (as in open source)

Woah woah woah...  Open source is NOT the same as Free (as in
freedom).  Free software requires the guarantee of freedom.  Distributing
source code without ensuring the right to redistribute modified and
unmodified source code is hardly respecting liberty and freedom.

> After the bits settled, I think Linux would just have another open
> source competitor, but one with a bit more of a foothold than FreeBSD,
> for instance.

I don't think there's any competition whatsoever.  Those things that make
Windows appealing to some (outside of its corporate backing) are the same
things recognized as flaws by user's of GNU/Linux or the unices.

And, of course, when software is free (as in freedom) there is no need for
competition.  We have something better, then; we have cooperation.  Note
that we have competition when code becomes LESS free (think Xemacs vs. GNU
Emacs where Xemacs is less free because of the lack of proper copyright
transfer in the codebase... of course, Linux has the same problem).

> In the end that wouldn't be bad, since the competition would be good
> for consumers of that software.  Oh yeah, and I mean "competition" as
> defined by Adam Smith, not Bill Gates.

Adam Smith is an economist and economics is the study of scarcity.  In
(free) software, there is no need for scarcity.  The competition would be
between developers (whose resources are scarce) and appeal to users is a
secondary concern.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Nov 21 14:19:04 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 14:19:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Goodthink (was: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211118170.15753-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211211413300.11396-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 21 Nov 2002, Floyd Mann wrote:
> > We all tend to get annoyed about someone going off topic,
> > especially when it's a wildly off-topic rant about something
> > we don't care about. However, in this case, Jeme's assessment
> > of the new economy is exactly correct.
> 
> I find this assertion disturbing, more or less akin to "it is ok to
> post long-winded political diatribes on this list as long as your
> political views match mine."

I think he's trying to say that the discussion was an attempt to assess
the root causes of a problem and discuss those rather than the
superficialities of a particular labor market.

There was no "long-winded political diatribe" (and believe me, being
responsible for many in my day, I know one when I write one).  There was
an attempt to describe the economic system we've achieved to date and how
it relates to the current labor market.

> Toeing the anti-corporate line is not a prerequisite to being
> interested in Linux.

Certainly not.  I don't know that anything I wrote was overtly
anti-corporate.  Now, if I'd gone off quoting Adam Smith and his argument
that "the firm" is a threat to the public good (and his perception of the
free market as an instrument of public benefit) and so on, that would
perhaps be more overtly anti-corporate.

If the logical activist conclusion to my assessment of the new economy is
to take an anti-corporate view, then so be it.  But the assessment itself
was not anti-corporate.  It was merely a description of the state of
affairs in our economy with a few notes as to why things are the way they
are.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Thu Nov 21 15:30:10 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 15:30:10 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <1037905966.2487.32.camel@red>
Message-ID: <20021121233010.96633.qmail@web10412.mail.yahoo.com>

I agree that there are very important issues out there, and we
sometimes feel strongly about it. However, I would think that writing
several paragraphs on one's political stance in a Linux/Unix/Technology
listserve is off topic.

I'm new to this listserve, and I certainly don't want to make waves,
but if every person decided to write a bunch of paragraphs on what we
felt strongly about then pretty soon we'd have to wade through Amway
sales pitches, global warming warnings, starving people in Africa or
that we're all destined for an eternity being tortured in Hell because
we haven't chosen the "right" religion. All of these subjects are of
utmost importance to someone out there, but I'd hope not to have to
wade through them in this listserve.

Anyway, I hope nobody was offended by my original sentence of this
being a Linux listserve, as in the couple of weeks I've been on the
list I have had one Linux bug fixed, lots of suggestions on another,
and was able to contribute to help someone else with a hardware issue.

-Scott

information. DShield is a free and open service.

a percentage of that 3.6 million do think is required to put one of the above
addresses on the top 10 list?

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Thu Nov 21 15:53:47 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 15:53:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] hiring full-time: PHP programmer
In-Reply-To: <20021121233010.96633.qmail@web10412.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021121233010.96633.qmail@web10412.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200211211553.47487.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 21 November 2002 15:30, Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> I agree that there are very important issues out there, and we
> sometimes feel strongly about it. However, I would think that writing
> several paragraphs on one's political stance in a Linux/Unix/Technology
> listserve is off topic.
>
> I'm new to this listserve, and I certainly don't want to make waves,
> but if every person decided to write a bunch of paragraphs on what we
> felt strongly about then pretty soon we'd have to wade through Amway
> sales pitches, global warming warnings, starving people in Africa or
> that we're all destined for an eternity being tortured in Hell because
> we haven't chosen the "right" religion. All of these subjects are of
> utmost importance to someone out there, but I'd hope not to have to
> wade through them in this listserve.

I like that the list is fairly loose about what is on-topic, having 'topic 
cops', like some lists, is worse than wandering a bit.  But the same old 
rants from the same old ranters don't interest me, nor do other people's 
half-baked poli-sci and conspiracy theories. Even if they're right, I don't 
care- that's not why I come here. Plug-talk is available for any subject. I 
suspect posts more appropriate for Plug-talk end up here, for lack of an 
audience.  

You're right that everyone has beliefs that are of the utmost importance to 
them. Where some of them blow it is insisting on spouting diatribes, without 
considering the context or the audience. It's a big turnoff to be lectured 
and talked at, and treated like you know nothing, like you have never given 
thought to the issues. I think most of PLUGers have given a thought or two to 
the larger issues, and really don't need to be yelled at and talked down to.

It seems to self-correct pretty well. Stick around and enjoy the fun.
--

Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Red Hat 8 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

discussion was regarding the state of the economy for tech workers.

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211211555520.30176-100000@serpentor.cobrala>

On Thursday 21 November 2002 15:58, Preston Crawford wrote:
> I think most of PLUGers have given a thought or two to
>
> > the larger issues, and really don't need to be yelled at and talked down
> > to.
>
> When Freedom and the Constitution in this country are being shredded at
> record pace by politicians and corporate thugs it's sometimes hard to stay
> silent. Especially since silence=agreement with the status quo.

Agreed. I'd like to draw a distinction between talking about these things, and 
a person feeling like they possess The Truth, and Must Educate The Ignorant 
Masses, and turning every little thing into a diatribe. There's quite a gap 
between the two.

Something to consider- how does ranting on PLUG help anything? Except sharing 
misery with friends, perhaps. :)   Again, I'm not in favor of getting all 
restrictive over keeping on topic. Me, I think it's better to not waste my 
energy pissing and moaning on PLUG and Slashdot and such about the state of 
the world, and to put those energies to work where they have a chance to do 
some good. Just because I don't talk about my various activisms here, for 
example, doesn't mean I'm sitting on my fat happy ass doing nothing.

From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Thu Nov 21 17:02:57 2002

On Thu, 21 Nov 2002, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Something to consider- how does ranting on PLUG help anything? Except sharing
> misery with friends, perhaps. :)   Again, I'm not in favor of getting all
> restrictive over keeping on topic. Me, I think it's better to not waste my
> energy pissing and moaning on PLUG and Slashdot and such about the state of
> the world, and to put those energies to work where they have a chance to do
> some good. Just because I don't talk about my various activisms here, for
> example, doesn't mean I'm sitting on my fat happy ass doing nothing.

Of course not. I try to effect change in my personal life as well. I
know I don't do enough, and wish I could find a way to affect greater
change.

Where I'm coming from, however, is this. Given that our nation is under
such a colossal assault from corrupt politicians and corporations I tend
to believe that while something may not expressly *help*, it never hurts
to disagree with the status quo. To weigh in. Because the more you weigh
in, the  more you dissent, the more you say, at the very least, "I don't
agree, this is why I don't agree." If enough people did that. If enough
people made their opinions known, then perhaps some would think a little
more about the little choices they make, the things they do, the things
they don't do. Perhaps it would make a difference. Perhaps not.

All I know, is that in times like these I don't want to passively allow
lies and half truths to go unchallenged. If a discussion arises and I have
the time to weigh-in, I will. And I won't begrudge someone else for doing
likewise. What this nation needs is more discussion, more dialogue, not
less. Even if it's a little OT. You can disagree, of course, but that's my
opinion.

Preston




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Nov 21 17:21:06 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 17:21:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] DShield, anyone using this?
In-Reply-To: <1037924188.4995.7.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <E18F0zz-0002Si-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
	<1037924188.4995.7.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1037928066.3585.21.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

I had a similiar situation with my Apache access logs. I used this sight
to perform a reverse IP address lookup: 

  http://eamnesia.com/index.jsp

>From this information I gathered that many of the attacks were coming
from attbi.com's domain.

The nature of the attacks tells me that a worm had infected innocent
computers and was hitting my port 80.

I simply mailed a copy of the relavent portions of the log to
abuse at attbi.com. To their credit, they dispacted several automated
emails and the activity seems to have reduced.

This isn't the technical answer but if it gets the job done effectively
then who cares?

Hope This Helps,


Cooper

From bob at bmtsolutions.com  Thu Nov 21 17:26:52 2002
From: bob at bmtsolutions.com (Bob)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 17:26:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI Wirless  SusE 8.1
Message-ID: <200211211726.52502.bob@bmtsolutions.com>

I am pulling my hair out over this.  Actually this has been a fun learning 
experience.   I first tried the  520+ series but I found out there was no 
opensource drivers yet and does not support the new chipset.  Thanks for the 
help of Mark and Russell I have been able to make headway. . So I replace the 
card and installed D-Link DWL -520 wireless PCI Adapter.  I do see the card 
uses the Prism chipset.  I think that is good? The computer detected the card 
wonderfully and even labels it as a d-link wireless card.  But....I am having 
trouble from there.

First I went modified /etc/sysconfig/eth0 and changed wireless='no' to 
wireless='yes'  I then changed the wireless settings 
    operating mode = ' manage'
    networkname (ESSID) = 'default' (this is what the router is set to by 
    default for at the present.)

Next I did a rcnetwork reboot.  I get the following error:  
    ifup-wireless: command 'iwconfig eth0 mode managed' returned
     ifupwireless: Error for wireless request "Set Mode" (8B06): Set failed
     device eth0 operation not supported.

I get several of these types of errors and, of course, the card does not talk 
to the router.  I looked through the knowledge base and the archived mail 
list and did not see anything that leads me to a solution.  I am sure I am 
overlooking something.     

I am really feeling stupid about this and hate to ask, but can anyone please 
lend a guiding hand.  Is it possible I might have to compile a new kernel that 
supports what I am trying to do.   I am just about ready to throw in the 
towel  ;-)

Thanks very much.

bob

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 16:53, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Port 137 (and 138, 139) are NetBIOS ports. I *think* that this may be due to
> the Bugbear virus which propogates through NetBIOS over your network. It's
> not you, it's other machines "out there".
> 
> I've got it too. My logs get filled with "port 139" attacks (which is a
> NetBIOS vulnerability attack) and port 137 hits.

I get hit on 137 through 139 regularly - Windoze boxen on my subnet
constantly broadcast to and from them looking for other Windoze boxen
they think are on their local network.

If I don't filter them out of my logs, I record about three hits per
minute on each of those ports.

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 17:21, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> I went to download the new ATI drivers but it seems they're only available
> in this "rpm" format. How do I install these files on Debian - is there an
> "rpm" reader?

I just glanced at the page with those drivers on it... but if they're
anything like the nVidia drivers, it was a combo kernel module and XFree
module.

Be aware, the kernel module likely won't work if it was built for a
kernel other than the one you're using.

Rob

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 21 18:41:09 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 18:41:09 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI Wirless  SusE 8.1
In-Reply-To: <200211211756.06302.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
References: <200211211726.52502.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
    <863cpufkme.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <200211211756.06302.bob@bmtsolutions.com>
Message-ID: <E18F4By-0008LD-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Your fine. The cards show up as eth0. and are configured like wire based cards.
iwconfig will tell you the wireless parameters, ifconfig will give you the IP
configuration of the wireless card. I don't know if you can get away with  not
removing your first eth0. Removing it and then reconfiguring the new card as
eth0 is your best bet. After that or if you think you're fine, use the command
lsmod as root. If you're not seeing the wireless modules, then you can add them
by hand or reboot. Even though I did what you've done in yast, I had to first
add the modules by hand. I realized on my second install that I could just
reboot. I rebooted to make sure the modules would come up at boot. I had the
card first in my desktop to play with and then moved it to my headless pc
router. 

So to recap the above ramble, reboot and see if it just works. If not, remove
your old eth0 if you didn't and do what you did before to configure the card.
Reboot again and see if it works. This is all I had to do. 

You can probably use ad-hoc to talk to an AP if managed still gives you grief. 
Most APs will do both. The only issue I have with my setup was I could not set
the encryption. I don't have the same card as you do so this might not be an
issue with your setup, but it might be an issue if you AP is set up to not
except non encrypted packets.

Thank you
Russell

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Nov 21 19:39:39 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 19:39:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
Message-ID: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>

In the last several days, I have installed RH 8.0 on three machines from
RH supplied installation CD's (the 3 CD set, not the 2 CD evaluation
set). The first machine is a 200 Mhz MMX Pentium, the second, a 550 Mhz
AMD K6, and the third an IBM Thinkpad 390X with a 400 Mhz Celeron. The
first two machines have 64 Mb of RAM, each, and the laptop has 96 Mb.

The installation went smoothly on all three machines. I am now
interested in addressing performance problems on the first two machines.
The laptop doesn't seem to have any performance problems that show up to
my eye. On the 200 Mhz Pentium, things seem to work as expected with the
exception of mpg123, which I reported a couple of days ago. On the 550
Mhz AMD, the entire feel of the system is slow, feeling even slower than
the 200 Mhz Pentium.

I'm assuming that the solution is optimizing the kernel for each
machine. I understand from replies to an earlier post that I need to
read up on the low latency patch, and have done some of that.

Today's question is, where do I start reading about what options to
specify (or however it's done) to get a kernel that works well with the
AMD K6 chip as opposed to the Pentium chip. (BTW, I get good performance
from Win98 on the AMD machine and on the Laptop, although I feel as if
the 400 Mhz Celeron on the laptop runs faster than the 550 Mhz AMD.)

I have started reading
http://www.redhat.com/support/resources/howto/kernel-upgrade/ and find
that, "This guide was written specifically for the Intel platform." They
mention specific instructions for Alpha Systems and SPARC systems, but
don't say anything about AMD systems, at least not as far as I've
gotten.

I've also looked in the book Mastering Red Hat Linux 7.1 and found some
hints as to where to look to see what I have. I find in /usr/src and
directory linux-2.4.18-14, and within that a directory configs which has
files ending with athlon.config, i386.config, i586.config, i686.config,
and x86_64.config, among others, but nothing specifically referencing an
AMD K6. How do I know which configuration to use, or is there another
source of configurations for AMD chips?

I've also started reading the howto at:

http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/docs/HOWTO/other-formats/html_single/Kernel-HOWTO.html

It talks about loading the source rpm from the redhat CD. I think I
already have the source -- I selected "everything" during the
installation. The question is where to find information specifically
related to AMD K6.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Nov 21 21:10:26 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 21:10:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Maple 8 on Linux ?
In-Reply-To: <20021121163321.XDJA1052.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
References: <20021121163321.XDJA1052.rwcrmhc52.attbi.com@rwcrwbc55>
Message-ID: <1037941826.12062.21.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 08:33, joncoulsey at attbi.com wrote:
> I'm in calc 1 (251) at PSU this term and have been using Gnuplot for some of the
> homework assignments. I also have the TI-89, which has the same software as the
> TI-92, but can be had for $40-$60 than the TI-92. Some of the students have
> Maple, but I think the student edition is still $120. Gnuplot and the TI-89 do
> it for me, but that may change in some of the higher level stuff. 

Do you know about the emacs calculator?  It's in XEmacs or it runs in
GNU Emacs... in Debian, for emacs you must install the calc package, but
for XEmacs, it's already included.  You can then type "M-x calc" and get
what is essentially a souped up HP-48 that can also do some algebra.  It
uses Gnuplot to draw plots.

There is also a great Gnuplot mode for the emacsen, that is installed
when you install gnuplot, under Debian.  It gives you a special mode for
editting gnuplot scripts, where you can send commands from the edit
buffer to a live gnuplot process.  This works very well on a laptop
right there in class.  You get way better plots that you get with a
simple hand calculator.  The only missing feature is the trace; where
you move a cursor along the curve to find the function's value at some
point.  You don't really need that though, since it's not hard to simply
compute the value by hand.

I also like to use Guile, MIT Scheme, or CMUCL running under XEmacs
while in math class.  I use it to compute function values, and also have
written some simple algebra routines (learned from "Scheme and the Art
of Programming", MIT Press) and stuff like the distance formula.

Another cool tool for Calculus is "Maxima" running as a session object
under "TeXmacs".  TeXmacs is pretty awesome for taking notes in a math
class, since once you learn how, you can type math at full speed.  It
uses real TeX fonts onscreen, WYSIWYG.  TeX is what is used to typeset
mathematics textbooks in real life.  "Maxima" is the original computer
algebra system, developed years ago for the US Deptartment of Energy. 
It's written in Common Lisp (CLTL Lisp, if you know what that means it
matters) and is now released under the GPL.  It is maintained at the
University of Texas by a professor and his crew.  The Debian Maxima
package runs under GNU Common Lisp (GCL), also maintained at utexas.

Both the emacs calculator and maxima, for a lisp programmer, are very
interesting programs...  I have not figured them out yet, but plan to do
so.  Anyone on PLUG know much about them?  Any hints?  Perhaps if this
gets going, we should move it's thread to "plug-devel".

I have not tried GRI yet, but plan to.  It looks very good.  Another
tool I plan to learn to use is GNU "R", for statistics.  It is one of
THE tools for that sort of work.  There is also a mode in XEmacs for
both R and for GRI.  The one for R is called "ESS", or "Emacs Speaks
Statistics".

Running inferiour processes like that under XEmacs or TeXmacs is really
wonderful.  Once you learn how to do it, you'll wonder how you got along
without it.

If enough people are interested in learning to use these tools together,
let me know, and we can set up a meeting or something.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Nov 21 21:54:47 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 21:54:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1037944487.12057.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 19:39, Richard Steffens wrote:
> In the last several days, I have installed RH 8.0 on three machines from
> RH supplied installation CD's (the 3 CD set, not the 2 CD evaluation
> set). The first machine is a 200 Mhz MMX Pentium, the second, a 550 Mhz
> AMD K6, and the third an IBM Thinkpad 390X with a 400 Mhz Celeron. The
> first two machines have 64 Mb of RAM, each, and the laptop has 96 Mb.
> 
> The installation went smoothly on all three machines. I am now
> interested in addressing performance problems on the first two machines.
> The laptop doesn't seem to have any performance problems that show up to
> my eye. On the 200 Mhz Pentium, things seem to work as expected with the
> exception of mpg123, which I reported a couple of days ago. On the 550
> Mhz AMD, the entire feel of the system is slow, feeling even slower than
> the 200 Mhz Pentium.

For playing MP3's, you might like to try "xmms", make it SUID root, and
check off the "use realtime priority" option.  See if that makes it work
a little better.  It is safe to make "xmms" setuid to root, since it
drops permissions very early, right after setting it's scheduling
priority to realtime round robin.  (A quick look at the source code will
verify that.)

> I'm assuming that the solution is optimizing the kernel for each
> machine. I understand from replies to an earlier post that I need to
> read up on the low latency patch, and have done some of that.

The performance problems might have more to do with disk I/O latency
than anything else.  Install and read about the "hdparm" tool.  You can
use it to improve disk performance by quite a lot.  Turn on 32bit I/O,
and DMA, and set multi count to 16.  That alone will often give you
another several megabytes per second throughput.  If you've got UDMA 33
or 66 hard drive + controller, but the BIOS does not set the disks into
that mode automaticly, then you can also use "hdparm" to set the UDMA
mode.  It only works when the hardware can do it though.

> Today's question is, where do I start reading about what options to
> specify (or however it's done) to get a kernel that works well with the
> AMD K6 chip as opposed to the Pentium chip.

There's a checkoff in the kernel configuration (make menuconfig) for
what type of CPU you have.  If you are running blazingly new Debian
unstable ("Sid"), you could try to use the "apt-build" tool to install
all your software, and have it autobuild each package with full per-CPU
optimizations.  I've not tried to do this yet myself, so don't know how
well it works.

installed on drizzle.pdxlinux.org, including the LDP "HOWTO" documents
and this mailing list's archive.

From revans at e-z.net  Thu Nov 21 22:13:34 2002

References: Thu Nov 21 18:52:54 2002@"Russell Evans" <revans@e-z.net>
Message-ID: <20021122064112.DWCK26148.rwcrmhc51.attbi.com@linux>

I was never able to use the binary Nvidia driver on my box. After the posts 
last week, I realized that I wasn't the only one and it might not be the fact
that I bought a cheap card. I started looking for an answer and found one that
worked for me. In the BIOS set PnP OS to no , and set  Assign IRQ to VGA set to
yes. 

Thank you
Russell

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Nov 21 22:49:56 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 21 Nov 2002 22:49:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Debian "alien" and "equivs" (care and feeding)
In-Reply-To: <1037928671.3572.25.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211211718060.21858-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
	 <1037928671.3572.25.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <1037947796.12048.52.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 17:31, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Tyler,
> 
> Alien:
>   
>   http://kitenet.net/programs/alien/

Yes, just "apt-get install alien", then "man alien".  Another tool in
this category that every Debian admin should know about is "equivs".

It does not always work right, since Red Hat packages are most often not
Debian Policy compliant.  They go through a lot less trouble making
certain that things are installed in FHS compliant locations, I am
told.  The libraries are not always named the same either, and
interpackage dependancies can differ, since Debian tends to split things
up more, or the packages names are just different.

You might want to just open the RPM with "mc" (midnight commander) and
copy what you need out, then hand install it.  You should at least use
"mc" to poke around inside the generated .deb to see that the locations
it will install things are kosher and compatible.  Be aware that if you
hand install stuff, it can get blown away on upgrade (of the X11
packages, in this case), so to prevent that, you might like to place the
affected packages on "hold" status.

If you use "aptitude" (or ye olde "dselect") for your package management
tasks, you can put a package on "hold" using the "=" key.  That will
prevent "aptitude" from automaticly marking that package (and any
dependancies) for upgrade.  For example, I use this to hold onto my
custom build of "iptables", which I needed to match some special patches
(POM) applied to my kernel.  I've also used it, on "drizzle", to ensure
that the EVMS user space tools are not upgraded past the version built
into the kernel there.

I've used "equivs" to declare library dependancies for an older copy of
"Maple" installed on a computer at PSU.  Without the "equivs" generated
pseudopackage, "apt" would have uninstalled the libraries that older
version of "Maple" was built against, since it would have seen them as
no longer in use by anything.

> Use Linux, and reap the pleasures of getting yelled at and insulted.

Karl's response pointed the inquisitor to a rich source of useful
information related to the original post.  I don't see how that's yelling
or insulting.

Now MY comment was sarcastic and uncalled-for, but it wasn't an attempt to
ridicule this person for lack of knowledge.  It was an attempt to ridicule
the person for not asking a question at all and playing this
passive-aggressive game wherein one whines about what they want and still
expects people to meet those needs without being directly asked.  
Personally, I find such behavior not only rude, but indicative of serious
ego problems on the part of the whiner.

> Did it ever occur to you that not all people posting here have a good
> command of English?

Not that this was directed particularly at me, but I'd just like to say
that my response is related to the fact that there was no request, just an
expectation of service.

I understand that in some languages no change is made to a sentences
structure at all when a question is asked.  I have no idea if that's the
case with this person's native tongue, but throwing a question mark on the
end would have done it for me.

> You preach 'Linux is the best! Join us!', then jump all over people
> who don't write posts that meet your exacting standards.  That'll win
> people over, why, just think- if you insult ten newbies per day, who
> in turn each insult ten newbies, and so on, Linux will achieve world
> domination in no time.

Now, see, here's the REAL reason I replied to this post.

I (to take this last bit personally, however incorrect that may be) might
preach "GNU is the best!  Use Free Software!" and I surely will jump all
over a person who doesn't write posts that meet my exacting standards.  
But I see those actions as complementary, not contradictory.  It's not
insulting to point out sloppiness in reason or laziness in activity and it
is exactly sloppy reasoning and laziness that prevent people from using
Free Software in the first place (exception: people with vastly different
priorities than I have; say, people who hate and wish harm to fall upon
others and themselves).

So having exacting standards and working uphold standards is the same
thing as encouraging Free Software, it's just the hard way.

From bob at bmtsolutions.com  Thu Nov 21 23:16:54 2002
From: bob at bmtsolutions.com (Bob)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 2002 23:16:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PCI Wirless  SusE 8.1
In-Reply-To: <E18F4By-0008LD-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <200211211726.52502.bob@bmtsolutions.com> <200211211756.06302.bob@bmtsolutions.com> <E18F4By-0008LD-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200211212316.54393.bob@bmtsolutions.com>

On Thursday 21 November 2002 18:41, Russell Evans wrote:
> Your fine. The cards show up as eth0. and are configured like wire based
> cards. iwconfig will tell you the wireless parameters, ifconfig will give
> you the IP configuration of the wireless card. I don't know if you can get
> away with  not removing your first eth0. Removing it and then reconfiguring
> the new card as eth0 is your best bet. After that or if you think you're
> fine, use the command lsmod as root. If you're not seeing the wireless
> modules, then you can add them by hand or reboot. Even though I did what
> you've done in yast, I had to first add the modules by hand. I realized on
> my second install that I could just reboot. I rebooted to make sure the
> modules would come up at boot. I had the card first in my desktop to play
> with and then moved it to my headless pc router.
>
> So to recap the above ramble, reboot and see if it just works. If not,
> remove your old eth0 if you didn't and do what you did before to configure
> the card. Reboot again and see if it works. This is all I had to do.
>
> You can probably use ad-hoc to talk to an AP if managed still gives you
> grief. Most APs will do both. The only issue I have with my setup was I
> could not set the encryption. I don't have the same card as you do so this
> might not be an issue with your setup, but it might be an issue if you AP
> is set up to not except non encrypted packets.
>
> Thank you
> Russell

Russell I got it working.  I deleted the eth0 and used Yast to to install the 
wireless card.  I went edited /etc/sysconfig/network/ifcg-eth0 and changed 
wireless='no'  to yes.  I rebooted and bang it is working.  I can not believe 
how hard is was making.  But I have learned a bunch in this venture.  Thanks 
everyone and especially Russell.

Now I just got to get encryption to work and I am golden. But I am going to 
wait until this weekend to tackle that one. 


bob

manually..  I sure someday I will have to run across having to do this. 

Again thanks for all you help.  

Bob

>>  silent. Especially since silence=agreement with the status quo.
>
>Agreed. ...snip... Me, I think it's better to not waste my
>energy pissing and moaning on PLUG and Slashdot and such about the state of
>the world, and to put those energies to work where they have a chance to do
>some good. Just because I don't talk about my various activisms here, for
>example, doesn't mean I'm sitting on my fat happy ass doing nothing.



	Me, either, Carla!  ...  ;-) ...

	I've deleted most of the original posts in this thread, due 
to the subject line. However, I'll chime in with THIS article, that I 
feel is highly relevant to the NEW direction that this tread has 
taken:

	eWeek: "Tech Outlook 2003" ...
		http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,713861,00.asp

	To add my $0.02 to this conversation, I think that placating 
these ethically ignorant, evil, or simply economically dangerous 
"executives" who think that they can fire someone making $60K per 
year, and hire someone with the same, or MORE, experience for $40K is 
obscene and evil, at the very least.

	Like Ayn Rand's "John Galt" (in her book, "Atlas Shrugged"), 
I choose to remove my participation from this punitive charade that 
masquerades as the Computer Information Technology industry. These 
people (US companies) need US more than we need THEM.
	Speaking (again) for myself, I have other skills and 
experience beyond Computer IT, and I'm already using them! I know 
that others do not, so I don't fault them for participating in this 
horrendous mess by not "dropping out" as I have. The folks that feel 
that they have "no choice" but to endure dramatic pay cuts, job loss, 
or ever-increasing responsibilities, longer hours and job stress have 
my sympathy and pity. I've discovered that perfectly usable 
rack-mounted servers also make perfectly good DOOR STOPS, too.

	It's up to each one of use to use his/her "moral compass" to 
decide when "enough is enough." Enduring this abuse amounts to 
"enabling" (psychological definition) - just as much as if you were 
to buy an alcoholic a drink!
	I encourage everyone and anyone who has other skills or 
dreams to pursue them. Create your own bunker and hunker down. Let 
the IT war rage outside of your "bubble", and emerge safely - with 
your skills intact! - when the climate is much more in your favor.





Patrick Beart

From alexlinux at qwest.net  Thu Nov 21 23:46:35 2002
From: alexlinux at qwest.net (alex)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 02:46:35 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Fwd: OpenOffice default paper size
Message-ID: <1037951195.1934.10.camel@alexlinux.qwest.net>

I saw three lines that I changed in order for it to come up as a letter
size default. The first line did nothing so I just went ahead and
changed the other 2 (checking each change) and it took all 3 to effect
the change. Of course right now it seems that lpr has dumped all over
itself and I am unable to print at all. Still working that one out.

Alex

Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
What are the other two places? I only made the one change and it solved 
my problems. I did find two other places in my system's psprint.conf 
file but those paper size values were associated with the two printers 
I have setup. I was able to setup the appropriate paper size for each 
printer when I set them up in the admin program.

Thanks,

Tony

On Tuesday 19 November 2002 21:27 pm, alex wrote:
> Here's an update to the paper size from way back when on the 26th of
> September this year.
>
> There are 3 places that you need to change the paper size at in order
> for this to work but work it will.
>
> Anthony Schlemmer wrote....
>
> according to: http://www.jca.umbc.edu/FAQ_Computing.html
>
> "There is no way (AFAIK) that a user can change their default page
>  size. But the SysAdmin may do so by editting the file:
>
> /path/to/OpenOffice/share/psprint/psprint.conf
>
> In this file, look for the parameter: PPD_PageSize . Set it to an
> appropriate value, like Letter."
>
>
> The file is nicely commented; changing it worked great on my
>  installation

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 13:30, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 21 November 2002 13:08, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > Do you know about the "man" command?  I assume that by now you do...
> ><snip useless blah blah>

What I said was:

Do you know about the "man" command?  I assume that by now you do... 
The "sshd" has a man page, and if you read that and tinker a little,
you'll know about as much about it as the rest of us.

If you knew me a little better and could imagine the tone I'd have taken
when speaking that remark, you'd not be so quick to call it rude.  I'd
have a smile and a twinkle in my eye when I took the jab at you...

You called the most relevant part of my statement "useless", Karla. 
That was that "if you read it's man page and tinker a little you'll know
as much about it as the rest of us".  That is to say, it's really not
THAT mysterious; there is not much archana beyond the man page's
contents, so don't be afraid to just go from there.

I try to find answers first from documentation, then from a list search
(http://new.pdxlinux.org/search.html), then by a more global internet
search, then by asking.

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Nov 22 08:17:58 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 08:17:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <1037944487.12057.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211220815130.1640-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> There's a checkoff in the kernel configuration (make menuconfig) for
> what type of CPU you have.

You need gcc 3.2 for any AMD-related optimizations, IIRC. Not sure if that
applies to the older Althons at all.

> If you are running blazingly new Debian unstable ("Sid"), you could try
> to use the "apt-build" tool to install all your software, and have it
> autobuild each package with full per-CPU optimizations.  I've not tried
> to do this yet myself, so don't know how well it works.

I've been experimenting with apt-build and have to say it hasn't worked
very reliably, at least for the large programs where such a utility is
more convenient and useful than apt-get source. It doesn't appear to have
generated a lot of popularity yet, either, but I should keep trying it and
figure out more.

Tyler



On 21 Nov 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 19:39, Richard Steffens wrote:
> > In the last several days, I have installed RH 8.0 on three machines from
> > RH supplied installation CD's (the 3 CD set, not the 2 CD evaluation
> > set). The first machine is a 200 Mhz MMX Pentium, the second, a 550 Mhz
> > AMD K6, and the third an IBM Thinkpad 390X with a 400 Mhz Celeron. The
> > first two machines have 64 Mb of RAM, each, and the laptop has 96 Mb.
> >
> > The installation went smoothly on all three machines. I am now
> > interested in addressing performance problems on the first two machines.
> > The laptop doesn't seem to have any performance problems that show up to
> > my eye. On the 200 Mhz Pentium, things seem to work as expected with the
> > exception of mpg123, which I reported a couple of days ago. On the 550
> > Mhz AMD, the entire feel of the system is slow, feeling even slower than
> > the 200 Mhz Pentium.
>
> For playing MP3's, you might like to try "xmms", make it SUID root, and
> check off the "use realtime priority" option.  See if that makes it work
> a little better.  It is safe to make "xmms" setuid to root, since it
> drops permissions very early, right after setting it's scheduling
> priority to realtime round robin.  (A quick look at the source code will
> verify that.)
>
> > I'm assuming that the solution is optimizing the kernel for each
> > machine. I understand from replies to an earlier post that I need to
> > read up on the low latency patch, and have done some of that.
>
> The performance problems might have more to do with disk I/O latency
> than anything else.  Install and read about the "hdparm" tool.  You can
> use it to improve disk performance by quite a lot.  Turn on 32bit I/O,
> and DMA, and set multi count to 16.  That alone will often give you
> another several megabytes per second throughput.  If you've got UDMA 33
> or 66 hard drive + controller, but the BIOS does not set the disks into
> that mode automaticly, then you can also use "hdparm" to set the UDMA
> mode.  It only works when the hardware can do it though.
>
> > Today's question is, where do I start reading about what options to
> > specify (or however it's done) to get a kernel that works well with the
> > AMD K6 chip as opposed to the Pentium chip.
>
> There's a checkoff in the kernel configuration (make menuconfig) for
> what type of CPU you have.  If you are running blazingly new Debian
> unstable ("Sid"), you could try to use the "apt-build" tool to install
> all your software, and have it autobuild each package with full per-CPU
> optimizations.  I've not tried to do this yet myself, so don't know how
> well it works.
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
