Subject: RE: [PLUG] DShield, anyone using this?


Michael,

Thanks for the information. I just went back through my logs and found
that the first time my logs were emailed to me for review and contained
the start of the port 137 probes was Oct. 2, 2002, which is 2 days post
w32.bugbear.  BTW, bugbear is not a virus, but a worm.

I could kick myself for not putting these two facts together, but I was
ass deep in a swamp full of alligators at the time.

Thanks again,

Jim

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 19:53, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Port 137 (and 138, 139) are NetBIOS ports. I *think* that this may be due
to
> the Bugbear virus which propogates through NetBIOS over your network. It's
> not you, it's other machines "out there".
>
> I've got it too. My logs get filled with "port 139" attacks (which is a
> NetBIOS vulnerability attack) and port 137 hits.

> > Top ports probed
> > http://www.dshield.org/topports.html
> >
> > The worst
> > http://www.dshield.org/top10.html
> >
> > There were 3669393 reports of port 137 being probed on 2002-11-20. How
> much of
> > a percentage of that 3.6 million do think is required to put one of the
> above
> > addresses on the top 10 list?
> >
> > Thank you
> > Russell
> >
> >
> > _______________________________________________
> > PLUG mailing list
> > PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> > http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Nov 22 10:24:51 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 10:24:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.
In-Reply-To: <200211211330.33371.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <004a01c2907a$8ac3e8e0$74ff013d@invent>
	 <01d101c2914c$665fc690$1dff013d@invent>
	 <1037912892.12057.0.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <200211211330.33371.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1037989491.14407.17.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2002-11-21 at 13:30, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 21 November 2002 13:08, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > Do you know about the "man" command?  I assume that by now you do...
> ><snip useless blah blah>
> 
> Use Linux, and reap the pleasures of getting yelled at and insulted. Hey, 
> there's a recruiting pitch. K. Prasad, I hope you found the useful responses 
> in this thread.

I hate it when people scream about rudeness and meanness when somebody
tries to explain how to find an answer to a question instead of just
spewing forth the answer to the question.

This is far too common in the computing world.  People have a question,
they ask it, and then they get an answer, hand-holding them through the
whole thing.  They then learn absolutely nothing that could help them in
their next project (like... say... an NNTP server?)... and when the next
obsticle appears, they're dependent upon free tech support to solve it.

If, instead of being told exactly what to do, they're told where to look
for the answer to their question... chances are they'll look there the
next time and won't have to ask for help.  Eventually they'll get to the
point where they can start helping other people with their questions.

But no, Carla, this is the rude way to do things, huh?

Give a man a fish and he is fed for a day.  Teach a man to fish and he
is never hungry again.

If you were saying Karl was being rude in the specific language used - I
didn't read it as being rude at all.  You should have learned by now
that Internet communications are prone to being mis-interpreted - we
don't have tone or body language to help set the mood.  That makes it
somewhat stupid to jump on somebody in things like this - where it could
be questionable what tone the poster was posting in.

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>




From kevinc at dOink.COM  Fri Nov 22 10:37:33 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 10:37:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ISO & CDR checksums
Message-ID: <20021122183735.8127F2FEB3@joseph.doink.com>

I'm having an odd trouble with ISO checksums.  I created my own ISO 
of some Mandrake 9.0 contrib rpms.  Then I run the md5sum on that ISO.
I also burn the ISO to CDR and subsequently compute the md5sum of the 
CDR like so 'dd if=/dev/scd1 | md5sum'.  This has always worked, 
except for when the CD drive mounts or unmounts during the dd.  I 
think I've prevented the (un)mounting problem, and yet I can't get 
the md5sum of one burned ISO to be identical on the burned CDR and 
the ISO spinning on the harddrive.  Doing just the same thing with 
other ISOs is working with the same equipment and method.  Oddly 
enough, I can read the burned suspect CDR just fine when I mount it 
*AND* the md5/gpg signatures on all the RPMs on the CDR are just fine.

Do you think it's safe to consider the burned ISO good?

Does anyone have a better technique for computing the md5sum of the 
CDR?

Thanks....

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 11:36:26 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 11:36:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.
In-Reply-To: <1037989491.14407.17.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <004a01c2907a$8ac3e8e0$74ff013d@invent> <200211211330.33371.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <1037989491.14407.17.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <200211221136.26818.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The sad thing is that when someone needs help for the most common 
configuration items for Linux/Unix like: email, FTP, SSH, DNS there are 
a number of websites with good information available online. I went 
though this with OpenBSD when I needed to figure out how to setup DNS 
and sendmail and a Google search with the proper keywords yielded 
quickly yielded pages with all of the information I needed.

Certainly it's fine to spell out the solution step-by-step but I would 
hope that most people trying to do system configuration for the various 
Unix services might want to learn something in the process and not be 
above RTFM replies that include relevant man pages and/or URLs.

Of course we've all seen idiotic responses from some people that give 
the stock "RTFM" response with no relevant resources sited which is 
just a waste of bits IMHO.

Tony

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 11:52:41 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 11:52:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com> <1037944487.12057.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3DDE8B09.B5B33CE0@attbi.com>

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> For playing MP3's, you might like to try "xmms", make it SUID root, and
> check off the "use realtime priority" option.

Thanks. I'll look into that.

> > I'm assuming that the solution is optimizing the kernel for each
> > machine. I understand from replies to an earlier post that I need to
> > read up on the low latency patch, and have done some of that.
> 
> The performance problems might have more to do with disk I/O latency
> than anything else.  Install and read about the "hdparm" tool.  You can
> use it to improve disk performance by quite a lot.  Turn on 32bit I/O,
> and DMA, and set multi count to 16.  That alone will often give you
> another several megabytes per second throughput.  If you've got UDMA 33
> or 66 hard drive + controller, but the BIOS does not set the disks into
> that mode automaticly, then you can also use "hdparm" to set the UDMA
> mode.  It only works when the hardware can do it though.

Lots of good stuff to learn. I think this machine may be old enough that
most of the higher performance stuff won't be there, but I'll look into
it.

> > Today's question is, where do I start reading about what options to
> > specify (or however it's done) to get a kernel that works well with the
> > AMD K6 chip as opposed to the Pentium chip.
> 
> There's a checkoff in the kernel configuration (make menuconfig) for
> what type of CPU you have.

I guess I'll just give that a try. I understand that compiling the
kernel doesn't change what's installed, so I won't really hurt anything
if I get it wrong the first (or second, or third) time. The important
thing is to make sure I don't overwrite the boot image (or whatever that
file is called), and add another option to GRUB. When I get back this
evening, I'll give it a try.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From alex at daniloff.com  Fri Nov 22 12:05:46 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:05:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one =?iso-8859-1?q?box=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <1037989491.14407.17.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <200211222005.gAMK5kv28476@gate.daniloff.com>

Hello Lunux folkz,
I have a Linux box with three NIC's in it (eth0, eth1 and eth2).
I need to divide my local network into two subnets e.g.
192.168.1.0 on eth1 and 192.168.2.0 on eth2
and perform their masquerading and firewalling on eth0.
Let say eth0 assigned to 63.215.105.0 network.
I assume that I can choose subnet mask ether 
255.255.255.0 or 255.255.0.0 for both these subnets.
Please correct me if I'm wrong!
Now I setup routing tables in this order:
route add -net 127.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 lo
route add -net 63.215.105.0 255.255.255.0 eth0
route add default gw 63.215.105.1
route add -net 192.168.1.0 255.255.0.0 eth1
route add -net 192.168.2.0 255.255.0.0 eth2

I hope, this will produce routing between two
subnets on eth1 and eth2 and routing between
gateway and eth0.
Please correct me if I'm wrong. 

How I can masquerade eth1 and eth2 on eth0 interface
simultaneously?

Thank you in advance for any thoughts or info.

Alex

  



From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 12:11:11 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:11:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211222005.gAMK5kv28476@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222005.gAMK5kv28476@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <200211221211.11824.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think you'll want a subnet of 255.255.255.0 for the two 192.168.x.x 
subnets. By only using 255.255.0.0 it matches only 192.168.x.x so the 
system won't know which interface to use so you need to match that 
third octet as well.

Tony

From yrn4dsl at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 12:15:43 2002
From: yrn4dsl at attbi.com (david)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:15:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended Reading?
Message-ID: <20021122121543.20e303f8.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>

Hello all,

I find myself buying one or two unix related books each month. Unfortunately I've been burned a few times by books that were, inaccurate, full of fluff or just plain badly written. In the hope that my experience may help someone else, here are my opinions on my latest 2 purchases. I would hesitate to call this a review. How about a tip?


DNS & BIND Cookbook by Cricket Liu
O'Reilly & Associates

If you're an experienced DNS admin and you already have the current edition of DNS & BIND you probably don't need this book. I found very little in this book that wasn't covered at least in passing in DNS & BIND. Unlike the cricket book, the DNS & BIND Cookbook covers answers to specific problems rather than covering the entire topic in depth. I'd buy it with, not instead of, DNS & BIND. 

Pros: 	1 If you have a specific problem with DNS or you like lots of examples, this is the book for you.
	2 It's relatively cheap. I bought mine for $28 at Powell's.
	3 You won't strain you back toting it around (about 220 pages).
	4 It answered a couple of questions I had that were not covered well enough for me by the Cricket book.

Cons:	1 It's short. It may not have what you're looking for.
	2 It covers a lot of the same territory as DNS & BIND.



Absolute BSD, The Ultimate Guide to FreeBSD by Michael Lucas
No Starch Press

I found the title a to be a bit overstated. The foreward begins with a pompous, "Twenty five years. My god, has it really been that long?" The cover is just plain ugly. All of these flaws are relatively minor defects in a good book about FreeBSD. Absolute BSD is aimed at using FreeBSD as a server platform, not a desktop OS. I think there may be better guides for complete beginners, but for those familiar with 'nix and wanting to get a little further beyond the basics Absolute BSD is a good reference.

Pros:	1 Good coverage of doing "real work" with FreeBSD.
	2 Good coverage of kernel tuning and customizing.
	3 Each BSD and Linux ditribution has it's own configuration quirks. Chapter 9 covers FreeBSD's /etc in depth.
	4 The ugly brown cover will conceal any coffee stains.

Cons:	1 Misleading title? My ultimate guide to FreeBSD would be having the FreeBSD Core team on site, offering advice, and smacking me with a rubber chicken when I screw up. 
	2 How much relevance will it have when FreeBSD 5 is stable?



In short I consider both purchases to be money well spent, of course YMMV.

Here's the flip side of the coin. Does anyone have any recommendations on books on LDAP, preferably OpenLDAP?



From yrn4dsl at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 12:19:21 2002
From: yrn4dsl at attbi.com (david)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:19:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.
In-Reply-To: <200211221136.26818.aschlemm@attbi.com>

	<200211211330.33371.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 12:34:32 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:34:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Samba config question
Message-ID: <3DDE94D8.54C2122B@attbi.com>

I'm trying to get Samba working again. I remember that for my setup, I
needed very little in the smb.conf file. I've found a couple of places
that tell me what to do, starting with:

http://www.troubleshooters.com/linux/samba.htm

It's a nice step-by-step guide. It starts with simply making the linux
machine visible to the windows machines. That part works. The smb.conf
file looks like this:

[global]
   guest account = pcguest
   workgroup = House

With that for an smb.conf file, I can see the linux machine from windows
explorer.

The next step is to make /tmp visible and accessible. Instructions at
that web site and in a book say that all I need do is add the following
to my smb.conf file, (well, the web site had me create another
directory, /scratch, but with the same permissions as /tmp, and the
result was the same):

[tmp]
   comment = Temporary file space
   path = /tmp
   read only = no
   public = yes

When I restart Samba and try to look at anything on the linux machine
from windows explorer, I get a password prompt. The book and the web
site don't mention this happening at this stage. The message looks like
this:

---------------------------------------------------------------
Enter Network Password

	You must supply a password to make this connection:

	Resource: \\NEC\IPC$

	Password:
---------------------------------------------------------------

(The name of the linux machine is nec.)

I did try adding the following to the [global] section, but it made no
difference:

   security = share

I assume that there's some other step I'm omitting. Could someone point
me in the right direction, please.

Thanks.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From alex at daniloff.com  Fri Nov 22 12:37:51 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)

OK,
If I set subnet mask to 255.255.255.0 for the both 192.168.x.x
subnets will these subnets be visible for each other?
If I need to masquerade them on eth0 how these eth1 and eth2 
interfaces should be represented?

Thanks.
Alex  

-------------------
> I think you'll want a subnet of 255.255.255.0 for the two
192.168.x.x 
> subnets. By only using 255.255.0.0 it matches only 192.168.x.x so
the 
> system won't know which interface to use so you need to match that 
> third octet as well.
> 
> Tony
> 
> On Friday 22 November 2002 12:05 pm, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> > Hello Lunux folkz,
> > I have a Linux box with three NIC's in it (eth0, eth1 and eth2).

> > Let say eth0 assigned to 63.215.105.0 network.
> > I assume that I can choose subnet mask ether
> > 255.255.255.0 or 255.255.0.0 for both these subnets.
> > Please correct me if I'm wrong!
> > Now I setup routing tables in this order:
> > route add -net 127.0.0.0 255.0.0.0 lo
> > route add -net 63.215.105.0 255.255.255.0 eth0
> > route add default gw 63.215.105.1
> > route add -net 192.168.1.0 255.255.0.0 eth1
> > route add -net 192.168.2.0 255.255.0.0 eth2
> >
> > I hope, this will produce routing between two
> > subnets on eth1 and eth2 and routing between
> > gateway and eth0.
> > Please correct me if I'm wrong.

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 12:34, Richard Steffens wrote:
> I'm trying to get Samba working again. I remember that for my setup, I
> needed very little in the smb.conf file. I've found a couple of places
> that tell me what to do, starting with:
> 
> http://www.troubleshooters.com/linux/samba.htm
> 
> It's a nice step-by-step guide. It starts with simply making the linux
> machine visible to the windows machines. That part works. The smb.conf
> file looks like this:
> 
> [global]
>    guest account = pcguest

> 
> With that for an smb.conf file, I can see the linux machine from windows
> explorer.
> 
> The next step is to make /tmp visible and accessible. Instructions at
> that web site and in a book say that all I need do is add the following
> to my smb.conf file, (well, the web site had me create another
> directory, /scratch, but with the same permissions as /tmp, and the
> result was the same):

> [tmp]
>    comment = Temporary file space
>    path = /tmp
>    read only = no
>    public = yes

> When I restart Samba and try to look at anything on the linux machine
> from windows explorer, I get a password prompt. The book and the web
> site don't mention this happening at this stage. The message looks like
> this:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------
> Enter Network Password
> 
> 	You must supply a password to make this connection:
> 
> 	Resource: \\NEC\IPC$
> 
> 	Password:
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> (The name of the linux machine is nec.)

You will be asked for a password, even for a guest account.  If you
don't enter a password (just hit return, or click ok), then you will be
connected as the guest user.  BTW, the guest user needs to have a system
account, and a SAMBA account, what you choose for a password doesn't
seem to matter.  You may also need to add the line:

guest ok = yes

under your [tmp] section.
> 
> I did try adding the following to the [global] section, but it made no
> difference:
> 
>    security = share
> 
> I assume that there's some other step I'm omitting. Could someone point
> me in the right direction, please.

HTH,

Derek Loree

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 14:46:24 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 14:46:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DDE8B09.B5B33CE0@attbi.com>
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>
	 <1037944487.12057.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <3DDE8B09.B5B33CE0@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038005183.17911.75.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 11:52, Richard Steffens wrote:
> I guess I'll just give that a try. I understand that compiling the
> kernel doesn't change what's installed, so I won't really hurt anything
> if I get it wrong the first (or second, or third) time. The important
> thing is to make sure I don't overwrite the boot image (or whatever that
> file is called), and add another option to GRUB.

Be careful that if you are building the same kernel version that you are
running that you don't overwrite the installed modules with the new ones
without making a backup first!  (This is one area where Debian's
"make-kpkg" from `kernel-package' really shines.  You can use the
`--append-to-version' or `--revision' switch to make the kernel's uname,
and thus module install directory, unique.)

This is THE paper about booting the Linux OS.  (The LaTeX source is next
to it at that site, IIRC.)

ftp://icaftp.epfl.ch/pub/people/almesber/booting/bootinglinux-current.ps.gz

Also see the Lilo technical manual, and the GRUB texinfo manual.

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/lilo-doc/
http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/grub-doc/html/grub.html

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Nov 22 14:54:55 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 14:54:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <86bs4hp64g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> writes:

Alex> OK, If I set subnet mask to 255.255.255.0 for the both
Alex> 192.168.x.x subnets will these subnets be visible for each
Alex> other?  If I need to masquerade them on eth0 how these eth1 and
Alex> eth2 interfaces should be represented?

Yes, they'll be able to see each other.  Machines on each "span" will
have a default gateway of the router.  The router knows all (at least
locally).  If you've got the iproute2 tools:

  IP=/sbin/ip
  IPTABLES=/sbin/iptables

  DSL_IF=eth0
  DSL_IP=63.215.105.xxx  # insert your static IP here
  DSL_GATEWAY=63.215.105.1

  LAN_1_IF=eth1
  LAN_1_IP=192.168.1.1

  LAN_2_IF=eth2
  LAN_2_IP=192.168.2.1

  $IP link set up dev $LAN_1_IF
  $IP addr add ${LAN_1_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $LAN_1_IF
        
  $IP link set up dev $LAN_2_IF
  $IP addr add ${LAN_2_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $LAN_2_IF

  $IP link set up dev $DSL_IF
  $IP addr add ${DSL_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $DSL_IF

The router has a default gateway (of whatever is your upstream):

  $IP route add default scope global via $DSL_GATEWAY

The masquerading is configured relative to the external
interface, e.g.:

   $IPTABLES -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o $DSL_IF -j MASQUERADE

Also, need to make sure forwarding is enabled, e.g.:

   echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 15:02:12 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 15:02:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <200211221502.12416.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Your system should automatically route the traffic to the proper 
192.168.x.x subnet since a 255.255.255.0 mask matches the first three 
octets so it will know what interface goes with what private subnet.

You would need to masquerade the traffic from the 192.168.x.x subnets 
when it goes out the eth0 interface since that is the only network 
interface with a publicly routable IP address. 

Also, make sure you set the default gateway on the systems on the 
192.168.1.x and 192.168.2.x subnets to the respective IP address you've 
assigned to the eth1 and eth2 interfaces since your firewall system 
will be the default gateway for systems on your private subnets.

You should be able to masquerade all traffic from the private subnets by 
only matching the first two octets. Something like 168.192.0.0/16 will 
match traffic from both private subnets.

Tony

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 15:08:21 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 15:08:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Finding relevant RFC's on www.pdxlinux.org.
In-Reply-To: <200211222005.gAMK5kv28476@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222005.gAMK5kv28476@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1038006501.17911.97.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

For our convenience, I've installed the Debian packages containing the
Internet RFC documents on the PLUG web server.

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/RFC/
http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/RFC/rfc-index.txt.gz

You can use your browser's text search function (Ctrl-f in Galeon and
Mozilla) to search for stuff, then get the RFC number.

Try looking for "subnet", "cidr", "route", etc.  The actual RFC's can be
found via the attached script.  It uses "galeon -n" as written, or you
can edit it and make it use "gnome-moz-remote" or whatever you like. 
Install it in /usr/local/bin, and you'll always have it available.

I use Gnome, and have replaced the little foot menu on my lower panel
with the "mini_commander" applet.  It lets you set up match expressions
and commands to run when an expression you type there matches.  I have
it match the expression "^[rR][fF][cC] *([0-9]+)" and have that run
"moz-remote-rfc-by-number \1".  Now I can type or paste a string like
"rfc1219" into the mini commander, and Galeon visits that RFC in the
blink of an eye.

http://new.pdxlinux.org/search.html

... should locate RFC's also.  For instance, try typing "subnet" into
the search box there.

-------------- next part --------------
A non-text attachment was scrubbed...
Name: moz-remote-rfc-by-number
Type: text/x-sh
Size: 649 bytes
Desc: not available
Url : http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/attachments/20021122/ffe633d6/attachment.bin 

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 15:12:17 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)

Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211221502.12416.aschlemm@attbi.com>

	 <200211221502.12416.aschlemm@attbi.com>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:02, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> You should be able to masquerade all traffic from the private subnets by 
> only matching the first two octets. Something like 168.192.0.0/16 will 
> match traffic from both private subnets.

Unless you want them treated differently for filtering purposes, of
course.  If one side is faculty and the other is student workstations,
for instance, you may well have different rules for each.  (Do as I say
not as I do?)

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Nov 22 15:18:03 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 14:46, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> Be careful that if you are building the same kernel version that you are
> running that you don't overwrite the installed modules with the new ones
> without making a backup first!  (This is one area where Debian's
> "make-kpkg" from `kernel-package' really shines.  You can use the
> `--append-to-version' or `--revision' switch to make the kernel's uname,
> and thus module install directory, unique.)

You don't need any kind of a special utility to do that...

If you edit the Makefile and put something in for 'EXTRAVERSION' you'll
get a specially named kernel version and module location.

When I was playing with Win4Lin, for instance, everything was 2.4.18-w4l
so it didn't cause problems with the pre-exiting 2.4.18 kernel that was
in place.

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 15:22:47 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 15:22:47 -0800

In-Reply-To: <1038006501.17911.97.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:08, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> The actual RFC's can be
> found via the attached script.  It uses "galeon -n" as written, or you
> can edit it and make it use "gnome-moz-remote" or whatever you like. 
> Install it in /usr/local/bin, and you'll always have it available.

I just realized that this script does not do a lot of good if you don't
have the RFC's installed on your own machine.  Well, for now, you'll
have to find them by hand.  They are all linked to in:

http://www.hegbloom.net/doc/RFC/links/

From alex at daniloff.com  Fri Nov 22 15:35:19 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 15:35:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one =?iso-8859-1?q?box=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <86bs4hp64g.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <200211222335.gAMNZJA28688@gate.daniloff.com>

Russell,
Thank you very much for your response.
Aren't iproute2 tools including routing utilities for 2.2.x kernels
only? 
That's what I red in iproute2 package description.
Since I'm using 2.4.19 kernel, what kernel routing utilities/features
should I use in  this case?

Many thanks in advance.

Alex

-------------------
> >>>>> "Alex" == Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> writes:
> 
> Alex> OK, If I set subnet mask to 255.255.255.0 for the both
> Alex> 192.168.x.x subnets will these subnets be visible for each
> Alex> other?  If I need to masquerade them on eth0 how these eth1
and
> Alex> eth2 interfaces should be represented?
> 
> Yes, they'll be able to see each other.  Machines on each "span"
will
> have a default gateway of the router.  The router knows all (at
least
> locally).  If you've got the iproute2 tools:
> 
>   IP=/sbin/ip
>   IPTABLES=/sbin/iptables
> 
>   DSL_IF=eth0
>   DSL_IP=63.215.105.xxx  # insert your static IP here
>   DSL_GATEWAY=63.215.105.1
> 
>   LAN_1_IF=eth1
>   LAN_1_IP=192.168.1.1
> 
>   LAN_2_IF=eth2
>   LAN_2_IP=192.168.2.1
> 
>   $IP link set up dev $LAN_1_IF
>   $IP addr add ${LAN_1_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $LAN_1_IF
>         
>   $IP link set up dev $LAN_2_IF
>   $IP addr add ${LAN_2_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $LAN_2_IF
> 
>   $IP link set up dev $DSL_IF
>   $IP addr add ${DSL_IP}/24 broadcast + scope global dev $DSL_IF
> 
> The router has a default gateway (of whatever is your upstream):
> 
>   $IP route add default scope global via $DSL_GATEWAY
> 
> The masquerading is configured relative to the external
> interface, e.g.:
> 
>    $IPTABLES -t nat -A POSTROUTING -o $DSL_IF -j MASQUERADE
> 
> Also, need to make sure forwarding is enabled, e.g.:
> 
>    echo "1" > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
> 
> 
> -- 
> Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever
made,
> seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower,
more
>                          stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
>                                         -- Burl Ives as Rufus
Hennessy
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug
>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:18, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 14:46, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > Be careful that if you are building the same kernel version that you are
> > running that you don't overwrite the installed modules with the new ones
> > without making a backup first!  (This is one area where Debian's
> > "make-kpkg" from `kernel-package' really shines.  You can use the
> > `--append-to-version' or `--revision' switch to make the kernel's uname,
> > and thus module install directory, unique.)
> 
> You don't need any kind of a special utility to do that...
> 
> If you edit the Makefile and put something in for 'EXTRAVERSION' you'll
> get a specially named kernel version and module location.

Sure, or you can use "make EXTRAVERSION=.1 ...".  See:

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/info2www?(make)Overriding




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 15:40:44 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 15:40:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211222335.gAMNZJA28688@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222335.gAMNZJA28688@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1038008444.17906.123.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:35, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Aren't iproute2 tools including routing utilities for 2.2.x kernels
> only? 
> That's what I red in iproute2 package description.
> Since I'm using 2.4.19 kernel, what kernel routing utilities/features
> should I use in  this case?

AFAICT, the same interface works for 2.4 kernels.

root at bittersweet:~
# apt-cache search iproute
ipmenu - A cursel iptables/iproute2 GUI
iproute - Professional tools to control the networking in Linux kernels
root at bittersweet:~
# apt-cache show iproute  
Package: iproute
Priority: extra
Section: net
Installed-Size: 817
Maintainer: Juan Cespedes <cespedes at debian.org>
Architecture: i386
Version: 20010824-8
Depends: libc6 (>= 2.2.4-4)
Filename: pool/main/i/iproute/iproute_20010824-8_i386.deb
Size: 517870
MD5sum: 25eb4de53e0d520ca3862bb6989a2545
Description: Professional tools to control the networking in Linux
kernels
 This is `iproute', the professional set of tools to control the
 networking behavior in kernels 2.2.x and later.
 .
 At least, the options CONFIG_NETLINK and CONFIG_RTNETLINK must
 be compiled in the running kernel

From rsteff at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 16:29:49 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 16:29:49 -0800
Subject: Resolved: [PLUG] Samba config question
References: <3DDE94D8.54C2122B@attbi.com> <9232.206.190.138.42.1037998122.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
Message-ID: <3DDECBFD.8E4CC346@attbi.com>

Matt King wrote:

> >   guest account = pcguest

> From smb.conf on my machine concerning the guest account directive:
> 
> # Uncomment this if you want a guest account, you must add this to
> /etc/passwd otherwise the user "nobody" is used

Derek Loree wrote:

> You will be asked for a password, even for a guest account.  If you
> don't enter a password (just hit return, or click ok), then you will be
> connected as the guest user.  BTW, the guest user needs to have a system
> account, and a SAMBA account, what you choose for a password doesn't
> seem to matter.  You may also need to add the line:
> 
> guest ok = yes
> 
> under your [tmp] section.

That was the problem. I commented out "guest account = pcguest" and got
the condition I was looking for. nobody is what I used to have. That's
what I want this time, too. Since this is a network at home, behind a
router, and I want it to be available to any machine in the house,
whether it's me on linux, or my wife on windows, I don't want it to ask
for a password for /tmp or one other directory that I will create for
windows file storage.

Thank you both for your comments. Together, they explained what I needed
to know. This time, I'm keeping a paper log of the things I'm doing to
the machine, so I won't have to remember which files to back up if I
ever do a start from scratch OS load again.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Fri Nov 22 17:07:40 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 17:07:40 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Samba config question
In-Reply-To: <3DDE94D8.54C2122B@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021123010740.13435.qmail@web10408.mail.yahoo.com>

You need to add a Samba user:

smbpasswd -a {username}

The -a adds a user to Samba's database so you can log in.

-Scott

--- Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> wrote:
> I'm trying to get Samba working again. I remember that for my setup,
> I
> needed very little in the smb.conf file. I've found a couple of
> places
> that tell me what to do, starting with:
> 
> http://www.troubleshooters.com/linux/samba.htm
> 
> It's a nice step-by-step guide. It starts with simply making the
> linux
> machine visible to the windows machines. That part works. The
> smb.conf
> file looks like this:
> 
> [global]
>    guest account = pcguest
>    workgroup = House
> 
> With that for an smb.conf file, I can see the linux machine from
> windows
> explorer.
> 
> The next step is to make /tmp visible and accessible. Instructions at
> that web site and in a book say that all I need do is add the
> following
> to my smb.conf file, (well, the web site had me create another
> directory, /scratch, but with the same permissions as /tmp, and the
> result was the same):
> 
> [tmp]
>    comment = Temporary file space
>    path = /tmp
>    read only = no
>    public = yes
> 
> When I restart Samba and try to look at anything on the linux machine
> from windows explorer, I get a password prompt. The book and the web
> site don't mention this happening at this stage. The message looks
> like
> this:
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
> Enter Network Password
> 
> 	You must supply a password to make this connection:
> 
> 	Resource: \\NEC\IPC$
> 
> 	Password:
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> (The name of the linux machine is nec.)
> 
> I did try adding the following to the [global] section, but it made
> no
> difference:
> 
>    security = share
> 
> I assume that there's some other step I'm omitting. Could someone
> point
> me in the right direction, please.
> 
> Thanks.
>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:55, Bill Thoen wrote:
> "Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:
> > 
> > On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 15:34, Bill Thoen wrote:
> > > When you add a new user as a private FTP only account, how do you
> > > set the default file creation privileges? Can I do this in
> > > /etc/ftpaccess, or does that not work for directories outside the
> > > /var/ftp tree?
> > >
> > > I'm using RedHat 7.1 with a text-only interface.
> > 
> > But which ftp server daemon?  There are several.
> 
> xinetd.

No, that's not the FTP server daemon.  "inetd" is the Internet super
daemon.  It listens on a bunch of ports, on behalf of other service
daemons.  When a connection comes in for one, it fork/exec's the daemon
for that port.  This way, they don't all always have to be running.  It
saves system resources.  Speaking of saving system resources, IMO,
"xinetd" is somewhat of a hog by comparision to plain vanilla "inetd". 
The security fud protection features it provides can be provided by
"tcpd" (tcp-wrappers).  This way, you need only one very lightweight
process running for all those rarely used services.

Ok, so now we know how your FTP daemon is being launched.  "xinetd" is
listening for FTP connections, then launching the actual ftp server
daemon when one comes in.  If you serve a LOT of ftp, you might want to
shut it off in "xinetd", and run a standalone ftp daemon.  The same one
that inetd is starting should work in that mode also, started by an
/etc/init.d script.

So now, back to the original question.  Which brand of FTP server daemon
is it?  wu-ftpd ?  proftpd ?  Once we know that, we can learn how to
configure it by RTFM.  (The man pages provided by it's package can be
gotten via a package manager query | grep.)




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 22 13:47:37 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 13:47:37 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Server.
In-Reply-To: <20021122121921.66fad8fc.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211221345560.10702-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

> On more than one occasion I have been so lost that I couldn't even

> who omit the RTFM and provide only a link. I sometimes think the only
> factor determining whether or not a person is a clueless idiot is what
> side of the bed they climbed out of that morning. Of course the non-idiot
> side of my bed is against the wall :)

  The debian users have the answer, of course: apt-get install clue

Rich




From revans at e-z.net  Fri Nov 22 16:54:30 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 16:54:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Routing and firewalling in one box?
In-Reply-To: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200211222037.gAMKbpi28529@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <E18FP0J-0006NU-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I still under the impression that you are using SuSE, so I answering this SuSE
specific.

If you are using SuSEFirewall2 then you have to specify in
/etc/sysconfig/SuSEfirewall2 :
# Do you want to allow routing between interfaces of the same class
# (e.g. between all internet interfaces, or all internal network interfaces)
# be default (so without the need setting up FW_FORWARD definitions)?
#
# Choice: "yes" or "no", if not set defaults to "no"
#
FW_ALLOW_CLASS_ROUTING="yes"

To masquerade requires a few settings in /etc/sysconfig/SuSEfirewall2. 

# Which is the interface that points to the internal network?
#
# Enter all the network devices here which are trusted.
# If you are not connected to a trusted network (e.g. you have just a
# dialup) leave this empty.
#
# Choice: leave empty or any number of devices, seperated by a space
# e.g. "tr0", "eth0 eth1 eth1:1" or ""
#
FW_DEV_INT="eth1 eth2"

# Should routing between the internet, dmz and internal network be activated?
# REQUIRES: FW_DEV_INT or FW_DEV_DMZ
#
# You need only set this to yes, if you either want to masquerade internal
# machines or allow access to the dmz (or internal machines, but this is not
# a good idea). This option supersedes IP_FORWARD from
# /etc/sysconfig/network/options
#
# Setting this option one alone doesn't do anything. Either activate
# massquerading with FW_MASQUERADE below if you want to masquerade your
# internal network to the internet, or configure FW_FORWARD to define
# what is allowed to be forwarded!
#
# Choice: "yes" or "no", if not set defaults to "no"
#
FW_ROUTE="yes"

# Do you want to masquerade internal networks to the outside?
# REQUIRES: FW_DEV_INT or FW_DEV_DMZ, FW_ROUTE
#
# "Masquerading" means that all your internal machines which use services on
# the internet seem to come from your firewall.
# Please note that it is more secure to#
# Which internal computers/networks are allowed to access the internet
# directly (not via proxys on the firewall)?
# Only these networks will be allowed access and will be masqueraded!
#
# Choice: leave empty or any number of hosts/networks seperated by a space.
# Every host/network may get a list of allowed services, otherwise everything
# is allowed. A target network, protocol and service is appended by a comma to
# the host/network. e.g. "10.0.0.0/8" allows the whole 10.0.0.0 network with
# unrestricted access. "10.0.1.0/24,0/0,tcp,80 10.0.1.0/24,0/0tcp,21" allows
# the 10.0.1.0 network to use www/ftp to the internet.
# "10.0.1.0/24,tcp,1024:65535 10.0.2.0/24" is OK too.
# Set this variable to "0/0" to allow unrestricted access to the internet.
#
FW_MASQ_NETS="" communicate via proxies to the
# internet than masquerading. This option is required for FW_MASQ_NETS and
# FW_FORWARD_MASQ.
#
# Choice: "yes" or "no", if not set defaults to "no"
#
FW_MASQUERADE="192.168.1.0/24 192.168.2.0/24"

SuSEFirewall2 is pretty well commented and there are other options you should
set according to your policies.

Thank you
Russell



On Fri, 22 Nov 2002 12:37:51 -0800, Alex Daniloff said:

> OK,
>  If I set subnet mask to 255.255.255.0 for the both 192.168.x.x
>  subnets will these subnets be visible for each other?
>  If I need to masquerade them on eth0 how these eth1 and eth2 
>  interfaces should be represented?

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 17:24:04 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 17:24:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] [Debian] KDE 3.0 on woody/sid mixed machine.
In-Reply-To: <1038013662.5796.33.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1038013662.5796.33.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1038014644.22051.14.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 17:07, Jim Webb wrote:
> I'm having trouble updating some KDE packages both base and libs.

:-)

I had no trouble at all, once I figured this out:

Appended to "/etc/apt/sources.list":

# KDE 3, from http://www.cupis.co.uk/debian/kde3.html
#
deb     http://download.us.kde.org/pub/kde/stable/latest/Debian/sid ./
deb-src http://download.us.kde.org/pub/kde/stable/latest/Debian/sid ./

# Kdevelop
#
deb http://people.debian.org/~njordan kde3.0/


Appended to "/etc/apt/preferences":

Package: *
Pin: origin download.us.kde.org
Pin-Priority: 989

Package: *
Pin: origin people.debian.org
Pin-Priority: 989

Now "aptitude" selects the new KDE packages preferentially over the ones
at http.us.debian.org.  Amazing tools, huh folks?  I LOVE DEBIAN.

The upgrade proceeded without a hitch, and in 45 minutes I had KDE 3.0
running.

Subject: [PLUG] The RTF{M,S} prerequisites graph.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211221345560.10702-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211221345560.10702-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1038015144.22050.24.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 13:47, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 22 Nov 2002, david wrote:
> 
> > On more than one occasion I have been so lost that I couldn't even
> > formulate the proper question. I have always appreciated the courtesy
> > shown by those who provide a link along with RTFM, and the mercy of those
> > who omit the RTFM and provide only a link. I sometimes think the only
> > factor determining whether or not a person is a clueless idiot is what
> > side of the bed they climbed out of that morning. Of course the non-idiot
> > side of my bed is against the wall :)
> 
>   The debian users have the answer, of course: apt-get install clue

Yes, good point, Rich.  It's best, that is, most useful and relevant,
when giving a RTFM response, to try and help the newbie fill out the
prerequisite graph[1].  If they don't even know about "man" or "info",
or "google", they need to be TAUGHT that.  If they don't know WHAT MAN
PAGE TO READ, then we need to help them learn HOW to find out which one
to read.

[1] graph -- as in mathematical graph theory - nodes and edges.  Put
your googles on if you don't know what that is.  It's used by the
package manager (dpkg or rpm) and by the "make" utility.

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 18:12:15 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk ouellette)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 18:12:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD player
Message-ID: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>

Where do I look for the causes of my daughter having no sound from her 
cd player in her new Amptron running RH 8.0? Sndconfig works fine.
 Dirk




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Nov 22 18:35:19 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 18:35:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD player
In-Reply-To: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
References: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038018919.9275.20.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Check the permissions of /dev/dsp, /dev/audio, and /dev/mixer. Make sure
you daughter has write permissions. 

The best solution, if these files are owned by group `audio,' is to make
your daughter's login name a member of group `audio.'

If not, I would first make the permissions permiscous temporarily, see
if it works, and then change the group to audio, lock down the
permissions to 660, and then make her part of the audio group.


-Cooper

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 18:12, Dirk ouellette wrote:
> Where do I look for the causes of my daughter having no sound from her 
> cd player in her new Amptron running RH 8.0? Sndconfig works fine.
>  Dirk
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Nov 22 18:31:34 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 18:31:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD player
In-Reply-To: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
References: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038018694.24091.3.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 18:12, Dirk ouellette wrote:
> Where do I look for the causes of my daughter having no sound from her 
> cd player in her new Amptron running RH 8.0? Sndconfig works fine.

Odds are the audio wire running from the CD-ROM drive to the sound card
isn't plugged in.

Is there a play button on the front of the CD-ROM drive?  If so, try
that.  CD playing doesn't rely on software drivers.

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>




From mikedela at ipns.com  Fri Nov 22 18:38:23 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 18:38:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD player
In-Reply-To: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <FASQPNKGIDQP95ZWQN152UPMLIFDAGA.3ddeea1f@miked>

Most no-sound I've found is related to mis-wiring. 

Does the PC make other sounds? If so, you might be missing the redbook audio cable that goes from the CD-ROM 
straight to the sound card. It goes on the opposite side of the IDE connecor as the power plug.

If there are no other sounds, check to see if the speakers are plugged into the PC correctly. Sometimes the 
plugs fit into the wrong places so it's easy to plug in incorrectly.

That's my 2 cents.

Mike

503-702-6749
mikedela at ipns.com 





From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Nov 22 18:45:07 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 18:45:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
Message-ID: <200211230245.gAN2j7213555@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

I'd like to start a shell directly from init, bypassing getty and login.
I put this in my inittab:

# Run bash on first serial port.
S0:2345:respawn:/bin/bash --login

This does start bash, and if I do an 'exit', I immediate get another
bash prompt.  However, signals (ctl-c, ctl-z, and friends) do not work.  
For example, if I do a 'ping', I can never get control back.  It looks
like my problem may be related to terminal process groups.

Does anyone know the correct way to do this?

thanks,
galen





From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Nov 22 18:46:48 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 18:46:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] CD player
In-Reply-To: <1038018919.9275.20.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
References: <3DDEE3FF.7070506@attbi.com>
	 <1038018919.9275.20.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <1038019608.24335.4.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 18:35, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Check the permissions of /dev/dsp, /dev/audio, and /dev/mixer. Make sure
> you daughter has write permissions. 
> 
> The best solution, if these files are owned by group `audio,' is to make
> your daughter's login name a member of group `audio.'
> 
> If not, I would first make the permissions permiscous temporarily, see
> if it works, and then change the group to audio, lock down the
> permissions to 660, and then make her part of the audio group.

While that's true of most audio playing - it isn't of CD audio.

CD audio goes out the back of the drive directly to the sound card.  I
suppose if you're using some sort of software CD player (which does
nothing but tells the drive to play) you could be looking at bad
permissions for /dev/cdrom (or whatever your cdrom is)... but /dev/dsp,
/dev/audio, and /dev/mixer shouldn't have any effect on playing CDs.

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

From tranceboy at tranceboy.com  Fri Nov 22 19:06:53 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Another pre-linux newbie question...

I was preparing to install FreeBSD when a friend of mine recommended Gentoo
Linux, and now, after having looked at their pages, I'm interested.

Does anyone here use Gentoo?  How easy is it going to be for a novice Linux
user to install and configure?  As a disclaimer and warning, let it be noted
that I'm not an incredibly patient person when it comes to computers - I
don't mind waiting for 8 hours for something to compile/install, but if I
need to read the gideon bible just to get to the 8 hours of waiting, I am
not interested.  Please note that this is not an "I'm not willing to read
anything", but I'm also uninterested in becoming an authority on
dependencies just so I can watch movies on my system.

I like the idea of a light, fast system that's customized for my hardware,
however, so if installing Gentoo would not be an ordeal or an exercise in
frustration for someone who isn't a unix administrator, I'm definitely up
for it.  I've taken a look at the Gentoo installation pages, and nothing in
there looks too horrible, but I'd prefer impressions from someone who has
been through the install process, along with any pointers or
recommendations.

Thanks,
-henry




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Fri Nov 22 18:53:47 2002
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 18:53:47 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Another pre-linux newbie question...
In-Reply-To: <002301c2929d$60718b90$4501a8c0@discordia>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211221838510.3077-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Fri, 22 Nov 2002, tranceboy wrote:

> I was preparing to install FreeBSD when a friend of mine recommended Gentoo
> Linux, and now, after having looked at their pages, I'm interested.
>
> Does anyone here use Gentoo?  How easy is it going to be for a novice Linux
> user to install and configure?  As a disclaimer and warning, let it be noted
> that I'm not an incredibly patient person when it comes to computers - I
> don't mind waiting for 8 hours for something to compile/install, but if I
> need to read the gideon bible just to get to the 8 hours of waiting, I am
> not interested.  Please note that this is not an "I'm not willing to read
> anything", but I'm also uninterested in becoming an authority on
> dependencies just so I can watch movies on my system.
>
> I like the idea of a light, fast system that's customized for my hardware,
> however, so if installing Gentoo would not be an ordeal or an exercise in
> frustration for someone who isn't a unix administrator, I'm definitely up
> for it.  I've taken a look at the Gentoo installation pages, and nothing in
> there looks too horrible, but I'd prefer impressions from someone who has
> been through the install process, along with any pointers or
> recommendations.

I've got Gentoo on my laptop and it is now my favorite distro - I've used
Slackware, Debian, RedHat and Mandrake (and I've installed Lycoris).
Gentoo is definately not the easiest of these to install (that distinction
goes to Lycoris), but Gentoo is definately best when it come to installing
software  and upgrading (Debian is second).

Hmmm...  In general I'd say that if you're a newbie that you probably
wouldn't want to start out with Gentoo.  However, if you really don't mind
doing a bit of work up front and you've read the docs on Gentoo.org (which
are actually quite good) and you feel comfortable with them then I'd say
go for it.  You'll learn a lot more about Linux with Gentoo than you would
with, say Mandrake or Lycoris.  However, I would recommend that you have a
fast internet connection (though, I did it over dial-up which took a few
days :) and that you also have another machine next to it browsing the
Gentoo site - that makes it much easier.

Final warning: if this is your first foray into Linux you're jumping in at
the deep end of the pool. However if you feel you can 'swim' in the
deep end you'll find that when you get a Gentoo system setup you'll like
it a lot as you won't have to deal with the dependency problems that are
rampant on distros that use rpm packages (RedHat, Mandrake) and you'll
also find that since all of the packages are compiled specifically for
your architecture that things will run noticably faster than pre-compiled
distros that give you the lowest common denominator binaries that'll run
on the  386.

Phil




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Nov 22 19:29:18 2002

> to do some homework.


Don't worry about Karl, just don't feed him.  When confronted with figuring 
out which virtual manual to pull out from the library installed on your 
system, a very useful command is `apropos` (I believe it's the same as man 
-k, but I like typing apropos).

So in your case, a question about ftp permissions, try
$ apropos ftp

You should get a nice fat list and now be in the right aisle.

If you have a broadband connection, you can use google in much the same 
way...hmm `apropos:` ?

Good luck,
Kyle Accardi





From prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com  Fri Nov 22 19:33:42 2002
From: prestonc at crawfordsolutions.com (Preston Crawford)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 19:33:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Another pre-linux newbie question...
In-Reply-To: <002301c2929d$60718b90$4501a8c0@discordia>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211221927260.10852-100000@serpentor.cobrala>


On Fri, 22 Nov 2002, tranceboy wrote:

> I was preparing to install FreeBSD when a friend of mine recommended Gentoo
> Linux, and now, after having looked at their pages, I'm interested.

Boy. From what I've heard you could spend upwards of 4 or 5 days trying to
get Gentoo running. Which in my mind isn't really a great way to learn how
to actually run the system day-to-day. This is all personal preference,
of course. And what works for me, may not work for others, but the way I
personally learned is just to immerse myself. Drop Windows, cut the cord
and try to do the things I normally did using Linux. First Red Hat, then
Mandrake, then SuSE. Those are by no means lightweight, but I don't need
lightweight as much as I need fully functional and headache-free so I can
focus on programming.

A good route to go, might be to try FreeBSD. I REALLY like FreeBSD. If the
Java support in FreeBSD were better I'd probably switch to it 24/7. And
that's an OS that travels light. It's also pretty free of configuration
widgets so you are forced to learn how to administer it from the
command-line. An awesome learning experience, in my opinion, and a great
OS on which to learn. Problem is that I get the impression that not all
skills are transferrable to Linux. It's somewhat similar, but different to
administer. So depending on what your goals are it might not be of as much
use. But personally if I was trying to learn the Unix-like way of doing
things from scratch and didn't have heavy multi-media needs (or Java needs
currently) I'd go with FreeBSD.

Preston

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 19:52:40 2002

Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
In-Reply-To: <200211230245.gAN2j7213555@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200211230245.gAN2j7213555@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <1038023560.9366.1.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 18:45, Galen Seitz wrote:
> I'd like to start a shell directly from init, bypassing getty and login.
> I put this in my inittab:
> 
> # Run bash on first serial port.
> S0:2345:respawn:/bin/bash --login
> 
> This does start bash, and if I do an 'exit', I immediate get another
> bash prompt.  However, signals (ctl-c, ctl-z, and friends) do not work.  
> For example, if I do a 'ping', I can never get control back.  It looks
> like my problem may be related to terminal process groups.
> 
> Does anyone know the correct way to do this?

Try seeing if using an "stty" command form and/or "tset" from your
shell's login script will turn those signalling keys on there.

You might want to have a look at what "login" does before it fork/exec's
the user's shell.




From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Fri Nov 22 19:54:32 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 19:54:32 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
In-Reply-To: <200211230245.gAN2j7213555@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211221947440.16588-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

> I'd like to start a shell directly from init, bypassing getty and login.
> Does anyone know the correct way to do this?

Yes. An excellent method for this is described in the article below:

"Automated Logins Revisited"
Adrian J. Chung
http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue72/chung.html


-- From the article:

Using your favourite text editor create a file named autologinfred.c and
type in this short C program:

int main() {
   execlp( "login", "login", "-f", "fred", 0);
}

The execlp system call invokes the command "login -f fred" and replaces
the current processing context with this invocation. The man page for
login describes the action of the -f argument. Compile this tiny C program
using the GNU C-compiler:

$ gcc -o autologinfred autologinfred.c

Gain root privileges (using su) and copy the executable to a public
directory:

# cp autologinfred /usr/local/sbin/

Now take a look at /etc/inittab. This is the configuration file is used by
init, the very first process started when Linux initialises. You should
observe lines similar to the following:

1:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty1
2:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty2
3:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty3

The exact contents of /etc/inittab differ from distribution to
distribution. On Debian systems one sees:

1:2345:respawn:/sbin/getty 38400 tty1
2:23:respawn:/sbin/getty 38400 tty2
3:23:respawn:/sbin/getty 38400 tty3

Edit the line beginning with "1:2345" so that it reads as follows:

1:2345:respawn:/sbin/getty -n -l /usr/local/sbin/autologinfred 38400 tty1

The above will cause the user fred to be logged in automatically on the
first virtual console. On some GNU/Linux distributions (like RedHat)
/sbin/agetty must be used instead. The -l <alternative login> argument to
getty substitutes the default /sbin/login program with the one we compiled
earlier. The -n tells getty to not prompt for a user ID.

[...]
http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue72/chung.html




On Fri, 22 Nov 2002, Galen Seitz wrote:

> I put this in my inittab:
>
> # Run bash on first serial port.
> S0:2345:respawn:/bin/bash --login
>
> This does start bash, and if I do an 'exit', I immediate get another
> bash prompt.  However, signals (ctl-c, ctl-z, and friends) do not work.
> For example, if I do a 'ping', I can never get control back.  It looks
> like my problem may be related to terminal process groups.
>
> Does anyone know the correct way to do this?
>
> thanks,
> galen
>
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Fri Nov 22 21:45:19 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 2002 21:45:19 -0800
Subject: Gentoo (was Re: [PLUG] Another pre-linux newbie question...)
In-Reply-To: <20021122194312.157d95fd.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
References: <002301c2929d$60718b90$4501a8c0@discordia> <20021122194312.157d95fd.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211222145.19306.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

I've managed to get Gentoo mostly installed, but it took a while. I have 
yet to configure things like sound and X. I've got an aging P-II 400 and 
it was really wheezing compiling such things as OpenOffice.  I really 
think you shouldn't bother with a source-based distro unless you've got a 
PC that's 2GHz or better.  I used the "stage 3"  tarballs and still had a 
couple of compilation steps that were on the order of 12 hours each.  This 
led to some "domestic friction" with my spouse :-)

I installed 1.4rc1.  I don't think I'd recommend 1.4 until they're actually 
done with it. I ran into many annoying problems that prevented me from 
moving forward such a Gimp being pulled in en masse for gimp-print and 
then finding out that the Gimp ebuild was broken.  Then, the KDE 3.04 
ebuild was broken against X 4.2.0...  The ebuild gurus seem to have worked 
most of this out, but it was not a pleasant introduction to Gentoo.

If you are really new to Unix, I really wouldn't recommend any of the "some 
assembly required" distros.  Learn the basics with one that makes getting 
something running easy.  After three years of beating my head on Red Hat, 
I'm not going to recommend it to anyone.  Mandrake has been pleasing to 
some collegues (and I have a soft spot for French things).  I personally 
like SuSE, but I don't think it's as easy for the newbie as Mandrake.

All that said, I'd love to see a little discussion group on Gentoo.  I am 
very interested in source-based distros and tried Sorcerer before its 
creator went loony and the whole thing split into three projects.  
Sorcerer had the fine point of needing over 40 hours of compile time on my 
machine.  Ouch.  However, within about three days, I was able to write 
"spells" for it and feel like I knew what was going on.  Gentoo isn't 
giving me that feeling of total understanding.

Best,
Kyle

O.T.: Est-ce qu'il y a des francophones ici?  Je cherche des amis pour 
parler en francais.  Comme vous pouvez le constater, mon francais n'est 
pas grande chose...





From lemming at attbi.com  Fri Nov 22 22:23:45 2002

>>Linux, and now, after having looked at their pages, I'm interested.

I run Gentoo on one of my boxes.  It's a PIII-650 and it took 3 - 5 days 
of compiling different packages to get to the point where it was very 
usable.  I really like it though.  On the other hand, I've got other 
machines that were running Redhat & Suse to use while waiting.

The 3-5 days were not constant either.  Most of it was seeing what I 
wanted to install, going to bed or work and then seeing how it went. 
Not much work really.  The support available via www.gentoo.org and it's 
forums is great.

For a Linux newbie though, I wouldn't recommend it.

-Mark

From deathfox at moochercrew.org  Fri Nov 22 23:11:53 2002
From: deathfox at moochercrew.org (Chris Emery)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 23:11:53 -0800
Subject: Gentoo (was Re: [PLUG] Another pre-linux newbie question...)
In-Reply-To: <200211222145.19306.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
References: <002301c2929d$60718b90$4501a8c0@discordia>
	 <20021122194312.157d95fd.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
	 <200211222145.19306.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <1038035512.24495.6.camel@kero>

> All that said, I'd love to see a little discussion group on Gentoo.  I am 
> very interested in source-based distros and tried Sorcerer before its 
> creator went loony and the whole thing split into three projects.  
> Sorcerer had the fine point of needing over 40 hours of compile time on my 
> machine.  Ouch.  However, within about three days, I was able to write 
> "spells" for it and feel like I knew what was going on.  Gentoo isn't 
> giving me that feeling of total understanding.

So, to swing a little off the main post.  You might look into ebuilder. 
Makes it kinda easy to build gentoo ebuilds.  Also, as portage has
matured ebuilds are getting nicer and nicer, in some situations it's as
easy as emake, einstall within the ebuild itself.  Though sadly I always
seem to look into things that aren't that easy.  Oh, and after much
streamlining (about 3 or 4 installs) I've gotten gentoo down to a one
day install.  To get most of my stuff running, it's about 2 days to
perfection.

Oh, and back on topic, I would be leary of sugesting gentoo to a
newbie.  Though the package management is great, and 1.4 autodetects
stuff, there isn't a cohesive program for instalation, instead you get
to do all sorts of things one at a time.  I think during the summer, if
nobody has bothered I might see how hard writing an installer is, who
knows, it might be easy with gentoo *shrug*.  But yeah, I say no for
newbies.

Chris Emery




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Nov 22 23:34:41 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 22 Nov 2002 23:34:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211221947440.16588-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211221947440.16588-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1038036880.9370.5.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I got this to work finally, like this:

int
main (int argc,
      char ** argv)
{
  execl ("/bin/login", "/bin/login", "-f", "karlheg", 0);
}

as "/usr/local/sbin/autologin_karlheg", and:

5:2345:respawn:/sbin/getty -n -l /usr/local/sbin/autologin_karlheg 38400
vc/5

(wrapped by evolution)

You could make that user's login shell be just about anything, provided
it does all the things a login shell is expected to do.




From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Nov 23 00:08:03 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 00:08:03 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Is there a simple How To for sendmail?
In-Reply-To: <000501c292bf$215b0fe0$0a00000a@ele02>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211230004110.32496-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 22 Nov 2002, Eric Aos wrote:
> I would like to replace my Exchange server with Sendmail.
> 
> So far, I can send and receive mail directly on the server (SUSE), but
> how do I establish a POP3 connection from my windows machine to the
> server to retrieve the mail?

Sendmail is an MTA (Mail Transfer Agent).  It speaks SMTP for sending and
receiving email and has some limited ability to deliver email locally by
writing to a fixed mail directory (though most people these days have
sendmail hand mail over to procmail for local delivery).  It is not a post
office server.  You'll need to run a different daemon to provide that
service.

I kind of like the courier mail system, but there are all kinds of POP and
IMAP servers available.  Try searching by protocol on
<URL: http://www.freshmeat.net >.  A search like "POP3 daemon" should give
some pretty reasonable results.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org




From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sat Nov 23 00:23:01 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 00:23:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 22 Nov 2002 18:45:07 PST."
             <200211230245.gAN2j7213555@tinman.seitzassoc.com> 
Message-ID: <200211230823.gAN8N1214398@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Thanks to everyone for your help.  I should have told you that I was
trying to save space by eliminating getty and login entirely.  Also, I was
trying to avoid having to create a new program.  Alas, with those 
constraints, I'm not sure it is possible.  Here's the best I could 
come up with.  This at least eliminates login.

In inittab:
T0:23:respawn:/sbin/agetty -f /etc/issue.galens -l /bin/direct -n \
38400 ttyS0 vt100

In /bin/direct:
#!/bin/sh
exec -cl /bin/bash


thanks again,
galen

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Nov 23 08:43:32 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 08:43:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Is there a simple How To for sendmail?
In-Reply-To: <000501c292bf$215b0fe0$0a00000a@ele02>
References: <000501c292bf$215b0fe0$0a00000a@ele02>
Message-ID: <200211230843.33029.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Friday 22 November 2002 23:08, Eric Aos wrote:
> I would like to replace my Exchange server with Sendmail.
>
> So far, I can send and receive mail directly on the server (SUSE), but how
> do I establish a POP3 connection from my windows machine to the server to
> retrieve the mail?
>
> Any clues appreciated.
> Thanks,
> Eric

Ewww, Sendmail! I would use Postfix or Exim. But that's not what you asked. :)
To retrieve mail with a Windows client, all you do is configure the mail 
client itself. Give it your mail server settings, mail.linuxbox.com, or 
whatever yours is, and the account name and password. 

I believe that people should spend lots of money on books, to support 
hardworking authors. Lots and lots of books. However, if you venture to 
Safari Books on O'Reilly, they are magically viewable for free. Do a search 
for Sendmail, you'll get a long list of books to look at. 
http://safari.oreilly.com/

--

Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Red Hat 8 and Kmail

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Nov 23 08:59:46 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 08:59:46 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Control of 'ls' display
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211230851370.14512-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  As part of my port of a DOS/win32 application to linux I need to rename
source code files to have meaningful names rather than the cryptic
abbrevations forced by the 8.3 naming restrictions. For whatever reason, the
author of the original code put each function in it's own .c file. Oodles
and oodles of files in the directory.

  When I listed the directory contents it displayed in three columns across
the screen. The idle thought wandered into my head that the arrangement was
probably done by bash counting the number of files and assigning one-third
to each display column. But, after I had converted a few dozen names, the
display became two columns rather than three. My experience with looking at
lots of directory displays suggests that the shell tries to fit them on a
single line, but creates columns (down, rather than across) as the number or
length becomes too large.

  So, just out of curiosity I would like to learn what controls this
display. I assume that it's something within bash (or the shell of your
choice). Is the algorithm some generally accepted standard or does it vary
with the phase of the moon and the tides?

Rich




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sat Nov 23 09:55:12 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 09:55:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Control of 'ls' display
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211230851370.14512-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <3DDFC100.8050009@pacifier.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:

>   When I listed the directory contents it displayed in three columns across
> the screen. The idle thought wandered into my head that the arrangement was
> probably done by bash counting the number of files and assigning one-third
> to each display column. But, after I had converted a few dozen names, the
> display became two columns rather than three. My experience with looking at
> lots of directory displays suggests that the shell tries to fit them on a
> single line, but creates columns (down, rather than across) as the number or
> length becomes too large.
> 
>   So, just out of curiosity I would like to learn what controls this
> display. I assume that it's something within bash (or the shell of your
> choice). Is the algorithm some generally accepted standard or does it vary
> with the phase of the moon and the tides?


Not sure what process handles these but it works in a VT as well as an xterm,

$ echo $COLUMNS
92

$ echo $LINES
55


guess is that ls checks $COLUMNS and determines how many columns it can 
display based on the longest filename.

Are you asking how to make the listing go across

a b
c d

instead of down?

a c
b d

I think ls can do that, but I'm not awake enough to look.

--
Kyle Accardi

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Nov 23 11:16:37 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 11:16:37 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231111010.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I've not used emacs since I upgraded from RH 6.2 to 7.3 at the beginning
of September. It was an unpleasant surprise this morning to discover that
Red Hat replace my entire ~/.emacs with it's shitty -- and inappropriate --
new version. I'm royally pissed at this! I cannot recall an upgrade in the
past 5 years where Red Hat replaced an existing config file -- especially in
a user's home/ directory -- without saving the old one or just adding the
new one as *.rpmnew.

  I've lost all the custom colors and control key movements that I had
carefully added over time. The "new, improved" version 21.<whatever> doesn't
tell me what column the cursor is on and I no longer can match a
parenthesis, brace, bracket or angle-bracket by typing the '%' key or by
pressing alt-ctrl-n and ...-p.

  This replacement without saving is a major flaw and I'll find someone at
Red Hat who should learn of this.

Not a happy camper,

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 11:42:30 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 11:42:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231111010.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231111010.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211231142.30342.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do you have a backup of your home directories so you have a version of 
your .emacs file you could restore? I take a paranoid approach and 
always backup /home before doing an upgrade just in case something goes 
wrong. That way I haven't put myself into a totally helpless situation 
since I'll be able to restore /home from a backup.

I've actually never needed the backup as I've not had an upgrade fail on 
me yet (knocking on my wooden desk very hard as I write this). :-)

Tony

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 11:47:22 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 11:47:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
Message-ID: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>

I'm trying to get my internal home web site running again on RH 8. I
followed the instructions in the books I have but have been unsuccessful
in getting php working. The book says to add the following to httpd.conf

AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps

I have those lines in the file. 

apachectl configtest reports:

Syntax OK.

Apache itself is working; I can connect to the web site from other
machines in the house. However, when I try looking at a page with <?
phpinfo() ?> as its only content, I get a blank page instead of the long
page of php information that I should get. And, when I look at any other
web page that uses php, I see the php commands instead of the results of
those commands. From this, I assume that Apache is not using php.

What step am I missing?

Thanks in advance for the help.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From rob at euglug.net  Sat Nov 23 12:01:23 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 12:01:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>; from rsteff@attbi.com on Sat, Nov 23, 2002 at 11:47:22AM -0800
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021123120123.A62801@cogit8.org>

Their should be another line in the apache config that tells apache to load
the PHP shared object file.  (Not sure if 'shared object' file is what it's
called).

On my Debian box, that line looks like:

  LoadModule php4_module /usr/lib/apache/1.3/libphp4.so

Stating the obvious here, but the web pages with php should be named with
the .php extension, according to your config, to be parsed by PHP.

HTH,
Rob

> On 20021123.1147, Richard Steffens said ...
>
> I'm trying to get my internal home web site running again on RH 8. I
> followed the instructions in the books I have but have been unsuccessful
> in getting php working. The book says to add the following to httpd.conf
> 
> AddType application/x-httpd-php .php

> 
> I have those lines in the file.

>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 12:17:29 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 12:17:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231147171.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231147171.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211231217.29063.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Do you have a .emacs~ backup file laying around from the last time you 
edited your .emacs file in emacs? My .emacs and .bash_profile files 
have followed me from job to job over the years and would hate to lose 
them.

One thing I do for my critcal text files is to put them into revision 
control using RCS. I find this very handy as it makes it difficult for 
me to completely lose a file as I can always go back to an older 
working version if I find my newer version doesn't work for me. Theres 
no way that a system upgrade will touch my RCS files so I won't lose 
any critical files even if my system upgrade changes on of them.

I would have to give Red Hat two thumbs down for going through user 
directories and changing or removing user configuration files without 
saving the old file as a backup. Since no .rpmnew file was created it 
makes me wonder if it was something other than "rpm" that did the 
damage. There might have been some post install script or something 
that did this. I suppose they could have had emacs do when you first 
started it up as well I don't really know.

Tony
