From ali at axian.com  Sat Nov 23 12:22:32 2002
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 12:22:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] emacs-21.2.1
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231143170.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Sat, Nov 23, 2002 at 11:47:08AM -0800
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231143170.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021123122232.A16698@zaphod.axian.com>

Try putting this in your .emacs file:

 '(tool-bar-mode nil nil (tool-bar))

It appeared when I turned off the toolbar in the Customize pages.
I believe that you can also turn of the toolbar in your X resources.
Ali

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 12:48:25 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 12:48:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Nov 23 12:55:22 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?

On Sat, 23 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> Do you have a .emacs~ backup file laying around from the last time you 
> edited your .emacs file in emacs? My .emacs and .bash_profile files 
> have followed me from job to job over the years and would hate to lose 
> them.

  Nope. One of the tasks of ~/.bash_logout is to get rid of backups. When I
want to save a file I copy it to a different name rather than leave it with
the tilde hanging off the end.
 
> One thing I do for my critcal text files is to put them into revision 
> control using RCS. I find this very handy as it makes it difficult for 
> me to completely lose a file as I can always go back to an older 
> working version if I find my newer version doesn't work for me. Theres 
> no way that a system upgrade will touch my RCS files so I won't lose 
> any critical files even if my system upgrade changes on of them.

  I read about this recently in Linux Journal but haven't implemented it
yet.
 
> I would have to give Red Hat two thumbs down for going through user 
> directories and changing or removing user configuration files without 
> saving the old file as a backup. Since no .rpmnew file was created it 
> makes me wonder if it was something other than "rpm" that did the 
> damage. There might have been some post install script or something 
> that did this. I suppose they could have had emacs do when you first 
> started it up as well I don't really know.

  No, the datestamp on the file is Sept. 5, when I did the upgrade and had
it upgrade emacs, too.

  Of course there's no way of recovering the file now, so I can find the
humor in the contact name given to me (and presumably correctly typed from
the business card provided) bounces from redhat.com as 'no such user'. I
guess that if you're going to screw up you might as well do it thoroughly
and not half-way. Sigh.

Thanks, Tony,

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 12:59:32 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 12:59:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com> <20021123120123.A62801@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <3DDFEC34.8DA113B6@attbi.com>

Thanks for the ideas. They were a good start, but I'm still stuck.

Rob Hudson wrote:

> Their should be another line in the apache config that tells apache to load
> the PHP shared object file.  (Not sure if 'shared object' file is what it's
> called).
> 
> On my Debian box, that line looks like:
> 
>   LoadModule php4_module /usr/lib/apache/1.3/libphp4.so

I found it on RH 8.0 at /usr/lib/httpd/modules/libphp4.so and added the
line

   LoadModule php4_module /usr/lib/httpd/modules/libphp4.so

to my httpd.conf file. Then I restarted httpd and got the message:

[root at nec conf]# /etc/rc.d/init.d/httpd restart
Stopping httpd:                                            [  OK  ]
Starting httpd: [Sat Nov 23 12:16:43 2002] [warn] module php4_module is
already loaded, skipping
                                                           [  OK  ]
[root at nec conf]#

>From this, I assume that this installation of Apache has the php4 module
compiled in, or something like that.

However, now httpd is not running. If I try to access it locally with
Mozilla, I get an alert message that says:

The connection was refused when attempting to contact 192.168.0.254.

(That's the ip address of the machine.)

If I try to stop httpd at this point, it fails.

[root at nec conf]# /etc/rc.d/init.d/httpd stop
Stopping httpd:                                            [FAILED]
[root at nec conf]#

Starting claims to work, but ps -ax | grep httpd only returns the line
showing the grep command. httpd was working before I started on this,
this afternoon.

I switched back to the httpd.conf file supplied by RH and tried to start
it again. It started with the message:

[root at nec conf]# /etc/rc.d/init.d/httpd start
Starting httpd: httpd: Could not determine the server's fully qualified
domain name, using 127.0.0.1 for ServerName
                                                           [  OK  ]
[root at nec conf]#

Now I can see the web site again, both locally from Mozilla, and from
other machines in the house. I must have messed up something in
httpd.conf.

> Stating the obvious here, but the web pages with php should be named with
> the .php extension, according to your config, to be parsed by PHP.

Yep. I sort of thought that might be what the AddType lines were all
about.

Thinking that the message about the domain name might be a clue, I
checked in /etc/hosts and found that I had 192.168.0.255 instead of
192.168.0.254 listed for nec, which is the machines name. I fixed that,
but it didn't make any difference. If I run hostname, it reports nec.
Now that I think about it, I used to be able to reach the web site by
typing nec in the address line of a browser, but now I have to put in
the ip address, so there must be something missing regarding the name of
the machine as Apache sees it.

Any other thoughts on either the machine name or php?

Thanks for the help.

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From vincentdamewood at yahoo.com  Sat Nov 23 13:01:45 2002
From: vincentdamewood at yahoo.com (Vincent Damewood)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 13:01:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021123210145.55903.qmail@web13806.mail.yahoo.com>

How are you accessing the files? http://127.0.0.1/ or
with file:///var/www/ (or whatever Red Hat uses)? The
only way I ever got that kind of error was by
accessing the files directly (file://), which doesn't
even touch apache, and thus, no PHP, but by accessing
your site through http://127.blah it actually does go
through apache.

HTH,
Vincent Damewood

Subject: [PLUG] Control of 'ls' display
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211230851370.14512-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211230851370.14512-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 08:59, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   When I listed the directory contents it displayed in three columns across
> the screen. The idle thought wandered into my head that the arrangement was
> probably done by bash counting the number of files and assigning one-third
> to each display column. But, after I had converted a few dozen names, the
> display became two columns rather than three. My experience with looking at
> lots of directory displays suggests that the shell tries to fit them on a
> single line, but creates columns (down, rather than across) as the number or
> length becomes too large.
> 
>   So, just out of curiosity I would like to learn what controls this
> display. I assume that it's something within bash (or the shell of your
> choice). Is the algorithm some generally accepted standard or does it vary
> with the phase of the moon and the tides?

RTFS (Read The Fine Source) or UTSL (Use The Source, Luke) "ls":

(Sorry for the word wrapping done by "evolution" composer.  Anyone know
how to turn that off?)

karlheg at bittersweet:~
% dpkg --search =ls
coreutils: /bin/ls
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% cd /usr/local/src/debian

Makefile.am   csplit.c	     groups.sh*  mknod.c     shred.c	 tty.c
Makefile.in   cut.c	     head.c	 mv.c	     sleep.c	 uname.c
ansi2knr.1    date.c	     hostid.c	 nice.c      sort.c	 unexpand.c

basename.c    dd.c	     id.c	 nohup.sh*   stat.c	 unlink.c

chroot.c      env.c	     ls-ls.c	 ptx.c	     tac.c	 whoami.c
cksum.c       expand.c	     ls-vdir.c	 pwd.c	     tail.c	 yes.c
comm.c	      expr.c	     ls.c	 remove.c    tee.c
copy.c	      factor.c	     ls.h	 remove.h    test.c
copy.h	      false.c	     md5.c	 rm.c	     touch.c
cp-hash.c     fmt.c	     md5sum.c	 rmdir.c     tr.c
cp-hash.h     fold.c	     mkdir.c	 seq.c	     true.c
karlheg at bittersweet:coreutils-4.5.3/src
% make TAGS
perl -w -- ./dcgen ./dircolors.hin > dircolors.h-t
mv dircolors.h-t dircolors.h
tags=; \
here=`pwd`; \
list='basename.c cat.c chgrp.c chown-core.c chmod.c chown.c chown-core.c
chroot.c cksum.c comm.c cp.c copy.c cp-hash.c csplit.c cut.c date.c dd.c
df.c ls.c ls-dir.c dircolors.c dirname.c du.c echo.c env.c expand.c
expr.c factor.c false.c fmt.c fold.c install.c copy.c cp-hash.c head.c
hostid.c hostname.c id.c join.c kill.c link.c ln.c logname.c ls.c
ls-ls.c md5sum.c md5.c mkdir.c mkfifo.c mknod.c mv.c copy.c cp-hash.c
remove.c nice.c nl.c od.c paste.c pathchk.c pinky.c pr.c printenv.c
printf.c ptx.c pwd.c rm.c remove.c rmdir.c seq.c md5sum.c sha1sum.c
shred.c sleep.c sort.c split.c stat.c stty.c su.c sum.c sync.c tac.c
tail.c tee.c test.c touch.c tr.c true.c tsort.c tty.c uname.c unexpand.c
uniq.c unlink.c uptime.c users.c ls.c ls-vdir.c wc.c who.c whoami.c
yes.c system.h sys2.h checksum.h copy.h cp-hash.h ls.h dircolors.h
remove.h chown-core.h fs.h wheel.h wheel-size.h   '; \
unique=`for i in $list; do \
    if test -f "$i"; then echo $i; else echo ./$i; fi; \
  done | \
  gawk '    { files[$0] = 1; } \
       END { for (i in files) print i; }'`; \
test -z "$tags$unique" \
  || etags    \
     $tags $unique
karlheg at bittersweet:coreutils-4.5.3/src
% xg ls.c

(xg is a script that calls on my running XEmacs via "gnuclient")

From rob at euglug.net  Sat Nov 23 13:09:50 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 13:09:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFEC34.8DA113B6@attbi.com>; from rsteff@attbi.com on Sat, Nov 23, 2002 at 12:59:32PM -0800
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com> <20021123120123.A62801@cogit8.org> <3DDFEC34.8DA113B6@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021123130950.C62801@cogit8.org>

> On 20021123.1259, Richard Steffens said ...
>
> Any other thoughts on either the machine name or php?
> 
> Thanks for the help.

If it's compiled into apache, it should work.  You might want to check your
php.ini file (not sure where it would be) for this:

  short_open_tag = Off

If it's on, you can open up PHP in your HTML using just '<?' and closing
with '?>'.  If it's off, you have to open with '<?php'.

Some people like it off so XML documents won't be parsed as PHP:

  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>

-Rob




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 13:13:32 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 13:13:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFEC34.8DA113B6@attbi.com>
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com> <20021123120123.A62801@cogit8.org>
	 <3DDFEC34.8DA113B6@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038086012.9366.40.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 12:59, Richard Steffens wrote:
> However, now httpd is not running. If I try to access it locally with
> Mozilla, I get an alert message that says:
> 
> The connection was refused when attempting to contact 192.168.0.254.

When this sort of thing happens -- apache is mysteriously not running in
this case -- check it's debug log file.  (Implying that you should set
the loglevel appropriately.)

I've found segmentation faults in Apache (and XS mod_perl) modules this
way; once I was having trouble with "Set::Object" causing mod_perl to
segv the apache process.  It would just die on me; the log contained a
minimial clue as to what was occuring, I guessed where it was, and found
that you cannot add "undef" to a Set::Object.  Rather than handling that
gracefully, it would segmentation fault. I bug reported it, and they
fixed it.




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 13:17:02 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 13:17:02 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
In-Reply-To: <200211230823.gAN8N1214398@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200211230823.gAN8N1214398@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <1038086222.9388.43.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 00:23, Galen Seitz wrote:
> Thanks to everyone for your help.  I should have told you that I was
> trying to save space by eliminating getty and login entirely.

Well, then obviously what you must do is write a C replacement for getty
that sets up the terminal then execs the shell.  Perhaps "mingetty" has
what you want?  Maybe it's even all you need?




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 13:20:03 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 13:20:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init?
In-Reply-To: <200211230823.gAN8N1214398@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
References: <200211230823.gAN8N1214398@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <1038086403.9388.47.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 00:23, Galen Seitz wrote:
> Thanks to everyone for your help.  I should have told you that I was
> trying to save space by eliminating getty and login entirely.

Perhaps what you need is "busybox".  You can build that with an "ash"
shell, "getty", and "init".  One binary does it all.  It will link with
ulibc also, if you need to get really small.  Also, in the
smallification department, there's a tool used by the Debian
"boot-floppies" installer that performs a library reduction.  It creates
a subset of the shared object libraries... the subset .so's it makes
contain ONLY the union of the sets of functions actually used by all of
the binaries in your small closed system.  This is fine unless you want
to drop arbitrary binaries onto it -- they MIGHT need a library routine
that got elimintated by the tree shaker.




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 13:24:59 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 13:24:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Upgrade doesn't touch /home, eh?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231250350.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211231250350.15128-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211231324.59744.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Definitely consider setting up RCS or CVS. For local stuff RCS is really 
easy to setup and emacs has support for it so you can check files 
in/out of RCS from within emacs. I generally use RCS from emacs but I'm 
comfortable checking files in/out from the command-line as well.

Tony

On Saturday 23 November 2002 12:55 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Sat, 23 Nov 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > Do you have a .emacs~ backup file laying around from the last time
> > you edited your .emacs file in emacs? My .emacs and .bash_profile
> > files have followed me from job to job over the years and would
> > hate to lose them.
>
>   Nope. One of the tasks of ~/.bash_logout is to get rid of backups.
> When I want to save a file I copy it to a different name rather than
> leave it with the tilde hanging off the end.
>
> > One thing I do for my critcal text files is to put them into
> > revision control using RCS. I find this very handy as it makes it
> > difficult for me to completely lose a file as I can always go back
> > to an older working version if I find my newer version doesn't work
> > for me. Theres no way that a system upgrade will touch my RCS files
> > so I won't lose any critical files even if my system upgrade
> > changes on of them.
>
>   I read about this recently in Linux Journal but haven't implemented
> it yet.
>
> > I would have to give Red Hat two thumbs down for going through user
> > directories and changing or removing user configuration files
> > without saving the old file as a backup. Since no .rpmnew file was
> > created it makes me wonder if it was something other than "rpm"
> > that did the damage. There might have been some post install script
> > or something that did this. I suppose they could have had emacs do
> > when you first started it up as well I don't really know.
>
>   No, the datestamp on the file is Sept. 5, when I did the upgrade
> and had it upgrade emacs, too.
>
>   Of course there's no way of recovering the file now, so I can find
> the humor in the contact name given to me (and presumably correctly
> typed from the business card provided) bounces from redhat.com as 'no
> such user'. I guess that if you're going to screw up you might as
> well do it thoroughly and not half-way. Sigh.
>
> Thanks, Tony,
>
> Rich
>
>
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com





From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Sat Nov 23 13:25:57 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 13:25:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038086757.1118.8.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 11:47, Richard Steffens wrote:

> AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
> AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps
<snip>
> What step am I missing?

Did you fix mime.types?  On my vanilla slackware apache/php install,
here's what I have for PHP:

rob at linuxbox:/etc/apache$ grep php * | grep -v \# | grep -v php.ini
httpd.conf:    DirectoryIndex index.html index.php index.ht
httpd.conf:Include /etc/apache/mod_php.conf
httpd.conf:    AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
httpd.conf:    AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps
httpd.conf:LoadModule php4_module        modules/libphp4.so
httpd.conf:AddType application/x-httpd-php .php  
mime.types:mime.types:application/x-httpd-php                    phtml
pht php
mime.types:mime.types:application/x-httpd-php-source             phps
mime.types:mime.types:application/x-httpd-php3                   php3
mime.types:mime.types:application/x-httpd-php3-preprocessed      php3p
mime.types:mime.types:application/x-httpd-php4                   php4
mod_php.conf:LoadModule php4_module libexec/libphp4.so
mod_php.conf:AddModule mod_php4.c
mod_php.conf:AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
mod_php.conf.example:LoadModule php4_module libexec/libphp4.so
mod_php.conf.example:AddModule mod_php4.c
mod_php.conf.example:AddType application/x-httpd-php .php


-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Sat Nov 23 13:42:39 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 13:42:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021123214239.47813.qmail@web10410.mail.yahoo.com>

Richard,

You need to turn on short_open_tags in /etc/php.ini. I had the same
problem when I went from RedHat 7.3 to RedHat 8.

You might want to write your future PHP scripts with the "proper" PHP
tags, like:

<?php phpinfo(); ?>

instead of short tags:

<? phpinfo(); ?>

-Scott

--- Richard Steffens <rsteff at attbi.com> wrote:
> I'm trying to get my internal home web site running again on RH 8. I
> followed the instructions in the books I have but have been
> unsuccessful
> in getting php working. The book says to add the following to
> httpd.conf
> 
> AddType application/x-httpd-php .php
> AddType application/x-httpd-php-source .phps
> 
> I have those lines in the file. 
> 
> apachectl configtest reports:
> 
> Syntax OK.
> 
> Apache itself is working; I can connect to the web site from other
> machines in the house. However, when I try looking at a page with <?
> phpinfo() ?> as its only content, I get a blank page instead of the
> long
> page of php information that I should get. And, when I look at any
> other
> web page that uses php, I see the php commands instead of the results
> of
> those commands. From this, I assume that Apache is not using php.
> 
> What step am I missing?
> 
> Thanks in advance for the help.
> 
> -- 
> Regards,
> 
> Dick Steffens
> http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/
>

> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org

From robby at planetargon.com  Sat Nov 23 14:09:11 2002
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 14:09:11 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache and php question
In-Reply-To: <20021123214239.47813.qmail@web10410.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <3DDFDB4A.55D5D55@attbi.com>
        <20021123214239.47813.qmail@web10410.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <55901.12.231.224.10.1038089351.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>

I'll second that.
If you start working with another language with php...such as xml, you
will find problems with the short tags being turned on.
I'm currently in the process of doing find and replaces on <? to change
them to <?php on a lot of old code because I am using XML now and needed
to turn short tags off.

<? phpinfo() ?>
and
<? xml version="1.0" ?>
won't work together otherwise. (at least as far as I know...)

-Robby

<?echo Scott VanHoosen managed to take the time to type out the following:

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Nov 23 14:26:30 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 14:26:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: Apache and php question
References: <20021123214239.47813.qmail@web10410.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3DE00096.1E065BF0@attbi.com>

Scott VanHoosen wrote:

> You need to turn on short_open_tags in /etc/php.ini. I had the same
> problem when I went from RedHat 7.3 to RedHat 8.
> 
> You might want to write your future PHP scripts with the "proper" PHP
> tags, like:
> 
> <?php phpinfo(); ?>
> 
> instead of short tags:
> 
> <? phpinfo(); ?>

I tested this by changing the phpinfo.php file as you recommend above.
Works like a charm with no other changes to httpd.conf or php.ini. Looks
like I either missed something several months ago when I first learned
how to write php, or the books I used missed something. Now I know
better.

Regarding short_open_tags, Rob Hudson wrote:

> Some people like it off so XML documents won't be parsed as PHP:
> 
>   <?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?>

That makes sense. I'll try the php.ini file change to make sure
everything's OK, and then probably go back and edit the offending .php
files to fix them.

Thanks to all for the advice.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Sat Nov 23 14:58:47 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 14:58:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] start shell directly from init? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "23 Nov 2002 13:20:03 PST."
             <1038086403.9388.47.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> 
Message-ID: <200211232258.gANMwl221852@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 00:23, Galen Seitz wrote:
> > Thanks to everyone for your help.  I should have told you that I was
> > trying to save space by eliminating getty and login entirely.
> 
> Perhaps what you need is "busybox".  You can build that with an "ash"
> shell, "getty", and "init".  One binary does it all.  It will link with
> ulibc also, if you need to get really small.  Also, in the
> smallification department, there's a tool used by the Debian
> "boot-floppies" installer that performs a library reduction.  It creates
> a subset of the shared object libraries... the subset .so's it makes
> contain ONLY the union of the sets of functions actually used by all of
> the binaries in your small closed system.  This is fine unless you want
> to drop arbitrary binaries onto it -- they MIGHT need a library routine
> that got elimintated by the tree shaker.
> 

Busybox is on my list of things to do, but it has a low priority right
now.  It's good to know about the library reduction tool.  BTW, this
is on a serial port, so mingetty won't work.

galen

From bprew at logiccloud.com  Sat Nov 23 15:43:38 2002
From: bprew at logiccloud.com (Benjamin Prew)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 15:43:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended Reading?
In-Reply-To: <20021122163844.673d32eb.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
References: <20021122121543.20e303f8.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
	<200211221244.22324.mark@linuxhardware.net> 
	<20021122163844.673d32eb.yrn4dsl@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038095018.1600.69.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I've been thinking about something similar to Safari, only using real
books instead of e-books.  It would follow the same format: monthly fees
that differ based on the number of books you wanted to read at any one
time.  So, the lowest fee would only allow you to have one book out at
any one time.  But, you would be able to return at anytime to get a
different book.

Ideally, the monthly fee would be as close an nominal as possible, but
it would almost have to be more then Safari's monthly fee, as you would
have to physically ship the books back and forth.  Similar to
netflix.com.  

How does this sound, would you use it?  Would it be useful?  Or do most
people like having permanent copies of the books they buy?


On Fri, 2002-11-22 at 16:38, david wrote:

> > the short term.  The basic subscription is $10 for five points.  Most books 
> > are one point, although some are 1/2 and some are more. You can swap out once 
> > a month.  They also are starting to include books by other publishers.
> > 
> > Thanks for the review.
> >

From dbridges at austin.rr.com  Sat Nov 23 16:16:44 2002
From: dbridges at austin.rr.com (David Bridges)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 18:16:44 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Editor in Console window
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207220630100.10101-100000@appl-ecosys.com> (Rich
 Shepard's message of "Mon, 22 Jul 2002 06:33:11 -0700 (PDT)")
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207220630100.10101-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <878yzjddoz.fsf@dnbridge.dyndns.org>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Not sure if this will help you Rick, but here is an old post that you sent with your .emacs file.


>   Below is a copy of ~/.emacs. They're always a work in progress and readily
> shared among users. I like the same appearance of emacs whether it's running
> on a console or in a virtual terminal during an X session. Take what works
> for you.
>
> Rich
> -----------------------------------------------------------
> (cond (window-system
>   (setq default-frame-alist
>     '((width            . 350)
>       (height           . 400)
>       (font . "-adobe-courier-medium-r-*--*-165-*-*-m-*-iso8859-1")
>       (foreground-color . "white")
>       (background-color . "black")
>       (mouse-color      . "Orchid")
>       (cursor-color     . "Orchid")
>       (icon-type        . t)      ; gnu picture as Emacs icon
>       (icon-name        . nil)    ; use frame title
>   ))
>   (setq frame-title-format "%b")      ; set frame title to buffer name
>   (setq  icon-title-format "%b")      ; set  icon title to buffer name
> ))
>
> (custom-set-variables)
> (custom-set-faces
>  '(default ((t (:size "14"))) t))
> (setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)
> (add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)
> (setq-default transient-mark-mode t)
> ;(require 'tex-site)
> (require 'ps-print)
> (global-font-lock-mode t)                                                           
> (setq font-lock-maximum-decoration t)
>
> (cond (window-system
>   (setq font-lock-face-attributes
> ;              face                     fg        bg  bf  it  ul 
>     '((font-lock-comment-face       "GreenYellow" nil  t   t  nil)
>       (font-lock-string-face        "wheat"   nil nil  t  nil)
>       (font-lock-keyword-face       "purple"      nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-type-face          "MediumVioletRed" nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-function-name-face "DarkOliveGreen4"       nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-variable-name-face "DodgerBlue"       nil  t  nil nil)
>       (font-lock-reference-face     "SeaGreen"        nil nil  t   t ))
>     font-lock-maximum-decoration t
>     font-lock-support-mode 'lazy-lock-mode
>     font-lock-verbose nil
>     lazy-lock-stealth-verbose nil
>   )
>   (if (fboundp 'global-font-lock-mode)
>       (global-font-lock-mode t)
>       (add-hook 'find-file-hooks 'turn-on-font-lock))
> ))
>
> ;; kludge until colors work correctly:
> (make-face 'rbs-comment-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-comment-face "wheat")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-string-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-string-face "LightPink1")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-keyword-face "khaki1")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-keyword-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-type-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-type-face "Goldenrod1")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-type-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-function-name-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-function-name-face "PaleGreen1")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-function-name-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-variable-name-face "turquoise2")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-variable-name-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-reference-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-reference-face "Magenta2")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-reference-face "black")
>
> (make-face 'rbs-constant-face)
> (set-face-foreground 'rbs-constant-face "black")
> (set-face-background 'rbs-constant-face "black")
>
> ; let the new face be the font face
> (setq font-lock-comment-face 'rbs-comment-face)
> (setq font-lock-string-face 'rbs-string-face)
> (setq font-lock-keyword-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
> (setq font-lock-type-face 'rbs-type-face)
> (setq font-lock-function-name-face 'rbs-function-name-face)
> (setq font-lock-variable-name-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)
> (setq font-lock-reference-face 'rbs-reference-face)
> (setq font-lock-constant-face 'rbs-constant-face)
>
> ;; for C code:
> (global-set-key "%" 'match-paren)
>
> (defun match-paren (arg)                                                                  
> "Go to the matching parenthesis if on parenthesis otherwise insert %."                    
>       (interactive "p")                                                                   
>       (cond ((looking-at "\\s\(") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\)") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\{") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\}") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\[") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
>             ((looking-at "\\s\]") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
>             (t (self-insert-command (or arg 1)))))




From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Nov 23 16:17:39 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat, 23 Nov 2002 16:17:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Recommended Reading?
In-Reply-To: <1038095018.1600.69.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211231606240.8858-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 23 Nov 2002, Benjamin Prew wrote:
> I've been thinking about something similar to Safari, only using real
> books instead of e-books.  It would follow the same format: monthly fees
> that differ based on the number of books you wanted to read at any one
> time.  So, the lowest fee would only allow you to have one book out at
> any one time.  But, you would be able to return at anytime to get a
> different book.
> 
> Ideally, the monthly fee would be as close an nominal as possible, but
> it would almost have to be more then Safari's monthly fee, as you would
> have to physically ship the books back and forth.  Similar to
> netflix.com.  
> 
> How does this sound, would you use it?  Would it be useful?  Or do most
> people like having permanent copies of the books they buy?

This is a brilliant system and the more people involved, the more books
could be shared by the widest segment of the public.

I'm quite thankful that such a system has already been devised and
implemented (by Benjamin Franklin, no less) and is called the "public
library".

The fee is shockingly nominal when spread across all of our society.  
Hell, we could probably double the amount we spend on the system and it
would be an even better deal.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 16:27:56 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 16:27:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Better console keymap for XEmacs.
In-Reply-To: <878yzjddoz.fsf@dnbridge.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0207220630100.10101-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	 <878yzjddoz.fsf@dnbridge.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <1038097676.19209.14.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

For XEmacs:

Use "m4" on the xhypermap.m4 to generate a console keymap that gives
sane keysyms for Ctrl-_ and shifted function keys, etc.  Dump it into a
file by using the shell's ">" operator.  On a Debian GNU/Linux system,
you would then copy that into /etc/console, gzip it, then use
"install-keymap" to make it get installed on reboot.

Then, install the "ext-fkeymap.el" into your
"~/.xemacs/xemacs-packages/lisp/user" or anyplace you like, on your
`load-path', and follow the instructions at the top of the file to
install it in your XEmacs.  Now you can use "Ctrl-_" for undo, shifted
function keys, and Meta-Left / Meta-Right for `backward-sexp' and
`forward-sexp', just like under the X Window System.

A similar "ext-fkeymap.el" could probably be written for GNU Emacs; this
one MIGHT even Just Work; I've never tried it.

-------------- next part --------------
#
# hypermap.map 1994/11/11
# Michael Shields <shields at tembel.org>
#
# A keymap redesigned for sanity.
#
# Further sanitization to make it work better for XEmacs by:
#
# 1998-2001 Karl M. Hegbloom <karlheg at hegbloom.net>
# $Id: xhypermap.m4,v 1.3 2001/10/01 00:55:56 karlheg Exp $
#
# I renamed it to xhypermap.m4 - the `function-key-map' in xemacs must
# be extended also for this to work the way I intend it to.  It will
# give you meta-arrowkey, C-S-_ (undo), and modifier + function key on
# the Linux console in XEmacs.
#
# I believe it will require quite a lot of adjustment in order for it
# to function correctly for other charsets.
#
charset "iso-8859-1"

divert(-1)
#
# This keymap is a ground-up reimplementation of the keyboard map,
# intended to be consistent and rational.  It uses an m4 metalanguage to
# declare the key mappings.  Usage is `m4 hypermap.map | loadkeys'.
#
# # m4 xhypermap.m4 | gzip -c -9 > /etc/console/boottime.kmap.gz
#
# The modifier flags used are `shift' (1), `control' (4), and `alt' (8).
# Left and right modifiers are not distinguished.
#
# In general, Meta is always distinguished, and M-S-KEY is distinct from
# M-KEY.  This is good news for Emacs users.  C-S-KEY is consistently
# folded into C-KEY.
#
# Shift is more loosely interpreted than the other modifiers; usually if
# S-KEY has no special meaning, the action will be the same as KEY.
# However, if M-KEY or H-KEY is undefined, nothing happens.
#
# Because Caps Lock's position is so out of proportion to its utility,
# it's been totally redefined to a new sort of modifier, which I've
# arbitrarily named `Hyper'.  Shift is ignored with Hyper.  Hyper
# provides dead keys:
#	H-`	dead accent grave
#	H-'	dead acute accent
#	H-^	dead circumflex
#	H-t	dead tilde
#	H-d	dead diaeresis
# and ISO-8859-1 symbols (some more mnemonic than others):
#	H-SPC	nobreakspace
#	H-!	inverted bang
#	H-h	cents (`hundredths')
#	H-#	pounds sterling
#	H-$	currency
#	H-y	yen
#	H-|	broken bar
#	H-s	section (the galaxy symbol)
#	H-c	copyright
#	H-a	feminine ordinal
#	H-<	left guillemot
#	H-]	not sign (it's angular)
#	H--	soft hyphen
#	H-r	registered trademark symbol
#	H-=	macron
#	H-0	degrees
#	H-[	plus/minus (near + and -)
#	H-k	superior 2 (jkl form a series)
#	H-l	superior 3
#	H-u	mu
#	H-p	pilcrow
#	H-:	centered dot
#	H-j	superior 1
#	H-o	masculine ordinal
#	H->	right guillemot
#	H-q	1/4 fraction (qwe form a series)
#	H-w	1/2 fraction
#	H-e	3/4 fraction
#	H-?	inverted question mark
#	H-x	multiplication symbol
#	H-%	division symbol
#
# You can also use Hyper plus Alt to type characters by decimal code on
# the keypad, as with Alt alone, or in hex on the main keyboard.  And
# H-TAB is a Caps Lock.
#
# Function keys work as marked, except that Alt plus a function key
# switches to the corresponding virtual console.
# 
# A-F1     - A-F12     --> console  1 through 12
# S-A-F1   - S-A-F12   --> console 13 through 24
# C-A-F1   - C-A-F12   --> console 25 through 36
# S-C-A-F1 - S-C-A-F12 --> console 37 through 48
#
# That should be plenty enough.  Perhaps you can standardize on the
# locations of X servers and logging consoles?
#
# #### Finally, you can change the behavior of the Caps Lock and Controls
# with m4 command-line options.  The default values are equivalent to
# `-DCAPSLOCK_K=Hyper -DLEFTCTRL_K=Control -DRIGHTCTRL_K=Control'.  You
# can remove the Hyper code entirely with `-DCAPSLOCK_K=Caps_Lock'.
#
# This file is arranged vaguely by key position on the classic PC layout.
#
changequote({,})

define({CAPSLOCK_K},{Control})
define({CAPSLOCK_KEYSYM},{Caps_On})  # Caps_On       or  Caps_Lock
define({LEFTSHIFT_K},{Uncaps_Shift}) # Uncaps_Shift  or  Shift
define({RIGHTSHIFT_K},{Uncaps_Shift})
define({LEFTCTRL_K},{_Hyper})
define({RIGHTCTRL_K},{_Hyper})
define({LEFTALT_K},{_Meta})
define({RIGHTALT_K},{_Alt})
define({LEFTGR_K},{_Alt})
# de fi ne({RIGHTGR_K},{_Meta})
define({RIGHTGR_K},{Compose})
define({MENU_K},{Last_Console})

# ----------------------------------
# Set default values.
#
# Caps_Lock or Caps_On
ifdef({CAPSLOCK_KEYSYM},,{define({CAPSLOCK_KEYSYM},{Caps_On})})
ifdef({CAPSLOCK_K},,{define({CAPSLOCK_K},CAPSLOCK_KEYSYM)})

# Shift or Uncaps_Shift
ifdef({LEFTSHIFT_K},,{define({LEFTSHIFT_K},{Uncaps_Shift})})
ifdef({RIGHTSHIFT_K},,{define({RIGHTSHIFT_K},{Uncaps_Shift})})

ifdef({LEFTCTRL_K},,{define({LEFTCTRL_K},{Control})})
ifdef({RIGHTCTRL_K},,{define({RIGHTCTRL_K},{Control})})

ifdef({LEFTGR_K},,{define({LEFTGR_K},{_Hyper})})
ifdef({RIGHTGR_K},,{define({RIGHTGR_K},{_Hyper})})

ifdef({LEFTALT_K},,{define({LEFTALT_K},{_Meta})})
ifdef({RIGHTALT_K},,{define({RIGHTALT_K},{_Alt})})

# Figure out if any key is a _Hyper key.  If so, define {hyper}, for
# {ifdef} testability.
#
ifelse(CAPSLOCK_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       LEFTCTRL_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       RIGHTCTRL_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       LEFTGR_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       RIGHTGR_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       LEFTALT_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})},
       RIGHTALT_K,{_Hyper},{define({_hyper_})})

define({_Meta},{AltGr})
define({_Alt},{Alt})
define({_Hyper},{CtrlR})

# divert
#
# Let it allocate them dynamicly.
#
#dnl keymaps 0,1,4,5,8,9,12,13{}ifdef({hyper},{,128,129,132,133,136,137,140,141})

divert(-1)
# General usage of these macros is MACRO(KEYCODE, UNSHIFTED, SHIFTED).

# We first undefine {shift}, which only causes problems.
#
undefine({shift})

define({SIMPLE}, {keycode $1 = $2 $2})

define({KEY},
{			keycode $1 = $2 VoidSymbol
Shift			keycode $1 = $3
		_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_$2
Shift		_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_$3})

# This macro adds Control variations to a key.
define({CONTROL},
{	Control		keycode $1 = $2
Shift	Control		keycode $1 = $2
	Control	_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_$2
Shift	Control	_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_$2})

# Add _Hyper variations to a key.
define({HYPER}, ifdef({_hyper_},
{			_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2
Shift			_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2}))
define({CONTROLHYPER}, ifdef({_hyper_},
{	Control		_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2
Shift	Control		_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2}))
define({METAHYPER}, ifdef({_hyper_},
{		_Meta	_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2
Shift		_Meta	_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2}))
define({CONTROLMETAHYPER}, ifdef({_hyper_}, dnl Ludicrous.
{	Control	_Meta	_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2
Shift	Control	_Meta	_Hyper	keycode $1 = $2}))

# Special case for letters.  Best to be explicit.
define({LETTER},
{			keycode $1 = {+}$2 VoidSymbol
Shift			keycode $1 = {+}translit($2, {a-z}, {A-Z})
		_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_$2
Shift		_Meta	keycode $1 = Meta_{}translit($2, {a-z}, {A-Z})
CONTROL($1, {Control_}$2)})

# For function keys.  Call here is FUNCTION(KEYCODE, FKEYNUM).
define({BANKSIZE}, 12)
define({FUNCTION},
{				keycode $1 = {F}$2 VoidSymbol
Shift				keycode $1 = {F}eval($2 + BANKSIZE)
	Control			keycode $1 = {F}eval($2 + BANKSIZE * 2)
                _Meta		keycode $1 = {F}eval($2 + BANKSIZE * 3)
			_Hyper	keycode $1 = {F}eval($2 + BANKSIZE * 4)

		_Alt	keycode $1 = {Console_}$2
Shift		_Alt	keycode $1 = {Console_}eval($2 + BANKSIZE)
	Control	_Alt	keycode $1 = {Console_}eval($2 + BANKSIZE * 2)
Shift	Control	_Alt	keycode $1 = {Console_}eval($2 + BANKSIZE * 3)})

# For the keypad digits.  KPDIGIT(KEYCODE, DIGIT).
define({KPDIGIT},
{			keycode $1 = KP_$2 VoidSymbol
Shift			keycode $1 = KP_$2
		_Meta	keycode $1 = Ascii_$2
Shift		_Meta	keycode $1 = Ascii_$2
METAHYPER($1, Ascii_$2)})

# And a special approximation:
define({Meta_Return}, {Meta_Control_m})
divert

KEY(1, Escape, Escape)
    CONTROL(1, Escape)

FUNCTION(59, 1)
FUNCTION(60, 2)
FUNCTION(61, 3)
FUNCTION(62, 4)
FUNCTION(63, 5)
FUNCTION(64, 6)
FUNCTION(65, 7)
FUNCTION(66, 8)
FUNCTION(67, 9)
FUNCTION(68, 10)
FUNCTION(87, 11)
FUNCTION(88, 12)

KEY(2, one, exclam)
    HYPER(2, exclamdown)
    METAHYPER(2, Hex_1)
KEY(3, two, at)
    CONTROL(3, nul)
    METAHYPER(3, Hex_2)
KEY(4, three, numbersign)
    HYPER(4, pound)
    METAHYPER(4, Hex_3)

    HYPER(5, currency)
    METAHYPER(5, Hex_4)

    METAHYPER(6, Hex_5)

    HYPER(7, dead_circumflex)
    METAHYPER(7, Hex_6)

    METAHYPER(8, Hex_7)

    METAHYPER(9, Hex_8)
KEY(10, nine, parenleft)
    METAHYPER(10, Hex_9)
KEY(11, zero, parenright)
    HYPER(11, degree)
    METAHYPER(11, Hex_0)
			keycode 12 = minus VoidSymbol
Shift			keycode 12 = underscore
		_Meta	keycode 12 = Meta_minus
Shift		_Meta	keycode 12 = Meta_underscore
    	Control		keycode 12 = F61
Shift	Control		keycode 12 = {Control_}underscore
	Control	_Meta	keycode 12 = Meta_minus
Shift	Control	_Meta	keycode 12 = Meta_minus
    HYPER(12, hyphen)

# Modifiers.
keycode  58 = CAPSLOCK_K

SIMPLE(69, Num_Lock)

keycode  70 = Scroll_Lock
	Shift	keycode  70 = Show_Memory
	Control	keycode  70 = Show_State
	_Alt	keycode  70 = Show_Registers

# SysRq.  I suppose there's some reason it's ^\.
#
SIMPLE(99, {Control_}backslash)
#
# Not very secure if an ordinary user has writes to reprogram the
# keymap.  That is a security issue with the current Linux console
# drivers, afaik, particularly in a school computing lab environment.
#
Control _Alt _Hyper keycode 99 = SAK

SIMPLE(119, Pause)
# Ctrl-Break seems to have low-level hardware behind it.
SIMPLE(101, Break)

SIMPLE(110, Insert)
_Hyper keycode 110 = KeyboardSignal

SIMPLE(102, Find)
_Hyper keycode 102 = Console_1

keycode 104 = Prior Scroll_Backward

SIMPLE(111, Remove)

SIMPLE(107, Select)

keycode 109 = Next Scroll_Forward

SIMPLE(103, Up)
	Control				keycode 103 = F62
		_Meta			keycode 103 = F63
##				_Hyper	keycode 103 = Graph_Screen

SIMPLE(105, Left)
	Control				keycode 105 = F64
		_Meta			keycode 105 = F65
			_Alt		keycode 105 = Decr_Console
				_Hyper	keycode 105 = Decr_Console

SIMPLE(106, Right)
	Control				keycode 106 = F66
		_Meta			keycode 106 = F67
			_Alt		keycode 106 = Incr_Console
				_Hyper	keycode 106 = Incr_Console

SIMPLE(108, Down)
	Control				keycode 108 = F68
		_Meta			keycode 108 = F69
##				_Hyper	keycode 108 = Text_Screen

# This was the extra key on my old keyboard.
#
# Control _Alt keycode 124 = SAK

Control	_Alt keycode 83 = Boot
Control	_Alt keycode 111 = Boot

# Stock VT102 string definitions.
string F1 = "\033[[A"
string F2 = "\033[[B"
string F3 = "\033[[C"
string F4 = "\033[[D"
string F5 = "\033[[E"
string F6 = "\033[17~"
string F7 = "\033[18~"
string F8 = "\033[19~"
string F9 = "\033[20~"
string F10 = "\033[21~"
string F11 = "\033[23~"
string F12 = "\033[24~"

string F13 = "\033[25~"
string F14 = "\033[26~"
string F15 = "\033[28~"
string F16 = "\033[29~"
string F17 = "\033[31~"
string F18 = "\033[32~"
string F19 = "\033[33~"
string F20 = "\033[34~"

string Find = "\033[1~"
string Insert = "\033[2~"
string Remove = "\033[3~"
string Select = "\033[4~"
string Prior = "\033[5~"
string Next = "\033[6~"
string Macro = "\033[M"
string Pause = "\033[P"

string F21 = "\033[35~"
string F22 = "\033[36~"
string F23 = "\033[37~"
string F24 = "\033[38~"

string F25 = "\033[39~"
string F26 = "\033[40~"
string F27 = "\033[41~"
string F28 = "\033[42~"
string F29 = "\033[43~"
string F30 = "\033[44~"
string F31 = "\033[45~"
string F32 = "\033[46~"
string F33 = "\033[47~"
string F34 = "\033[48~"
string F35 = "\033[49~"

# control - (for 'redo, if you like that.)

# control/meta left
string F64 = "\033[78~"

# control/meta down

# control ;

software that I hope will enable us to open the PLUG lists back up to
legitimate non-member posting.

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sat Nov 23 18:15:39 2002

Subject: [PLUG] PLUG-test re-created - BEWARE OF VIRUS TESTS
Message-ID: <1038104139.4827.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I just re-created PLUG-test.  I am so far the only one subscribed.
Before you subscribe beware that I plan to do virus scanner and spam
scanner tests there.  Don't sign on if you are running Outbreak Express,
for instance, unless you are doing that ON PURPOSE.

Anyone got a Klez virus they can throw at it?  It will accept posts from
anyone...  plug-test at lists.pdxlinux.org

Let's find out if "spamassassin" (with "razor2") knows about the common
viruses... Or will it also need a virus scanner?

I've got it set so that anything with:

subject: \*\*\*\*\*SPAM\*\*\*\*\*

... in the headers will get blocked for list manager approval.  Exim
scans all mail on the way in with spamassassin.

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Sat Nov 23 18:52:33 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 18:52:33 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG-test re-created - BEWARE OF VIRUS TESTS
In-Reply-To: <1038104139.4827.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <1038104139.4827.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <1038106352.1117.41.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 18:15, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> Anyone got a Klez virus they can throw at it?  It will accept posts from
> anyone...  plug-test at lists.pdxlinux.org
> 
> Let's find out if "spamassassin" (with "razor2") knows about the common
> viruses... Or will it also need a virus scanner?

I think if you want to block viruses, you need AMaViS (which does work
with SpamAssasin) or something similar.  I don't know how well Exim
works with it - I'm a postfix kinda guy myself.  :-)

I wouldn't be terribly surprised if SA did block a few viruses on
accident, though.

It's worth noting that my combo AMaViS/SpamAssasin *has* blocked a few
legit PLUG emails since I installed them... as well as a few legit
emails from other lists.  It is rare, but does happen.  I'm willing to
put up with it myself, though.  :-)

> I've got it set so that anything with:
> 
> subject: \*\*\*\*\*SPAM\*\*\*\*\*
> 
> ... in the headers will get blocked for list manager approval.  Exim
> scans all mail on the way in with spamassassin.

Does SA drop the email or add SPAM to the subject line?

Mine drops it, but it isn't a complete SA setup.

If it drops it, you may want to add a bounce message - so those legit
emailers know there is a problem.  Spam emails would just bounce to
non-existant addresses.

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 23 19:00:46 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 23 Nov 2002 19:00:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG-test re-created - BEWARE OF VIRUS TESTS
In-Reply-To: <1038106352.1117.41.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <1038104139.4827.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1038106352.1117.41.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1038106846.4827.25.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-11-23 at 18:52, AthlonRob wrote:
> Does SA drop the email or add SPAM to the subject line?

It modifies the subject line, probably adds another header or two, and
edits the body of the message with information about why it marked it as
spam.  In Mailman's admin page for a list, under "Privacy Options",
there's a text box where you enter regular expressions, one per line, to
be tried against the message headers.  When one matches, the message is
held for moderator approval.  So now anything flagged as SPAM is held
for approval.

I have not opened the list yet, but will as soon as I get AMaViS / OAV
Scannerdaemon / Spamassassin all working right under Exim.  I'm tired of
the constant non-member posts.  I'd rather just let them through, but
many of them are virus or SPAM.  I want those stopped, but any random
person posting via the USENET interface or via a web email archive ought
to get through.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Nov 24 01:02:00 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 24 Nov 2002 01:02:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Virus and SPAM scanning implemented for PLUG mail.
Message-ID: <1038128520.4870.63.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I've installed and set up "AMaViS" with the "clamav" virus scanner, as
well as Spamassassin.  These are run by Exim for all incoming email to
lists.pdxlinux.org.  Virus email is quarantined, and the person who sent
it is sent a notice regarding the virus, so they'll know they've been
infected.  Mail flagged as SPAM has the subject line modified, with the
string "*****SPAM*****" prepended.  The Mailman list software
configuration allows a list of expressions that if one matches a mail
header, that mail is held for moderator approval rather than sent out to
the list members.  I've added an expression to match SPAM tagged email.

You may test this by sending SPAM and virus email to the "PLUG-test"
list, or even straight to the normal "PLUG" list if you like.  It SHOULD
not show up at all now, even if you're a subscriber.

After we are all comfortable with this, I suggest that we open the list
back up to allow non-member posting again.

If anyone wants to know how it was done, just log into
drizzle.pdxlinux.org and look over the "/etc/exim/exim.conf" file along
with the conffiles for amavis, clamav, and spamassassin.




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Nov 24 05:49:32 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 24 Nov 2002 05:49:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] [Drizzle Users] Is everyone checking their mail?
Message-ID: <1038145772.28714.5.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Just wondering if everyone with a user account on Drizzle is checking
their mail there on a regular basis or not?

When I send mail to "users at drizzle.pdxlinux.org", are you all reading
it, I wonder?  (I'd have sent this there if I was certain it would reach
all of you.)  I need to know because very soon I will be implementing
cram-md5 authentication for both the IMAP and TLS SMTP AUTH (for
authorized relay).

Will this be a problem for anyone (with an account on drizzle)?  Do all
of your mail user agents (MUA's) support:

IMAP with TLS on port 143, or IMAPS (IMAP over SSL on port 993)
SMTP AUTH, preferrably over a TLS encrypted connection?

I'm pretty sure that Evolution can do these things.

From kevinc at dOink.COM  Sun Nov 24 08:19:54 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Sun, 24 Nov 2002 08:19:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] BRU backup with CRU crash recovery
Message-ID: <20021124161956.772972FEAA@joseph.doink.com>

I'm using BRU for backup and CRU for crash recovery.  CRU initiates a 
BRU backup for use in the crash recovery process.  In the 'cru' 
script there's this note:

# This is the CRU main startup script.  It is run on the host system and calls
# the other elements to create the boot and root disks, as well as perform a
# full CRU-compatible backup.
#
# NOTE: It is very important that the 'crubackup' script be used to create
#       the recovery backup.  While it is possible to MANUALLY recover from
#       a standard BRU backup, the automated recovery requires that the backup
#       be created in a specific manner for proper operation.

Looking further in the script it calls 'dobackup' which calls 'bru' 
like this:

bru -cvvv -O -A -m -R -f ${DEVICE} -L "CRU system backup" - </tmp/CRU.backup

which looks more or less like a vanilla 'bru' command line.  About a 
month ago I sent an email to the BRU support line, since I'm a paying 
customer, asking them what's special about the backup initiated by 
CRU.  I haven't heard anything back yet.  I'd like to add the option 
to use compression to the above command line since w/o compression 
the backup takes twice as many tapes and twice as long to complete.

Any thoughts?   Thanks....






From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Nov 24 08:38:48 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 24 Nov 2002 08:38:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] BRU backup with CRU crash recovery
In-Reply-To: <20021124161956.772972FEAA@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211240833580.30324-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 24 Nov 2002, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:

> which looks more or less like a vanilla 'bru' command line.  About a 
> month ago I sent an email to the BRU support line, since I'm a paying 
> customer, asking them what's special about the backup initiated by 
> CRU.  I haven't heard anything back yet.  I'd like to add the option 
> to use compression to the above command line since w/o compression 
> the backup takes twice as many tapes and twice as long to complete.
> 
> Any thoughts?   Thanks....

  I keep intending to set up CRU but have never gotten around to it. Sigh. I
_really_ should, I know. Anyway, ...

  What version of BRU are you using? They (now The Tolis Group) dropped the
-Z compression option from release 17.x Something about it being built in or
automatically detected; I forget the exact reason. Anyway, I modified incbru
and it's been chugging along just fine so it must work.

  I don't have the fastest tape drive available, only 3-4M per minute, but
it was the fastest I could afford. Besides, there's not that much data (only
about 16G). I don't know whether or not it's compressed because the logs
don't show it one way or the other and the backups are every night on a 60G
tape.

  FWIW, I've had excellent support (e-mail and phone) from the guys there on
the few occasions I've needed it.

Rich

From kaile at centerspan.com  Mon Nov 25 08:44:15 2002

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Nov 25 09:21:29 2002
From: plug at magnetinternet.com (Matt King)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 09:21:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] how to e2fsck without keeping /' mounted?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0211241622330.29650-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0211241622330.29650-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <8270.66.93.41.98.1038244889.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Boot with a floppy or cd-rom and check it that way.  tomsrtbt
<http://www.toms.net/rb/> comes to mind.  That way you won't mount any of
your disk partitions.

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

From creelan at engr.orst.edu  Sun Nov 24 11:25:39 2002
From: creelan at engr.orst.edu (Tyler F. Creelan)
Date: Sun, 24 Nov 2002 11:25:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Spamassassin installed SITE WIDE now.
In-Reply-To: <1038102402.4833.3.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211241047030.8621-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

Hi Karl -

> You no longer need to run "spamc" via .procmailrc or an exim filter in
> .forward, since I've hooked it in site-wide. All incoming mail will now
> All incoming mail will now be SPAM scanned.

Out of curiousity, what happens to messages when they test positive for
spam? It gets sent on to us with **SPAM** in the subject line, correct?

In theory the positive message could also be deleted or placed in a folder
for review by the sysadmin, but as legitimate email is often tagged
positive, this could violate the user's privacy. For example, if
spamassassin tagged a steamy letter from your girlfriend as spam, you
wouldn't want the admin reading the letter and forwarding it on to you.

Another guideline established on site-wide spam filtering is to provide
users the means to opt out. For example, most users don't receive a lot of
spam and it would be annoying if one of their friend's emails were
consistently flagged as spam. Mandatory spam filtering also constitutes a
kind of censorship in that messages containing certain phrases, or manners
of expression (ie shouting in all caps), are usually flagged.

Anyway, I don't get many messages on this account, but generally its
important to balance spam filtering and protecting user privacy/freedom of
speech. Observing the "tag and forward" and "opt-out" policies helps to
achieve this.

Thanks,

Tyler


On 23 Nov 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> You no longer need to run "spamc" via .procmailrc or an exim filter in
> .forward, since I've hooked it in site-wide.
>
> All incoming mail will now be SPAM scanned.  I THINK this will also
> catch most viruses...  Anyone know?
>

I know the public library exists, and whenever possible, I use it.  But,
I have found they they have a dismal selection of technical books, hence
the previous message.  If the library had such a great selection, why
would anyone buy books in the first place? 

Also, this system would allow for book reviews, similar to amazon.com,
and would keep a nice, updated list of books, both learning and
reference.  I feel that that it could be worth a monthly fee to be able
to "check-out" a good, quality book on a language I am only going to use
for side-projects, or something I am personally interested in.

References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>

I'm getting ready to compile the kernel. I'm getting confusing
information from multiple sources about just which set of source files
to work with. There are some kind of source files on the machine put
there during the RH 8.0 installation process. But, the README file in
there (/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-14) says not to use them. Instead it says
to unpack the source from the CD into my home directory. I looked on the
three CD's I have and do not find the source. I do find a README file on
the CD's that says the source is on either CD 4 or 5.

I did a google search for the Linux kernel and found
linux-2.4.18.tar.gz. I'm assuming that there will probably be something
different between this kernel source and what I'd get from Redhat. At
the Redhat ftp site I find kernel-2.4.18-14.src.rpm. Is that the same as
what I've already got installed? Is there someplace else I should be
looking for a tar.gz file that would be the source for 2.4.18-14?

I suspect that there will be many different answers to the question,
what source should I use? I want to maintain as much compatibility with
the existing installation as possible while compiling the kernel
optimized for the AMD K-6. Or, does that matter? Would it be safe to use
the latest stable kernel source, which is something like 2.4.19, or
would that break things done in the installation?

Thanks for any advice.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

Since nobody else using KDE is speaking up, I gave it a shot. Takes a little 
jumping through hoops, but KOrganizer deals with it fine once it's in.
Had to save it off to a file manually and do a Merge from within KOrganizer. 
KMail doesn't have integrated support to toss it at KOrganizer, but it's on 
the "Todo" list:
http://korganizer.kde.org/korgtodo.html#subKOrganizer%20-%201047142960.423

It's actually fairly trivial, it would appear.

Message-ID: <3DE23684.7020907@attbi.com>

Good morning everyone. I need help with a class lab assignment. I am 
supposed to get nfs running on two machines, be able to mount a 
directory on the server...and so on. I have nfs compiled into both 
kernels and it shows up in the /proc/filesystems file. I have mounted 
directories on the server box that show up in the /etc/fstab file. When 
I try to mount a directory from the client side I get this error:   
mount: 10.0.0.40: failed, reason given by server, Permission denied.   
In the /etc/export file the directory has these parameters: (insecure, 
no_root_squash, rw), insecure just because I was trying to remove all 
barriers to get this to work......Does anyone have some advice? I am 
about to start hitting my head against the wall....

Thanks,
Terrel Woolbright
terrelw1 at attbi.com




From mark at linuxhardware.net  Mon Nov 25 09:57:59 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 09:57:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] NFS problem
In-Reply-To: <3DE23684.7020907@attbi.com>
References: <3DE23684.7020907@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200211250957.59651.mark@linuxhardware.net>

After you added your entries to /etc/exports, did you run exportfs -a (on the 
NFS server)?

Also, I found this NFS how-to to be very helpful when I first started using 
NFS.

http://nfs.sourceforge.net/nfs-howto/

Mark

> SMTP AUTH, preferrably over a TLS encrypted connection?
> 
> I'm pretty sure that Evolution can do these things.

All my mail is forwarded off to my main address.
 
Wil

From richard.langis at sun.com  Mon Nov 25 10:08:13 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 10:08:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] NFS problem
References: <3DE23684.7020907@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DE2670D.1060301@sun.com>

You might check your logs to see more information about the specific 
error - try to mount the directory, and then 'ls -lt | head' the 
/var/log directory.  Pick the top file and tail it to see what your 
error could be.

Here's my /etc/exports file:  (stupid line wrap)

# cat /etc/exports
/home/users     192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0(rw)
/var/cache/apt/archives         192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0(rw,no_root_squash)
/usr/share/public               192.168.1.0/255.255.255.0(rw)

Here's /etc/fstab from a remote system:

# tail /etc/fstab
192.168.1.252:/home/users   /home/users     nfs 
rsize=8192,wsize=8192,timeo=14,intr     0       0
192.168.1.252:/usr/share/public     /usr/share/public       nfs 
rsize=8192,wsize=8192,timeo=14,intr     0       0

# mount
192.168.1.252:/home/users on /home/users type nfs 
(rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192,timeo=14,intr,addr=192.168.1.252)
192.168.1.252:/usr/share/public on /usr/share/public type nfs 
(rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192,timeo=14,intr,addr=192.168.1.252)

Hope that helps somewhat.  I noticed that you said you were using 
/etc/export (sans 'S'), that could be an issue.

Good luck.

-R

From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov 25 10:11:11 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 10:11:11 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] NFS problem
In-Reply-To: <3DE23684.7020907@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211251002361.2225-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 25 Nov 2002, Terrel Woolbright wrote:

> Good morning everyone. I need help with a class lab assignment. I am
> supposed to get nfs running on two machines, be able to mount a
> directory on the server...and so on. I have nfs compiled into both
> kernels and it shows up in the /proc/filesystems file. I have
> mounted directories on the server box that show up in the /etc/fstab
> file. When I try to mount a directory from the client side I get
> this error:  mount: 10.0.0.40: failed, reason given by server,
> Permission denied.

I'd be interested to know what it says in /var/log/messages on the 
server. There are a couple things to look at:

* the Linux portmap is typically compiled against libwrap, so you'll 
  need to make sure that /etc/hosts.{allow,deny} allow incoming 
  connections from your client

* sometimes, /var/lib/nfs/*tab will store old/errant information about 
  which machines are mounting what, and new mounts will stall. A 
  reboot can help or, if you're up to it, pop rmtab into a text 
  editor, remove current references to your client system, and retry 
  the mount operation

* double-check that there are no ipchains or iptables rules that would 
  prohibit your client from accessing the server

* check the troubleshooting section of the nfs FAQ:

    http://nfs.sourceforge.net/nfs-howto/troubleshooting.html

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Nov 25 10:08:11 2002

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 10:32:30 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 10:32:30 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Citeseer, DjVu - Finding CS research publications on the net.
Message-ID: <1038214378.28714.42.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

One more for the RTFM department:

If you are a CS student or professional, you need to know about:

 http://citeseer.nj.nec.com/cs

It's the BEST way to find research articles in the Computer Science
field.  I wonder if there are any similar sites, using the same
software, holding collections of articles for other sciences?

I've found that the best document format for reading many of these is
DjVu.  It's the fastest one, and works well with older papers that have
been scanned from paper hardcopy, like the older MIT AI memos.  Many of
the PDF files are hard to read since they've been converted from
postscript, and don't contain very good fonts.

To use DjVu, if you run Debian GNU/Linux, you can use "apt-get" to
install:

djview - utilities for the extraordinary DjVu image format
djvulibre-bin - utilities for the extraordinary DjVu image format
djvulibre-plugin - browser plugin for the extraordinary DjVu image format

?Are there similar packages available for those using other Linux
distributions?

> Out of curiousity, what happens to messages when they test positive for
> spam? It gets sent on to us with **SPAM** in the subject line, correct?

That was my understanding...

> In theory the positive message could also be deleted or placed in a folder
> for review by the sysadmin, but as legitimate email is often tagged
> positive, this could violate the user's privacy. For example, if
> spamassassin tagged a steamy letter from your girlfriend as spam, you
> wouldn't want the admin reading the letter and forwarding it on to you.

Sure, in theory... but the only messages that are getting sent to a
sysadmin for checking are those sent to the *public list*... so in this
case that is not an issue.

It would be one hell of a sysadmin who would go through your mail and
look for spam... lol  :-)

> Another guideline established on site-wide spam filtering is to provide
> users the means to opt out. For example, most users don't receive a lot of
> spam and it would be annoying if one of their friend's emails were
> consistently flagged as spam. Mandatory spam filtering also constitutes a
> kind of censorship in that messages containing certain phrases, or manners
> of expression (ie shouting in all caps), are usually flagged.
> 
> Anyway, I don't get many messages on this account, but generally its
> important to balance spam filtering and protecting user privacy/freedom of
> speech. Observing the "tag and forward" and "opt-out" policies helps to
> achieve this.

Since all it does is add something to the subject line... I wouldn't be
very conerned if I were you.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 11:06:07 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)

Subject: [PLUG] how to e2fsck without keeping /' mounted?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0211241622330.29650-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

On Sun, 2002-11-24 at 16:30, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> Hi folks -
> 
> I'm trying to check my '/' filesystem, and according to e2fsck I should
> unmount my filesystem before checking it. However, when I try to
> unmount the filesystem ("umount /") I get this error:
> 
> "umount: /: device is busy"
> 
> How do I unmount my '/' filesystem so it can be checked without using the
> / filesystem itself?

An ext2 file system does not need to be umounted, IIRC, it will work if
you mount it read only.  It's been a long time since I've needed to
fsck.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 11:11:36 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 11:11:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DE1B151.967B55DD@attbi.com>
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>  <3DE1B151.967B55DD@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038251496.2964.32.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

It is possible that Red Hat has patches in their kernels that are not in
the stock kernels (yet if ever).  I know that, at least for a while,
perhaps that's changed recently, you have to use a Debian kernel-source
packaged kernel if you plan to use Debian's "initrd-tools", since they
create a "cramfs" initrd, and the stock kernel cannot use "cramfs" for
an initrd.

When you install the Debian kernel-source package, it drops a .tar.bz of
the kernel into /usr/src.  That tarball opens up into
"kernel-source-<version>/", rather than into "linux/", so that you can
have the sources to several kernels installed without conflict.

I would assume that Red Hat does the similar.

any privacy concerns.  :-)

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Nov 25 11:30:43 2002

Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?

Message-ID: <1038252643.10366.16.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Sun, 2002-11-24 at 15:55, Jeff wrote:
> I need to rename several files, by replacing spaces with underscores. 
> Can someone point me in the right direction for a script that can do this?
> 
> Jeff
> 

/usr/bin/rename is in newer versions of util-linux, if it exists you can
simply run:
$ rename " " _ *\ *

to replace the spaces with underscores in all of the filenames that
contain spaces.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 11:43:52 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 11:43:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] how to e2fsck without keeping /' mounted?
In-Reply-To: <1038252280.26512.16.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0211241622330.29650-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
	 <8270.66.93.41.98.1038244889.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
	 <1038250143.26509.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>  <3DE271C9.1000809@sun.com>
	 <1038252280.26512.16.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1038253432.11837.8.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 11:24, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 10:54, Richard Langis wrote:
> > What about dropping down to single-user mode, mounting / read-only and 
> > running fsck?
> > 
> > No loss of uptime that way.  ;)
> 
> I tried that just yesterday and couldn't remount / ro.  I didn't feel
> like dicking with it at the time (this is my play box, not the server)
> so I just touched the file and rebooted.  :-)

You must shut down all services that have files open for writing. 
Generally, this means going to runlevel 1, with "telinit 1".  DON'T DO
THIS ON A REMOTE MACHINE!

On "drizzle.pdxlinux.org", runlevel 2 is the lowest remote level I have
configured.  There are no services running aside from the devfsd and
sshd at runlevel 2.  I can "telinit 2" from here, to shut down
everything, then "telinit 4" to bring it back up again, with no reboot. 
I have done this several times now, after system upgrades, to ensure
that the newly upgraded libraries are in use by all daemons.

Drizzle will never need a fsck, since it uses Reiserfs.

From rob at euglug.net  Mon Nov 25 11:47:08 2002
From: rob at euglug.net (Rob Hudson)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 11:47:08 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <3DE27C55.6030103@pacifier.com>; from sandbox@pacifier.com on Mon, Nov 25, 2002 at 11:39:01AM -0800
References: <20021124235522.GA13873@feather.net> <3DE27C55.6030103@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org>

There's an old perl script by Larry Wall that I dropped in my bin directory.
It allows you to use regexes to rename files.  To replace spaces with
underscores, you would write this:

  # rename 's/ /_/g' fileglob*.txt

Attached is the perl script.
-------------- next part --------------
#!/usr/bin/perl

#Usage: ren perlexpr [files]

($op = shift) or die "Usage: ren perlexpr [filenames]\n";

if (!@ARGV) {
  @ARGV = <STDIN>;
  chop(@ARGV);
}

for (@ARGV) {
  $was = $_;
  eval $op;
  die $@ if $@;
  unless ($was eq $_) {
    rename($was,$_) or die "Unable to rename $was: $!\n";
  }
}

=head1 NAME

B<ren> - use a perl expression to rename multiple files

=head1 SYNOPSIS

B<ren> perl_expression [files]

=head1 DESCRIPTION

B<Ren> uses a perl expression to rename multiple files.  For more information about
perl expressions, consult the perl man pages, F<Learning Perl> by Randal
Schwartz, F<Programming Perl> by Larry Wall, or your local friendly
Perl programmer.

For example, to rename all files foo.* to bar.*, use

  ren 's/foo/bar/;' foo.*


=head1 AUTHORS

Randal Schwartz, Larry Wall

=head1 DATE

October 11, 1996

=cut

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 11:56:11 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 11:56:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org>
References: <20021124235522.GA13873@feather.net>
	 <3DE27C55.6030103@pacifier.com>  <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org>
Message-ID: <1038254171.11834.13.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 11:47, Rob Hudson wrote:
> There's an old perl script by Larry Wall that I dropped in my bin directory.
> It allows you to use regexes to rename files.  To replace spaces with
> underscores, you would write this:
> 
>   # rename 's/ /_/g' fileglob*.txt
> 
> Attached is the perl script.

The problem is that when the shell globs, it won't get the file names
with spaces in them -- they'll be split on IFS, which contains a space!

You have to walk the directory with Perl, or use an explicit list of
file names, either with spaces "\" escaped, or inside a perl script.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon Nov 25 12:13:15 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 12:13:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
References: <20021124235522.GA13873@feather.net> <3DE27C55.6030103@pacifier.com> <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org> <mailman.1038254236.27184.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86smxp76hw.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Karl" == Karl M Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org> writes:

Karl> The problem is that when the shell globs, it won't get the file names
Karl> with spaces in them -- they'll be split on IFS, which contains a space!

Not true!

    mkdir /tmp/XX
    cd /tmp/XX
    touch "a b.txt" "a c.txt" "a d.txt" "b a.txt" "b b.txt" random.txt
    ls -l
    perl -e 'print "<<$_>>\n" for @ARGV' *.txt

==>

    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 a b.txt
    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 a c.txt
    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 a d.txt
    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 b a.txt
    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 b b.txt
    -rw-r--r--  1 merlyn  wheel  0 Nov 25 12:12 random.txt
    <<a b.txt>>
    <<a c.txt>>
    <<a d.txt>>
    <<b a.txt>>
    <<b b.txt>>
    <<random.txt>>

See?  /bin/sh isn't that dumb. :)

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Mon Nov 25 12:29:19 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 12:29:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <1038252643.10366.16.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

You may need to run the rename thing a few times... I've found that it
only replaces the first instance of a space in a filename, so it the
filename has four spaces you must run it four times to get them all
changed.

-Scott

>>>>> "Derek" == Derek Loree <derek at infotects.com> writes:

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Nov 25 13:48:45 2002

As I mentioned in another thread, I was doing some office archeology
recently.  In addition to other things, I came across one of my
notebooks for 1992-1993.  In it, as part of an entry on November 17th,
1992, I found the following:

 Marcus came by a little later and we installed an operating system
 called Linux on a partition on Sharon's machine.  Was at the office
 until 6 a.m.!  Ouch.

We were installing a thing called SLS, for "SoftLanding System", I
think.  Basically, a bunch of floppy images that we sucked down on a
14.4k modem.

So, just a week late, here is to 10 years of liberation and freedom
with GNU/Linux!

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon Nov 25 14:51:57 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 14:51:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org> on Mon, 25 Nov 2002 11:47:08 PST.
Message-ID: <200211252251.gAPMpwG17858@opal-tiger-saga.tigerfood.org>

Rob Hudson <rob at euglug.net>:
> There's an old perl script by Larry Wall that I dropped in my bin directory.
> It allows you to use regexes to rename files.

ren will clobber files if you're not careful, and I kept
running into situations that it won't handle right, like
    ren 's/\d+/$& + 1/e' 1 2 3 4
will end up moving 1 to 4.  so I wrote my own a while ago,
and it's become almost generally usable now.
    http://tigerfood.org/felix/cmv
--

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon Nov 25 15:46:56 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)

Colin Kuskie <ckuskie at dalsemi.com>:
> ren will let you clobber files, just like rm -f will.

well, yes, but the variant I wrote comes much closer to "do
what I want" all the time, which makes it more useful than
ren.  like, it also does things like
    cmv 'tr/1234/2341/' 1 2 3 4
the way I want it to.

kernel-du-jour happens to be."
------------

I found kernel-2.4.18-14.src.rpm at the ftp.redhat site. What I don't
know is if that is the full source, or if, when installed, that will
simply replace the stuff in /usr/src that I already have.

From don at truedisk.com  Mon Nov 25 17:52:50 2002
From: don at truedisk.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 17:52:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ISO & CDR checksums
References: <20021122183735.8127F2FEB3@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <3DE2D3F2.8010206@truedisk.com>


Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> I'm having an odd trouble with ISO checksums.  I created my own ISO 
> of some Mandrake 9.0 contrib rpms.  Then I run the md5sum on that ISO.
> I also burn the ISO to CDR and subsequently compute the md5sum of the 
> CDR like so 'dd if=/dev/scd1 | md5sum'.  This has always worked, 
> except for when the CD drive mounts or unmounts during the dd.  I 
> think I've prevented the (un)mounting problem, and yet I can't get 
> the md5sum of one burned ISO to be identical on the burned CDR and 
> the ISO spinning on the harddrive.  Doing just the same thing with 
> other ISOs is working with the same equipment and method.  Oddly 
> enough, I can read the burned suspect CDR just fine when I mount it 
> *AND* the md5/gpg signatures on all the RPMs on the CDR are just fine.
> 
> Do you think it's safe to consider the burned ISO good?
> 
> Does anyone have a better technique for computing the md5sum of the 
> CDR?
> 

Weird.  My usual burn/check routine looks like this:

    # cdrecord -v  my_image.iso
       ... lots of messages ...

    # md5sum my_image.iso /dev/cdrom
    58caad7d93b06c1c0e2af1ce2111a4ae  my_image.iso
    58caad7d93b06c1c0e2af1ce2111a4ae  /dev/cdrom

The main difference here is that I don't use dd(1).

We had some weirdness with some early RH 6.2 kernels and ASUS
motherboards which excercised a Via chipset bug, and could get
different answers depending on which programs accessed the IDE
devices.  Not a common problem, but not unheard of, either.

- Don
