From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 18:19:03 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 18:19:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] personal GNU/Linux anniversary
In-Reply-To: <86wun18gn6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86wun18gn6.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1038277143.11834.25.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

My first experience with Linux was during the Winter of 1995 (probably
Jan. or Feb), with "Yggdrasil Fall '94 Plug-n-Play Linux".  I was living
in a ski village in Idaho.  I'd UPS'd my brand new 486DX-33 8Mb RAM to
myself.  It was running Dos 6.0 and Windows 3.1.  My girlfriend had a
discount software mail order catalog, and in there was a $9.99 CD with a
"Unix Clone, all source code included".  It sounded fun, and was cheap,
so I ordered it.

They had a graphical installer based on Tcl/Tk on the X Window System. 
It ran Linux 1.0, IIRC.  Within a month, I had blown away the DOS
partition and given the entire machine over to Linux.  I have not used
anything but Linux since that day.

From flee at aracnet.com  Mon Nov 25 18:36:57 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 18:36:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <1038276359.11837.19.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> on 25 Nov 2002 18:05:59 PST.
Message-ID: <200211260236.gAQ2avw18482@opal-tiger-saga.tigerfood.org>

"Karl M. Hegbloom" <karlheg at pdxlinux.org>:
> On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 12:13, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> > See?  /bin/sh isn't that dumb. :)
> Hmmm.  What shell is that?  Does POSIX mandate that behavior? 

yes, I think you misunderstand shell parsing.  this is
described in detail in the "EXPANSION" section of the bash
man page.  globbing happens after a command is split into
words, the globbing generates a list of words, it doesn't
get concatenated together and re-split.  all unix shells I
can think of are like that.
--



From heinlein at attbi.com  Mon Nov 25 18:39:15 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 18:39:15 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DE2B859.B22BBEF7@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211251827440.4469-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Mon, 25 Nov 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> I found kernel-2.4.18-14.src.rpm at the ftp.redhat site. What I
> don't know is if that is the full source, or if, when installed,
> that will simply replace the stuff in /usr/src that I already have.

Dick,

If I were you, I'd shy away from building kernels using Red Hat's 
source package. It's not that it's bad; it's just that it's unwieldy, 
with lots of patches, backports, etc. Plus, if you do things Red Hat's 
way, you won't end up with a kernel that's much smaller or more 
optimized than Red Hat's.

I'd grab the 2.4.19 tarball from kernel.org and any of the gazillions
of patches floating around the Net you think will help your particular
machine(s). You can use Red Hat's /boot/config-$(uname -r) file, which
should already be installed, as a guide to your configuration.

The only exception to the "grab the kernel.org tarball" would be the 
case where you rely on a patch set that Red Hat has made to work: 
user-mode Linux, LVM, crypto API, blue tooth, gigabit-over-copper 
ethernet, or what-have-you. In that case, I'd recommend just using Red 
Hat's build rather than struggling long and hard for the pretty 
dubious return of duplicating Red Hat's stock kernel.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 18:46:12 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 18:46:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DE2B859.B22BBEF7@attbi.com>
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>  <3DE1B151.967B55DD@attbi.com>
	 <1038251496.2964.32.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <3DE2B859.B22BBEF7@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038278771.11834.55.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 15:55, Richard Steffens wrote:
> "Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:
> 
> > When you install the Debian kernel-source package, it drops a .tar.bz of
> > the kernel into /usr/src.  That tarball opens up into
> > "kernel-source-<version>/", rather than into "linux/", so that you can
> > have the sources to several kernels installed without conflict.
> > 
> > I would assume that Red Hat does the similar.
> 
> Thanks, Karl. I was hoping to find that to be the case, too. However, in
> /usr/src/linux-2.4.18-14/README, under the section "INSTALLING the
> kernel:" it says:
> 
> ------------
> "If you install the full sources, put the kernel tarball in a directory
> where you have permissions (eg. your home directory) and unpack it..." 
> 
> "Do NOT use the /usr/src/linux area! This area has a usually incomplete)
> set of kernel headers that are used by the library header files. They
> should match the library, and not get messed up by whatever the
> kernel-du-jour happens to be."
> ------------

Oh, wow.  That's really way bogus.  The libc6-dev package ought to ship
the <linux/*> and <asm/*> headers and install them under /usr/include,
rather than symlinking to ones in /usr/src/linux.  (One more reason why
serious developers should not work fromn a Red Hat box. <grin/>)  There
might be some things to read regarding this issue in the debian-devel
mailing list archives, and perhaps also in the /doc/libc6-dev/ readme's
on www.pdxlinux.org.

It's also bogus that Linus ships the kernel sources tarred up so they
open to "linux/" like that.  I wonder how many times people have opened
up a new kernel tarball right over the top of the old, realizing too
late that they forgot to move the old one aside for safe keeping?  That
is why the Debian kernel-source tarballs are repacked so they open into
"kernel-source-<version>/" instead.

That also is somewhat bogus, in light of the potential to install
kernel's other than Linux!  It ought to be "linux-source-<version>", and
perhaps the "<version>" ought to include not only the upstream kernel
version, but also the "-N" Debian package "build" version number as
well.  This way, you could have "hurd-source-<version>" or
"freebsd-source-<version>", for example.

I build kernel's in "/usr/src", which is group owned and writeable by a
group called "ksrc", on my machine.  Actually, by default, on a freshly
installed Debian machine, "/usr/src" is group owned by "src".  Users in
that group have writes there.

I always use the "kernel-package" package's `make-kpkg' utility to build
my kernel and modules as a .deb, since the postinst script in the
resulting "kernel-image-...deb" takes care of ensuring that my initrd is
rebuilt, and that the boot loader is configured for the new kernel.

The "initrd-tools" setup on Debian is pretty good.  It lets you
customize what will end up in the initrd image.  The image is not
generated until after you install the kernel-image.  It's not shipped
inside the kernel-image, since that would eliminate the possiblity to
place custom software inside of it, and would make it need to be a lot
smarter about knowing what device is your "/", etc.  If you want to know
more, I suggest just grabbing the source to it.  (ask for an account on
drizzle.pdxlinux.org if you want access to a Debian box where you can
easily "apt-get source" to have a look.)

> I found kernel-2.4.18-14.src.rpm at the ftp.redhat site. What I don't
> know is if that is the full source, or if, when installed, that will
> simply replace the stuff in /usr/src that I already have.

You should be able to use "mc" (midnight commander) to look inside of
the .rpm package, to see what it will install and where.





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 19:04:04 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 19:04:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211251827440.4469-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211251827440.4469-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <1038279844.11842.70.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 18:39, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> The only exception to the "grab the kernel.org tarball" would be the 
> case where you rely on a patch set that Red Hat has made to work: 
> user-mode Linux, LVM, crypto API, blue tooth, gigabit-over-copper 
> ethernet, or what-have-you. In that case, I'd recommend just using Red 
> Hat's build rather than struggling long and hard for the pretty 
> dubious return of duplicating Red Hat's stock kernel.

This is another part of the kernel building process in which Debian's
system really shines.  Not only are there "kernel-source-<version>"
packages (which only install a Linux source .tar.bz2, not the Debian
kernel building setup, which is installed by the "kernel-package"
package), there are many "kernel-patch-*" packages.

Kernel patch packages are generated by a special script, found in
"dh-kpatches".  They install the patch itself, as a "diff -u", in
"/usr/src/kernel-patches/{all,i386,sparc,ppc,...}/<patchname>/".  Also,
in "/usr/src/kernel-patches/{all,i386,...}/{apply,unpatch}/<patchname>",
are shell scripts that apply the named patch or unpatch the kernel in
your PWD.  Those scripts can be run automaticly by "make-kpkg", if you
like.

This is a really nice setup.  It makes it very easy to install a
customized kernel on several machines, or to get one running with well
tested and reasonably stable patches for XFS, FreeSwan IPSEC, or EVMS.

Debian really is very well set up for the non-casual Linux user, server
admin, and developer.





From satimis at writeme.com  Mon Nov 25 19:23:14 2002
From: satimis at writeme.com (Stephen Liu)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 11:23:14 +0800
Subject: [PLUG] Problem - Installating RH7.3 on a RAID-0 box co-exiting with
 Windows
Message-ID: <5.1.1.6.0.20021126112257.02e32ab0@pop.net-yan.com>

Hi all folks,

I installed RH7.3 on a RAID-0 box which has following setup

(2 HDDs, each 40G)
Drive/partition
C   FAT16 200MB as boot section
D   FAT32 22G Win98/Win2000 dual boot machine
E   FAT32 48G For installation of RH7.3
F   FAT32 remainder For Win98/Win2000 data storage

At time of installation I selected automatic.  After installation I could 
not start the PC.  The screen hanged on ;
....
.......
GRUB

I booted up the PC with the rescue floppy and RH7.3 started.

on KDE console window
# fdisk -l

Disk /dev/hdc: 16 heads, 63 sectors, 77557 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 1008 * 512 bytes

Disk /dev/hdc doesn't contain a valid partition table

Disk /dev/hda: 16 heads, 63 sectors, 77557 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 1008 * 512 bytes

    Device Boot    Start       End    Blocks   Id  System
/dev/hda1   *         1       102     51376+  83  Linux
/dev/hda2           103     75997  38251080   83  Linux
/dev/hda3         75998     77557    786240   82  Linux swap

During "shutdown" The screen hanged at

Halting system
md: stopping all md devices
flushing ide devies : hda hdc hdg hdh
System halted

I suppose

hda = drive-C
hac = drive-D
hdg = drive-E (not CD-Writer)
hdh = drive-F (not CD-Rom)

Kindly advice how to rectify this mistake moving RH7.3 to hdg(drive-D) and 
create GRUB on hda(drive-C)

If impossible kindly advise how to uninstall RH7.3

Thanks in advance.

Stephen Liu





From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon Nov 25 19:34:22 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 19:34:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>  <3DE1B151.967B55DD@attbi.com>	 <1038251496.2964.32.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>	 <3DE2B859.B22BBEF7@attbi.com> <1038278771.11834.55.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3DE2EBBE.8010901@pacifier.com>

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 15:55, Richard Steffens wrote:
> 
>>"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:
>>
>>
>>>When you install the Debian kernel-source package, it drops a .tar.bz of
>>>the kernel into /usr/src.  That tarball opens up into
>>>"kernel-source-<version>/", rather than into "linux/", so that you can
>>>have the sources to several kernels installed without conflict.
>>>
>>>I would assume that Red Hat does the similar.
>>
>>Thanks, Karl. I was hoping to find that to be the case, too. However, in
>>/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-14/README, under the section "INSTALLING the
>>kernel:" it says:
>>
>>------------
>>"If you install the full sources, put the kernel tarball in a directory
>>where you have permissions (eg. your home directory) and unpack it..." 
>>
>>"Do NOT use the /usr/src/linux area! This area has a usually incomplete)
>>set of kernel headers that are used by the library header files. They
>>should match the library, and not get messed up by whatever the
>>kernel-du-jour happens to be."

> 
> Oh, wow.  That's really way bogus.  The libc6-dev package ought to ship
> the <linux/*> and <asm/*> headers and install them under /usr/include,
> rather than symlinking to ones in /usr/src/linux.  


I don't think RedHat has put system headers in /usr/src/linux for a while 
now.  (Not sure if 6.2 did or not.)  They are in the proper place now, that 
being /usr/include/linux.  Maybe their warning has more to do with some 
stupid apps & libraries that look to /usr/src/linux for headers.


> It's also bogus that Linus ships the kernel sources tarred up so they
> open to "linux/" like that.  I wonder how many times people have opened
> up a new kernel tarball right over the top of the old, realizing too
> late that they forgot to move the old one aside for safe keeping?  

Agreed.  In RedHat 7.3 (and this started a little earlier) RedHat doesn't 
use /usr/src/linux for anything.  Instead you'll see 
/usr/src/linux-2.4.18-17.7.x, so you would be safe to untar an official 
kernel tarball there.


On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 18:39, Paul Heinlein wrote:

 > The only exception to the "grab the kernel.org tarball" would be the
 > case where you rely on a patch set that Red Hat has made to work:
 > user-mode Linux, LVM, crypto API, blue tooth, gigabit-over-copper
 > ethernet, or what-have-you. In that case, I'd recommend just using Red
 > Hat's build rather than struggling long and hard for the pretty
 > dubious return of duplicating Red Hat's stock kernel.

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

 > This is another part of the kernel building process in which Debian's
 > system really shines.  Not only are there "kernel-source-<version>"
 > packages (which only install a Linux source .tar.bz2, not the Debian
 > kernel building setup, which is installed by the "kernel-package"
 > package), there are many "kernel-patch-*" packages.


It would be nice if RedHat released their kernel patches as a seperate 
rpm/s.  Maybe that's their "value add" and they expect you to just diff the 
source if you really want to know.

--
Kyle Accardi

>>>>> "Karl" == Karl M Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org> writes:

Karl> On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 12:13, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
>> See?  /bin/sh isn't that dumb. :)

Karl> Hmmm.  What shell is that?  Does POSIX mandate that behavior? 

It worked that way in the V7 One True Shell.  Every Bourne-like shell
after that has always said "IFS happens before globbing".  Even
csh-like shells work that way.  I don't know what shell you're using
that doesn't work that way... maybe you're thinking of COMMAND.COM
or something.

Out of respect for the work that Linus has created, I ask
that we not cow-tow to RMS.

It's fine to say GCC and GNU Emacs.  But Linux is Linux.  The GNU
project had nothing to do with it, any more than Portland General had
to do with this message just because my computer is plugged in to the
wall, or Apple because I'm typing on a powerbook.

I met Linus recently.  He actually said the words "Randal, I will
have to kill you now" when I was joking around and said "GNU/Linux".
Given the amount of restraint he showed the rest of the week,
that statement was damning.

Please, out of respect for Linus, it's just "Linux".  Thank you.

>>>>> "Galen" == Galen Seitz <galens at seitzassoc.com> writes:

They are a little squirrelly with their product numbering.  For
example, they call their external version a 224000N also, even though
Seagate calls their external version a 624000N.  

Another thing, the unit I got was an "internal" with a 5.25-inch
bezel.  Even though Seagate sells different bezels and their own
literature tells you how to dismantle various things, the unit I got
came with warranty "dots" ("warranty void if broken") that connected
the mechanism body with the steel mounting rails it came with in such
a way as to preclude changing the bezel.  Since they were patently
absurd, I didn't hesitate to break them anyway to remove the mounting
rails.

Another curiosity is that the refurb is selling for the same prices as
new, which casts a little doubt on the newness.  I must say though,
our unit gave every appearance of mint condition.

When I bought our first 12/24gig DDS3 five years ago or so, it was
nearly $1k, so $229 seemed worth the risk.

And sorry, I don't have any information autoloaders.

>> It's also bogus that Linus ships the kernel sources tarred up so they
>> open to "linux/" like that.  I wonder how many times people have opened
>> up a new kernel tarball right over the top of the old, realizing too
>> late that they forgot to move the old one aside for safe keeping?  

No guarantees, but I think Linus started using more descriptive names
for the root of the tarball a while back.  That could just be wishful
thinking on my part, however.  Also, it might only be a 2.5.x thing.


> It would be nice if RedHat released their kernel patches as a seperate
>  rpm/s.  Maybe that's their "value add" and they expect you to just
> diff the  source if you really want to know. 

While it's true that all the patches are in a single src rpm, each patch is
in a separate file.  The patch filenames give a pretty good indication of
what is in each patch.  Diffing against a standard kernel shouldn't be
necessary.

galen

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Mon Nov 25 22:27:35 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 2002 22:27:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 25 Nov 2002 21:48:07 PST."
             <3DE30B17.9000709@pacifier.com> 
Message-ID: <200211260627.gAQ6RZ203133@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> > While it's true that all the patches are in a single src rpm, each patch is
> > in a separate file.  The patch filenames give a pretty good indication of
> > what is in each patch.  Diffing against a standard kernel shouldn't be
> > necessary.
> 
> 
> Cool, where are they in the tree?
> 

If you install the src rpm, you should find the pristine tarball along 
with the patches in the redhat/SOURCES directory.  When you build, the
tarball gets untarred in the redhat/BUILD directory, then the patches
are applied to that tree.

galen

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 22:55:05 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 22:55:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Please, it's not GNU/Linux
In-Reply-To: <86el993s2a.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
References: <86el993s2a.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <1038293704.11840.97.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 19:53, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> It's fine to say GCC and GNU Emacs.  But Linux is Linux.  The GNU
> project had nothing to do with it, ...

Bullshit.  If not for GNU Compiler Collection, GNU Emacs, and all of the
GNU tools, there could be no Linux kernel.  Even if there was a Linux
kernel, what would you run with it if not for GNU?

So, when referring to the kernel, it's "Linux".  But when referring to
the entire system of kernel + userland software, it's "GNU/Linux",
pronounced "GNU over Linux".

> are applied to that tree.


Hmm,

$ rpm -q kernel-source
kernel-source-2.4.18-3
kernel-source-2.4.18-17.7.x

$ ls -l /usr/src/redhat/SOURCES/
total 0

browsing kernel-source-2.4.18-18.7.x.i386.rpm
looks like everything gets dumped into /usr/src/linux-2.4.18-18.7.x

Confused,
Kyle Accardi

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Nov 25 23:14:19 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 25 Nov 2002 23:14:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
In-Reply-To: <3DE2EBBE.8010901@pacifier.com>
References: <3DDDA6FB.B346529B@attbi.com>  <3DE1B151.967B55DD@attbi.com>
	 <1038251496.2964.32.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <3DE2B859.B22BBEF7@attbi.com>
	 <1038278771.11834.55.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <3DE2EBBE.8010901@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1038294859.7309.8.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-11-25 at 19:34, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> 
>  > This is another part of the kernel building process in which Debian's
>  > system really shines.  Not only are there "kernel-source-<version>"
>  > packages (which only install a Linux source .tar.bz2, not the Debian
>  > kernel building setup, which is installed by the "kernel-package"
>  > package), there are many "kernel-patch-*" packages.

Thought about that some after I wrote it... the word I should have
chosen, rather than "shines" is "Coruscates".  Debian is truely a
treasure trove!

> It would be nice if RedHat released their kernel patches as a seperate 
> rpm/s.  Maybe that's their "value add" and they expect you to just diff the 
> source if you really want to know.

Well, Debian's kernel-source package's kernel has a few patches applied
to it wrt Linus's upstream kernel.  Or, at least it did last time I
checked.  They are SUPPOSED to submit the patches back upstream when
that is appropriate.  The main one is the one that lets a "cramfs" image
serve as an initrd image.  Debian's "initrd-tools" rely on that feature!

The stock kernel-source package will generate a stock kernel-image.  If
you want EVMS, XFS, to build a special user mode linux, or to add IPSEC,
you must install a kernel-patch for it, run the patch, then rebuild your
kernel.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Mon Nov 25 23:23:48 2002

I purchased the book "GNU C++ for Linux," which
contains the code for the programs on a CD. It is to
be installed in a user account under "src" with a
subdirectory for each chapter.

I think I must have installed it as root. When I issue
a command such as the following

$g++ program.cpp -o program

I receive the message "permission denied," although it
will compile as root user. Can I change the
permissions on this directory so that the ordinary
user can compile programs? How would I do it?

From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Nov 26 00:11:49 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 00:11:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File permissions
In-Reply-To: <20021126072348.13808.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <ZY64RM1USO84CB2VHCWTVSWQD9950B7.3de32cc5@mike>

chown is the golden command.

# chown mike.user /this

Would, if I get it right, make the folder owned by "mike" of 
the group "user".

I'm not at a terminal now, but I'm sure you could type "man 
chown" and get the manull for the command.

Mike

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Nov 26 00:21:06 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 00:21:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File permissions
In-Reply-To: <ZY64RM1USO84CB2VHCWTVSWQD9950B7.3de32cc5@mike>
References: <ZY64RM1USO84CB2VHCWTVSWQD9950B7.3de32cc5@mike>
Message-ID: <86of8cwxl9.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Mike" == Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> writes:

Mike> chown is the golden command.  # chown mike.user /this

Mike> Would, if I get it right, make the folder owned by "mike" of the
Mike> group "user".

Use the -R to recursively descend the tree, as in:

  chown -R mike.user /this

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Nov 26 01:35:29 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 01:35:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Please, it's not GNU/Linux
In-Reply-To: <86el993s2a.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211260120360.8004-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 25 Nov 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> Out of respect for the work that Linus has created, I ask that we not
> cow-tow to RMS.

Out of respect for the principles of the Free Software Foundation and the
GNU project, I ask that we not ignore their contribution.

> It's fine to say GCC and GNU Emacs.  But Linux is Linux.

Linux is a kernel.  I'm perfectly happy calling Linux "Linux".

But the operating system I run is GNU on top of a Linux kernel.

> The GNU project had nothing to do with it, any more than Portland
> General had to do with this message just because my computer is
> plugged in to the wall, or Apple because I'm typing on a powerbook.

The kernel, maybe... but the operating system most of us run is more GNU
than Linux.

And isn't true that Linus intentionally modified the source of Linux to
run GNU software as written, without porting, because it was easier than
porting each piece of GNU software to Linux?

> I met Linus recently.  He actually said the words "Randal, I will have
> to kill you now" when I was joking around and said "GNU/Linux". Given
> the amount of restraint he showed the rest of the week, that statement
> was damning.

So Linus' opinion differs from mine and just about everyone else that
cares about the future of freedom and culture.  That's nothing new.

> Please, out of respect for Linus, it's just "Linux".  Thank you.

As a programmer, sure, props to the man who put in the effort and
(somewhat) manages the project.  As a human being, sure, I will defend his
rights as staunchly as any other person.

But I have absolutely no respect for Linus' lack of vision and social
consciousness.  I think that he is essentially short-sighted and selfish.  
I feel he turned his back on an opportunity to serve mankind by taking a
place as champion of Freedom.  Instead, he giggles and titles his book
"Just For Fun".  The man squandered perhaps a once-in-a-generation chance
at revolution.

Personally, I think there's still time and opportunity for him to redeem
himself, but he shows no sign of taking it... not from where I sit.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From nknight at pocketinet.com  Tue Nov 26 04:34:54 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 04:34:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Please, it's not GNU/Linux

On Monday 25 November 2002 07:53 pm, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> Out of respect for the work that Linus has created, I ask
> that we not cow-tow to RMS.

Out of respect to every reasonable person on this over-politicized rock, I ask 
that you stop going around in circles about it. We don't care. Really. The 
debate is about as meaningful as my decision to wake up 5 seconds later today 
was. Call it whatever you want. We're tired of the debate, it doesn't 
accomplish anything. Stow your egos and get on with life. We'd rather you go 
back to vi vs emacs, at least there's a tangible distinction.  The sky isn't 
going to fall because four arbitrary characters were added or subtracted from 
the also-arbitrary name of an operating system.

For all the "advancement" of human civilization, we still fight over what to 
call something that humans could survive just fine without. I feel like I'm 
back in kindergarten.



From brucek at kingkon.com  Tue Nov 26 04:57:07 2002
From: brucek at kingkon.com (Bruce Kingsland)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 04:57:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] setuid best practice?
Message-ID: <20021126045707.Q32455@defiant.ncplus.net>

Howdy,

I need to run an equivalent of the following script as a non-root
user:
_________________________________________
#! /bin/bash

# pppDial written recently by Bruce Kingsland, with help from the list.

# This dials the fone using pppd with certain variables. The variables are
# set in the following while case, and can be in any order. The command is at
# the end, and the usage is shown here.

until [ $# -eq 0 ] ; do
  case $1
    in
      dial)
        pppd /dev/ttyS1 115200 :1.2.3.4 remotename ISP user USER connect \
	"/usr/sbin/chat -v '' AT OK ATM1 OK ATDT1234567890 CONNECT '\d\c'"
	shift
        ;;
      stop)
	killall pppd
	exit
        ;;
      *)
        echo Broken Code
	exit 77
        ;;
  esac
done
_________________________________________

The pppd part needs to be run as root. I need for a couple users to
be able to stop the pppd so that they can use the landline, and then
for them to be able to restart the pppd when they need back online.
But I don't need for them to know how to become root.

My think is that I "setuid pppDial", and then local users can run the
tool. Actually, remote users could run the stop version, but then
they'd be disconnected. By local users, I mean folks on other clients
on the inside network.

I'm aware of the security hole concerns of using setuid, which is the
primary reason for this posting; how do I do this properly? Are there
any gotcha's that I'm not aware of here? Any other things of valueable
interest?

TIA
-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730

D/2B8DA3D7 g/2884A18E  49C3 BBDE 6BC5 3F39 0C03  3BE4 FBC5 2C8D 2B8D A3D7

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 26 06:53:53 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 06:53:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] xpdv vs. acroread
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211260650290.4688-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I have a bunch of pdf files created a few years ago from WordPerfect docs
-> postscript -> ps2pdf. I can view them with acroread (but the typeface
does not display well) but now with xpdf. They load in xpdf, but each page
is blank.

  Might there be a generic reason why a pdf file can be seen in one view but
not the other? Is this a function of the application's recognition of the
typeface used?

  Guess I need to take them apart and reassemble them.

TIA,

Rich




From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Nov 26 07:36:13 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 07:36:13 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] xpdv vs. acroread
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211260650290.4688-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211260731480.3879-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> I have a bunch of pdf files created a few years ago from WordPerfect
> docs -> postscript -> ps2pdf. I can view them with acroread (but the
> typeface does not display well) but now with xpdf. They load in
> xpdf, but each page is blank.
> 
> Might there be a generic reason why a pdf file can be seen in one
> view but not the other? Is this a function of the application's
> recognition of the typeface used?

Just shooting from the hip: I know that acroread ships with its own
resource fonts and type-rendering libraries. Perhaps that's the
difference.

You could always try running xpdf under strace to see if it's failing 
to find the fonts that it needs.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Tue Nov 26 08:06:34 2002
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)

In-Reply-To: Your message of "Mon, 25 Nov 2002 23:05:03 PST."
             <3DE31D1F.5000806@pacifier.com> 
Message-ID: <200211261606.gAQG6Y207049@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > 
> > If you install the src rpm, you should find the pristine tarball along 
> > with the patches in the redhat/SOURCES directory.  When you build, the
> > tarball gets untarred in the redhat/BUILD directory, then the patches
> > are applied to that tree.
> 
> 
> Hmm,
> 
> $ rpm -q kernel-source
> kernel-source-2.4.18-3
> kernel-source-2.4.18-17.7.x
> 
> $ ls -l /usr/src/redhat/SOURCES/
> total 0
> 
> browsing kernel-source-2.4.18-18.7.x.i386.rpm
> looks like everything gets dumped into /usr/src/linux-2.4.18-18.7.x
> 

Okay, I see why you are confused.  I should have been more explicit
when I said src rpm.  You need the src.rpm package, not the
kernel-source package.

kernel-2.4.18-18.7.x.src.rpm

BTW, in case you didn't know it, midnight commander (the mc command) 
understands rpm files.  You can use mc to explore an rpm without
having to install it.  

galen





From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Tue Nov 26 08:26:48 2002
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 08:26:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
Message-ID: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D894@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

A program that simply launches 10 threads that just malloc, wait 100
milliseconds, and free the data and then loop.  

This simple program segmentation faults. I'm using glibc version 2.2.2. I
was wondering if malloc has reentrancy problems or not ? 

Thoughts?

thanks
_tisson



From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Tue Nov 26 08:39:28 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 08:39:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D894@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
References: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D894@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <200211260839.28300.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Tuesday 26 November 2002 08:26, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:
> A program that simply launches 10 threads that just malloc, wait 100
> milliseconds, and free the data and then loop.
>
> This simple program segmentation faults. I'm using glibc version 2.2.2.
> I was wondering if malloc has reentrancy problems or not ?
>
> Thoughts?

Probably.  You might need to set some define to make it threadsafe.  
Check... well, no, the malloc man page is from 1993.  That's not going to 
help.

Put mutexes around your calls to malloc.  See if that helps.  If not, maybe 
you're doing something you shouldn't in your threads?  Sharing a global 
variable by accident perhaps?

Best,
Kyle

From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Tue Nov 26 08:50:54 2002
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 08:50:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
Message-ID: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D895@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

Thanks Kyle,

Yes. It works perfectly fine with mutexes but I'm not sharing anything other
than the memory allocated by malloc. I wanted to avoid mutex locking for
performance reasons. If malloc is already reentrant/thread safe, why should
I be doing extra locking?

From m at netpro.to  Tue Nov 26 09:35:59 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 09:35:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Plugger and spaces (%20) in URL attached documents
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211260928500.17330-100000@lukem.com>

I'm using Mozilla 1.1, Plugger, and the Outlook Web Access for my Linux
users to connect to an Exchange server.  I've modified /etc/pluggerrc to
use OpenOffice for opening MS Excel documents.  File attachments show up
as links.  If the attachment has spaces in the name, then I get errors
when clicking the link.

The OpenOffice splash screen pops up and then a dialog box says:

Error loading document file:///tmp/plugtmp/PHONE%20DIRECTORY-%20March.xls:
/tmp/plugtmp/PHONE DIRECTORY- March.xls does not exist.

/tmp/plugtmp has this file:

PHONE%20DIRECTORY-%20March.xls

Does anyone have any suggestions on how to handle spaces in URL
attachments with Plugger and/or OpenOffice?
Thanks,
~Matt




From flee at aracnet.com  Tue Nov 26 09:47:32 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 09:47:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D894@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com> on Tue, 26 Nov 2002 08:26:48 PST.
Message-ID: <200211261747.gAQHlWk20279@opal-tiger-saga.tigerfood.org>

"Mathew, Tisson K" <tisson.k.mathew at intel.com>:
> A program that simply launches 10 threads that just malloc, wait 100
> milliseconds, and free the data and then loop.  
> This simple program segmentation faults. I'm using glibc version 2.2.2. I
> was wondering if malloc has reentrancy problems or not ? 

what's your sample program?  it looks like the malloc in
glibc 2.x should already cooperate with pthreads.  (it uses
pthread_atfork to set up the mutexes it needs.)
--

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 26 11:01:37 2002

On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> PHONE%20DIRECTORY-%20March.xls
> 
> Does anyone have any suggestions on how to handle spaces in URL
> attachments with Plugger and/or OpenOffice?

Matt,

  I get those space fillers in file names, URLs and everything else
Microsoft that someone's created with spaces in their names. I've tried to
teach them that not every one in the world runs Microsoft, and not even Mac
users can see the names the way they can. Most don't care.

  So, if you find a working solution (other than world domination by linux),
please let me know, too.

Thanks,

Rich





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Nov 26 11:04:58 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 11:04:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] xpdf and acroread
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211261103190.5292-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  I found the solution: upgrade from xpdf 1.whatever to 2.0. It's terribly
slow but it works. Now I don't have to disassemble it and put it back
together with different typefaces. I always seem to have a piece or two left
over when I do this.

Rich

From richard.langis at sun.com  Tue Nov 26 11:32:53 2002
From: richard.langis at sun.com (Richard Langis)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 11:32:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Plugger and spaces (%20) in URL attached documents
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211260928500.17330-100000@lukem.com> <200211261125.27675.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <3DE3CC65.9080304@sun.com>

Actually...  I've had this problem myself with SO6 under Solaris.  I 
think it is a problem with Mozilla sending out the wrong filename.

Shouldn't /tmp/plugtmp have the file:

PHONE\ DIRECTORY-\ March.xls?  Since the %20's are a (what, URI?) 
web-based 'shortcut', and the filesystem isn't web-based.  ;)

-R

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue Nov 26 11:58:04 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 11:58:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] RIAA provides me with new .signature quote
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211261130080.5248-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211261150470.3879-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Phil Tomson wrote:

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
> "Or perhaps the truth is less interesting than the facts?"
> Amy Weiss (accusing theregister.co.uk of engaging in 'tabloid journalism')
> Senior VP, Communications
> Recording Industry Association of America
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

The thing is, she's got a point -- at least in the abstract. (In the 
particulars, the RIAA can go jump off a bridge, but in the 
abstract...)

Consider the following 'fact':

  "Paul showed up at the movie theater last month in his underwear."

The 'fact' is true (yes, I wear underwear when going to the theater), 
but the rhetorical force of the argument is hardly the truth. Why? 
Because the writer is trying to give the impression that Paul showed 
up at the theater "in nothing but his underwear."

The writer could deny that such was his intent -- but I think it'd
take a fairly naive person to accept his denial at face value.

IOW, it's quite easy to string nothing but true facts together in 
order to tell a lie.

Now, back to your normal off-topic PLUG posts...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Nov 26 12:39:43 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 12:39:43 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Plugger and spaces (%20) in URL attached documents
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211260928500.17330-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211260928500.17330-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <1038343183.7309.42.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 09:35, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I'm using Mozilla 1.1, Plugger, and the Outlook Web Access for my Linux
> users to connect to an Exchange server.  I've modified /etc/pluggerrc to
> use OpenOffice for opening MS Excel documents.  File attachments show up
> as links.  If the attachment has spaces in the name, then I get errors
> when clicking the link.
> 
> The OpenOffice splash screen pops up and then a dialog box says:
> 
> Error loading document file:///tmp/plugtmp/PHONE%20DIRECTORY-%20March.xls:
> /tmp/plugtmp/PHONE DIRECTORY- March.xls does not exist.
> 
> /tmp/plugtmp has this file:
> 
> PHONE%20DIRECTORY-%20March.xls
> 
> Does anyone have any suggestions on how to handle spaces in URL
> attachments with Plugger and/or OpenOffice?

Perhaps you should "apt-get source plugger" and fix it?  I bet it's a
simple fix.

If the file is not found under the first name it tries, the one with the
URL escaping, then run the URL unescape function on it, and try again. 
Any moderately competent C programmer should have no trouble getting it
to work in an hour or so.  Don't forget to submit your patch upstream
accompanied by a "ChangeLog" entry paste-in.  (Don't send a patch to
ChangeLog; send a paste-in for it.)





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Nov 26 12:59:29 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 12:59:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D895@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
References: 
	 <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D895@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <1038344369.7309.61.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

[ Move to plug-devel ? ]

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 08:50, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:
> Yes. It works perfectly fine with mutexes but I'm not sharing anything other
> than the memory allocated by malloc. I wanted to avoid mutex locking for
> performance reasons. If malloc is already reentrant/thread safe, why should
> I be doing extra locking? 

I wonder if -D_REENTRANT does anything for "malloc"?  My
"/usr/include/malloc.h" contains, near the top:

  $Id: malloc.h,v 1.22 2002/03/12 21:58:54 drepper Exp $
  `ptmalloc2', a malloc implementation for multiple threads without
  lock contention, by Wolfram Gloger <wg at malloc.de>.

  VERSION 2.7.0

It is owned by:
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% dpkg --search /usr/include/malloc.h 
libc6-dev: /usr/include/malloc.h
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% dpkg --status libc6-dev | grep '^Version:'
Version: 2.3.1-5

So, the first question is, what version of libc are you working with? 
(and on what distro, just out of curiosity?)

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Kyle Hayes [mailto:kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net] 
> Sent: Tuesday, November 26, 2002 8:39 AM
> To: PLUG
> Subject: Re: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
> 
> On Tuesday 26 November 2002 08:26, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:
> > A program that simply launches 10 threads that just malloc, wait 100
> > milliseconds, and free the data and then loop.
> >
> > This simple program segmentation faults. I'm using glibc version 2.2.2.
> > I was wondering if malloc has reentrancy problems or not ?
> >
> > Thoughts?
> 
> Probably.  You might need to set some define to make it threadsafe.  
> Check... well, no, the malloc man page is from 1993.  That's not going to 
> help.
> 
> Put mutexes around your calls to malloc.  See if that helps.  If not, maybe 
> you're doing something you shouldn't in your threads?  Sharing a global 
> variable by accident perhaps?
> 
> Best,
> Kyle

From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Tue Nov 26 14:43:32 2002
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 14:43:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
Message-ID: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D8A1@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

Here is the code; I'm running glibc 2.2.2 on XScale iq80320. 

-------------------------- 
#define MYSIZE                          (1*1024)
#define SLEEP_TIME                      (100*1000) // usec

void *AllocThread(void *pvArg);

int main(int argc, char **argv)
{
  pthread_t hThread;
  int       ii;
  int       iLimit=12;

  for(ii=0;ii<iLimit;ii++)
    pthread_create(&hThread,NULL,AllocThread,NULL);

  AllocThread(NULL);

  return 0;
}

void *AllocThread(void *pvArg)
{
  struct timeval tv;
  char          *pBuff=NULL;

  for(;;)
    {
      if((pBuff=(char *)malloc(MYSIZE))==NULL)
        printf("Could not alloc in parent!\n");
      else
        memset(pBuff,0x05,MYSIZE);

      tv.tv_sec=0;
      tv.tv_usec=SLEEP_TIME;
      select(0,NULL,NULL,NULL,&tv);
      if(pBuff)
        free(pBuff);
    }

  return NULL;
}
------------------------------------------------------------

thanks
_tisson

-----Original Message-----
From: Mathew, Tisson K [mailto:tisson.k.mathew at intel.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, November 26, 2002 1:46 PM

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Tue Nov 26 14:49:21 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 14:49:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEIDMAAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Well, I managed to get a connection to the VPN server.
I used PoPToP, as recommended by another list person.

Now for the "but..." portion of this post:

I can connect, but it's not an encrypted VPN session - I'm working on that
part.
The second and REALLY the problem is that I connect, but I only have TCP/IP
to use. I can't do "net use K: \\server\share and have it create the share.
I believe it's a Netbios issue - Netbios isn't going over the wire.

I'm sure I need to give oodles more information to get a coherent answer,
but I'm just looking for someplace to start looking. I've done web searches
and it's not a subject that I've seen alot on. At least, nothing *very*
recent.

[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Michael Luevane
Sent: Tuesday, November 19, 2002 5:10 PM
To: Plug at Lists. Pdxlinux. Org
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help


Hello, pluggers!

First off, I was impressed with the turnout at the clinic. That was ver'
kewl to see that kind of response.

That said, I need help, dagnabbit!

I'm trying to set up VPN on our network. I've got Mandrake 9.0 for the
server and Win2k clients. I've also got FreeS/Wan on the server, and IPSEC
looks like it's up and running - ipsec verify returns everything hunky.

I have a Hawking firewall and it (supposedly) passes VPN traffic just fine.
I had VPN installed on our last server (NT4) and VPN worked just fine.

When I try to VPN locally from my machine, I get no answer (error 678).

Any tips/tricks/pointers/help on getting Win2k clients to VPN into a Linux
server?

Thanks in advance,

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Nov 26 15:37:59 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 15:37:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] MWVLUG December Meeting Announcement
Message-ID: <1038353880.3787.60.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

                  M W V L U G  M E E T I N G  A N N O U N C E M E N T


Check out this month's meeting announcement at the MWVLUG's new website:

   http://www.mwvlug.org

You can find driving directions to this month's meeting here:

   http://www.mwvlug.org/directions.shtml


WHEN: Tuesday, December 3rd at 7:00 p.m.

WHERE: Huvland Building on Oregon State University's campus. Near the
intersection of NW 30th and Campus Way in Corvallis, Oregon.

SCHEDULE:

7:00 p.m. - 7:15 p.m.: ``In The News'' -- All the Latest News That's Fit
To Print!

7:15 p.m. - 8:00 p.m.+

PRESENTATION: "Perl Code Review" by Randal L. Schwartz

Part one is an introduction to code reviews, describing various
processes and motivations for code inspection, including how to sell
your boss on doing them. Part two is a sample set of items for your Perl
code review checklists, including the reasoning behind the items.

Randal is the President and CEO of Stonehenge Consulting Services, Inc.
based out of Portland Oregon. He is the co-author of several books,
including O'Reilly's ``Programming Perl (The Camel Book)'', ``Learning
Perl, 3rd Edition'', and ``Effective Perl Programming: Writing Better
Programs With Perl,'' among others.

When Randy's not writing books, he's writing a monthly column for Linux
Magazine and a bi-monthly column for SysAdmin Magazine. In addition,
he's also written more than a hundred columns for Unix Review and Web
Techniques Magazine.

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov 26 16:35:06 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 16:35:06 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOGEAAMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOGEAAMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1038357305.4993.73.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 14:49, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Well, I managed to get a connection to the VPN server.
> I used PoPToP, as recommended by another list person.

Your welcome :)
> 
> Now for the "but..." portion of this post:
> 
> I can connect, but it's not an encrypted VPN session - I'm working on that
> part.

You need to look for something called MPPE, this is the native Micro$oft
encryption.  The corporate side of the VPN connection needs to
understand it as well, I had to patch the kernel on the linux box that I
set up for this.

> The second and REALLY the problem is that I connect, but I only have TCP/IP
> to use. I can't do "net use K: \\server\share and have it create the share.
> I believe it's a Netbios issue - Netbios isn't going over the wire.

If you can ping the WINS server, you should be able to browse the
network.  Try using the "Find Computer" tool instead of net use K: (and
specify the ip address of the computer you are trying to share files
with, not the NETBIOS name, you can use the name once your remote
machine has participated in a NETBIOS election or revelation or
obfuscation or whatever you want to call it.) 

Remember, that NETBIOS is not a service that updates its list of hosts
instantly, it can take up to half an hour.

If that doesn't work, send us a diagram of the parts of your network
that you are using to try to establish this connection, please specify
what OS is on each piece of equipment and where the private ip addresses
get translated to public ip addresses.

> 
> I'm sure I need to give oodles more information to get a coherent answer,
> but I'm just looking for someplace to start looking. I've done web searches
> and it's not a subject that I've seen alot on. At least, nothing *very*
> recent.

HTH

Derek Loree

From rsteff at attbi.com  Tue Nov 26 17:49:19 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 17:49:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RH 8.0 Kernel Compiling
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211251827440.4469-100000@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <3DE4249F.1F7C6E9A@attbi.com>

Paul Heinlein wrote:

> If I were you, I'd shy away from building kernels using Red Hat's
> source package.
< snip >
> I'd grab the 2.4.19 tarball from kernel.org and any of the gazillions
> of patches floating around the Net you think will help your particular
> machine(s).

I will give that a try. For the first go at it, I'm following the
instructions I finally found at:
http://ftp-mirror.internap.com/pub/redhat/8.0/

Earlier, I wrote:

> Thanks, Karl. I was hoping to find that to be the case, too. However,
> in /usr/src/linux-2.4.18-14/README, under the section "INSTALLING the
> kernel:" it says:
> 
> ------------
> "If you install the full sources, put the kernel tarball in a directory
> where you have permissions (eg. your home directory) and unpack it..." 
> 
> "Do NOT use the /usr/src/linux area! This area has a usually
incomplete)
> set of kernel headers that are used by the library header files. They
> should match the library, and not get messed up by whatever the
> kernel-du-jour happens to be."
> ------------

"Karl M. Hegbloom" wrote:

> Oh, wow.  That's really way bogus.

I'm not sure why there seem to be conflicting instructions depending on
which documentation I read, but in appendix A of the Official Red Hat
Linux Customization Guide, there are instructions for determining
whether the kernel source is installed, and how to take a stock .config
file and modify just the parts you want to change. I've done that and
changed only the cpu type to K6. I want to see how that works.

Those instructions tell me to build the new kernel while in
/usr/src/linux-2.4/ and the process will take care of keeping this
version separate from the existing one by means of a line in Makefile
that says EXTRAVERSION = -14custom

I changed to the directory /usr/src/linux-2.4 and then ran:

make mrproper
cp configs/kernel-2.4.18-14 .config
make xconfig
  (the only change I made was to select K6 as the processor)
make dep
(edited Makefile and changed EXTRAVERSION = -14custom to EXTRAVERSION =
-14-021126)
make bzImage
make modules

As I type this, I'm still watching modules being made. The next thing
the documentation says to do is:

     Use the command make modules_install to install the kernel modules
     (even if you did not build any). Make sure that you type the
     underscore (_). This will install the kernel modules into the
     directory path /lib/modules/KERNELVERSION/kernel/drivers (where
     KERNELVERSION is the version specified in the Makefile). In the
     example it would be /lib/modules/2.4.18-7.95custom/kernel/drivers/.

>From that I expect that versions will be kept separate from each other. 

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From derek at infotects.com  Tue Nov 26 18:08:39 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 18:08:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEAHMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOKEAHMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1038362919.4997.91.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 17:08, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Thanks. I've already got MPPE working. I think ;) I am working with getting
> certificates going and all that.

No need for certificates, mppe just happens, it is an encryption scheme,
not an authentication scheme.  You should be able to tell by looking at
the properties of the connection from the Win2k Side.
> I'll look tonight at the "Find computer" - I forgot about that - thanks :)
> 
> Here's the setup:
> 
> Home (Win2k, SP2) <-> Cable modem <-> Internet <-> Firewall/DSL router/NAT
> <-> Server (Linux 2.4.19, Mandrake 9.0)

Do you have a server designated as the WINS server?  Is the Linux server
the end point of the VPN, or the DSL router?

The setup I have, which allows more than one roadwarrior to connect to
the corporate LAN looks like this:

Road (Win2k)/VPN <------> Internet <------> Linux box/firewall/NAT/VPN

If the Roadwarrior is behind a firewall, that firewall needs to have GRE
protocol forwarded (which Microsoft's Internet Connection Sharing
appears to have by default).  This forwarding is the reason only one
Roadwarrior can connect through that firewall.  I can have lots
(hundreds, I think) of Roadwarriors connect to the Linux box.
> 
> Repeat the mantra: I will make it work... I will make it work...I will make
> it work...

It will work... it will...

Derek Loree




From bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph  Tue Nov 26 19:28:57 2002
From: bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph (BMDimaculangan)

Subject: [PLUG] TCP_ERROR
Message-ID: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEBKCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>

Two weeks ago we change our ISP.  Everything was up and running from that
time.  Early morning today we encountered problem with our webmail, from our
users outside the company.  Page error displayed is as follows:

Message ID
 TCP_ERROR

Problem Description
 The system was unable to communicate with the server.

Possible Problem Cause

The Web server may be down.
The Web server may be too busy.
The Web server may be experiencing other problems, preventing it from
responding to clients.
The communication path may be experiencing problems.



-----------------------


What seems to be the problem...


TIA

--bmd




From mikedela at ipns.com  Tue Nov 26 19:51:25 2002
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 19:51:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] TCP_ERROR
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCKEBKCDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <RPD9QD7676093VQPXXA5B0VSTN86.3de4413d@miked>

Sounds like the mail server is down. Maybe there's an interruption in your 
internet connectivity.

Can you ping the server? Can you get telnet access to the box on port 25?

Those are the easy answers, anyway.

Mike

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Nov 26 20:48:55 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 20:48:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] xdm -> gdm, how to start gdm?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211261938090.19158-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GHP.4.44.0211261938090.19158-100000@or.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1038372535.2085.14.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 19:48, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> I installed gdm because I heard automated logins were supported, and after
> installation Debian's apt asked if I wanted to change my default xserver
> to gdm from xdm and I selected yes.
> 
> Now, however, neither gdm nor xdm starts when I boot. In fact, I get this
> message: "xdm: not running because xdm is not default Xserver". How do I
> get gdm to start on boot?

It already should be, sounds like.  You can run the debconf
configuration again by typing, as root:

dpkg-reconfigure -plow gdm

Next, type:

grep initdefault /etc/inittab

... to see what your default runlevel is, then run:

ls -l /etc/rcL.d

... where L is your default runlevel, and see that there's a S99gdm in
there pointing to ../init.d/gdm.

You can start or stop gdm by hand with:

/etc/init.d/gdm start
/etc/init.d/gdm stop

> Also I started gdm manually and it didn't execute the programs in my
> .xinitrc file.  How do I configure gdm to read my .xinitrc?

Do you use Gnome, KDE, or the Debian XSession?  Use the "Session" menu
on GDM to select one.  I don't use an .xinitrc anymore, since I use the
Gnome session, and use "Settings | Session | Session Properties and
Startup Programs" to launch a few things.  The gnome-session session
manager will restart anything I had running last time I logged out. 
That's what it's for.





From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue Nov 26 20:56:03 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 2002 20:56:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Accessing Web sites
References: <Pine.LNX.4.50.0211261942230.22680-100000@freyr>

Jim Woodruff wrote:
> Is it just me or have other Linux users found Web sites
> that refuse connections with Linux machines?  I'm finding
> several sites (soundblaster.com, toshiba.com, clausing.com)
> that either refuse to connect or time out when accessing
> from my Linux box, while my wife's Window's ME box connects
> without delay.
> 
> I'm running Debian with mozilla-browser 1.1-1. My wife also
> uses Mozilla 1.1.

Those three work for me using mozilla 1.0.1.  I've seen/heard of sites that 
refuse to work with mozilla, but that doesn't seem to be the problem here.

Occasionally, when mozilla starts acting weird, I run `ps fax` and will 
often notice dozens of zombies spawned from mother mozilla.  Closing the app 
will zambonie the zombies.  Then launch mozilla again...all is well.

--
Kyle Accardi

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Nov 26 21:17:22 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 21:17:22 -0800
Subject: ECN (Re: [PLUG] Accessing Web sites)
In-Reply-To: <3DE45063.5050507@pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.50.0211261942230.22680-100000@freyr>
	 <3DE45063.5050507@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1038374242.2111.31.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 20:56, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Jim Woodruff wrote:
> > Is it just me or have other Linux users found Web sites
> > that refuse connections with Linux machines?  I'm finding
> > several sites (soundblaster.com, toshiba.com, clausing.com)
> > that either refuse to connect or time out when accessing
> > from my Linux box, while my wife's Window's ME box connects
> > without delay.
> > 
> > I'm running Debian with mozilla-browser 1.1-1. My wife also
> > uses Mozilla 1.1.
> 
> Those three work for me using mozilla 1.0.1.  I've seen/heard of sites that 
> refuse to work with mozilla, but that doesn't seem to be the problem here.
> 
> Occasionally, when mozilla starts acting weird, I run `ps fax` and will 
> often notice dozens of zombies spawned from mother mozilla.  Closing the app 
> will zambonie the zombies.  Then launch mozilla again...all is well.

I don't think it's Mozilla at all.  I think it's ECN (explicit
congestion notification).  Try this, as root:

echo 0 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_ecn

... and see if it starts working.  If so, then either put that into a
startup script, or if you have "/etc/sysctl.conf" (Debian) then add:

net.ipv4.tcp_ecn = 0

... to it.  If you use some sort of firewall tool, like "fwbuilder", ECN
should be explictly set to OFF in there as well.

Apparently, ECN is fairly recent, and many firewalls drop packets with
that option set.

camper. I started the process at about 4:20 this afternoon and I

there are more things to understand if I want to get everything I should

will be appreciated.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Nov 26 21:37:31 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 26 Nov 2002 21:37:31 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
In-Reply-To: <200211261334.45708.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
References: 
	 <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D89C@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
	 <200211261334.45708.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <1038375451.2111.35.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 13:34, Kyle Hayes wrote:
> On Tuesday 26 November 2002 13:16, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:
> > I'm running glibc 2.2.2 on ARM/XScale with pthreads
> 
> Try the -D_REENTRANT trick others have mentioned.  It is possible that the 
> ARM version does not support pthreads as well I suppose.  Not likely, but 
> possible.

-D_REENTRANT can only have some effect if one of the included headers
ifdef's on it.  The Debian Policy Manual mandates that all development
libraries must be built with -D_REENTRANT.

> Can I play with and ARM too? :-)  I've thought the ARM architecture was 
> amazingly nice when I got the first brochures in 1987...  Sigh.  I've 
> never even been able to use a computer with an ARM.

You could if you are an official Debian maintainer:

http://www.debian.org/ports/arm/

I just remembered that there is another difference between my Thinkpad
and my desktop machines: memory. The Thinkpad has 96 Mb and the desktop
has 64 Mb. I'll have to add some memory to the desktop and see what
happens. I'm guessing that the GIMP tends to use a lot of memory for
editing images, and that, combined with all the stock stuff in RH 8.0,
means that 64 Mb isn't enough. The sleeve from the RH 8.0 evaluation
CD's says that 64 Mb is the  minimum memory required for text-mode, the
minimum for graphics is 128 Mb, and the recommended for graphics is 192
Mb. I'll have to see just how much I can stuff into that odd
motherboard.

From mikel at quantecllc.com  Wed Nov 27 08:34:14 2002
From: mikel at quantecllc.com (Michael Luevane)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 08:34:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <1038362919.4997.91.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOIECFMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>

Ah. Well, I tried Find Computers last night - no go. I can ping the server
and I can browse the webpage on the server (it's just the Apache default
page right now).

The Linux box *is* the WINS server. If, by the "end point" of the VPN you
mean "which device has the IP address that you tell your connectoid to talk
to", that would be the router. The router then uses NAT to sent VPN to the
server.

See, this was all working just hunky dory with the Windows NT server. I'm
(fairly) certain that it's something I need to do on the Linux server to
make it all play nice. I'm not worried at the moment about having more than
one VPN connection, although I might have an issue later - depends on if we
open another office or if we get more people trying to work from home.

/===================================================\
| Michael Luevane       | 503.228.2992              |
| Network Administrator | mikel at quanteclc.com       |
| Quantec, LLC          | http://www.quantecllc.com |
\===================================================/

-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
[mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of Derek Loree
Sent: Tuesday, November 26, 2002 6:09 PM
To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: RE: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help


On Tue, 2002-11-26 at 17:08, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Thanks. I've already got MPPE working. I think ;) I am working with
getting
> certificates going and all that.

No need for certificates, mppe just happens, it is an encryption scheme,
not an authentication scheme.  You should be able to tell by looking at
the properties of the connection from the Win2k Side.
> I'll look tonight at the "Find computer" - I forgot about that - thanks :)
>
> Here's the setup:
>
> Home (Win2k, SP2) <-> Cable modem <-> Internet <-> Firewall/DSL router/NAT
> <-> Server (Linux 2.4.19, Mandrake 9.0)

Do you have a server designated as the WINS server?  Is the Linux server
the end point of the VPN, or the DSL router?

The setup I have, which allows more than one roadwarrior to connect to
the corporate LAN looks like this:

Road (Win2k)/VPN <------> Internet <------> Linux box/firewall/NAT/VPN

If the Roadwarrior is behind a firewall, that firewall needs to have GRE
protocol forwarded (which Microsoft's Internet Connection Sharing
appears to have by default).  This forwarding is the reason only one
Roadwarrior can connect through that firewall.  I can have lots
(hundreds, I think) of Roadwarriors connect to the Linux box.
>
> Repeat the mantra: I will make it work... I will make it work...I will
make
> it work...

It will work... it will...

Derek Loree


_______________________________________________
PLUG mailing list
PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Wed Nov 27 08:47:40 2002
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 08:47:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
Message-ID: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D8AE@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

Thanks Karl,

Sorry for missing the header files, it was a cut-paste error. I have seen it
running without any problems for a longer time with 100msec sleep,
eventually it will seg fault but without the sleep it seg faults sooner both
times the seg fault is at either chunk_alloc or chunk_free (I have made the
sleep to one iteration of the for loop in the code below). Apparently it
works fine if I add mutex around malloc and free. 

I'm running a XScale Linux ( Kernel Version 2.4.7 ) distribution from
LynuxWorks (http://www.lynuxworks.com/products/bluecat/bluecat.php3) & glibc
2.2.2 

-------------------------------------------------------------
#include <pthread.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdio.h>
#include <sys/time.h>
#include <unistd.h>

#define MYSIZE                          (1*1024)
#define SLEEP_TIME                      (100*1000) // usec

void *AllocThread(void *pvArg);

int main(int argc, char **argv)
{
  pthread_t hThread;
  int       ii;
  int       iLimit=12;

  for(ii=0;ii<iLimit;ii++)
    pthread_create(&hThread,NULL,AllocThread,NULL);

  AllocThread(NULL);

  return 0;
}

void *AllocThread(void *pvArg)
{
  struct timeval tv{0,SLEEP_TIME}; /*sleep only at the first iteration */
  char          *pBuff=NULL;

  for(;;)
    {
      if((pBuff=(char *)malloc(MYSIZE))==NULL)
        printf("Could not alloc in parent!\n");
      else
        memset(pBuff,0x05,MYSIZE);

      select(0,NULL,NULL,NULL,&tv);
      if(pBuff)
        free(pBuff);
    }

  return NULL;
}

/* compile: gcc -o malloc_test malloc_test.c -l pthread */

------------------------------------------------------------

thanks
-tisson

It would not build as shown; I had to add some #include directives. 
Attached is what I was able to compile and run.  It seems to work fine.

P-III).

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Wed Nov 27 09:53:45 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 09:53:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Malloc and Glibc
In-Reply-To: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D8AE@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
References: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D8AE@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <200211270953.45191.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Wednesday 27 November 2002 08:47, Mathew, Tisson K wrote:
> Thanks Karl,
>
> Sorry for missing the header files, it was a cut-paste error. I have
> seen it running without any problems for a longer time with 100msec
> sleep, eventually it will seg fault but without the sleep it seg faults
> sooner both times the seg fault is at either chunk_alloc or chunk_free
> (I have made the sleep to one iteration of the for loop in the code
> below). Apparently it works fine if I add mutex around malloc and free.
>
> I'm running a XScale Linux ( Kernel Version 2.4.7 ) distribution from
> LynuxWorks (http://www.lynuxworks.com/products/bluecat/bluecat.php3) &
> glibc 2.2.2

GLibc 2.x should be threadsafe I think.  At least since 2.1. I think it is 
very likely that you have a different version from what Ulrich Drepper and 
his gang of merry hackers have.  

If your test program works fine with mutexes and will invariably crash 
without, then you definitely have a version of glibc that is not 
threadsafe.  That means that nearly everything else in it is going to be 
risky.  Even in a threadsafe glibc, there are some functions that are not 
threadsafe (strtok comes to mind).  However, malloc should not be one of 
them.

I'd contact LynuxWorks (if you've got support) and find out if they made a 
version with the threading disabled.  It is possible that they did for 
embedded work (to save on size? to save on speed? to make for more support 
calls?).

If you can get the package source for your version of glibc, you might be 
able to check the compilation flags and see if support for threading is 
off.  My faulty memory also says that there might be a #define in a header 
file that lets you know if _REENTRANT was turned on for glibc.  I'm not 
sure where you'd find this though.

If possible, you might want to see if you can build your own version of 
glibc for the ARM and see if that helps.  Building GLibc takes a couple of 
hours on my P-II 400.  I've probably got a lot more RAM than your systems 
do.  You might be able to build a cross compilation chain if LynuxWorks 
doesn't provide one.

Best,
Kyle

From jerry at linuxscripts.com  Wed Nov 27 10:16:15 2002

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Nov 27 10:58:54 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 10:58:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake + Win2K + VPN = need help
In-Reply-To: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOIECFMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
References: <GGEILBHDNBMGHFFFEIGOIECFMCAA.mikel@quantecllc.com>
Message-ID: <1038423533.4997.129.camel@dereklinux>

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 08:34, Michael Luevane wrote:
> Ah. Well, I tried Find Computers last night - no go. I can ping the server
> and I can browse the webpage on the server (it's just the Apache default
> page right now).

Sounds like the VPN is working.  I'm also assuming that you can "find"
to the Linux box when you access it through the LAN.  In which case,
NETBIOS on the remote machine is most likely using a protocol other than
TCP/IP, like IPX or NETBEUI or...

Apparently for this to work, TCP/IP must be the only protocol "bound" to
NETBIOS, the easiest way to do that is to remove all other protocols. 
Remember, that the VPN connection is different from the Internet
connection, and the two can have different protocols.

The last thing I can think of is the subnet.  NETBIOS is supposed to be
routable, meaning that it is supposed to be a well behaved protocol and
follow the TCP/IP rules.  However, reality according to Redmond is very
different.  Make sure that the IP address of the remote side is in the
same subnet as the IP address of the server.
> 
> The Linux box *is* the WINS server. If, by the "end point" of the VPN you
> mean "which device has the IP address that you tell your connectoid to talk
> to", that would be the router. The router then uses NAT to sent VPN to the
> server.

This doesn't read quite right.  When you use the VPN to connect to the
router, your remote machine should look like just another box on the
local network, with the IP address assigned by the router (or DHCP, if
the router is configured that way.)  So, I guess the big question is,
which box is controlling the IP address assignment of your VPN
connection.

My recommendation is to replace the router/firewall/NAT device with a
linux box that has a nice fresh 2.4 kernel with iptables enabled, PoPToP
(with mppe patch) and some firewall/NAT rules.  The documentation at
SourceForge is good enough to get things properly patched and configured
for reasonable security.

Hope some of this helps,

Derek Loree

From gturner at calufrax.unzane.com  Wed Nov 27 11:04:56 2002
From: gturner at calufrax.unzane.com (Gerald Turner)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 11:04:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Accessing Web sites
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.50.0211261942230.22680-100000@freyr>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.50.0211261942230.22680-100000@freyr>
Message-ID: <87lm3ebzqf.fsf@calufrax.unzane.com>

Jim Woodruff <jawoodruff at attbi.com> writes:

> Is it just me or have other Linux users found Web sites that refuse
> connections with Linux machines?

Sounds like Explicit Congestion Notification (IP, RFC 2481).

Have a look at the option in the kernel Configure.help.

Add this line to /etc/sysctl.conf:

  net/ipv4/tcp_ecn=0

Or just "echo 0 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_ecn"

-- 
Gerald Turner    Email: gturner at unzane.com    Phone: (503) 788-1720
GPG: 0xFA8CD6D5  21D9 B2E8 7FE7 F19E 5F7D  4D0C 3FA0 810F FA8C D6D5

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Nov 27 11:37:45 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 11:37:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How is env initilized?
Message-ID: <1038425865.4997.157.camel@dereklinux>

Hi All,

I've got a puzzler that probably fits in the category of "Everybody
knows that, why do we need to document it?"

The opening scene:  I've been experimenting with backing up live
servers, essentially running tar (--except /proc) on a live server, with
all services running, and seeing if I can restore the tarball on a
different box.

Don't laugh; I have had it work on two different servers, better than I
was expecting!  Of course the third server I tried this on didn't work
as well as the first two.  The problems that occurred are not the kinds
of things I was expecting either.

The most annoying is the $PATH setting for the root user.  On the
original server, when logged into bash as root:

server:/home# echo $PATH
/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/bin/X11

The same command on the restored box, logged into bash as root:

server-test:/home# echo $PATH
/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/bin/X11

So, I'm confused about where the environment gets the values for its
variables, linux is supposed to be "file based", so there should be (a)
file(s) with this information in it (them).  What files contain the bash
environment?  (If you through the book at me, please include the
relevant sections.)  How can only part of PATH get lost?  It seems like
it aught to be an all or nothing kind of thing.

Another problem, I'm not sure if this is related or not, is that the
command /sbin/ifup isn't there after the restore; /sbin/ifdown and
/sbin/ifconfig are there, just no ifup.

I didn't have any of these problems on the first two servers, just the
third one.  BTW, I tried this several times, thinking that the tarball
got corrupted, with the same results.

TIA,

Derek Loree

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Nov 27 11:56:56 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 11:56:56 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] How is env initilized?
In-Reply-To: <1038425865.4997.157.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211271150180.1236-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 27 Nov 2002, Derek Loree wrote:

> I've got a puzzler that probably fits in the category of "Everybody
> knows that, why do we need to document it?"

It's documented in the INVOCATION section of the bash(1) man page.

> So, I'm confused about where the environment gets the values for its
> variables, linux is supposed to be "file based", so there should be
> (a) file(s) with this information in it (them).  What files contain
> the bash environment?  (If you through the book at me, please
> include the relevant sections.)  How can only part of PATH get lost?  
> It seems like it aught to be an all or nothing kind of thing.

The various distributions set up shell environments in subtly 
different ways, so a lot will depend on what distro you're using.

Plus, there's often a difference in environments between interactive 
and non-interactive shells, *and* between login and non-login shells. 
There's an obtuse truth table for figuring out which quadrant you're 
in. The bash man page will explain it better than I can.

In general, you'll want to start your investigation with /etc/profile.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Nov 27 11:58:38 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 11:58:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice will not load
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211270911260.9211-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <200211271158.38897.aschlemm@attbi.com>

It seems confusing to have two copies installed so you might want to get 
rid of the older version for simplicity's sake. Since "soffice" is a 
shell script, have you tried running "sh -xv soffice" to see if there's 
any thing funny going on. The script sets and tweaks some environment 
variables before exec'ing the "soffice.bin" file.

Tony

From ed at alcpress.com  Wed Nov 27 12:09:34 2002
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 12:09:34 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux on RS-6000
In-Reply-To: <3de51e74.59d8.0@pcez.com>
References: <3de51e74.59d8.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1038427774.1261.70.camel@red>

> <good_question>
> "Hello, I have a RS-6000 that I'm interested in installing Linux on. I
> was wondering if anyone has this experience and if they have any
> suggestions regarding the pros and cons of the different distrobutions
> which can be used for this hardware?"
> </good_question>

> <difficult_question>
> "What distributions can install on a RS-6000?"
> </difficult_question>

The people on this list have varying levels of technical expertise,
experience, and willingness to find their own answers. Some of us
don't need to be spoon fed answers. We're willing to do the research
on our own. When I posted my question "What distributions can install
on a RS-6000?", I expected that I'd get answers that told me which
distributions I should be researching. Someone might volunteer other
information. I would take it from there and spend time doing research.
I might come back with more detailed questions later.

It was a simple question - not a <difficult_question> - and the
answers could have been simple. Instead I was criticized for not
doing a Google search. Apparently, the person thought I was unwilling
to do any work to get the answer. In my experience, Google does not
provide ALL the answers. There could be a RS-6000 Linux distribution
out there that I might not find in a Google search.

When I tell people, such as my students, that the PLUG list is a
resource for them, I caution them that they sometimes have to pay
the price for this free support. Being hassled because of faulty
assumptions is one such price.

Ed
