	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211271150180.1236-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Thanks Paul,

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 11:56, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On 27 Nov 2002, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > I've got a puzzler that probably fits in the category of "Everybody
> > knows that, why do we need to document it?"
> 
> It's documented in the INVOCATION section of the bash(1) man page.
> 
> > So, I'm confused about where the environment gets the values for its
> > variables, linux is supposed to be "file based", so there should be
> > (a) file(s) with this information in it (them).  What files contain
> > the bash environment?  (If you through the book at me, please
> > include the relevant sections.)  How can only part of PATH get lost?  
> > It seems like it aught to be an all or nothing kind of thing.
> 
> The various distributions set up shell environments in subtly 
> different ways, so a lot will depend on what distro you're using.
> 
> Plus, there's often a difference in environments between interactive 
> and non-interactive shells, *and* between login and non-login shells. 
> There's an obtuse truth table for figuring out which quadrant you're 
> in. The bash man page will explain it better than I can.
> 
> In general, you'll want to start your investigation with /etc/profile.

This was productive, to an extent.  I'm running Debian-Woody on all
three servers, and the /etc/profile contains:

# /etc/profile: system-wide .profile file for the Bourne shell (sh(1))
# and Bourne compatible shells (bash(1), ksh(1), ash(1), ...).

PATH="/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/bin/X11:/usr/games"                                                                                                                        
if [ "$BASH" ]; then 
  PS1='\u@\h:\w\$ ' 
else  
  if [ "`id -u`" -eq 0 ]; then  
    PS1='# '    
  else  
    PS1='$ '    
  fi   
fi   

export PATH PS1  

umask 022 
(EOF)

Which explains where the user path comes from, it is hardwired, for lack
of a better word.  I don't understand the embedded if statements
though.  How can the prompt string be used to modify the PATH (which it
obviously is, why else would the export statement be there)? 

When I issue the command "echo $PS1", I get the the following:

\u@\h:\w\$

Not as confused, but still looking like it.

Derek Loree

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Nov 27 13:20:04 2002

On 27 Nov 2002, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:

> and when I have -voice mail- I can't connect.
> 
> If I get my voice mail..then I connect just fine...
>

Marvin,

  Do what us simple folks did in the Old Days: put an answering machine on
your line. Then, when you're using it for a connection to the 'Net folks
calling you will receive a busy signal and will call back later. When you're
not there, the answering machine catches the calls for you.

Rich

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Nov 27 14:00:22 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 14:00:22 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] How is env initilized?
In-Reply-To: <1038431086.4997.181.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211271353150.1236-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

Sorry for the long-ish quoted section, but I wanted to get the whole 
context...

> This was productive, to an extent.  I'm running Debian-Woody on all
> three servers, and the /etc/profile contains:
> 
> # /etc/profile: system-wide .profile file for the Bourne shell (sh(1))
> # and Bourne compatible shells (bash(1), ksh(1), ash(1), ...).
> 
> PATH="/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/bin/X11:/usr/games"                                                                                                                        
> if [ "$BASH" ]; then 
>   PS1='\u@\h:\w\$ ' 
> else  
>   if [ "`id -u`" -eq 0 ]; then  
>     PS1='# '    
>   else  
>     PS1='$ '    
>   fi   
> fi   
> 
> export PATH PS1  
> 
> umask 022 
> (EOF)
> 
> Which explains where the user path comes from, it is hardwired, for
> lack of a better word.  I don't understand the embedded if
> statements though.  How can the prompt string be used to modify the
> PATH (which it obviously is, why else would the export statement be
> there)?

The PS1 variable has nothing to do with PATH. If you type 'help 
export' from a bash prompt, you'll see that you can export multiple 
variables into the environment with one command.

In this case, /etc/profile is exporting PATH and PS1 at the same time;
that's all there is to it. There's no secret (or even unsecret)  
relation between the two variables.

> When I issue the command "echo $PS1", I get the the following:
> 
> \u@\h:\w\$
> 
> Not as confused, but still looking like it.

The tokens available for the bash prompt are listed in the PROMPTING 
section of the bash man page. In this case, you've got

              \u     the username of the current user
              \h     the hostname up to the first `.'
              \w     the current working directory

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Nov 27 14:17:20 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 14:17:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ppp
References: <1038431599.591.10.camel@libranet> <20021127132519.A20556@stargate.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <3DE54470.1030504@pacifier.com>

Russ Johnson wrote:
> * Marvin J. Kosmal <lamsokvr at xprt.net> [2002-11-27 13:14]:
> 
>>
>>Hi People.
>>
>>
>>Having a ppp conection problem..
>>
>>I just got voice mail...
>>
>>and when I have -voice mail- I can't connect.
>>
>>If I get my voice mail..then I connect just fine...
> 
> 
> This is probably a function of your modem. It doesn't hear the dial tone, and fails. 
> 
> You'll have to turn off the wait for dialtone feature of your modem. Most likely, this is at&m# where # is a number between 0 and 9. It's been a while, so I may be wrong as far as the at code... 


Are you saying that when you have voice mail, and pick up the phone to make 
a call, you hear a "da da da da" before you get a dialtone?

Russ's answer might work, but I'm not sure if the central office is would 
notice the modem's dialing tones before it has presented you with a real 
dialtone.  Maybe put a delay in your dialing prefix string that is longer 
than the notification tones (da da).  You should be able to use a few commas 
each of which IIRC represents 3 seconds.

--
Kyle Accardi

-----Original Message-----
From: Tyler F. Creelan [mailto:creelan at engr.orst.edu]
Sent: Wednesday, November 27, 2002 2:31 PM
To: 'plug at lists.pdxlinux.org'
Subject: RE: [PLUG] HP 9000 712/xx


I was browsing google and it looks like these machines can easily boot
linux off the network. For example:

http://lists.parisc-linux.org/hypermail/parisc-linux/0616.html

and here:

http://pateam.esiee.fr/parisc-linux-boot/PA-RISC-Linux-Boot-HOWTO/index.html

Also a description of how to install NetBSD off the LAN on HP 9000 712/60:

http://www.netbsd.org/Documentation/network/netboot/intro.hp700.html

HTH

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Nov 27 15:05:11 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 15:05:11 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] ppp

On Wed, 27 Nov 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> You should be able to use a few commas each of which IIRC represents 3
> seconds.

  A comma was always a half-second delay. But, you can string together as
many as you want. I used to have 5 or 6 in the modem dial string when I was
dialing out of a hotel room and had to wait for an outside dialtone after
dialing '9'.

Happy Thanksgiving all (in the US),

Rich

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Nov 27 15:15:45 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 15:15:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Newsletter
In-Reply-To: <20021127130810.A426@stargate.dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <27201-16308@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 27 Nov 2002, Russ Johnson russj-at-dimstar.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> * Karl M. Hegbloom <karlheg at pdxlinux.org> [2002-11-27 11:43]:
> > On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 09:17, Russ Johnson wrote:
> > > AUGH! SPAM!
> > 
> > Yes, and not 24 hours have gone by since I opened the list, thinking
> > that spamassassin would catch them all.
> 
> Well, even spamassassin isn't 100%. :)
> 
> It catches most of the spam directed at me. About 95% or better of the
> spam that my system actually accepts, gets tagged as spam. Thankfully,
> I have some measures in place that tell my mail server not to allow
> connections from several thousand machines on the 'net.

My Spamassassin config caught it.  Admittedly, I have it cranked up a
bit more than the defaults...

Here's the content analysis on that "Newsletter" message:

>SPAM: Content analysis details:   (7 hits, 4 required)
>SPAM: FROM_HAS_MIXED_NUMS (-1.5 points) From: contains numbers mixed in
with letters

That rule is because of my sneakemail forwarding-- originally I
whitelisted anything from my sneakemail but thanks mostly to some of the
other mailing lists I'm on I had to stop this.  Believe me, PLUG is one of
the more well-behaved lists from a spam standpoint.

>SPAM: INVALID_DATE       (0.5 points)  Invalid Date: header (not RFC 822)
>SPAM: DOUBLE_CAPSWORD    (1.1 points)  BODY: A word in all caps repeated
on the line
>SPAM: HTTP_WITH_EMAIL_IN_URL (2.6 points)  URI: 'remove' URL contains an
email address
>SPAM: CTYPE_JUST_HTML    (4.3 points)  HTML-only mail, with no text
version

That last one is my "big gun" to slap down the HTML-only mailers.  Unless
the mail has other redeeming qualities it's going to get filtered.

Here's the line from my spamassassin user_prefs:

score CTYPE_JUST_HTML 4.3

  -- Steve

PS: My preference would be to keep the list closed.

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Nov 27 15:30:10 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 15:30:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ppp
In-Reply-To: <3DE54470.1030504@pacifier.com>; from sandbox@pacifier.com on Wed, Nov 27, 2002 at 02:16:58PM -0800
References: <1038431599.591.10.camel@libranet> <20021127132519.A20556@stargate.dimstar.net> <3DE54470.1030504@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20021127153010.B20556@stargate.dimstar.net>

* Kyle Accardi <sandbox at pacifier.com> [2002-11-27 14:19]:
> Russ Johnson wrote:
> > This is probably a function of your modem. It doesn't hear the dial tone, and fails. 
> > 
> > You'll have to turn off the wait for dialtone feature of your modem. Most likely, this is at&m# where # is a number between 0 and 9. It's been a while, so I may be wrong as far as the at code... 
> 
> 
> Are you saying that when you have voice mail, and pick up the phone to make 
> a call, you hear a "da da da da" before you get a dialtone?
> 
> Russ's answer might work, but I'm not sure if the central office is would 
> notice the modem's dialing tones before it has presented you with a real 
> dialtone.  Maybe put a delay in your dialing prefix string that is longer 
> than the notification tones (da da).  You should be able to use a few commas 
> each of which IIRC represents 3 seconds.

Yes, the switching equipment will understand the DTMF sent prior to the stutter tone stoping. 

At least, I never had a problem with that when I was running that configuration. 
-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

* Olds, Aaron M <Olds.Aaron at emeryworld.com> [2002-11-27 13:34]:
> I have an HP 9000 712/60 machine that does not have a CD-ROM drive
> or a floppy drive.  I would like to install Debian Woody but can't
> without a floppy or cdrom.  I can't seem to find any information on
> the web that states whether this machine can take a PC style floppy
> drive.  Does anyone know?  Moreover, it has an external SCSI II port
> on the back but I have read that it only accepts a minimal set of
> external cdrom drives do to buffer size differences.  Is there another 
> method that I could use to get Linux on this thing such as somehow 
> remotely install the distro?  Doesn't seem possible without a floppy
> drive at least.  I know it is an old machine but I just want to put 
> it to good use :)

I have some old HP9000's in my lab that take a regular, external, SCSI cdrom. I think it's a standard Toshiba drive, and the housing is pretty generic. 

I run HP-UX on these boxes, but I've reinstalled with that external CDROM several times, without error.

_______________________chat script...---------------------

# 
# ispauth PAP
# abortstring
ABORT BUSY ABORT 'NO CARRIER' ABORT VOICE ABORT 'NO DIALTONE' ABORT 'NO
DIAL TONE' ABORT 'NO ANSWER' ABORT DELAYED
# modeminit
'' ATZ
# I had delays here
# '' \d\d\d\d\d\d\d\d\d
# but that didn't work..

# ispnumber
OK-AT-OK ATDT3603144221
# ispconnect
CONNECT \d\c
# prelogin

# ispname
# isppassword
# postlogin


##################end Chatscript##################


TIA

Marivn

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Nov 27 16:52:54 2002
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 16:52:54 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] xpdv vs. acroread
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211260731480.3879-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211271648240.4363-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

Yes, there seem to be differences between what xpdf and acroread can
handle.  Generally, I use acroread.  (Yes, it is proprietary, but it
works.)  Well, it sort of works.  As I recall, acroread (and WordPerfect)
will not work if X is configured for 24 bit graphics.  I have to have
X configured for 16 or 32 bits, but not 24.  Of course, maybe this has
been changed.  I haven't tested this recently.

                                                   Dave

On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On Tue, 26 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
>
> > I have a bunch of pdf files created a few years ago from WordPerfect
> > docs -> postscript -> ps2pdf. I can view them with acroread (but the
> > typeface does not display well) but now with xpdf. They load in
> > xpdf, but each page is blank.
> >
> > Might there be a generic reason why a pdf file can be seen in one
> > view but not the other? Is this a function of the application's
> > recognition of the typeface used?
>
> Just shooting from the hip: I know that acroread ships with its own
> resource fonts and type-rendering libraries. Perhaps that's the
> difference.
>
> You could always try running xpdf under strace to see if it's failing
> to find the fonts that it needs.
>
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
>

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Wed Nov 27 19:33:07 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 19:33:07 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla 1.2 on RedHat 8
In-Reply-To: <1037928066.3585.21.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>
Message-ID: <20021128033307.9877.qmail@web10412.mail.yahoo.com>

After installing Mozilla 1.2 on my RedHat 7.1 workstation at work,
someone mentioned installing it on RedHat 8 with "Xft." I didn't know
what that was, but I just installed it on my home workstation, which is
RedHat 8, and it is cool! It's really nice fonts now.

Anyway, bravo to Mozilla for making a great-looking browser, and to
RedHat for making a more more appealing desktop (Bluecurve). I just
started using Linux a year ago, but jumped in with both feet, using it
exclusively at home and at work. I quickly fell in love with it, but
felt the general "ugliness" of the desktop and browser was a drawback.
Improvements like this I think are another step toward Linux on the
mainstream desktop.

-Scott

From jimwebb at charter.net  Wed Nov 27 20:17:15 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (Jim Webb)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 23:17:15 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and LCD flat panel monitors
Message-ID: <1038457034.5847.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Is anybody using LCD flat panel monitors with their Red Hat linux
boxes?  What can I expect from kudzu and Red Hat, if I switch from the
crt to a flat panel?  Will I have to reconfigure xf86 config file or
will kudzu handle it?

Happy holidays,

Jim
-- 




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Wed Nov 27 20:22:29 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 20:22:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and LCD flat panel monitors
In-Reply-To: <1038457034.5847.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1038457034.5847.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1038457349.22184.29.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:17, Jim Webb wrote:
> Is anybody using LCD flat panel monitors with their Red Hat linux
> boxes?  What can I expect from kudzu and Red Hat, if I switch from the
> crt to a flat panel?  Will I have to reconfigure xf86 config file or
> will kudzu handle it?

AFAIK, Kudzu does NOT deal with monitor settings at all.  That is the
domain of the X Window System configuration tools.  Before you shut down
to install the LCD panels, you should configure the machines so that X
will not start when it boots.  Halt, install the panels, reboot, and
then reconfigure X using the same tools you used the first time.





From sandbox at pacifier.com  Wed Nov 27 20:33:19 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 2002 20:33:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and LCD flat panel monitors
References: <1038457034.5847.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <3DE59C8F.8060302@pacifier.com>

Jim Webb wrote:
> Is anybody using LCD flat panel monitors with their Red Hat linux
> boxes?  What can I expect from kudzu and Red Hat, if I switch from the
> crt to a flat panel?  Will I have to reconfigure xf86 config file or
> will kudzu handle it?

While I don't have an lcd panel, my laptop does.  The panel should act like 
any modern svga crt and tell the os (via kudzu) it's capabilities.  I 
suspect that kudzu will handle it gracefully if you are happy to keep (and 
the new panel can provide) the previous resolution.

Can't recall if kudzu will bring up monitor configuration or not.  If not, 
it should still work, then you can use the right tool (which seems to change 
names with every release).

That's all to say, there's nothing special about lcd panels AFA the os is 
concerned.  The video drivers shouldn't even care unless it's a hdtv.

--
Kyle Accardi

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Wed Nov 27 21:09:16 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 21:09:16 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and LCD flat panel monitors
In-Reply-To: <1038459088.22198.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <1038457034.5847.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1038457349.22184.29.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1038458875.22198.31.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1038459088.22198.33.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <1038460156.22184.40.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:51, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:47, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:22, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > > On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:17, Jim Webb wrote:
> > > > Is anybody using LCD flat panel monitors with their Red Hat linux
> > > > boxes?  What can I expect from kudzu and Red Hat, if I switch from the
> > > > crt to a flat panel?  Will I have to reconfigure xf86 config file or
> > > > will kudzu handle it?
> > > 
> > > AFAIK, Kudzu does NOT deal with monitor settings at all.  That is the
> > > domain of the X Window System configuration tools.  Before you shut down
> > > to install the LCD panels, you should configure the machines so that X
> > > will not start when it boots.  Halt, install the panels, reboot, and
> > > then reconfigure X using the same tools you used the first time.
> > 
> > Just out of curiosity, can anyone tell me what is the latest release
> > version of Kudzu, and is it available anywhere via CVS, offhand?
> > 
> > Probably I should just google for it...
> 
> http://rhlinux.redhat.com/kudzu/

Well, it looks like the latest version of "Kudzu" performs a DDC monitor
probe.  So, with a relatively modern video card and monitor, Kudzu will
go and get that information.  The question that remains is:  Do the Red
Hat boot scripts, when a new monitor is detected, automaticly
reconfigure the local X Server(s)?  Or, must that be done manually?

On Debian, the "dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86" command will execute
the "/var/lib/dpkg/info/xserver-xfree86.config" script under debconf. 
That script uses "read-edid | parse-edid" to get the similar information
that Kudzu is gathering.  It actually uses the same peice of source
code, internally.  That is, both Kudzu and read-edid use code that came
from the same source, originally.  This reconfiguration, on Debian, does
not happen automatically.  You must run it by hand.

Subject: [PLUG] FS & Free Stuff: Basement Clearance

Since it's been a while since there was such a giveaway on this list and the
holidays are upon us, fight off the blues with some stuff...


2) 3Com 3Station/2E
     Fan-less thin-clients.  x286, 0k ram (4 30pin simm sockets), vga, 2 com 

     ports, parallel, internal ethernet (bnc), external ethernet (DB-15),
     uses bootp?, missing top covers but otherwise ok
     $5ea

1) 3Com 3Station
     similiar to above, but a little older, chassis complete but slightly
     damaged.
     $5

2) Mac Plus
     At least one has been souped-up.  Couldn't tell you more, but both work
     and I have at least one keyboard/mouse.  (Developers signatures molded 

     into the inside of the cabinets! you want these)
     $15ea

1) Tektronics 4662 Interactive Digital Plotter
     11x17" bed, GPIB, two serial ports, joystick on front panel
     (Can't vouch for the interface, but the joystick moves the pen)
     $FREE

1) Altos TCU-8
     Some kind of network gear (terminal concentrator unit?) eight DB-9s on
     rear with RJ11 adaptors
     $FREE

1) Ungermann-Bass NIU-130
     No idea what this is.  Two DB-25F connectors lables "port1" and "port
     2", also two F-connectors labled "single cable forward" and "reverse"
     missing power supply (16vac)
     $FREE

1) Ungerman-Bass NIU-140
     Same as above except has a DB-15F labled "transceiver" in place of the
     F-connectors
     $FREE

3) Desktop AT chassis.
     All have power supplies.  These are of the heavy-guage variety back when
     the 386 roamed the earth, no sharp edges.
     $FREE

1) HP 400LR Vacuum Tube Voltmeter (VTVM)
     Rack-mount (4 RU) works fine
     $10

1) Tektronics Type 184 Time-Mark Generator
     For calibrating scopes, works, but no guarantee on accuracy
     $20

===============
Pictures available if you want.
Who knows what else is down here.

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Wed Nov 27 22:54:29 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 27 Nov 2002 22:54:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] DVD player
In-Reply-To: <1038463335.30384.18.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1038463335.30384.18.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1038466468.19163.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 22:02, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> What is the best DVD player for RedHat 8.0?

Any DVD player that works in any distribution of Linux should work in
RedHat 8.0... and any DVD player that works in RH 8.0 should work in any
other (up to date) distribution of Linux...

That said, I really like Ogle.  It plays CSS encrypted DVDs and those
without region settings.

Xine also plays DVDs, but to get it to play the encrypted DVDs, you have
to mess around a bit - I didn't have any success with it.

A good friend of mine was playing with VideoLAN the other day and said
he *really* liked it... play your DVDs out over your LAN, or view them
locally... it's a cool idea, but one I haven't played with (yet... I'm
finishing up my jabber server first!)  :-)

Rob

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 23:51, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:47, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:22, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > > On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 20:17, Jim Webb wrote:
> > > > Is anybody using LCD flat panel monitors with their Red Hat linux
> > > > boxes?  What can I expect from kudzu and Red Hat, if I switch from the
> > > > crt to a flat panel?  Will I have to reconfigure xf86 config file or
> > > > will kudzu handle it?
> > > 
> > > AFAIK, Kudzu does NOT deal with monitor settings at all.  That is the
> > > domain of the X Window System configuration tools.  Before you shut down
> > > to install the LCD panels, you should configure the machines so that X
> > > will not start when it boots.  Halt, install the panels, reboot, and
> > > then reconfigure X using the same tools you used the first time.
> > 
> > Just out of curiosity, can anyone tell me what is the latest release
> > version of Kudzu, and is it available anywhere via CVS, offhand?
> > 
> > Probably I should just google for it...
> 
> http://rhlinux.redhat.com/kudzu/

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Nov 28 06:20:16 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 06:20:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] kde AND gnome?
In-Reply-To: <3.0.5.32.20021128002205.007dee40@mail.inetarena.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211280608560.13620-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 28 Nov 2002, Paul Johnston wrote:

> Will soon be doing a custom install of Red Hat 7.3.  I've always
> used Gnome in the past, but this time would like to have KDE
> available to see what it is like.
> 
> Will the two desktop environments coexsist peacefully?

Yes. I install both in my standard configuration at work and have 
never had a problem.

> If so, how do you switch between the default desktop and the
> alternative?

The switchdesk utility should be able to handle it for you. Try the 
switchdesk(1) man page for info.


One note. I myself run Xfce, but occasionally make use of GNOME or KDE 
apps. (Xfce will automatically build GNOME and KDE app lists for its 
popup menus. Very sweet. Uh, but where was I? Oh, ...)

I really like a number of the KDE apps, but they're tied pretty
tightly into the KDE messaging system, DCOP. If you're running the KDE
desktop, DCOP is already running, but if you're running GNOME or
something else, it isn't. So if you're running GNOME and you start up,
say, kghostview and then run ps, you'll see a half-dozen of 'kdeinit'
entries. They'll go away shortly after you quit kghostview.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

about three days before I finally ripped OpenOffice off my box.  Fortunately, 
I did not have a large number of documents saved in OpenOffice format.  I 
tried reinstalling, downloading the latest and greatest, completely 
UN-installing then installing in different directories...nothing worked.  
OpenOffice worked great for while and then just went kaput.  It would be 
really nice to know what "unforgivable sin" was committed, but for now, I 
have returned to other office type applications (KOffice).

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Nov 28 09:46:34 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 09:46:34 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice will not load
In-Reply-To: <200211280949.33783.cipher@direcway.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211280938220.14350-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 28 Nov 2002, cipher wrote:

> This happened to me as well just recently.  I played around with this for 
> about three days before I finally ripped OpenOffice off my box.  Fortunately, 
> I did not have a large number of documents saved in OpenOffice format.  I 
> tried reinstalling, downloading the latest and greatest, completely 
> UN-installing then installing in different directories...nothing worked.  
> OpenOffice worked great for while and then just went kaput.  It would be 
> really nice to know what "unforgivable sin" was committed, but for now, I 
> have returned to other office type applications (KOffice).

  I also posted a request for help on the OO mail list. One fellow came back
with the suggestion that -- as root -- I re-run 'setup -net' and select the
'repair' option. (Aside: with OO installed, running setup provides three
choices: modify, repair and uninstall.) I did this but it made no
difference. So, I'm waiting to read something more from the developers and
folks who know the application better.

  This is a very strange situation and one that I've not seen before. Your
experience is equally strange. I'm not sufficiently guru to be able to
understand what could possibly be preventing the application from loading
after it worked for a few months. If nothing shows up in the process list,
and a 'repair' has been run, I wouldn't even know where to start looking for
a reason. Even for computers, this is totally illogical and irrational.

  But, when I get it figured out I'll post the solution here. As AbiWord
doesn't (yet) have the typefaces I need available, my business word
processing has been moved from WordPerfect to OpenOffice Writer. I'm sure
that the developers will focus on this problem since it's not just me and is
certainly a critical error.

Thanks,

Rich




From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Thu Nov 28 10:09:45 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 28 Nov 2002 10:09:45 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] DVD player
In-Reply-To: <20021128091046.A1646@feynman>
References: <1038463335.30384.18.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <20021128091046.A1646@feynman>
Message-ID: <1038506984.21730.3.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2002-11-28 at 09:10, Bill Barry wrote:
> Both ogle
> http://www.dtek.chalmers.se/groups/dvd/
> and xine
> http://xine.sourceforge.net/
> are good dvd players,
> but in both, the synchronization is off. Has anybody
> had luck getting video and audio synchronized with
> linux dvd players?

I noticed the audio being out of sync with the video with MPlayers, but
not with Ogle....

What sound system are you using?  I'm using ALSA... but compiled Ogle
before I switched to ALSA, so it was using OSS emulation.  The sound was
getting quite far out of sync set up like that... I recompiled ogle with
ALSA support and haven't had a problem with the sound being out of sync
since.

Could you be looking at a similar situation?  Perhaps you switched to
ALSA, but then apt-get'd or rpm -Uvh'd (I think that's right, isn't it?)
a precompiled ogle package?

If so, I'd remove the prebuild binaries and build it from source...  :-)

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

kdeinit: sending SIGTERM to children.

The lines up to and including 'trying....' all happen as the browser
is opening. The rest all happen as the browser is 'quit'ing. I'd build
the folder tree it is trying to make, or just remove the file that is

> 
> > and when I have -voice mail- I can't connect.
> > 
> > If I get my voice mail..then I connect just fine...

> 
> Marvin,
> 
>   Do what us simple folks did in the Old Days: put an answering machine on
> your line. Then, when you're using it for a connection to the 'Net folks
> calling you will receive a busy signal and will call back later. When you're
> not there, the answering machine catches the calls for you.

Doesn't work if you're never offline when non-programmers are likely
to try to call. After awhile, they get tired of always getting a
busy signal, and never call.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Nov 28 12:07:53 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 28 Nov 2002 12:07:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] pppc
In-Reply-To: <20021128115200.Y32455@defiant.ncplus.net>
References: <1038431599.591.10.camel@libranet>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0211271318240.10408-100000@appl-ecosys.com> 
	<20021128115200.Y32455@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <1038514073.6781.2.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

You are not connecting when you have voice mail because of the beeping
dial tone you get when you pick up the phone. 

The solution is to place a couple of delay strings in the chat script as
follows:

  http://www.linuxgazette.com/issue44/tag/18.html


-Cooper

> >
> > and when I have -voice mail- I can't connect.
> >
> > If I get my voice mail..then I connect just fine...
>
> This is probably a function of your modem. It doesn't hear the dial
> tone, and fails.
>
> You'll have to turn off the wait for dialtone feature of your
> modem. Most likely, this is at&m# where # is a number between 0 and
> 9. It's been a while, so I may be wrong as far as the at code...

M is speaker control. 0=off, 1=on until carrier, 2=on, 3=on for dial
only.

X is call progress result codes. should be set to 0 to ignore buzy/no
dialtone (that should be the factory setting). I have a Multi-Tech
modem, and it has some extended features that may not be in your
modem; so I'm only listing the standard AT commands here.

S6 defines how long the modem should wait for dialtone before
aborting. Default is 2 seconds.

S8 defins how long a  'comma' delays the dialing. Default is 2 seconds.

S11 defines spacing between dialed digits. Default is 70, Recommended
minimum is 50; I use 55.

-bk
-- 
Bruce Kingsland
Kingsland Konsulting
brucek at kingkon.com
360-531-3730
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
D/2B8DA3D7 g/2884A18E  49C3 BBDE 6BC5 3F39 0C03  3BE4 FBC5 2C8D 2B8D A3D7
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From paul at pflnet.ws  Thu Nov 28 13:11:18 2002
From: paul at pflnet.ws (Paul)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 13:11:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Snedmail on RH 8
Message-ID: <20021128131118.28a99bd6.paul@pflnet.ws>

It's been a while since I set up a server from scratch. Now I know why I'm doing it -- I forgot how. The OS is RedHat 8.0 from the Bible book. I've got imap, pop3 and Apache going by ...

chkconfig iptables off
chkconfig imap on
chkconfig ipop3 on
chkconfig httpd on

When I send mail to the box, I get a connection refused message.

telnet inet2 110 -- I have a conversation with the pop3 server
telnet inet2 25  -- Connection refused.

ps -ef|grep sendmail says ...

root       569     1  0 09:27 ?        00:00:00 
sendmail: accepting connections

smmsp      579     1  0 09:27 ?        00:00:00 
sendmail: Queue runner at 01:00:00

Should I start troubleshooting the firewall or Sendmail?

Regards,
Paul

---
Email: paul at pflnet.ws    
Web: http://www.pflnet.ws



From windon at windon.net  Thu Nov 28 13:22:57 2002
From: windon at windon.net (Chesley A. Windon)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 16:22:57 -0500 (EST)
Subject: [PLUG] Snedmail on RH 8
In-Reply-To: <20021128131118.28a99bd6.paul@pflnet.ws>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211281617360.16714-100000@aahz.windon.net>

On Thu, 28 Nov 2002, Paul wrote:
> When I send mail to the box, I get a connection refused message.
>
> Should I start troubleshooting the firewall or Sendmail?
> 
> Regards,
> Paul

Start by troubleshooting sendmail.

In your sendmail.cf file (Yes, I still edit the cf file and not the mc 
file.  No flames please. ;) look for:

O DaemonPortOptions=Port=smtp,Addr=127.0.0.1, Name=MTA

This line tells sendmail to _only_ accept SMTP connections from localhost.  
I change mine to read:

O DaemonPortOptions=Port=smtp,Addr=0.0.0.0, Name=MTA

This allows connections from any IP.  Before anyone starts asking about 
opening myself up to be used as an open relay, I control that throug the 
access file.

Make the appropriate change in the cf (or the mc) file, HUP sendmail and 
try connecting again.  This _should_ resolve the issue.

Regards,

Chesley

-- 
Chesley A. Windon
windon at windon.net




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Nov 28 14:02:18 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 14:02:18 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] ppp
In-Reply-To: <1038464119.588.4.camel@libranet>; from lamsokvr@xprt.net on Wed, Nov 27, 2002 at 10:14:56PM -0800
References: <1038464119.588.4.camel@libranet>
Message-ID: <20021128140218.B23375@stargate.dimstar.net>

* Marvin J. Kosmal <lamsokvr at xprt.net> [2002-11-27 22:16]:
> 
> Still having ppp problems..
> 
> I put ,,, in the chat script and that does not do the trick....
> 
> Any other ideas????
> 
> This is the modified part of the script
> 
> 
> OK-AT-Ok ATDT,,,,,,,,,,,3603144221

Actually, when I think about it, adding a delay there won't work. It's still picking up the line, and listening for a dialtone, during the pause. When it doesn't get a dialtone, or one it understands anyway, it aborts. 

I found the following page (google search) http://members.tripod.com/michaelgellis/modem.html.

On it, it looks like you need to change the string to ATX0DT3603144221

Russ Johnson
Stargate Online

From paul at pflnet.ws  Thu Nov 28 14:15:52 2002
From: paul at pflnet.ws (Paul)
Date: Thu, 28 Nov 2002 14:15:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Snedmail on RH 8
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211281617360.16714-100000@aahz.windon.net>
References: <20021128131118.28a99bd6.paul@pflnet.ws>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0211281617360.16714-100000@aahz.windon.net>
Message-ID: <20021128141552.559448a1.paul@pflnet.ws>

This WAS the ticket! The relay was refused. I edited /etc/mail/access and was good to go. THANKS!

Regards,
Paul

PS: That WAS in the book buried in other strange configs on page 749. It does say the 127.0.0.1 will restrict the use of port 25 to the localhost, it doesn't say to replace it with 0.0.0.0.

---

Hey everybody-

I'm in a bit of a bind with gcc versions.

I'm trying to compile the ICQv7 transport for my Jabber server.

It says it will compile with gcc 2.95.3, but seg faults a lot... it is
all C++.  It requires gcc 2.95.4 or better, but less than 3.2.

The server my jabber server is on is running gcc 2.95.3.

I'm running gcc 3.2 on my system sitting here.

So, sibn in #orlug suggested compiling gcc 2.95.4 and putting it in my
home directory, then modify cc accordingly... 

But there aren't any gcc 2.95.4 sources anywhere!

Debian seems to have used it for a while, and I know RedHat used it for
a while, but Slackware stuck with the official 2.95.3.

So......... does anybody either:  have gcc 2.95.4 running on a system
with libsigc++ version 1.0.0 or above and glibc 2.2.5 who wouldn't mind
compiling a few things for me... or happen to know where I can grab the
source for 2.95.4?  I can't use an srpm or source deb file - I need the
actual tarball (or a bzball).  I'm running slackware 8.1 on the server.

I'm really stuck... any ideas would be appreciated.  :-)

AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

Subject: [PLUG] GCC Woes

> > Hey everybody-

> >

> The README file says "gcc-3 recommended". It ought to work with 3.2. 
> Esspecially if it works with 3.1, as 3.2 is, mostly, just an ABI change.

Yep... it *should* work with 3.2, but that readme was written before 3.2
was close to release.

There's a patch available that is supposed to fix a few problems it has
with gcc 3.2, but it broke many things for me... my guess is that patch
was for something in CVS or the stable release - it didn't really say.

But, even if I did build it with 3.2, odds are it wouldn't work for my
gcc 2.95.3-compiled jabber server - due to the ABI change, binaries
created with GCC 3.2 are generally incompatable with binaries created by
2.95.

This whole thing is a little nuts... lol...  :-)

AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Nov 28 17:05:10 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 28 Nov 2002 17:05:10 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] GCC Woes
In-Reply-To: <1038523731.11009.10.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <1038523731.11009.10.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1038531910.3905.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-11-28 at 14:48, AthlonRob wrote:
> So......... does anybody either:  have gcc 2.95.4 running on a system
> with libsigc++ version 1.0.0 or above and glibc 2.2.5 who wouldn't mind
> compiling a few things for me... or happen to know where I can grab the
> source for 2.95.4?  I can't use an srpm or source deb file - I need the
> actual tarball (or a bzball).

Well, if Debian is using 2.95.4, they also have the source.  Debian
source files come in three peices.  There's an .orig.tar.gz, a .dsc, and
often a .diff.gz file.  All three are needed to create a Debian package
from that source.  The .orig.tar.gz is the upstream source.  The
.diff.gz contains a "diff -u" between the upstream and the Debian
version.  The .dsc is a "debian source control" file, used by
"dpkg-source" to verify and patch the source, in preparation for
building it.  There is also a newer source format, where the patches and
upstream tarfiles are contained in the .orig.tar.gz, and there is not a
.diff.gz.  In either case, you don't need special tools to get the
upstream source code out of the package.

Both gcc 3.2 and 2.95.4 are installed on drizzle.pdxlinux.org.  You can
"apt-get source jabber" there also, and see what the Debian maintainer
did to get it to compile.

Do you have an account on drizzle?  If not, email me your username, full
name, daytime telephone number, and ssh protocol 2 public key
(id_dsa.pub).  I'll create an account for you then.  It's not a super
fast box, but you CAN build software there.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Nov 28 22:47:00 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 28 Nov 2002 22:47:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice will not load
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211281439100.14958-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211281439100.14958-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86r8d4rhy3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

>>>>> "AS" == Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

AS> I wonder if using "strace" and tracing all of the system calls
AS> would help at all?
 
Rich>   I wondered the same thing. I thought that it might not since
Rich> the exectuable is called from within a shell script, but it
Rich> would be worth a trial to find out.

Just use the -f option to strace, and it will trace any process that
is forked from the one you start with.  Also, redirect output to a
file with a -o /tmp/foo.strace so that you can review it afterward.

Date: 29 Nov 2002 00:10:51 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] GCC Woes
In-Reply-To: <1038546077.11004.26.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
References: <1038523731.11009.10.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
	 <1038531910.3905.10.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1038546077.11004.26.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <1038557450.3899.61.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-11-28 at 21:01, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Thu, 2002-11-28 at 17:05, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> 
> > Well, if Debian is using 2.95.4, they also have the source.  Debian
> > source files come in three peices.  There's an .orig.tar.gz, a .dsc, and
> > often a .diff.gz file.  All three are needed to create a Debian package
> > from that source.  The .orig.tar.gz is the upstream source.  The
> > .diff.gz contains a "diff -u" between the upstream and the Debian
> > version.  The .dsc is a "debian source control" file, used by
> > "dpkg-source" to verify and patch the source, in preparation for
> > building it.  There is also a newer source format, where the patches and
> > upstream tarfiles are contained in the .orig.tar.gz, and there is not a
> > .diff.gz.  In either case, you don't need special tools to get the
> > upstream source code out of the package.
> 
> Ok, looks like that might be the way for me to at least get myself a
> tarball to work with... where would I find the said tarball?  :-)

Log onto drizzle, and type:

% apt-get --target-release unstable source jabber

> > Both gcc 3.2 and 2.95.4 are installed on drizzle.pdxlinux.org.  You can
> > "apt-get source jabber" there also, and see what the Debian maintainer
> > did to get it to compile.
> 
> I have jabber compiled - no sweat... what I'm trying to get compiled is
> a no-longer-maintained jabber transport to icq.
> 
> Jabber is way super cool - if you've never played with it, I'd suggest
> grabbing it and playing with it.  All your IM accounts (Yahoo, AIM, ICQ,
> MSN, even IRC) under one login.....

It's installed on drizzle now, but not running.  I also installed the
"jabber-dev" package, so you should be able to build the transports for
use on drizzle, provided all dependancies are met.

> > Do you have an account on drizzle?  If not, email me your username, full
> > name, daytime telephone number, and ssh protocol 2 public key
> > (id_dsa.pub).  I'll create an account for you then.  It's not a super
> > fast box, but you CAN build software there.
> 
> I do indeed have an account... and am compiling at the moment.  It's
> definitely harder to get something like this working when you don't have
> root access... lol... I needed libsigc++ for libicq2000, and man... what
> a bear to get it living nicely in my home directory!

Let me see if those are available on Debian...  Got them.  I'll install
them right after I fix Exim so that it does not scan each and every copy
of mail from the lists.

You can run the "aptitude" interface as a non-root user.  Use it to
locate things you need, then email me or /msg karlheg on IRC in #orlug
to get them installed.

> I did finally force that in to working and got libicq stuff compiled,
> now I'm putting jabber in my home directory, then I'll fight the icqv7
> transport - which is the final thing I need.  I just hope I don't run in
> to too many library problems between Debian and Slackware.  What glibc
> version is Drizzle under?

Find out with:

% dpkg --status libc6

... or just:

% ldd $(which ls)

... then follow the symlinks with "ls -l".

> Anyway... it's going... thanks for providing it for stuff like this. 
> :-)

Kernel panic: No init found.  Try passing init=option to kernel.

Kindly advise how to correct this mistake.

From m at netpro.to  Fri Nov 29 09:00:39 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 09:00:39 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Highlighted URL creates popup window - turn off?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211290858110.783-100000@lukem.com>

Whenever I highlight a URL in RH8 (using KDE), a window pops up asking me
which browser I would like to open the URL in.  This gets rather annoying
when I'm already using Mozilla and I highlight a URL in the location bar.
Does anyone know how to turn this feature off?
Thanks,

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Nov 29 09:08:19 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 29 Nov 2002 09:08:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel panic
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021130004833.00bdfc80@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021130004833.00bdfc80@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1038589703.4201.6.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Stephen,

The kernel is looking for init, wich is located on your root partition.
Check your root partitions for integrity, your /etc/lilo.conf (if you
are using lilo), your /boot/grub/grub.conf file (if you are using grub)
and your /etc/fstab to ensure that the root directory is defined
correctly. 

The overal picture is that the kernel is looking for the init daemon,
who's binary is located on the sytem's / directory (/sbin/init).

Posting /etc/lilo.conf, /boot/grub/grub.conf, /etc/lilo.conf, and the
output of the `fdisk -l > fdisk.txt' command would be helpful. You will
have to mount your root partition from rescue CD for some of these.


-Cooper

Figuring out

From nknight at pocketinet.com  Fri Nov 29 09:06:14 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 09:06:14 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Highlighted URL creates popup window - turn off?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211290858110.783-100000@lukem.com>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211290858110.783-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <200211290906.14198.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Friday 29 November 2002 09:00 am, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Whenever I highlight a URL in RH8 (using KDE), a window pops up asking me
> which browser I would like to open the URL in.  This gets rather annoying
> when I'm already using Mozilla and I highlight a URL in the location bar.
> Does anyone know how to turn this feature off?

Right click the clipboard in the bank of icons beside the clock on the 
taskbar. There's an item in the menu that says "Actions Enabled". Click it to 
disable.

This is perhaps the single most annoying "feature" I have ever seen in a 
desktop environment.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 29 11:49:36 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 11:49:36 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying installed video board
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291146260.17958-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  OK. Looking in /etc/X11/XF86Config-4, I find that there's a 3D Labs
Permedia 2 board installed. (AGP? I don't know, but the retailers will).
Anyway, a google search on this product revealed this insight:

"Permedia 2 On Linux

    "This document outlines the steps I took to get a 3DLabs Permedia 2 card
to work with a Redhat Linux 7.1 install. This basically entails downgrading
to XFree86 3.3.6. Another machine in the lab next door had to do the same to
get a Permedia 2 to work.

"Situation notes:

    "* The machine was previously working with Redhat 6.2, XFree86 3.3.6. It
was recently hacked, at which point Redhat 7.1 was installed, part of which
entails installing XFree86 4.0.3
    "* The X configuration process seemed to go well, and the machine ran at
full resolution and such. However, little white lines would appear whenever
scrolling or moving windows. More importantly, xscreensaver and xlock would
crash if left on for a time. The machine could still be telnetted into, but
the console would be rendered useless with an image stuck on the screen and
an inability to switch to a virtual console. The only solution was to
reboot, killing X had no affect. It's unclear if any application would have
also crashed.
    "* In an attempt to fix the problem, the machine was upgraded to XFree86
4.1.0. This was highly unstable---the machine would frequently completely
lock up to the point that it couldn't be telnetted into or pinged.
    "* A machine in another lab had experienced similar problems which were
only resolved by going to 3.3.6 so the same was done to this machine. This
seems to have fixed the problem."

  And when did my problems show up? Right after upgrading from RH 6.2 to
7.3. Another "Aha!" moment has occurred. So, I go buy a replacement for the
Permedia 2 and we should be OK.

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 29 11:42:00 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 11:42:00 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying installed video board
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291136180.17958-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Remember my thread about the root window being visually trashed on one of
the workstations? Well, I've decided the time has come to buy a replacement
video card. Before I do so, I'd like to identify what's there (without
taking it apart, of course).

  Running /bin/dmesg I see this:

Linux agpgart interface v0.99 (c) Jeff Hartmann
agpgart: Maximum main memory to use for agp memory: 28M
agpgart: Detected Intel 440BX chipset
agpgart: AGP aperture is 64M @ 0xf8000000

  But, this does not tell me that I have an AGP card installed. I looked
through other /proc files without seeing anything I could identify as a
video card brand, model or amount of vram on board.

  I'd appreciate a pointer to learn where this information is to be found. I
know that XFree86-config has a screen section; is that the only place?

TIA,

Rich




From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Nov 29 09:33:12 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 29 Nov 2002 09:33:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Flashplayer
In-Reply-To: <1038549253.27891.26.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1038549253.27891.26.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1038591191.13345.15.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Thu, 2002-11-28 at 21:54, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> How do I get Flashplayer to work with Galeon in RedHat 8.0?

If RedHat compiled Galeon with GCC 3.2, you need to have a 'fake'
library in place to use plugins compiled with GCC 2.95... except for
Java, the only way to use that right now is to compile it yourself
(which I hear is a real bear!).

If your symptoms are different, than ignore the rest of the post... but
when I had Galeon compiled with GCC 3.2 (under Slackware 9.0 - an early
beta) it just went *poof* every time I visited a flash site (after
installing the plugin).

What needs to be done is you need to modify the following post (I got it
from alt.os.linux.slackware) to fit Galeon, then just put it in place. 
LD_PRELOAD the library up near the top of the galeon script, if you want
to.  Or right before galeon-bin is called.

cat > libc++mem.c << "EOF"
// From http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=124006
void *__builtin_new(int size) {return (void*)malloc(size);}
void *__builtin_vec_new(int size) {return __builtin_new(size);}
void *__builtin_delete(void *ptr) {free(ptr);}
void *__builtin_vec_delete(void *ptr) {__builtin_delete(ptr);}
EOF
gcc -shared -fPIC -o libc++mem.so libc++mem.c

Move the resulting libc++mem.so to the location where run-mozilla.sh
file is installed (e.g. /opt/gnome/lib/mozilla-1.0.0/ or /opt/mozilla)

mv libc++mem.so /opt/mozilla

Open run-mozilla.sh and just below line 351 enter
export LD_PRELOAD=$MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME/libc++mem.so

I put the resulting libc++mem.so elsewhere, but it makes little
difference.

-- 
AthlonRob <athlonrob at data.4t3.com>

On Fri, 2002-11-29 at 13:01, Robert Kopp wrote:

> If not, is it difficult to compile and install KDE3
> from source? Instructions are provided on the KDE
> website, but I have not yet attempted to follow them.
> In any case, suggestions would be welcome. 

It definitely isn't a difficult compile... but it is a *long* one unless
you have a decent CPU and lots of RAM...

I've followed the directions at kde.org to build it, and have also done
so with the SlackBuild scripts Slackware provides... both times I ended
up with a fairly stable product that was considerably faster than what
you get by default.

KNode still crashes, though... lol... I no longer have any KDE anything
on my system today.

On 29 Nov 2002, Russell Senior wrote:

> You might try lspci -v.

  Here are the results:

01:00.0 Display controller: 3DLabs Permedia II 2D+3D (rev 01)
        Subsystem: 3DLabs AccelStar II 3D Accelerator
        Flags: bus master, 66Mhz, medium devsel, latency 64, IRQ 10
        Memory at feae0000 (32-bit, non-prefetchable) [size=128K]
        Memory at fe000000 (32-bit, non-prefetchable) [size=8M]
        Memory at fd800000 (32-bit, non-prefetchable) [size=8M]
        Expansion ROM at fead0000 [disabled] [size=64K]
        Capabilities: [4c] Power Management version 1
        Capabilities: [40] AGP version 1.0

  The bottom line suggests that it is an AGP slot card. I didn't know that
AGP takes a pci channel.

  So, I should get a replacement AGP video board. Any recommendations for a
low-end one?

Rich

From nknight at pocketinet.com  Fri Nov 29 17:18:58 2002
From: nknight at pocketinet.com (Nicholas Knight)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 17:18:58 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying installed video board
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291645490.18163-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291645490.18163-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211291718.58656.nknight@pocketinet.com>

On Friday 29 November 2002 04:48 pm, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   So, I should get a replacement AGP video board. Any recommendations for a
> low-end one?

How low-end?

There's older ATi Xpert and Radeon cards out there in the $30-40 range, but 
they'd be of questionable performance for 3D loads.

Googlegear also has a 32MB GeForce2 MX-200 for $50. TNT2 M64 cards for $33. 
GeForce4 MX's will run you anywhere from $50 to $100 depending on the card 
and will give reasonable 3D performance. In the somewhat higher-end, GeForce4 
Ti 4200's (great cards, my desktop uses one) can be found for as little as 
$120.

Finding new (as in, not used) cards under $30 that will work might be 
possible, but you'll have to look a bit to find them. I imagine you might be 
able to find used TNT's, Voodoo Banshees, and even GF2MX's for little or no 
cost if you looked hard enough.

You could also say to heck with AGP and talk somebody out of an old PCI video 
card if you're just looking for 2D work, I'm sure there's plenty of people 
out there with more of the things than they know what to do with.



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 29 17:30:05 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 17:30:05 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying installed video board
In-Reply-To: <200211291718.58656.nknight@pocketinet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291727090.18163-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 29 Nov 2002, Nicholas Knight wrote:

> How low-end?

  4-8M vram; 2D only.
 
> There's older ATi Xpert and Radeon cards out there in the $30-40 range, but 
> they'd be of questionable performance for 3D loads.

  Good enough for us. We don't play games, movies, or audio on the
computers; that's what the TV/VCR and stereo are for. Games can be played
anywhere.
 
> You could also say to heck with AGP and talk somebody out of an old PCI video 
> card if you're just looking for 2D work, I'm sure there's plenty of people 
> out there with more of the things than they know what to do with.

  Less than $50 is perfectly acceptable. As long as it works with
XFree86-4.2.0 and higher, I couldn't care less about the brand or model.

Thanks,

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Nov 29 17:41:24 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 17:41:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Identifying installed video board
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291645490.18163-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211291645490.18163-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200211291741.24156.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Rich,

I'm sure you'll get alot of suggestions...

When I got a new workstation a year and a half ago, I got an inexpensive 
ATI Xpert128 AGP card. It's nothing fancy but I've found it adequate 
for my Linux desktop which is strictly 2D. I'm currently running KDE 
3.x with XFree86 4.2.0 with this card. 

I did have some instability problems with XFree86 back with the early 
4.0.x versions with the this card but since I've been running with 
later versions of XFree like 4.1.0 and 4.2.0 it's been a stable setup 
for me.

When I got my system this particular ATI card was in the $50.00 price 
range as best as I recall. I'm sure there are better cards for less 
money now.

Tony

(same as /etc/hdc1 and /etc/hdc3)

# mkdir /mnt/rescue

mount:  Mounting /dev/hdc2  on  /mnt/rescue  failed:Device or Resource busy

Kindly advise.  Thanks

Stephen Liu


At 09:08 AM 11/29/2002 -0800, you wrote:
>Stephen,
>
>The kernel is looking for init, wich is located on your root partition.
>Check your root partitions for integrity, your /etc/lilo.conf (if you
>are using lilo), your /boot/grub/grub.conf file (if you are using grub)
>and your /etc/fstab to ensure that the root directory is defined
>correctly.
>
>The overal picture is that the kernel is looking for the init daemon,
>who's binary is located on the sytem's / directory (/sbin/init).
>
>Posting /etc/lilo.conf, /boot/grub/grub.conf, /etc/lilo.conf, and the
>output of the `fdisk -l > fdisk.txt' command would be helpful. You will
>have to mount your root partition from rescue CD for some of these.
>
>
>-Cooper
>
>Figuring out
>On Fri, 2002-11-29 at 08:49, Stephen Liu wrote:
> > Hi all folk,
> >
> > When starting K12-2.1.0 the screen hanged on :
> >
> > Kernel panic: No init found.  Try passing init=option to kernel.
> >
> > Kindly advise how to correct this mistake.

> > Thanks in advice.

From robbert at vafam.com  Fri Nov 29 19:44:24 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: 29 Nov 2002 19:44:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
Message-ID: <1038627864.2316.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>

How do I change the name of my computer so I don't keep seeing
localhost.localdomain.  I'm running RedHat 7.3.  I have tried changing
/etc/hosts but could not boot into gnome afterwards.  I attempted to
change the localhost after localhost.localdomain so it read:

127.0.0.1    localhost.localdomain    dell

But still showed localhost.local even after rebooting.

Any suggestions?

Robbert van Andel




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Nov 29 20:11:07 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 20:11:07 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <1038627864.2316.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211292010430.19378-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 29 Nov 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:

> How do I change the name of my computer so I don't keep seeing
> localhost.localdomain.  I'm running RedHat 7.3.  I have tried changing
> /etc/hosts but could not boot into gnome afterwards.  I attempted to
> change the localhost after localhost.localdomain so it read:

  man hostname

HOSTNAME(1)         Linux Programmer's Manual         HOSTNAME(1)

NAME
       hostname - show or set the system's host name
       domainname - show or set the system's NIS/YP domain name
       dnsdomainname - show the system's DNS domain name
       nisdomainname - show or set system's NIS/YP domain name
       ypdomainname - show or set the system's NIS/YP domain name
       nodename - show or set the system's DECnet node name

Rich




From m at netpro.to  Fri Nov 29 20:38:35 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 20:38:35 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211292010430.19378-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211292026340.16519-100000@lukem.com>

On Fri, 29 Nov 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:

> On 29 Nov 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
>
> > How do I change the name of my computer so I don't keep seeing
> > localhost.localdomain.  I'm running RedHat 7.3.  I have tried changing
> > /etc/hosts but could not boot into gnome afterwards.  I attempted to
> > change the localhost after localhost.localdomain so it read:
>
>   man hostname


This method will change the current hostname, but it won't survive a
reboot.

In RedHat, /etc/sysconfig/network should have a line that says:
HOSTNAME=whatever.you.want

When you boot, the script /etc/rc.sysinit will read /etc/sysconfig/network
and set the hostname for you.
~M




From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Nov 29 21:05:19 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 29 Nov 2002 21:05:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <1038627864.2316.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0211292103170.21200-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 29 Nov 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> How do I change the name of my computer so I don't keep seeing
> localhost.localdomain.  I'm running RedHat 7.3.  I have tried changing
> /etc/hosts but could not boot into gnome afterwards.  I attempted to
> change the localhost after localhost.localdomain so it read:
> 
> 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain dell
> 
> But still showed localhost.local even after rebooting.
> 
> Any suggestions?

Somewhere in your initialization scripts (/etc/rc<X>.d) your hostname is
set with the "hostname" utility.  You'll also want the information in your
/etc/hosts to match the hostname associated with each IP address (external
addresses, really... the loopback addresses can USUALLY be almost
anything).

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

> 
> # mount /dev/hdc2
> mount:
> Cannot read /etc/fstab no such file or directory
> 
> (same as /etc/hdc1 and /etc/hdc3)

Unless it's listed in /etc/fstab, you have to specify the mount point, not just the device. 

> Created a mount point
> 
> # mkdir /mnt/rescue
> # mount /dev/hdc2 /mnt/rescue
> mount:  Mounting /dev/hdc2  on  /mnt/rescue  failed:Device or Resource busy

When this is happening, what the output of 'mount' by itself?

Assuming it's not mounted anywhere. You can fsck it without mounting it.

# fsck /dev/hdc2

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Love is the delusion that one woman differs from another -- Murphy's Laws on Sex n?58

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Sat Nov 30 00:09:54 2002

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Nov 30 08:35:33 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 08:35:33 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211292026340.16519-100000@lukem.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211300834570.21080-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 29 Nov 2002, Matt Alexander wrote:

> This method will change the current hostname, but it won't survive a
> reboot.
> 
> In RedHat, /etc/sysconfig/network should have a line that says:
> HOSTNAME=whatever.you.want

  Thanks, Matt! I wasn't aware of this as I only used hostname when I
installed postfix.

Rich




From jimwebb at charter.net  Sat Nov 30 08:56:23 2002
From: jimwebb at charter.net (Jim Webb)
Date: 30 Nov 2002 11:56:23 -0500
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211300834570.21080-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211300834570.21080-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1038675382.5847.50.camel@localhost.localdomain>

You can also change the hostname on the fly by typing 
'echo FQDN > /proc/sys/kernel/hostname'  FQDN is fully qualified domain
name, which consists of hostname.domain.com or net, etc.  

TIA,

Jim


On Sat, 2002-11-30 at 11:35, Rich Shepard wrote:

From robbert at vafam.com  Sat Nov 30 09:02:15 2002
From: robbert at vafam.com (Robbert van Andel)
Date: 30 Nov 2002 09:02:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <1038675382.5847.50.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211300834570.21080-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1038675382.5847.50.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1038675735.1320.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>

These were the steps I took to change the name.  Granted, I'm not
running a server, just two home computers sharing a connection through
attbi.com.

Edit /etc/hosts to read as the following
127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain {computer name}

Edit /etc/sysconfig/network to read as the following
NETWORKING=yes
HOSTNAME={computer name}
        
I now have to computers named what I want.  Thanks for the help.

From russj at dimstar.net  Sat Nov 30 10:22:00 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 10:22:00 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Kernel panic
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021130225401.00b2fea0@pop.net-yan.com>; from satimis@writeme.com on Sat, Nov 30, 2002 at 11:07:27PM +0800
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021130091934.034feec0@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021130004833.00bdfc80@pop.net-yan.com> <5.1.1.6.0.20021130004833.00bdfc80@pop.net-yan.com> <1038589703.4201.6.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name> <5.1.1.6.0.20021130091934.034feec0@pop.net-yan.com> <20021129224740.B12441@stargate.dimstar.net> <5.1.1.6.0.20021130225401.00b2fea0@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <20021130102200.A25416@stargate.dimstar.net>

* Stephen Liu <satimis at writeme.com> [2002-11-30 07:10]:
> >When this is happening, what the output of 'mount' by itself?
> 
> # mount
> rootfs on /type rootfs (rw)
> /dev/root.old on /type ext2 (rw)
> /proc on /proc type proc (rw)
> /dev/pts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw)
> /proc/bus/usb on /proc/bus/usb type usbdevfs (rw)
> /tmp/cdrom on .mnt/source type iso9660 (rw)
> /tmp/loop0 on /mnt/runtime type ext3 (rw)
> /tmp/hdc2 on /mnt/sysimage type ext3 (rw)
> /tmp/hdc1 on /mnt/sysimage/boot type ext3 (rw)
> none on /mnt/sysimage/dev/pts type devpts (rw)
> none on /mnt/sysimage/proc type proc (rw)

OK, it's mounted on /mnt/sysimage. That /tmp/hdc2 is how it's referenced when you boot in rescue mode.

Unmount it 'umount /mnt/sysimage' and run fsck on that 'fsck /tmp/hdc2'.

Another thing. This will only repair the filesystem. If you have damaged files, they may not be recoverable. Unless you want to manually recover those (assuming the fsck fixes the filesystem) it's easier to simply reinstall from scratch.


You can back the information you want from the rescue mode, and then reinstall. Once the reinstall is done, restore the backed up information. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

Love is the delusion that one woman differs from another -- Murphy's Laws on Sex n?58

On Fri, 2002-11-29 at 17:41, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> When I got a new workstation a year and a half ago, I got an inexpensive 
> ATI Xpert128 AGP card. It's nothing fancy but I've found it adequate 
> for my Linux desktop which is strictly 2D. I'm currently running KDE 
> 3.x with XFree86 4.2.0 with this card.

I have one of those also, and find that it's a very good card.  The rage
128 frame buffer console for Linux works with it fairly well.  You can
have it boot into 1024x768-70, and have a nice large and flicker free
text console.  It also works well with XFree86 4.2.

My other machine has an ATI Radeon board that works well also, though I
cannot get it to boot to the larger screen size.  I can use "fbset
1024x768-70" to get it there after booting.

From dcf at aracnet.com  Sat Nov 30 12:11:58 2002
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 12:11:58 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache UserDir not translating paths to /home/username
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211301150570.407-100000@linux.sourballs.org>

I don't normally run Apache on my home desktop, but I'm using it to test
some CGI.  On a whim, I decided to make use of the UserDir directive.
So, in httpd.conf, I:

1) uncommented:
UserDir public_html

2) added:
<Directory /home/*/public_html>
    Options all
</Directory>

3) made sure /home/joe/public_html existed & had 777 perms.

4) stuck an index.html file in /home/joe/public_html.

5) fired up apache.

Browsing to http://localhost/~joe got me a 404 error:
File does not exist: /usr/local/httpd/htdocs/~joe

notice that the path isn't translated at all.

The UserDir module appears to be ok, though - here's the relevant bit
from http://localhost/server-info:

Module Name: mod_userdir.c
Content handlers: none
Configuration Phase Participation: Create Server Config
Request Phase Participation: Translate Path
Module Directives:
UserDir - the public subdirectory in users' home directories, or
'disabled', or 'disabled username username...', or 'enabled username
username...' Current Configuration:
httpd.conf
UserDir public_html

Anyone have any ideas why ~joe isn't becoming /home/joe/public_html?

(I don't even need to use the damned feature, I just want it to work...)

--
 David Fleck
 dcf at aracnet.com




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Nov 30 12:30:36 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 30 Nov 2002 12:30:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Apache UserDir not translating paths to /home/username
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211301150570.407-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211301150570.407-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <1038688236.22841.58.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

http://people.pdxlinux.org/~karlheg/apache/httpd.conf

... is the configuration for the PLUG web server.  Perhaps you'll find
it interesting and useful?  It makes extensive use of mod_macro, which
is built into the Debian Apache 1.3 (and available as a module for
Apache 2.0).

From m at netpro.to  Sat Nov 30 17:53:41 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 17:53:41 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache UserDir not translating paths to /home/username
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211301711330.407-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211301751140.18592-100000@lukem.com>

On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:
> I know I've been bit more than once in not having my /home/keith directory
> world readable and executable.

Technically, your home dir doesn't need to be world readable, just executable
so the web server can reach the public_html dir.  No one needs to be able
to list the contents of your home dir.  The public_html dir does need to
be readable and executable to whatever user the webserver runs as, however
(or just make it world-readable).
~M




From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Sat Nov 30 17:56:59 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 17:56:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] APT-RPM
In-Reply-To: <1038705043.13156.10.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211301723530.4808-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 30 Nov 2002, Jim Webb wrote:

>Eric, Thanks for the info.  So I should download
>apt-0.5.4cnc9-fr1.i386.rpm and install it.  I can get the GUI at the
>other site for the synaptic?  What repository do you use?

I have not been using apt in production, I use up2date on all of my production boxes.

In my tests, I can say that you can simply install the apt rpm and it will work
out-of-the-box. Synaptic will *almost* work out of the box, it requires you to
run "apt-get update" once before it will run the first time.

The default source is:

	rpm http://apt.freshrpms.net redhat/8.0/en/i386 os updates freshrpms

but since I'm working with Warren Togami at the University of Hawaii, I'm using
Warren's repository:  (see http://fedora.mplug.org/fedora.html)

	rpm ftp://videl.ics.hawaii.edu/mirrors/apt/ redhat/8.0/en/i386 os updates freshrpms


So far my experience has been that apt works ok for the most part, but is a little
funky with dependancies and conflict resolution. It messes up on Obsolete tags in
particular. Obsolete tags are usually only a factor when doing major upgrades, so
most people will never run into that. [Obsoletes don't work well with older (<2.8.x)
versions of up2date as well]

The user interface on Synaptic is somewhat non-intuitive. I had to play with it for
a while to figure out exactly how it is supposed to work work. It is much less
newbie-friendly than up2date. Once you get used to it, Synaptic works just fine.

Eventually I'll probably end up using a mix of up2date and apt. Up2date works
great for the official RH packages. Apt will be nice for third party package
support.

-Eric

>On Sat, 2002-11-30 at 19:59, Eric Harrison wrote:
>> On 30 Nov 2002, Jim Webb wrote:
>> 
>> >When you say apt and then allude to apt for rpm is there a difference. 
>> >I was going to download apt-rpm from http://apt-rpm.tuxfamily.org/.  Is
>> >there another place to get apt from?  
>> 
>> I've been playing with this one:
>> http://apt.freshrpms.net/
>> 
>> a GUI front-end for RH8.0:
>> http://ftp.freshrpms.net/pub/freshrpms/psyche/synaptic/
>> 
>> -Eric





From m at netpro.to  Sat Nov 30 18:01:18 2002
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 18:01:18 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Apache UserDir not translating paths to /home/username
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211301711330.407-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0211301753430.18592-100000@lukem.com>

On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, David Fleck wrote:

> However, that particular misconfiguration results in a '403
> Permission Denied' error - I'm just getting the straight '404 Not Found'.

I was playing around with my Apache configuration on a couple different
boxes and I wasn't able to duplicate your problem.  As a side note, on
1.3.x you can leave all the UserDir stuff commented out and it still
works.  2.0.x doesn't require you to uncomment the UserDir public_html
line, even though it says you have to in httpd.conf.  So your problem is
peculiar...  Since this usually just works.  Which distro and Apache
version are you running?  Have you tried removing and reinstalling Apache
just to be sure you didn't accidentally muck something else up in the
config?  Can you access files from the default web server location
(assuming anything is even there)?  Does http://localhost/ do anything?
~M

From rsteff at attbi.com  Sat Nov 30 18:20:13 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 18:20:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla and Java on RH 8.0
Message-ID: <3DE971DD.669D8847@attbi.com>

Where can I find instructions for getting Mozilla to use Java? I've
downloaded the self extracting file, j2re-1_4_1_01-linux-i586-rpm.bin,
and run it to produce j2re-1_4_1_01-fcs-linux-i586.rpm. Then I ran rpm
-ivh j2re-1_4_1_01-fcs-linux-i586.rpm. 

The next step, according to the instructions at
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.1/control_panel_script.html is to run
ControlPanel with the following options:

	ControlPanel [ ( -r scheme | -u scheme ) ] -c path -j path ]

-c refers to the path for the browser, which I found to be
/usr/bin/mozilla
-j refers to the path for the Java Runtime Environment, which is
/usr/java/j2rel.4.1_01
-r means register
-u means unregister
scheme is to be replaced with the name of a scheme. They list the
following, all geared towards Netscape: ns4, ns4E, ns4L, ns610, ns610L,
and ns610R.

Which one should I use for Mozilla 5.0, or is there something else I
need to do?

Thanks in advance for any clues.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Nov 30 20:45:21 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 30 Nov 2002 20:45:21 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Mozilla and Java on RH 8.0
In-Reply-To: <3DE971DD.669D8847@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211302042520.13620-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Where can I find instructions for getting Mozilla to use Java?

Dick,

I'm using an older Java (build 1.4.0_01-b03), but all I did was

  killall mozilla-bin
  su -
  cd /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins
  ln -s /usr/java/j2sdk1.4.0_01/jre/plugin/i386/ns610/libjavaplugin_oji.so
  exit # leave su session
  mozilla &

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

On 30 Nov 2002, Jim Webb wrote:

>Thorough as always, I see.  :-) What is the best way to handle
>situations where you are trying to update a package and you get
>dependency issues, but find it difficult to find the packages that are
>listed?  I had a situation where my screensavers don't work on my KDE
>desktop.  I've tried to update KDE since that is supposed to fix the
>bug.  I downloaded the kde packages, but I received a message saying
>that I needed an older or earlier version of kde base and libs packages
>then was available at rawhide.  I believe that the packages that were
>mentioned were released before RH 8 was released.  I don't understand
>why this happens in linux, but I'm trying to work my way around it.  I
>was hoping that apt would help since these are mentioned in up2date
>site.

You're trying to use packages from Rawhide? In that case you're on your
own, no automated tool is going to help there. Rawhide constantly changes
and offers ZERO assurances that the packages and/or package dependancies
will actually work.

KDE releases it's own packages for RH8.0, which may or may not be of
use to you:

	ftp://download.us.kde.org/pub/kde/stable/3.0.5/RedHat/8.0/i386/

-Eric
